('17', 0, 1, 2, 38) 1. LETTER T0 SIR CLAUDE HILL
('17', 0, 2, 3, 67) STEPHEN’S COLLEGE, DELHI, April 26, 1918
('17', 0, 3, 4, 108) DEAR SIR CLAUDE HILL,
('17', 0, 4, 5, 130) It was not without considerable pain that I had to decline the honour of serving on any of the Committee that will be appointed at the eventful Conference 1 or speaking to the main resolution 2. I feel that the Conference will be largely abortive with the most powerful leaders excluded from it.
('17', 0, 4, 6, 426) The absence of Mr. Tilak, Mrs. Besant and Ali Brothers from the Conference deprives it of any real weight.
('17', 0, 4, 7, 533) 3 I must confess that not one of us who were present at today’s meeting has the influence of these leaders with the masses.
('17', 0, 4, 8, 657) Refusal to have them at the Conference shows that there is no real desire to change the attitude hitherto adopted by those who are holding the reins of Government.
('17', 0, 4, 9, 821) And without any real alteration in the spirit all your concessions will lose their grace and force and will fail to evoke genuine loyalty from the masses.
('17', 0, 4, 10, 976) If I understand the purpose of the Conference aright, you wish to work upon the masses.
('17', 0, 4, 11, 1064) How to evoke in the Indian the loyalty of the Englishman is the ques tion before the Indian leaders.
('17', 0, 4, 12, 1165) I submit that it is impossible to do so unless you are prepared to trust the trusted leaders of the people and to do all that such trust means.
('17', 0, 4, 13, 1309) So far as Ali Brothers are concerned there is no proof of their guilt before the public and they have emph atically repudiated the charge of having corresponded with the ene my.
('17', 0, 4, 14, 1487) Most Mahomedans think what the Brothers think on the situation.
('17', 0, 4, 15, 1551) I feel that for other reasons also I could not effectively serve on
('17', 0, 5, 16, 1619) 1 This was the War Conference convened by Lord Chelmsford.
('17', 0, 5, 17, 1678) 2 The resolution read as follows: “That this Conference authorizes and requests His Excellency the Viceroy to convey to His Majesty the King Emperor an expression of India’s dutiful and loyal response to his gracious message, and assurance of her determination to continue to do her duty to her utmost capacity in the great crisis through which the Empire is passing.” 3 Tilak had not been invited; but, after an interview with the Viceroy on April 27, Gandhiji wired asking Tilak to attend the Conference.
('17', 0, 5, 18, 2185) This he declined to do as Government would not rescind the externment order issued against him.
('17', 0, 5, 19, 2281) Annie Besant, too, had received no invitation, while the Ali Brothers were still in internment.
('17', 1, 0, 1, 2377) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 1, 1, 2, 2417) the Conference.
('17', 1, 1, 3, 2433) I have just read the Home Mail papers.
('17', 1, 1, 4, 2472) They deal with the secret Treaties.
('17', 1, 1, 5, 2508) The revelations make painful reading, I do not know that I could call the Allies’ cause to be any longer just if these treaties are truly reported.
('17', 1, 1, 6, 2656) I do not know what effect the news will produce on the Mahomedans of India.
('17', 1, 1, 7, 2732) The Government will best serve the Empire if they were boldly to advise His Majesty’s Government to recede from the false and immoral position they placed themselves in by these treaties.
('17', 1, 1, 8, 2920) No one will be more glad than I would be to find that my reading of the papers is totally incorrect.
('17', 1, 2, 9, 3021) There will be no domestic peace in India so long as local officials administer affairs as they have been doing in Kaira.
('17', 1, 2, 10, 3142) I am sure the Viceroy does not wish that the people should not resist injustice and tyranny.
('17', 1, 2, 11, 3235) I do hope that the contemplated spoliation in Kaira will be stopped at once and the just demand of the Kaira people will be complied with.
('17', 1, 2, 12, 3374) I would like to warn the Government against accepting or initiating conscription.
('17', 1, 2, 13, 3456) I hope it will never flourish on the Indian soil.
('17', 1, 2, 14, 3506) But, in any case, it ought not to be introduced until all voluntary efforts have been honestly made and failed.
('17', 1, 2, 15, 3618) You will admit that the leaders have with remarkable self restraint hushed all the tales of the forcible recruitment that is reported to have gone on hitherto.
('17', 1, 2, 16, 3778) I venture to think that the danger point has been reached.
('17', 1, 2, 17, 3837) Lastly a thorough education in Home Rule has now so widely penetrated the masses that nothing short of very substantial evidence of the near advent of Home Rule will secure the real co operation of the people.
('17', 1, 2, 18, 4047) You will now understand and perhaps appreciate my reluctance
('17', 1, 3, 19, 4108) 1 Some light is thrown on the background to these observations of Gandhiji in Charles Freer Andrews, p.
('17', 1, 3, 20, 4212) 132. Gandhiji had asked Andrews to join him on his way to the War Conference.
('17', 1, 3, 21, 4290) “In the train on his way there Andrews read in the English New Statesman an account of the predatory ‘secret treaties’ unearthed by revolutionaries from the Russian Foreign Office; Great Britain was a signatory of these treaties, notwithstanding her public declarations of the disinterestedness of her fight for freedom.
('17', 1, 3, 22, 4611) Andrews thrust the papers before Gandhi.
('17', 1, 3, 23, 4652) ‘How can you take part in a war conference while this sort of double dealing is going on?’ he demanded.” This was another reason why Gandhiji had initially refused to attend the Conference.
('17', 1, 3, 24, 4842) Lord Chelmsford, however, in the course of an interview, repudiated the report about the treaties as having emanated from interested quarters and expressed his disbelief that the British Cabinet would enter into a treaty to cede Constantinople to Russia.
('17', 1, 3, 25, 5097) It was on the basis of this clarification that Gandhiji finally agreed to participate in the Conference.

('17', 2, 3, 7, 5514) 2. LETTER T0 J. L. MAFFEY
('17', 2, 4, 8, 5540) STEPHEN’S COLLEGE, DELHI, April 27, 1918
('17', 2, 5, 9, 5581) DEAR MR. MAFFEY, I duly received your wire as also your note of the l9th instant for both of which I thank you.
('17', 2, 5, 10, 5693) The development which the situation has since undergone renders the discharge of the [Ali] Brothers more than ever imperative.
('17', 2, 5, 11, 5820) After considerable hesitation and much deep thought, I have come to the conclusion that I cannot take part in the Conference and serve the cause for which it has been called.
('17', 2, 5, 12, 5995) My reasons are set forth in my letter to Sir Claude Hill, 1 copy of which I beg to enclose herewith.
('17', 2, 5, 13, 6096) I do not know whether His Excellency would still like to see me about the Brothers.
('17', 2, 5, 14, 6180) I am in Delhi up to the 29th, but can naturally prolong my stay if necessary.
('17', 2, 5, 15, 6258) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('17', 3, 10, 11, 6767) DEAR MR. MAFFEY,
('17', 3, 11, 12, 6784) I would like you please to secure for me His Excellency’s permission to deliver my speech at the Conference today in Urdu.
('17', 3, 11, 13, 6907) I intended to send a translation of it, but I think that I shall speak most effectively by merely speaking the words necessary to support the resolution in question.
('17', 3, 11, 14, 7073) The answer to my request you will perhaps send per Mr. Andrews.
('17', 3, 12, 15, 7137) 1 This took place on April 27. 2 Gandhiji received the next day the following message from Maffey: “The Viceroy does not believe in your ‘fear and trembling’.
('17', 3, 12, 16, 7296) Nor do I !
('17', 3, 12, 17, 7307) His Excellency is very glad indeed to hear that you will join the Conference.
('17', 3, 12, 18, 7385) I have written to Sir Claude Hill to inform him that you will join the Man Power Committee which meets at 11 a.m.” Earlier Gandhiji had received, according to Mahadev Desai’s Diary, Vol. IV, the following message from the Viceroy: “Please assure all your friends that I have already done what I possibly could do.
('17', 3, 12, 19, 7699) The Scheme submitted will not be exactly the Congress League Scheme, but will substantially be like it.
('17', 3, 12, 20, 7803) I hope tomorrow there will be no bargaining, no huckstering therefore.
('17', 3, 12, 21, 7874) The whole world—especially all in England—will be watching with anxiousness what happens tomorrow, everybody’s eyes are fixed on tomorrow and I do hope there will be no huckstering.”

('17', 5, 3, 3, 9845) April 29, 1918
('17', 5, 4, 4, 9860) DEAR MR. MAFFEY,
('17', 5, 5, 5, 9877) It was kind of you in spite of your overwhelming work to reread my letter and find time to answer it.
('17', 5, 6, 6, 9979) Pray convey my thanks to His Excellency for his kindly sentiments.
('17', 5, 7, 7, 10046) I am preparing two letters 2 for you which will follow you to Simla.
('17', 5, 7, 8, 10115) I hardly think I shall be ready before you leave.
('17', 5, 7, 9, 10165) One of them will contain definite suggestions in which you may use my services and the other will simply complete my view on the situation.
('17', 5, 8, 10, 10305) My trust in you is not to be easily shaken.
('17', 5, 8, 11, 10349) I entirely endorse what you say about rights.
('17', 5, 8, 12, 10395) But I have no business to inflict a long letter on you.
('17', 5, 9, 13, 10451) I always feel that I am committing a sin when I write to you.
('17', 5, 10, 14, 10513) Yours sincerely,
('17', 5, 11, 15, 10530) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 6, 1, 2, 10765) 7. LETTER TO VICEROY
('17', 6, 2, 3, 10786) DELHI, April 29, 1918 1
('17', 6, 3, 4, 10810) SIR, As you are aware, after careful consideration, I felt constrained to convey to Your Excellency that I could not attend the Conference for reasons stated in my letter 2 of the 26th instant.
('17', 6, 3, 5, 11004) But after the interview you were good enough to grant me, I persuaded myself to join it, —if for no other cause, then certainly out of my great regard for yourself.
('17', 6, 3, 6, 11169) One of my reasons for abstention,—and perhaps the strongest, —was that Mr. Tilak, Mrs. Besant, and the brothers Ali, whom I regard as among the most powerful leaders of public opinion, were not invited to the Conference.
('17', 6, 3, 7, 11390) I still feel that it was a grave blunder not to have asked them, and I respectfully suggest that the blunder might be partially repaired if these leaders were invited to assist the Government by giving it the benefit of their advice at the Provincial Conferences which, I understand, are to follow.
('17', 6, 3, 8, 11689) I venture to submit that no Government can afford to disregard leaders who represent large masses of the people, as these do, even though they may hold views fundamentally different.
('17', 6, 3, 9, 11872) At the same time, it gives me pleasure to be able to say that the views of all parties were permitted to be freely expressed at the Committees of the Conference.
('17', 6, 3, 10, 12034) For my own part, I purposely refrained from stating my views, either at the Committee on which I had the honour of serving—or at the Conference itself.
('17', 6, 3, 11, 12186) I felt that I could best serve the objects of the Conference by simply tendering my support to the resolutions submitted to it,—and this I have done without any reservation.
('17', 6, 3, 12, 12360) I hope to translate the spoken word into action as early as the Government can see its way to accept my offer, which I am submitting simultaneously herewith in a separate letter.
('17', 6, 3, 13, 12539) I recognize that, in the hour of its danger, we must give, —as we have decided to give—ungrudging and unequivocal support to the Empire, of which we aspire, in the near future, to be partners in the
('17', 6, 4, 14, 12738) 1 Though drafted on this date, it appears to have been sent to the Viceroy at Simla only the following day, with a covering note addressed to J. L, Maffey; vide the following item.
('17', 6, 4, 15, 12919) 2 Vide “Letter to Sir Claude Hill’; 26 4 1918.
('17', 7, 0, 1, 12966) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 7, 1, 2, 13006) same sense as the Dominions overseas.
('17', 7, 1, 3, 13044) But it is the simple truth that our response is due to the expectation that our goal will be reached all the more speedily on that account—even as the performance of a duty automatically confers a corresponding right.
('17', 7, 1, 4, 13262) The people are entitled to believe that the imminent reforms alluded to in your speech will embody the main, general principles of the Congress League Scheme, and I am sure that it is this faith which has enabled many members of the Conference to tender to the Government their whole hearted co operation.
('17', 7, 2, 5, 13568) If I could make my countrymen retrace their steps, I would make them withdraw all the Congress resolutions, and not whisper “Home Rule” or “Responsible Government” during the pendency of the war.
('17', 7, 2, 6, 13764) I would make India offer all her able bodied sons as a sacrifice to the Empire at its critical moment; and I know that India by this very act would become the most favoured partner in the Empire and racial distinctions would become a thing of the past.
('17', 7, 2, 7, 14017) But practically the whole of educated India has decided to take a less effective course, and it is no longer possible to say that educated India does not exercise any influence on the masses.
('17', 7, 2, 8, 14209) I have been coming into most intimate touch with the ryots ever since my return from South Africa to India, and I wish to assure you that the desire for Home Rule has widely penetrated them.
('17', 7, 2, 9, 14400) I was present at the sessions of the last Congress, and I was party to the resolution that full Responsible Government should be granted to British India within a period to be fixed definitely by a Parliamentary Statute.
('17', 7, 2, 10, 14621) I admit that it is a bold step to take, but I feel sure that nothing less than a definite vision of Home Rule—to be realized in the shortest possible time— will satisfy the Indian people.
('17', 7, 2, 11, 14809) I know that there are many in India who consider no sacrifice too great in order to achieve the end; and they are wakeful enough to realize that they must be equally prepared to sacrifice themselves for the Empire in which they hope and desire to reach their final status.
('17', 7, 2, 12, 15082) It follows, then, that we can but accelerate our journey towards the goal by silently and simply devoting ourselves, heart and soul, to the work of delivering the Empire from the threatening danger.
('17', 7, 2, 13, 15281) It will be national suicide not to recognize this elementary truth.
('17', 7, 2, 14, 15349) We must perceive that, if we serve to save the Empire, we have in that very act secured Home Rule.
('17', 7, 3, 15, 15448) Whilst, therefore, it is clear to me that we should give to the Empire every available man for its defence, I fear that I cannot say
('17', 8, 0, 1, 15581) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 9
('17', 8, 1, 2, 15619) the same thing about financial assistance.
('17', 8, 1, 3, 15662) My intimate intercourse with the ryots convinces me that India has already donated to the Imperial Exchequer beyond her capacity.
('17', 8, 1, 4, 15792) I know that, in making this statement, I am voicing the opinion of the vast majority of my countrymen.
('17', 8, 1, 5, 15895) The Conference means for me, and I believe for many of us, a definite step in the consecration of our lives to the common cause.
('17', 8, 1, 6, 16024) But ours is a peculiar position.
('17', 8, 1, 7, 16057) We are today outside the partnership.
('17', 8, 1, 8, 16095) Ours is a consecration based on the hope of a better future.
('17', 8, 1, 9, 16156) I should be untrue to you and to my country if I did not clearly and unequivocally tell you what that hope is.
('17', 8, 1, 10, 16267) I do not bargain for its fulfilment.
('17', 8, 1, 11, 16304) But you should know it.
('17', 8, 1, 12, 16328) Disappointment of the hope means disillusion.
('17', 8, 2, 13, 16374) There is one thing I may not omit.
('17', 8, 2, 14, 16409) You have appealed to us to sink domestic differences.
('17', 8, 2, 15, 16463) If the appeal involves the toleration of tyranny and wrongdoing on the part of officials, I am powerless to respond.
('17', 8, 2, 16, 16580) I shall resist organized tyranny to the uttermost.
('17', 8, 2, 17, 16631) The appeal must be to the officials that they do not ill treat a single soul, and that they consult and respect popular opinion as never before.
('17', 8, 2, 18, 16776) In Champaran, by resisting an age long tyranny, I have shown the ultimate sovereignty of British justice.
('17', 8, 2, 19, 16882) In Kaira, a population that was cursing the Government now feels that it, and not the Government, is the power when it is prepared to suffer for the truth it represents.
('17', 8, 2, 20, 17052) It is, therefore, losing its bitterness and is saying to itself that the Government must be a Government for the people, for it tolerates orderly and respectful disobedience where injustice is felt.
('17', 8, 2, 21, 17251) Thus, Champaran and Kaira affairs are my direct, definite, and special contribution to the war.
('17', 8, 2, 22, 17347) Ask me to suspend my activities in that direction, and you ask me to suspend my life.
('17', 8, 2, 23, 17433) If I could popularize the use of soul force, which is but another name for love force, in the place of brute force, I know that I could present you with an India that could defy the whole world to do its worst.
('17', 8, 2, 24, 17644) In season and out of season, therefore, I shall discipline myself to express in my life this eternal law of suffering and present it for acceptance to those who care.
('17', 8, 2, 25, 17811) And if I take part in any other activity, the motive is to show the matchless superiority of that law.
('17', 8, 3, 26, 17914) Lastly, I would like you to ask His Majesty’s Ministers to give definite assurances about Mahomedan States.
('17', 8, 3, 27, 18022) I am sure you know that every Mahomedan is deeply interested in them.
('17', 8, 3, 28, 18092) As a Hindu, I cannot be indifferent to their cause.
('17', 8, 3, 29, 18144) Their sorrows must be our sorrows.
('17', 9, 0, 1, 18179) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 9, 1, 2, 18220) the most scrupulous regard for the right of these States, and for the Muslim sentiment as to places of worship and in your just and timely treatment of the Indian claim to Home Rule, lies the safety of the Empire.
('17', 9, 1, 3, 18434) I write this, because I love the English Nation, and I wish to evoke in every Indian the loyalty of the Englishman.
('17', 9, 2, 4, 18550) I remain,
('17', 9, 3, 5, 18560) Your Excellency’s faithful servant,
('17', 9, 4, 6, 18596) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 9, 6, 8, 18656) 8. LETTER T0 J. L. MAFFEY
('17', 9, 7, 9, 18682) NADIAD, April 30, 1918 1
('17', 9, 8, 10, 18707) DEAR MR. MAFFEY, In pursuance of my declaration at the Conference yesterday, I wish respectfully to state that I place my services at the disposal of the authorities to be utilized by them in any manner they choose, save that I personally will not kill or injure anybody, friend or foe.
('17', 9, 8, 11, 18994) But it would be better perhaps if I were to state how, in my opinion, my services may be best used.
('17', 9, 8, 12, 19094) In the first place, it is necessary in order to make my work effective that I should receive permission to go to Chindwara and see the brothers Ali.
('17', 9, 8, 13, 19243) I would like to confer with them and ascertain from them their advice as to the objects of the Conference.
('17', 9, 8, 14, 19350) I have little doubt that they will approve of co operation.
('17', 9, 8, 15, 19410) If the Government would accept the request originally made by me, they would instantaneously soothe both Hindus and Mahomedans by releasing the brothers, if only as a war measure, in order to advance the objects of the Conference.
('17', 9, 8, 16, 19641) I shall be content for the time being with the permission to see them.
('17', 9, 8, 17, 19712) I merely state that their release would, from the war standpoint, be a more effective act.
('17', 9, 8, 18, 19803) Of course I shall reserve to myself the right to press for their release in any case.
('17', 9, 8, 19, 19889) Further I desire relief regarding the Kaira trouble.
('17', 9, 8, 20, 19942) Relief will
('17', 9, 9, 21, 19954) 1 The letter appears to have been drafted on April 29 but actually sent on this date.
('17', 10, 0, 1, 20040) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 11
('17', 10, 1, 2, 20079) entirely disengage me from that preoccupation which I may not entirely set aside.
('17', 10, 1, 3, 20161) It will also enable me to fall back for war purposes upon my co workers in Kaira and it may enable me to get recruits from the district.
('17', 10, 1, 4, 20298) The problem there is extremely simple.
('17', 10, 1, 5, 20337) I have suggested that the revenue—now probably less than four lakhs of rupees—be suspended this year, with the proviso that those who can will be put upon their honour and expected to pay revenue voluntarily.
('17', 10, 1, 6, 20546) I have already offered myself to see that the well to do cultivators pay the revenue.
('17', 10, 1, 7, 20632) If this offer is not acceptable, I have suggested an impartial committee to inquire into the differences between the authorities and the cultivators.
('17', 10, 1, 8, 20782) I suggest that action in this matter be taken as a war measure.
('17', 10, 1, 9, 20846) This will obviate the fear of the relief being regarded as a precedent.
('17', 10, 2, 10, 20918) Pray understand that my offer is not conditional upon relief in either case.
('17', 10, 2, 11, 20995) I merely ask for relief in the two cases in furtherance of the common object.
('17', 10, 3, 12, 21073) As for my work, I would like, for the time being, to travel about the country and place before the people the desirability of offering their services and ascertain the possibilities of success.
('17', 10, 3, 13, 21267) I would, if I am to do this, like detailed information as to the areas in which, in the opinion of the experts, work should be done and some instructions as to the nature of it and any further information that they may consider I should possess.
('17', 10, 4, 14, 21513) If it is desired that I should personally wait on any of the officials or meet you, I would be prepared to come up to Simla.
('17', 10, 4, 15, 21638) You may give me as short a notice as you like after the 4th of May.
('17', 10, 4, 16, 21706) My address would be Nadiad.
('17', 10, 5, 17, 21734) I suppose I must give you something of my past record.
('17', 10, 5, 18, 21789) I was in charge of the Indian Ambulance Corps consisting of 1,100 men during the Boer Campaign and was present at the battles of Colenso, Spionkop and Vaalkranz.
('17', 10, 5, 19, 21951) 1 I was specially mentioned in General Buller’s despatches.

('17', 15, 10, 16, 30514) 15. SPEECH AT ANTYAJ CONFERENCE, BIJAPUR 2
('17', 15, 11, 17, 30557) May 5, 1918
('17', 15, 12, 18, 30569) Before moving the resolution extending support to the Congress League Scheme and recommending to the Government to recognize the place of Antyajas,
('17', 15, 13, 19, 30717) Gandhiji asked twice:
('17', 15, 14, 20, 30739) How many Antyajas are present at this meeting?
('17', 15, 15, 21, 30786) Finding that there was none, he said, in Hindi:
('17', 15, 16, 22, 30834) Why are we wasting our time here, then, keeping awake till this hour of twelve?
('17', 15, 16, 23, 30914) We are like the parrot endlessly repeating Narayana,
('17', 15, 17, 24, 30967) 1 At a Bombay meeting, Sastri raised a point of order against moving a resolution on the Kheda Satyagraha on the ground that seven days’ notice of the resolution had not been given.
('17', 15, 17, 25, 31149) Gandhiji offered, in that case, to withdraw the resolution.
('17', 15, 17, 26, 31209) All except Sastri said they did not want this to be done; Sastri regretted he could not agree to the resolution.
('17', 15, 17, 27, 31322) It was dropped.
('17', 15, 17, 28, 31338) 2 This was the second Depressed Classes Mission Conference.
('17', 15, 17, 29, 31398) B. S. Kamat presided.
('17', 16, 0, 1, 31420) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 17
('17', 16, 1, 2, 31459) Narayana.
('17', 16, 1, 3, 31469) I would advise Bhai Shinde 1 to give up calling such conferences and to engage himself in some solid work.
('17', 16, 1, 4, 31576) We can purge ourselves of the sin of untouchability only through purity of heart.
('17', 16, 1, 5, 31658) Genuine feeling alone will ensure results, not any unnatural efforts.
('17', 16, 1, 6, 31728) We pass resolution after resolution for the removal of untouchability, but the result has been nil.
('17', 16, 1, 7, 31828) To prevent the unanimous passage of the resolution, one gentleman argued that the Conference will serve no practical purpose.
('17', 16, 1, 8, 31954) I say the same thing.
('17', 16, 2, 9, 31976) When I read out the resolution recommending acceptance of the Congress League Scheme, I had hoped that it would be supported by a member of the Antyaj community, but there is none here at all.
('17', 16, 2, 10, 32169) What is then the point of passing it?
('17', 16, 2, 11, 32207) What weight will it carry with Mr. Montagu?
('17', 16, 2, 12, 32251) I cannot move it.
('17', 16, 2, 13, 32269) This Conference has no right to pass such a resolution and, therefore, we cannot bring it up here.

('17', 16, 3, 21, 32869) It is a principle in law that he who seeks justice should render it to others.
('17', 16, 3, 22, 32948) I would ask you to give up all this play acting and in all sincerity of heart offer prayers at this midnight hour so that our sinfulness, our hardness of heart, may disappear.
('17', 16, 4, 23, 33124) [From Gujarati]
('17', 16, 5, 24, 33140) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV
('17', 16, 6, 25, 33169) 1 V. R. Shinde
('17', 17, 0, 1, 33184) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 17, 1, 2, 33225) 16. REPLY T0 GOVERNMENT PRESS NOTE ON KHEDA CRISIS 1
('17', 17, 2, 3, 33278) [AHMEDABAD,]
('17', 17, 3, 4, 33291) May 6, 1918
('17', 17, 4, 5, 33303) The Government Press Note 2 on the Kaira trouble is remarkable for the sins both of omission and commission.
('17', 17, 4, 6, 33412) As to the paragraph devoted to Messrs Parikh and Patel’s investigations, I wish only to say that, at the interview with His Excellency the Governor, the Commissi oner challenged the accuracy of their statements.
('17', 17, 4, 7, 33624) I Immediately suggested the appointment of a committee of inquiry.
('17', 17, 4, 8, 33691) Surely, it was the most proper thing that the Government could have done, and the whole of the unseemly executions, the removal of the cultivators’ milch cattle and their ornaments, the confiscation orders, could have been avoided.
('17', 17, 4, 9, 33923) Instead, as the Press Note says, they posted a Collector “of long experience”.
('17', 17, 4, 10, 34002) What could he do?
('17', 17, 4, 11, 34020) The best of officials have to move in a vicious circle.
('17', 17, 4, 12, 34076) They have to carry out the traditions of a service which has made of prestige a fetish and which considers itself to be almost infallible, and rarely admits its mistakes.
('17', 17, 5, 13, 34247) With reference to the investigation by Mr. Devdhar and his co workers, the Press Note leaves on the reader the impression that the Commissioner had responded to their suggestions.
('17', 17, 5, 14, 34427) At the interview at which I was present he challenged the report they had submitted to him and said distinctly that, whatever relief he granted would not be granted because of the report, which, he said in substance, was not true in so far as it contained any new things, and was not new in so far as it contained any true statements.
('17', 17, 6, 15, 34762) I cannot weary the public with the tragedy in the Matar Taluqa.
('17', 17, 6, 16, 34826) In certain villages of the Taluqa which are affected; by the irrigation canals, they have a double grievance: (1) the ordinary failure of crops by reason of the excessive rainfall, and (2) the total destruction of crops by reason of overflooding.
('17', 17, 6, 17, 35073) In the second case, they are entitled to full remission.
('17', 17, 6, 18, 35130) So far as I am aware, in many cases it has not been granted.
('17', 17, 7, 19, 35191) 1 A brief summary of the statement appeared earlier in New India on May 6. 2 This was issued on April 24.
('17', 18, 0, 1, 35297) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 19
('17', 18, 1, 2, 35336) It is not correct to say that the Servants of India Society stopped investigation in the Thasra Taluqa because there was no case for inquiry, but because they deemed it unnecessary, so their report says, as I had decided to inquire into the crops of almost every village.
('17', 18, 2, 3, 35608) The Press Note is less than fair in calling my method of inquiry “Utopian”.
('17', 18, 2, 4, 35684) I do adhere to my contention that, if the cultivators statements may be relied upon, my method cannot but yield absolutely reliable results.
('17', 18, 2, 5, 35825) Who should know better than the cultivator himself the yield of his crops?
('17', 18, 2, 6, 35900) I refuse to believe that lakhs of men could conspire to tell an untruth when there was no great gain in view and suffering a certainty.
('17', 18, 2, 7, 36036) It is impossible for thousands of men to learn by heart figures as to the yield—actual and probable—of even ten crops so that the total in each case would give less than a four anna crop.
('17', 18, 2, 8, 36224) I contend that my method contains automatic safeguards against deception.
('17', 18, 2, 9, 36298) Moreover, I had challenged the official annawari alike of kharif and rabi crops.
('17', 18, 2, 10, 36379) When I did so, the rabi crops were still standing.
('17', 18, 2, 11, 36430) I had, therefore, suggested that they could cut the rabi crops and test the yield and thus find the true annawari.
('17', 18, 2, 12, 36545) I had suggested this specially of Vadthal.
('17', 18, 2, 13, 36588) My argument was that if the cultivators’ annawari of such rabi crops was found to be correct and the officials’ wrong, it was not improper to infer that the cultivators’ valuations regarding the kharif crops were also right.
('17', 18, 2, 14, 36813) My offer was not accepted.
('17', 18, 2, 15, 36840) I may add that I had asked to be allowed to be present when the Collector visited Vadthal which was taken as a test village.
('17', 18, 2, 16, 36965) This request was also not accepted.
('17', 18, 3, 17, 37001) The Note is misleading inasmuch as it states that, in arriving at my annawari, I have not taken into account the rabi crops or the cotton crop.
('17', 18, 3, 18, 37145) I have taken these crops into account.
('17', 18, 3, 19, 37184) I have simply questioned the logic of the official system.
('17', 18, 3, 20, 37243) The reason is obvious.
('17', 18, 3, 21, 37266) If out of a population of one thousand men, only two hundred men grew rabi crops, it would be highly unjust to the eight hundred men to force up their annawari if without the rabi crops their crops showed only four annas or under.
('17', 18, 4, 22, 37497) I am surprised at the gross inaccuracies in the paragraph devoted to the crops in Limbasi.
('17', 18, 4, 23, 37588) In the first instance, I was not present when the official inquiry was made, and in the second instance the wheat, which is valued at Rs. 13,445, included wheat also from two neighbouring villages, so that out of the crops estimated at Rs. 13,445 three assessments had to be paid.
('17', 18, 4, 24, 37869) And what are Rs. 13,445 in a
('17', 19, 0, 1, 37898) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 19, 1, 2, 37939) population of eighteen hundred men?
('17', 19, 1, 3, 37975) For the matter of that, I am prepared to admit that the Limbasi people had a rice crop which too gave them as many rupees.
('17', 19, 1, 4, 38098) At the rate of forty rupees per head per year to feed a man, the Limbasi people would require Rs. 72,000 for their food alone.
('17', 19, 1, 5, 38225) It may interest the public to know that, according to the official annawari, the Limbasi wheat alone should have been worth Rs. 83,021. This figure has been supplied to me by the Collector.
('17', 19, 1, 6, 38415) To demonstrate the recklessness with which the Press Note has been prepared, I may add that if the Limbasi people are to be believed, the whole of the wheat crop was on the threshing floor.
('17', 19, 1, 7, 38605) According to their statements, nearly one third was foreign wheat.
('17', 19, 1, 8, 38672) The Limbasi wheat, therefore, would be under Rs. 9,000. The official annaweri is ten annas.
('17', 19, 1, 9, 38764) Now, according to the actual yield, the wheat annawari of Limbasi was eleven annas as against the official ten annas.
('17', 19, 1, 10, 38882) Moreover, a maund of wheat per bigha is required as seed and the Limbasi cultivators had 3,000 (Rs. 3 per maund equals Rs. 9,000) maunds of wheat on 1965 bighas; i.e., the wheat crop was a trifle over the seed.
('17', 19, 1, 11, 39093) Lastly, whilst the crop was under distraint, I had offered to the Collector to go over to Limbasi myself and to have it weighed so that there might be no question of the accuracy or otherwise of the cultivators’ statement.
('17', 19, 1, 12, 39316) But the Collector did not accept my offer.
('17', 19, 1, 13, 39359) Therefore, I hold that the cultivators’ figures must be accepted as true.
('17', 19, 1, 14, 39433) Merely to show how hopelessly misleading the Press Note is, I may state that the Gujarat Sabha did not pass a resolution advising passive resistance.
('17', 19, 1, 15, 39583) Not that it would have shirked it, but I felt myself that passive resistance should not be the subject of a resolution in a Sabha whose constitution was governed by the rule of majority, and so the Gujarat Sabha resolution left it open to individual members to follow their own bent of mind.
('17', 19, 1, 16, 39875) It is true that most of the active members of the Sabha are engaged in the Kaira trouble.
('17', 19, 2, 17, 39965) I must repudiate totally the insinuation that I dissuaded payment by people who wished to pay.
('17', 19, 2, 18, 40060) The figures given in the Press Note showing the collection in the different talukas, if they prove anything, prove that the hand of the law has hit them hard and that the fears of the ravanias and the talatis have proved too strong for them.
('17', 19, 2, 19, 40302) When after confiscation and sales under execution the Government show a clean bill and no arrears, will they contend that there was no case for relief or inquiry?
('17', 19, 3, 20, 40465) I admit that the suspension is granted as a matter of grace and
('17', 20, 0, 1, 40529) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 21
('17', 20, 1, 2, 40568) not as a matter of right enforceable by law, but the concession is not based on caprice, but is regulated by properly defined rules, and the Government do not contend that if the crops had been under four annas, they could have withheld suspensions.
('17', 20, 1, 3, 40818) The sole point throughout has been the difference as to annawari.
('17', 20, 1, 4, 40884) If it is true that, in granting concessions, the Government take into account also other circumstances, e.g., in the words of the Press Note, “the general economic situation’s, suspension is doubly necessary this year because of the plague and high prices.
('17', 20, 1, 5, 41141) The Collector told me definitely that he could not take this last into account.
('17', 20, 1, 6, 41221) He could grant suspension only under the rules which had reference only to crops and nothing else.

('17', 21, 3, 10, 43859) 17. SPEECH AT BOMBAY PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE
('17', 21, 4, 11, 43902) [BIJAPUR, May 6, 1918] 1
('17', 21, 5, 12, 43927) Mahatma Gandhi made a vigorgus speech in support of his resolution on the indenture system at the second day’s sitting of the Bombay Provincial Conference.
('17', 21, 5, 13, 44083) Mr. Gandhi moved:
('17', 21, 6, 14, 44101) This Conference emphatically urges that nothing short of a complete abolition of the indenture system of recruitment of labour in any form will meet the evils of the system which is a form of slavery which socially and politically debases the labourers and is detrimental to the economic and moral interests of this country.
('17', 21, 7, 15, 44426) Mr. Gandhi spoke in Hindi and giving a resume of the indenture system referred to the degrading effects which it had produced on our people in the Colonies.
('17', 21, 7, 16, 44583) He also described how it had lowered India and Indians in the estimation of the European peoples.
('17', 21, 7, 17, 44681) He condemned the Inter Departmental Committee’s recommendations on this question and said in an emphatic manner that the system should go once for all and that no reservations whatsoever should be made.
('17', 21, 8, 18, 44884) Young India, 8 5 1918
('17', 21, 9, 19, 44906) 1 The Conference, according to Bombay Secret Abstracts was held from May 5 to 8 at Bijapur.
('17', 21, 9, 20, 44998) Vithalbhai Patel presided.

('17', 22, 1, 2, 45064) 18. SPEECH AT ANTYAJ CONFERENCE, BIJAPUR
('17', 22, 2, 3, 45105) May 6, 1918
('17', 22, 3, 4, 45117) I have committed a serious indiscretion.
('17', 22, 3, 5, 45158) A friend came and said that I was unnecessarily creating a disturbance in Bijapur which is divided into two camps.
('17', 22, 3, 6, 45273) I did not know the real position.
('17', 22, 3, 7, 45307) I have not come to throw the apple of discord and to exacerbate the feelings of the parties.
('17', 22, 3, 8, 45400) Lokamanya Tilak must be here to guide you and me.
('17', 22, 3, 9, 45450) I am but a child of three in politics.
('17', 22, 3, 10, 45489) I have yet to see, to consider, and to learn things.
('17', 22, 3, 11, 45542) I apologize for creating this disturbance.
('17', 22, 3, 12, 45585) In common meetings one may explain his views thoroughly freely without being charged with the idea of creating a disturbance.
('17', 22, 3, 13, 45711) As I propose to put into practice the programme I have mapped out, I should not be anxious to ascertain the feeling running in all parts of India.
('17', 22, 3, 14, 45858) But as you are all come here with preconceived notions, I cannot discuss my position here.
('17', 22, 3, 15, 45949) I would like to exchange views and understand your feelings and deciding motives and reach the backs of your minds.
('17', 22, 3, 16, 46065) But I shall prefer to come here in a calmer atmosphere and shall only then come to steel your hearts when we are not cramped with resolutions before us.
('17', 22, 3, 17, 46218) I think Mr. Kelkar has taken the most reasonable position and that, at this stage, we must accept the Congress Committee’s resolution.

('17', 24, 11, 17, 49830) 22. SPEECH AT DHUNDAKUVA 3
('17', 24, 12, 18, 49857) May 13, 1918
('17', 24, 13, 19, 49870) Mahatmaji began to address the people by saying that the result of their struggle was a nearly complete, if not a complete, victory inasmuch as Mr. Pratt had not been able to execute his threats and carry out his vow.
('17', 24, 13, 20, 50088) He divided vows into two classes, viz., divine and devilish.
('17', 24, 13, 21, 50149) Those vows were divine which could not be broken and should be carried out even at the cost of life, and which could stand resistance.
('17', 24, 13, 22, 50284) Devilish vows were those that required ever to be resisted.
('17', 24, 13, 23, 50344) A satyagrahi made it his
('17', 24, 14, 24, 50369) 1 The speech was the one Gandhiji made at the Man Power Committee of the War Conference on April 28, 1918. 2 The speech was the one Gandhiji made at the Man Power Committee of the War Conference on April 28, 1918. 3 A village in Borsad taluka
('17', 25, 0, 1, 50612) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 25, 1, 2, 50653) business to offer his resistance to such vows every time and everywhere.
('17', 25, 1, 3, 50726) And Mr. Pratt’s was such a vow, that is, of the devilish type.
('17', 25, 1, 4, 50789) Mr. Pratt had always been respected by him (the speaker), and he was no bad officer, but those who were not bad officers sometimes committed serious blunders.
('17', 25, 1, 5, 50948) Mr. Pratt’s object was to punish the agriculturists for their disobedience of Government’s authority, but he could not punish them as he chose the devilish means.1 The whole district was now fired with a spirit that was never in the people before.
('17', 25, 1, 6, 51196) They had awakened to a sense of their rights.
('17', 25, 1, 7, 51242) Mahatmaji explained to them that in defending themselves against oppression by passive resistance to it, they had blessed the oppressor also, just as Prahlad by his passive resistance blessed his oppressive father.
('17', 25, 1, 8, 51457) Had Mr. Pratt been allowed to execute his threat, the whole nation would have raised a cry of horror, and Mr. Pratt would no doubt see some day that he was luckily spared that catastrophe.
('17', 25, 2, 9, 51646) Before concluding, he said he could not omit to refer to one painful incident that had been brought to his notice.
('17', 25, 2, 10, 51761) He had been told that the mukhi in Dabhasi was
('17', 25, 3, 11, 51808) using his evil influence to persuade people to evade the effects of attachments by keeping money easily accessible to attaching officers.
('17', 25, 3, 12, 51946) It was, Mahatmaji said, incredible that people could be so simply deluded.
('17', 25, 3, 13, 52021) It was nothing short of voluntary mischief on the people’s part, and calculated to spoil the whole movement.
('17', 25, 3, 14, 52130) We will respect the officers, but we won’t assist them; we will give them food and shelter, but surely we will not voluntarily point out to them the things to be attached.
('17', 25, 3, 15, 52302) He who believes that he can evade the effects of attachment by keeping ready things for being attached, has missed the whole spirit of the struggle.
('17', 25, 4, 16, 52451) The Dabhasi incident, he repeated, had shocked him, and he hoped it would nowhere be repeated.
('17', 25, 4, 17, 52546) One thing more he would add in conclusion.
('17', 25, 4, 18, 52589) He had heard that revenue officers had to go without food and water from some places.
('17', 25, 4, 19, 52675) He would like to suggest that passive resistance did not mean molestation of others, but simple and pure voluntary suffering.
('17', 25, 4, 20, 52801) He feelingly concluded by observing that there ought not to be a single house or village which belonged to a satyagrahi where there was not the practice of truth in word and deed, where no sweet words were spoken, and where one had to go away without food and shelter.
('17', 25, 5, 21, 53070) The Bombay Chronicle, 16 5 1918
('17', 25, 6, 22, 53102) 1 During the month, Government resorted increasingly to confiscation of land for realization of revenue arrears; but later, forfeiture of land was largely set aside and dues realized through auction of movable property.

('17', 34, 1, 2, 69304) 33. LETTER TO HANUMANTRAO
('17', 34, 2, 3, 69330) May 25, 1918
('17', 34, 3, 4, 69343) What I want you to do is not to sever your connection with the Society 1; but remaining in the Society do the Hindi work.
('17', 34, 3, 5, 69465) I would like Mr. Shastriar to permit you to go to Allahabad, stay there a year and learn Hindi fairly well, then return to Madras and side by side with your other work spread a knowledge of Hindi among the Telugu people.
('17', 34, 3, 6, 69686) The fact of your having studied Hindi will enlarge the scope of your work and enable you if the occasion arose to work among the masses outside the Madras Presidency.
('17', 34, 3, 7, 69853) I do not know whether you have noticed it.
('17', 34, 3, 8, 69896) I have.
('17', 34, 3, 9, 69904) There is almost an unbridgeable gulf between the Dravidians and all the other Indians.
('17', 34, 3, 10, 69991) The shortest and the most effective bridge is undoubtedly the Hindi language.
('17', 34, 3, 11, 70069) English can never take its place.
('17', 34, 3, 12, 70103) When Hindi becomes the common language among the cultured classes the Hindi vocabulary will soon filter down to the masses.
('17', 34, 3, 13, 70227) There is something undefinable about Hindi which makes it the easiest language to learn and somehow or other there is a licence taken about Hindi grammar such as I have not known to be taken about any other language.
('17', 34, 3, 14, 70444) The result is that the learning of Hindi becomes largely a matter of memory only.
('17', 34, 3, 15, 70526) Hence do I say that for doing national work a knowledge of Hindi is an absolute necessity.
('17', 34, 3, 16, 70617) What can be better than that a member of the Society should give himself a training in Hindi?
('17', 34, 3, 17, 70711) Mr. Gokhale once told me that he wanted a knowledge of Hindi to be obligatory on the part of all the members and that he wanted Hindi to be the language spoken at the Society’s meetings.
('17', 34, 3, 18, 70898) He added that the Tamilians and especially Mr. Shastriar presented the greatest difficulty.
('17', 34, 3, 19, 70990) He was too old to learn it !!!
('17', 34, 3, 20, 71021) You seem to think of Satyagrahashram as something apart from the Society.
('17', 34, 3, 21, 71095) But I do not.
('17', 34, 3, 22, 71109) During the last days of Mr. Gokhale’s life on this earth his wish was that I should open a branch in Gujarat and bring to life a province which appeared to be politically dead.
('17', 34, 3, 23, 71286) It fills me with pride to know that I have played a humble part in carrying out the programme.
('17', 34, 3, 24, 71381) It is a matter not of much moment that Satyagrahashram for very sound reasons cannot be recognized as a branch.
('17', 34, 3, 25, 71493) The work is there.

('17', 35, 3, 8, 72154) 34. SPEECH AT PATNA
('17', 35, 4, 9, 72174) May 25, 1918
('17', 35, 5, 10, 72187) Mr. Gandhi returned from Motihari to attend a meeting in Patna City on the 25th ultimo.
('17', 35, 5, 11, 72275) While in Champaran, he visited the District Magistrate and Sub Divisional Officer, Bettiah, and then went on and saw his schools at Shikarpur, Madhuban and Dhakka.
('17', 35, 5, 12, 72439) While at Motihari, he stayed with Babu Gorakh Prasad.
('17', 35, 5, 13, 72493) Numbers of ryots visited his camp, but most of them were instructed to take their grievances to their local representatives.
('17', 35, 5, 14, 72618) His visit caused a mild excitement as usual.
('17', 35, 6, 15, 72663) The meeting in Patna over which the Hon’ble Mr. Purnendu Narayan Sinha presided was an unusually crowded one, some 8,000 persons attending including over 300 sadhus.
('17', 35, 6, 16, 72829) It would seem that the people expected a more fiery speech than the one actually delivered, for the enthusiasm evinced at Mr. Gandhi’s arrival waned very low as the speech proceeded.
('17', 35, 7, 17, 73012) In his opening remarks he referred to the subject of a universal language in India and hoped that within a few years Hindus would learn Persian and Muhammadans would study Sanskrit, so that the two languages might eventually combine.
('17', 35, 7, 18, 73246) He then went on to say that he had no time to speak to them regarding affairs in Champaran or”the disgraceful episode at Shahabad, but he would say that mutual goodwill between Muhammadans and Hindus would not be attained by recourse to the Special Tribunals; that was a question of mutual consultation and arrangement.
('17', 35, 7, 19, 73566) The main subject of his speech was”Our Present Condition”.
('17', 35, 7, 20, 73625) The time had arrived for Indians to make their choice.
('17', 35, 7, 21, 73680) Such opportunities only come once in the lifetime of a nation.
('17', 35, 7, 22, 73743) He was addressing his remarks more specially to the educated classes.
('17', 35, 7, 23, 73813) India had been called on for another army; already some seven or eight lakhs were serving outside India and another five lakhs were to be recruited this year.
('17', 35, 7, 24, 73972) These persons were paid by Government and earned their living by military service.
('17', 35, 7, 25, 74055) India could not be proud of them, and derived no benefit from their existence.
('17', 35, 7, 26, 74134) The self government that the people were clamouring for was not the self government that he had in mind.
('17', 35, 7, 27, 74239) They must have a self government army, and for this it was incumbent on them to supply the five lakhs that Government wanted without waiting for Government to recruit
('17', 36, 0, 1, 74406) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 37
('17', 36, 1, 2, 74445) The advise he gave them was to raise a republican army, and he called on the people”to go along with him and go wherever the Government directed”.
('17', 36, 1, 3, 74592) (At this stage a fairly large number of people quietly slipped away from the meeting).
('17', 36, 1, 4, 74679) If they did not provide the men, Government would obtain them somehow or other if necessary by enforcing legal compulsion.
('17', 36, 2, 5, 74802) Another matter that be wished to speak to them about was the idea that self government meant the dismissal of the British from India—this was impossible.
('17', 36, 2, 6, 74956) All they wanted was to become a great partner in the British Empire.
('17', 36, 2, 7, 75025) A great leader of India had said.”We are prepared to fight, but on this condition, that you pledge yourself to grant self government to India.” In his opinion, this was not a straight way of obtaining self government.
('17', 36, 2, 8, 75243) He advocated that India should provide the men wanted, and impose no conditions— any calamity that overtakes the Empire is one that overtakes India as well.
('17', 36, 2, 9, 75400) The English race had two outstanding characteristics, they lived in friendship with those who know how to die and those who know how to kill, and they helped those who helped themselves; they would be of one heart with those who claimed their rights at the very first moment they showed their strength and their determination to obtain these rights.
('17', 36, 2, 10, 75750) Two essentials are necessary in self government—power over the army and power over the purse, and that is why he repeatedly said that India’s ambition to obtain self government would be blasted if they missed this opportunity of obtaining military training and assisting the Empire, and thereby obtaining self government.
('17', 36, 2, 11, 76072) This opportunity would never come again.
('17', 36, 2, 12, 76113) Only those who are weak are compelled to think of making conditions—the strong impose no conditions.

('17', 37, 0, 1, 77036) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 37, 1, 2, 77077) If we make a very subtle definition of truth, it includes many things.
('17', 37, 1, 3, 77148) But because our definition of truth is rather narrow, we are compelled to add a little to it.
('17', 37, 1, 4, 77242) In this struggle we are not to oppose anybody, we are not to abuse anybody.
('17', 37, 1, 5, 77318) If the opponent abuses us, we have to tolerate it.
('17', 37, 1, 6, 77369) If he gives a blow to us with a stick, we have to bear it without giving a blow in return.
('17', 37, 1, 7, 77460) Secondly, a satyagrahi has to be fearless.
('17', 37, 1, 8, 77503) He has only to perform his duty.
('17', 37, 1, 9, 77536) You know that so long as we stick to truth, we remain absolutely free from fear.
('17', 37, 1, 10, 77617) You will always get protection if your dealings will be straightforward.
('17', 37, 1, 11, 77690) When we are in the wrong, we feel very nervous about us.
('17', 37, 1, 12, 77747) Those gentlemen who have committed the crime 1 have run away from the village.
('17', 37, 1, 13, 77826) But you have not run away in the struggle of satyagraha.
('17', 37, 1, 14, 77883) Always stick to truth; never be mischievous.
('17', 37, 1, 15, 77928) A satyagrahi will always welcome imprisonment or a warrant, if he has committed a crime.
('17', 37, 1, 16, 78017) Even if he has not committed it, he should welcome it.
('17', 37, 1, 17, 78072) What if it is not committed and yet it be proved in Court?
('17', 37, 1, 18, 78131) The Government has authority over this body, not over the soul.
('17', 37, 1, 19, 78195) The soul can be conquered through love.
('17', 37, 1, 20, 78235) A satyagrahi understands this and, therefore, whether he has committed a crime or not, he remains fearless.
('17', 37, 1, 21, 78343) The gentleman who has removed the cattle unlawfully, will, I hope, admit his mistake and boldly say that he will undergo any punishment that may be ordered for him.
('17', 37, 1, 22, 78508) Only thus shall you be elevated.
('17', 37, 1, 23, 78541) It is no theft if we do not allow our goods to go into the hands of Government officers.
('17', 37, 1, 24, 78630) So long as they have not fallen in their hands, you can take them to another village, you can bury them, you can remove your cattle and take them anywhere you like.
('17', 37, 1, 25, 78795) But no sooner are they attached, either by a horde of Government officials or by any one of them, we should not even touch them.
('17', 37, 1, 26, 78924) We are not going to help Government in attachments, we do not protect our cattle for them, but as soon as any Government officer attaches our buffalo, we have no right to take it back.
('17', 37, 1, 27, 79109) Brothers and sisters, I appeal to you to act accordingly.
('17', 37, 1, 28, 79167) It is not our business to speak insolently to officers or to let loose our cattle when they come to us.
('17', 37, 1, 29, 79271) The Collector told me that the raiyats are very gracefully acting in the struggle, but such tricks as are played by some Khandhali people mar the beauty of the struggle.
('17', 37, 1, 30, 79441) I beg of you not to do so again.
('17', 37, 1, 31, 79474) Real bravery lies in receiving rather than in giving blows.
('17', 37, 2, 32, 79534) 1 This consisted in letting loose the buffaloes attached by revenue officials.
('17', 38, 0, 1, 79613) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 39
('17', 38, 1, 2, 79652) Yesterday, I was reading my Gita.
('17', 38, 1, 3, 79686) Therein I saw that one of the characteristics of a Kshatriya was ‘apalayanam’ !
('17', 38, 1, 4, 79766) It means that in face of danger a Kshatriya does not fall back, but, on the contrary, sticks to his post.
('17', 38, 1, 5, 79872) If our Government will not fight with the Germans as it does now, if our soldiers go and stand before them weaponless and will not use explosives and say,”We will die of your blows”, then, I am sure our Government will win the war at once.
('17', 38, 1, 6, 80112) But such an action requires samskar and India possesses most of it.
('17', 38, 1, 7, 80180) The vegetables that grow in India will not grow properly in England.
('17', 38, 1, 8, 80249) The seeds of samskar will flourish in India.
('17', 38, 1, 9, 80294) Pure bravery lies in the power of endurance.
('17', 38, 1, 10, 80339) It is real satyagraha.
('17', 38, 1, 11, 80362) It is mean to run away in face of danger.

('17', 45, 1, 2, 92110) colour bar in regard to issue of tickets, placing in, and removing from compartments, occupation of place on station platforms, empower minor officials remove without assigning reason.
('17', 45, 1, 3, 92295) Please make suitable representation appropriate quarters.
('17', 45, 1, 4, 92353) Community unanimous assert rights unless relief sought granted.
('17', 45, 1, 5, 92417) Mr. Cachalia was one of the staunchest workers during the passive resistance campaign that raged for eight years in South Africa.
('17', 45, 1, 6, 92547) During that campaign, he reduced himself to poverty, and accepted imprisonment for the sake of India’s honour.
('17', 45, 1, 7, 92658) One can, therefore, easily understand what is meant by the words”Community unanimous assert rights unless relief sought granted.” It is not a threat, it is the burning cry of distress felt by a community whose self respect has been injured.
('17', 45, 1, 8, 92899) It is evident that the white people of South Africa have not been visibly impressed by the war which is claimed to be waged for the protection of the ryots or weaker or minor nationalities.
('17', 45, 1, 9, 93089) Their prejudice against colour is not restrained even by the fact that local Indians have raised a volunteer bearer corps which is gallantly serving in East Africa with the column that was taken to East Africa by General Smuts.
('17', 45, 1, 10, 93317) The problem is difficult—it is complex.
('17', 45, 1, 11, 93357) Prejudices cannot be removed by legislation.
('17', 45, 1, 12, 93402) They will yield only to patient toil and education.
('17', 45, 1, 13, 93454) But what of the Union Government?
('17', 45, 1, 14, 93488) It is feeding the prejudice by legalizing it.
('17', 45, 1, 15, 93534) Indians would have been content if the popular prejudice had been left to work itself out, care being taken to guard against violence on either side.
('17', 45, 1, 16, 93684) Indians of South Africa could not complain even against a boycott on the part of the whites.
('17', 45, 1, 17, 93777) It is there already.
('17', 45, 1, 18, 93798) In social life, they are completely ostracized.
('17', 45, 1, 19, 93846) They feel the ostracism, but they silently bear it.
('17', 45, 1, 20, 93898) But the situation alters when the Government steps in and gives legal recognition to the anti colour campaign.
('17', 45, 1, 21, 94009) It is impossible for the Indian settlers to submit to an insulting restraint upon their movements.
('17', 45, 1, 22, 94108) They will not allow booking clerks to decide as to whether they are becomingly dressed.
('17', 45, 1, 23, 94196) They cannot allow a platform inspector to restrict them to a reserved part of the platform.
('17', 45, 1, 24, 94288) They will not, as if they were ticket of leave men, produce their certificates in order to secure railway tickets.
('17', 45, 1, 25, 94403) The pendency of the war cannot be used as an effective shield to cover fresh wrongs and insults.
('17', 45, 1, 26, 94500) The plucky custodians of India’s honour are doing their share in South Africa.
('17', 45, 1, 27, 94579) We are here bound to help them.
('17', 45, 1, 28, 94611) Meetings throughout India should inform the
('17', 46, 0, 1, 94655) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 47
('17', 46, 1, 2, 94694) white inhabitants of South Africa that India resents their treatment of her sons.
('17', 46, 1, 3, 94776) They should call upon the Government of India and the Imperial Government to secure effective protection for our countrymen in South Africa.
('17', 46, 1, 4, 94917) I hope that Englishmen in India will not be behindhand in lending their valuable support to the movement to redress the wrong.
('17', 46, 1, 5, 95044) Mr. Cachalia’s cable is silent on the grievance disclosed in the second batch of extracts.
('17', 46, 1, 6, 95135) It is not less serious.
('17', 46, 1, 7, 95159) In its effect it is far more deadly.
('17', 46, 1, 8, 95196) But the community is hoping to right the wrong by an appeal to the highest legal tribunal in the Union.
('17', 46, 1, 9, 95300) But really the question is above that tribunal.
('17', 46, 1, 10, 95348) Let me state it in a sentence.
('17', 46, 1, 11, 95379) A reactionary Attorney General has obtained a ruling from the Natal Supreme Court to the effect that subjects of ‘Native States’ are aliens and not British subjects and are, therefore not entitled to its protection so far as appeals under a particular section of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act are concerned.
('17', 46, 1, 12, 95689) Thus, if the local Court’s ruling is correct, thousands of Indians settled in South Africa will be deprived of the security of residence in South Africa, for which they fought for eight years and which they thought they had won.
('17', 46, 1, 13, 95918) At least a quarter of the Indian settlers of South Africa are subjects of the Baroda and Kathiawad States.
('17', 46, 1, 14, 96025) If any law considers them as aliens, surely it has to be altered.
('17', 46, 1, 15, 96091) It is an insult to the States and their subjects to treat the latter as aliens.
('17', 46, 2, 16, 96171) Yours, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('17', 49, 3, 9, 101642) It was the first condition of our struggle that the day the assessment dues of the poor were suspended, those who can afford to pay shall at once pay up the revenue.
('17', 49, 3, 10, 101808) In the beginning, Government was obstinate enough to say that it could not be done.
('17', 49, 3, 11, 101892) Government said that the assessment that was fixed by them must be paid up at the proper time.
('17', 49, 3, 12, 101987) The Mamlatdar has issued an order to the effect that those of you who can afford to pay up the assessment should pay it up and those who are really unable to pay will get suspension.
('17', 49, 3, 13, 102170) Thus the Government will get the revenue; the people will preserve their self respect and they will also be true to their vow.
('17', 49, 3, 14, 102297) We must thank the Mamlatdar for this kind order, but how?

('17', 52, 6, 8, 108630) KAIRA DISTRICT The struggle that the people of the district of Kaira entered upon on the 22nd of March last, has come to an end.
('17', 52, 6, 9, 108759) The people took the following vow on that day.
('17', 52, 7, 10, 108806) The meaning of this vow is that the Government suspending collection of the revenue from the poor, the well to do should pay the assessment due from them.
('17', 52, 7, 11, 108961) The Mamlatdar of Nadiad at Uttersanda, on the 3rd of June issued such orders, whereupon the people of Uttersanda, who could afford, were advised to pay up.

('17', 52, 7, 14, 109552) The Collector has replied to the effect that the order like the one in Uttarsanda is applicable to the whole district.
('17', 52, 7, 15, 109671) Thus the people’s prayer has at last been granted.

('17', 57, 1, 16, 119621) In Nadiad a holder owed only two annas on account of principal.

('17', 57, 1, 18, 119764) The Mamlatdar refused to restore the pots unless chothai was paid.
('17', 57, 1, 19, 119831) The holder has paid the chothai under protest and prevented the threatened sale of his pots.
('17', 57, 1, 20, 119924) Should not chothai be refunded in this case?
('17', 57, 1, 21, 119969) Orders of forfeiture have been issued in Sinnaj also and payments offered after the date of settlement have not been accepted.
('17', 57, 1, 22, 120096) I am going to Bombay for the Conference.
('17', 57, 1, 23, 120137) I hope to return by the 16th instant.
('17', 57, 1, 24, 120175) Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel will be at your service meanwhile.
('17', 57, 1, 25, 120232) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('17', 57, 2, 26, 120262) From a copy: C.W. 10698. Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi
('17', 57, 3, 27, 120315) 52. SPEECH AT NADIAD 1
('17', 57, 4, 28, 120338) June 8, 1918
('17', 57, 5, 29, 120351) In the Court of the Collector of Nadiad, acting as District Magistrate, Mr. Mohanlal Pandya and five others from Navagam were charged on June 8, 1918, with the theft of onions from a field.
('17', 57, 5, 30, 120541) 2 The accused asserted that they honestly believed that there was nothing illegal in their action.
('17', 57, 6, 31, 120640) 1 This has been collated with a Gujarati report in Kheda Satyagraha.
('17', 57, 7, 32, 120709) 2 The field had been declared forfeited by Government order, but Gandhiji had pointed out to the Collector that, as the survey number of the field was not stated in the notice of forfeiture, it could not be regarded as forfeited.
('17', 57, 7, 33, 120939) He had advised the collection of the onion crop on the field in view of the imminent monsoon.
('17', 57, 7, 34, 121033) Vide An Autobiography, Part V, Ch. XXIV.
('17', 58, 0, 1, 121074) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 59
('17', 58, 1, 2, 121113) Gandhiji too said in his evidence that the sole responsibility for the action lay with him, and it was he who had advised the accused to remove the onions.
('17', 58, 1, 3, 121269) If it was an offence to have removed them, justice required that the sentence should be passed against him.
('17', 58, 1, 4, 121377) After the case was over, 1 Mahatmaji addressed a large gathering of people outside the compound of the court.
('17', 58, 1, 5, 121487) [He said :]
('17', 58, 2, 6, 121499) Two feelings are uppermost in my heart just now: one of them fills me with gladness, the other with pain.
('17', 58, 2, 7, 121605) I am glad because the people of Kaira, true satyagrahis that they are, got this opportunity of going to jail.
('17', 58, 2, 8, 121715) My doubt whether the agriculturists of Kaira would be ready to go to jail has been removed.
('17', 58, 2, 9, 121807) I am pained because though British officers are good men generally, some of them show want of generosity and vision.
('17', 58, 2, 10, 121924) The Collector, having awarded a sentence of imprisonment, is welcome to think of jail as degrading and in the nature of a terrible hardship; it is nothing of the kind to us.
('17', 58, 2, 11, 122098) In spite of this, the experience that the people have got is, indeed, splendid.
('17', 58, 2, 12, 122178) So long as we do not learn how to endure jail sufferings and do not perceive the true meaning and lesson of jail pilgrimage, we do not understand the real meaning of satyagraha.
('17', 58, 2, 13, 122356) This is the fittest opportunity for all to understand it and we should feel sorry that we are not so fortunate as our brethren who went to jail.
('17', 58, 2, 14, 122501) I tried my utmost to go to jail.
('17', 58, 2, 15, 122534) I said that the responsibility from the beginning to the end was solely mine.
('17', 58, 2, 16, 122612) Bhulabhai 2 had acted after full consideration.
('17', 58, 2, 17, 122660) If there is any mistake it is mine, and yet I do not feel I am at all in the wrong.
('17', 58, 2, 18, 122744) I got the case transferred to the Collector with great effort.
('17', 58, 2, 19, 122807) This was a test case.
('17', 58, 2, 20, 122829) I had previously informed the Collector that I was not going to appeal from his judgement; and I am still of the same mind.
('17', 58, 2, 21, 122953) The Court’s finding is unjust and the sentence harsh.
('17', 58, 2, 22, 123007) One cannot expect a man occupying the chair of a judge to be a satyagrahi, for law does not recognize satyagraha.
('17', 58, 2, 23, 123121) This is a case in which we are bound to succeed if we go in appeal.
('17', 58, 2, 24, 123189) We have lost the case not because Vallabhbhai or myself did not cross examine any witness.
('17', 58, 2, 25, 123280) Any impartial judge with legal knowledge could say that the facts do not constitute any offence.
('17', 58, 2, 26, 123377) In spite of that, we are not going to appeal.
('17', 58, 2, 27, 123423) A satyagrahi cannot do that.
('17', 58, 2, 28, 123452) For him, the best way is to go to jail.
('17', 58, 2, 29, 123492) I would have been more glad if the sentence had been even more severe.
('17', 58, 2, 30, 123563) The Collector has ordered the onions to be confiscated.
('17', 58, 3, 31, 123619) 1 Two of the accused were sentenced to ten days’ imprisonment and the rest to twenty days’ imprisonment each.
('17', 58, 3, 32, 123729) 2 The owner of the onion field
('17', 59, 0, 1, 123760) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 59, 1, 2, 123801) If the Government can dare pocket the onions, let them do.
('17', 59, 1, 3, 123860) But what I want to tell the many Navagam friends present here is that the revenue arrears of Bhulabhai, Rs. 94/ , must be paid up to the Mamlatdar by tomorrow.
('17', 59, 1, 4, 124020) We have to respect the settlement.
('17', 59, 1, 5, 124055) I am going to say the same in the district meeting at Nadiad.

('17', 59, 1, 7, 124277) The Collector has acted in anger.

('17', 59, 1, 9, 124418) If he had quietly thought over the case and studied the law a little more carefully, he would have seen that there was no offence in the act.
('17', 59, 1, 10, 124560) If we mean to educate the officers, we must act in this manner again and again; and then they will understand that there cannot be any punishment for such a heroic people, that they deserve a loving handshake.
('17', 59, 1, 11, 124770) If we want to win over officers, we should be honest and courteous in our dealings with them.

('17', 59, 1, 15, 125161) As Mohanlal Pandya is with them, I have no anxiety for the rest.

('17', 59, 1, 17, 125325) This is not the first time when I have advised against an appeal.
('17', 59, 1, 18, 125391) In South Africa, when thousands went to jail, I never appealed.
('17', 59, 1, 19, 125455) There can be no appeal when we wish to go to jail by way of tapascharya.
('17', 59, 1, 20, 125528) Perhaps the Kaira people have not risen so high.
('17', 59, 1, 21, 125577) But if they have, I would advise them not to offer any defence and to allow the Court to do what it pleases.
('17', 59, 1, 22, 125686) There are two or three other cases pending in the district.
('17', 59, 1, 23, 125746) I advise you not to defend yourselves but to suffer imprisonment.
('17', 59, 1, 24, 125812) There is so much to be learnt in that; and it is my firm belief that we can advance the country by acting in this manner.

('17', 62, 1, 2, 128906) 55. LETTER TO LORD WILLINGDON
('17', 62, 2, 3, 128936) BOMBAY,
('17', 62, 3, 4, 128944) June 11, 1918
('17', 62, 4, 5, 128958) DEAR LORD WILLINGDON,
('17', 62, 5, 6, 128980) I trust you will not misunderstand this note.
('17', 62, 6, 7, 129026) I venture to think that your stopping of Messrs Tilak and Kelkar 1 yesterday was a serious blunder.
('17', 62, 6, 8, 129126) 2 They had been informed on your behalf that they could offer criticism but they could not move an amendment.
('17', 62, 6, 9, 129236) Your having stopped them will be resented as an insult to a great and growing party in the country.
('17', 62, 6, 10, 129336) Your action has made the position of workers delicate and difficult and if Mr. Tilak is an enemy of the Government or of the Empire you have undoubtedly strengthened his hands in the pursuit of his course.
('17', 62, 6, 11, 129542) But if you had allowed him and Mr. Kelkar to have their say, they would have gone away satisfied and it could have been said that you had given fair play to all.
('17', 62, 6, 12, 129704) Will you not publicly express your regret for the blunder or send for both of them, expressing your regret to them, and invite their co operation and discuss their viewpoint?
('17', 62, 6, 13, 129879) You will lose nothing and you will gain greatly in the estimation of the people, enhance your prestige, increase your capacity for securing help from the people and possibly win over the Home Rule party, and also nip in the bud an agitation that is bound to spring up 3 in the country.
('17', 62, 7, 14, 130165) I repeat my request that you will not misunderstand this note,

('17', 62, 9, 16, 130346) 2 The incident occurred on June 10 at the Bombay Provincial War Conference, over which Lord Willingdon presided.

('17', 65, 1, 2, 134846) 59. LETTER TO J. KER
('17', 65, 2, 3, 134867) NADIAD, June 14, 1918
('17', 65, 3, 4, 134889) DEAR MR. KER, I have just returned from Bombay and read your letter of the 10th instant to Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel.
('17', 65, 3, 5, 135003) It is clear that your instructions have not yet reached the Mamlatdars and the Talatis, for they have collected chothai from those whose goods were distrained but not sold.
('17', 65, 3, 6, 135176) I assume that in all such cases chothai collected would be refunded.
('17', 65, 3, 7, 135245) Your decision to collect chothai from those against whom forfeiture orders are passed creates a position different from the one taken up by you in your letter of the 4th instant and the impression left by you upon my mind in the course of our conversations.
('17', 65, 3, 8, 135503) My letter of the 3rd instant says,”Should you see your way to pass such orders, i.e., like those of the Uttarsanda Mamlatdar, I assume that there would be no chothai to be collected”.
('17', 65, 3, 9, 135687) You said in reply,”No quarter fine will of course be levied from those who come forward to pay even now.” In the circumstances your letter under reply means a revision of a previous intention.
('17', 65, 3, 10, 135880) I trust that you will give effect to the original intention.
('17', 65, 3, 11, 135941) I may add that at the public meeting at Nadiad held on the 8th instant I made the announcement in the terms of the original intention and told the people that the only outstanding question was as to the refund of chothai collected before the date of settlement.
('17', 65, 3, 12, 136203) I said the possibility of success in getting refund lay in their prompt payment of the assessment wherever they were able to pay.
('17', 65, 3, 13, 136333) In regard to the 3 Wadthal cases I admit the fact that in one case the villagers succeeded in preventing bidding to the full value of the property distrained.
('17', 65, 3, 14, 136492) But in the other two they failed in their plan and competitive bidding took place up to the full value of the buffaloes so that the chothai in the two cases remained unpaid for natural causes.
('17', 65, 3, 15, 136685) Your argument that if the bidding had resulted in the whole amount of execution being realized the question of refund would have arisen, applies equally to the other cases in which chothai is not to be executed.
('17', 65, 3, 16, 136897) The distinction can be drawn only where”tricking” can be proved.
('17', 65, 3, 17, 136962) I respectfully deny that in the third case there was any
('17', 66, 0, 1, 137019) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 67
('17', 66, 1, 2, 137058) tricking.
('17', 66, 1, 3, 137068) It was part of the game by all legitimate means to prevent the Government from collecting.
('17', 66, 1, 4, 137159) As to the forfeiture cases, I thank you for the consideration you propose to show regarding the forfeiture where the original holder has recently died.
('17', 66, 1, 5, 137311) As to the other two cases they fall under my request for a revision of your orders regarding chothai.
('17', 66, 1, 6, 137413) As to the case in which chothai execution has been levied for the sake of two anna arrears, I am making further inquiries.
('17', 66, 1, 7, 137536) Regarding the last paragraph of your letter, I can only say that throughout our conversations and my conversation with the Mamlatadar I spoke of suspension.
('17', 66, 1, 8, 137693) It is referred to in my letter of the 3rd instant.
('17', 66, 1, 9, 137744) I have described the order of the Mamlatdar as a suspension order.
('17', 66, 1, 10, 137811) In your letter of the 4th instant you have not repudiated my interpretation.
('17', 66, 1, 11, 137888) In fact the Mamlatdar’s order is clearly a suspension order made as a result of the conversation between him and me and in my humble opinion it is impossible to revise a decision on which people have already acted.
('17', 66, 1, 12, 138103) You may be aware that people have commenced voluntary payments all over except in Uttarsanda where we are having some difficulty.
('17', 66, 1, 13, 138233) There too payment has commenced but not as fully as is possible.
('17', 66, 1, 14, 138298) I hope therefore that you will be good enough to revise your view regarding the settlement.
('17', 66, 2, 15, 138390) Yours sincerely,
('17', 66, 3, 16, 138407) M. K. GANDHI
('17', 66, 4, 17, 138420) From a copy: C.W. 10700. Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi
('17', 66, 5, 18, 138473) 60. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, BOMBAY 1
('17', 66, 6, 19, 138512) June 16, 1918
('17', 66, 7, 20, 138526) It was not without very considerable hesitation that I accepted the invitation to preside over the deliberations of this great and important meeting.
('17', 66, 7, 21, 138676) We have met in order respectfully to protest against His Excellency Lord Willingdon’s conduct in the chair at the War Conference that met in the Town Hall on the 10th instant.
('17', 66, 8, 22, 138852) 1 Gandhiji presided over the meeting which was held in the evening at Shantaram Chawl in Girgaon, in the heart of Bombay city, and was attended by some 12,000 people.
('17', 66, 8, 23, 139019) The meeting was organized as an anti Willingdon demonstration to protest against the Governor’s provocative statements, at the Bombay Provincial War Conference, regarding Home Rule League leaders.
('17', 66, 8, 24, 139216) The meeting adopted two resolutions.
('17', 66, 8, 25, 139253) The day was observed as ‘Home Rule Day’.
('17', 67, 0, 1, 139294) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 67, 1, 2, 139335) entertain high regard for Lord Willingdon.
('17', 67, 1, 3, 139378) Of all the Governors in India, probably Lord Willingdon is the most popular.
('17', 67, 1, 4, 139455) He is known to hold liberal views regarding our aspirations.
('17', 67, 1, 5, 139516) It is, therefore, difficult for me to contemplate the proceedings of this meeting without sorrow, but I feel that I may not allow personal regard to interfere with the performance of an obvious duty, no matter how painful it may be.
('17', 67, 1, 6, 139749) The duty is plain.
('17', 67, 1, 7, 139768) Lord Willingdon convened the Conference, deliberately invited the prominent and leading members of the Home Rule Leagues.
('17', 67, 1, 8, 139890) They, not wishing to court insult on the one hand, and on the other, desiring to give ample previous notice to His Excellency of their intention to plead their views before the Conference, asked for information about the programme of the Conference.
('17', 67, 1, 9, 140140) Lord Willingdon had before him the experience of the Delhi Conference 1. He knew that the Home Rule League members had the first scope given them for discussion during the sittings of the Committees that were then formed.
('17', 67, 1, 10, 140362) He knew that many members of that Conference had delivered political speeches at its first sitting.
('17', 67, 1, 11, 140462) With all this knowledge in his possession, now mark what happened at the Conference.
('17', 67, 1, 12, 140547) In his opening remarks, he delivered a deliberate attack upon the Home Rule Leagues.
('17', 67, 1, 13, 140632) He accused them of constant obstruction.
('17', 67, 1, 14, 140673) He was not sure of the sincerity of their support.
('17', 67, 1, 15, 140724) The Conference platform was hardly the platform for such remarks.
('17', 67, 1, 16, 140790) If he did not want their co operation, he ought not to have invited the members of the Home Rule Leagues.
('17', 67, 1, 17, 140896) If he desired their co operation, it was hardly the way to tell them beforehand that he did not trust them.
('17', 67, 1, 18, 141004) He ought to have remembered that Home Rule Leaguers gave material assistance in one way.
('17', 67, 1, 19, 141093) Their organ, the Chronicle, has always urged upon the people to give all the help they can.
('17', 67, 1, 20, 141185) I venture to suggest to His Excellency that his aspersion upon the Leagues was, at the very least, a tactical blunder.
('17', 67, 1, 21, 141304) But this was not enough.
('17', 67, 1, 22, 141329) He wrote in reply to Mr. Kelkar’s inquiry as follows:
('17', 67, 2, 23, 141383) A certain number of speakers will be invited beforehand to move, second and support the resolutions to be laid before the Conference.

('17', 67, 3, 25, 141600) The resolutions laid before the Conference will be framed to give effect to the resolutions of the Delhi Conference and will betwo in number, the first in general terms and the second making specific proposals.
