('17', 75, 1, 2, 158013) 63. SPEECH AT NADIAD 1
('17', 75, 2, 3, 158036) June 17, 1918
('17', 75, 3, 4, 158050) In the course of his speech, Mr. Gandhi observed that it was the first and most important duty of the ryots to assist Government.
('17', 75, 3, 5, 158180) Full assistance should be given in order to overthrow the Germans.
('17', 75, 3, 6, 158247) The English were better than the Germans.
('17', 75, 3, 7, 158289) They had come into close contact with the English and they knew each other well, so it was their first duty to assist the English.
('17', 75, 3, 8, 158420) Some said that they should help only if they were given Home Rule.
('17', 75, 3, 9, 158487) He believed they could not preserve the country so long as they had no military traditions.
('17', 75, 3, 10, 158579) In due course they would get Home Rule.
('17', 75, 3, 11, 158619) By the mere fact of giving assistance they would get it.
('17', 75, 3, 12, 158676) Half a million men were required from India for active service during a year, and if they did not come forward to supply these men, Government would themselves enlist them and the army so raised will be called the Government army.
('17', 75, 3, 13, 158907) But if the men were supplied by them they should be called the national army.
('17', 75, 3, 14, 158985) The same rules and regulations that were heretofore in force would apply to the men so raised.
('17', 75, 3, 15, 159080) Home Rule without military power was useless, and this was the best opportunity to get it.
('17', 75, 3, 16, 159171) They should not, therefore, lose this opportunity.
('17', 75, 3, 17, 159222) He had had a talk with [Mr.] Tilak, Mrs. Annie Besant, Mr. Madan Mohan Malaviya and Mr. Motilal Nehru in this connection, and they were all of opinion that it was a good idea, but they doubted whether the ryots would accept these views.
('17', 75, 3, 18, 159459) He had faith in ryots.
('17', 75, 3, 19, 159482) Many men died of plague and cholera and so it would not be a hard thing to die in the war.
('17', 75, 3, 20, 159573) He was ready to go to the war if the people would come forward.
('17', 75, 3, 21, 159637) He was not a member of the Home Rule League.
('17', 75, 3, 22, 159682) To receive military training was the stepping stone to acquire Home Rule, and so each and every member of the Home Rule League should join.
('17', 75, 3, 23, 159822) It was rumoured the Indians were placed in the first row and were killed, but he did not believe this.
('17', 75, 3, 24, 159925) The English were a fighting race and he did not believe that such a people would remain in the rear and send others to the front.
('17', 75, 3, 25, 160055) If, however, such a time came he would himself object, and unless he were shot, he would not allow

('17', 76, 4, 9, 160942) 64. LETTER TO J. KER
('17', 76, 5, 10, 160963) NADIAD, June 18, 1918
('17', 76, 6, 11, 160985) DEAR MR. KER, I have your letter of the 17th instant in reply to mine of the 14th instant regarding certain points arising from the settlement.
('17', 76, 6, 12, 161129) As to paragraph 3 of your letter I can only say that the rules of interpretation require that that meaning should be attached to one’s language which one’s hearer is reasonably entitled to put upon it.
('17', 76, 6, 13, 161331) Your answer as to chothai was clearly in reply to my query and it left no room for doubt either in my mind or Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel’s that chothai was to be excused in every case in which it was not yet collected.
('17', 76, 6, 14, 161545) What is more, when one in good faith has already acted upon such interpretation, if the line you propose to adopt is sound, every order would be interpreted not as the readers, according to the natural meaning of words, understand it, but as the issuer has intended his language to mean.
('17', 76, 6, 15, 161833) Surely you do not ask for any such canon of interpretation.
('17', 76, 6, 16, 161893) Similarly for suspension, I feel that you are importing a most dangerous principle of interpretation of orders.
('17', 76, 6, 17, 162005) Suspension to me could only bear one meaning; ‘unauthorized arrears’ is not an unfamiliar expression to me.
('17', 76, 6, 18, 162113) I did not need to approach you for any such concession.
('17', 76, 6, 19, 162169) It would have been no concession.
('17', 76, 6, 20, 162203) You would not need time for consideration in issuing order for unauthorized arrears as you said you needed.
('17', 76, 6, 21, 162311) I brought the Mamlatdar’s order to your notice.
('17', 76, 6, 22, 162359) You confirmed it.
('17', 76, 6, 23, 162377) It is now open to you to go behind it and claim that the word bears not its natural meaning but a meaning which you now desire to give.
('17', 76, 6, 24, 162513) After your confirmation of the Mamlatdar’s
('17', 77, 0, 1, 162556) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 77, 1, 2, 162597) order, it is irrelevant whether he had authority to issue the order or not.
('17', 77, 1, 3, 162673) But I would add that I asked him whether he had authority for what he was saying.
('17', 77, 1, 4, 162755) On his saying he had, I asked him to issue written orders which he did.
('17', 77, 1, 5, 162827) I do hope that in the circumstances you will not allow yourself to be in the wrong and let the natural and just view prevail.
('17', 77, 2, 6, 162953) Yours sincerely,
('17', 77, 3, 7, 162970) From a copy: C.W. 10701. Courtesy: Chhaganlal Gandhi

('17', 78, 2, 3, 163868) June 21, 1918
('17', 78, 3, 4, 163882) SISTERS AND BROTHERS, I am sorry to see that very few women are present today.
('17', 78, 3, 5, 163961) What I have to say is meant for both.
('17', 78, 3, 6, 163999) I have not come here to preach, but to give you what seems to me right advice.
('17', 78, 3, 7, 164078) This meeting in Nadiad is the first of its kind in Gujarat.
('17', 78, 3, 8, 164138) It was here that the first meeting for satyagraha was held.
('17', 78, 3, 9, 164198) We displayed good strength and much capacity for suffering during that struggle.
('17', 78, 3, 10, 164279) It brought me into close contact with the people.
('17', 78, 3, 11, 164329) I feel, therefore, that in saying what I have to say to the whole of the country, I should make a start with this place.
('17', 78, 3, 12, 164450) We put up a determined fight against the Government, said many harsh and bitter things to it.
('17', 78, 3, 13, 164544) All this was necessary, but whether or not we had the right to do it, we have now an opportunity to show.
('17', 78, 3, 14, 164650) There is no room for vindictiveness in satyagraha; I am sure there was none in our struggle.
('17', 78, 3, 15, 164743) Let us consider whether it is desirable at all in any circumstances that we should associate ourselves with the Government.
('17', 78, 3, 16, 164867) I have closely watched its shortcomings during our struggle as also on other occasions, and have pointed them out too.
('17', 78, 3, 17, 164986) I have had, however, no opportunity at all in India to present its better side.
('17', 78, 3, 18, 165066) From my personal experience of dealings with it, I have learnt this at any rate: that we would do well not to be content with a subordinate position in the Empire.
('17', 78, 3, 19, 165230) It is a characteristic trait of the British that they would treat people who did so as beasts of burden.
('17', 78, 3, 20, 165335) We can benefit by our connection with them only if we live as their friends or partners.
('17', 78, 3, 21, 165424) They will protect the honour of their allies and be loyal to them unto death.
('17', 78, 3, 22, 165502) As a nation, they have some virtues.
('17', 78, 3, 23, 165539) They love justice; they have shielded men against oppression.
('17', 78, 3, 24, 165601) The liberty of the individual is very dear to them.
('17', 78, 3, 25, 165653) Why, then, should we think of breaking off our connection with them altogether?
('17', 78, 3, 26, 165733) Everyone needs a friend.
('17', 78, 3, 27, 165758) Japan, America, England—they are all obliged to maintain friendship with some nation or other.
('17', 78, 3, 28, 165853) Every country maintains a connection with another with which it is temperamentally allied.
('17', 78, 3, 29, 165944) India can be no exception to this.
('17', 78, 3, 30, 165979) We aspire to independence, but on this basis.
('17', 78, 3, 31, 166025) In this context, the examples of Australia and Canada are

('17', 79, 1, 2, 166274) generally cited; we demand a status like theirs.

('17', 79, 1, 4, 166388) That is exactly what we want for ourselves.
('17', 79, 1, 5, 166432) If we think a status such as this is really worth having, we should do what is necessary to achieve it.

('17', 79, 3, 28, 168361) People feel helpless before him.
('17', 79, 4, 29, 168394) With this cowardly fear in us, how can we be the equals of the British?

('17', 80, 1, 3, 168792) 1 We occupy the position of the Bhangi in the Empire.
('17', 80, 1, 4, 168846) Now we have an opportunity to emancipate ourselves from such a state and we can use it in either of two ways—in a spirit of friendliness or that of hostility.
('17', 80, 1, 5, 169005) If we would follow the latter course, we should not help them with a single man or with a single pie; we should even stop others from helping.
('17', 80, 1, 6, 169148) We should hope for a defeat of the Allies and fight the British and drive them out.
('17', 80, 1, 7, 169232) All this, even if desirable, is impossible.
('17', 80, 1, 8, 169276) Though we, advocates of swaraj, may not help the Government, other sections of the country have been helping it.
('17', 80, 1, 9, 169389) We have no strength to fight the Government, or anyone else for that matter.
('17', 80, 1, 10, 169466) It has succeeded in securing help from India to the tune of a million men and crores of rupees.
('17', 80, 1, 11, 169562) Evidently, therefore, if we now propose to push the British out of India in a spirit of hostility and be Bhangis no more, it does not seem likely that we shall in the foreseeable future succeed in breaking off the British connection through physical force.
('17', 80, 1, 12, 169819) We can, therefore, free ourselves only through a friendly approach.
('17', 80, 1, 13, 169887) This is not possible unless we render all possible help to the Government at the present juncture.
('17', 80, 1, 14, 169986) We want to be partners in the Empire.
('17', 80, 1, 15, 170024) If there were no Empire, with whom would we be partners?
('17', 80, 1, 16, 170081) Our hopes lie in the survival of the Empire.
('17', 80, 1, 17, 170126) By all means, let us fight its evils.
('17', 80, 1, 18, 170164) A brother fights the wrongs done by a brother.
('17', 80, 1, 19, 170211) If one brother seeks to deprive another of his right, the latter will resist, but will go all out to help the former in time of difficulty and so prove the fact of their being brothers, wiping out, sometimes, even old animosities.
('17', 80, 1, 20, 170442) There is no reason to believe that we cannot bring about such a result by dealing with the British in the right manner.
('17', 80, 1, 21, 170562) To be sure, we may fight the iniquities of the Empire.
('17', 80, 1, 22, 170617) Even today we may do so, if they were to inflict anything afresh.
('17', 80, 1, 23, 170683) At the same time, we should spare no effort in helping it to meet the danger which threatens it.
('17', 80, 1, 24, 170780) Besides, we shall learn military discipline as we help the Empire, gain military experience and acquire the strength to defend ourselves.
('17', 80, 1, 25, 170918) With that strength, we may even fight the Empire, should it play foul with us.
('17', 80, 1, 26, 170997) It knows this, and, therefore, it will prove the bona fides of the British Government if they permit us to enlist.
('17', 80, 1, 27, 171112) By raising an army now, we shall be insuring against future eventualities.

('17', 81, 1, 2, 171314) If the British people have the ability to rule, they do not owe it merely to their physical strength.

('17', 82, 1, 2, 173700) 67. APPEAL FOR ENLISTMENT
('17', 82, 2, 3, 173726) NADIAD, June 22, 1918
('17', 82, 3, 4, 173748) LEAFLET NO.
('17', 82, 4, 5, 173760) SISTERS AND BROTHERS OF KHEDA DISTRICT: You have just emerged successful from a glorious satyagraha campaign.
('17', 82, 4, 6, 173870) You have, in the course of this struggle, given such evidence of fearlessness, tact and other virtues that I venture to advise and urge you to undertake a still greater campaign.
('17', 82, 4, 7, 174049) You have successfully demonstrated how you can resist Government with civility, and how you can retain your self respect without hurting theirs.
('17', 82, 4, 8, 174194) I now place before you an opportunity of proving that you bear no hostility to Government despite your having given it a strenuous fight.
('17', 82, 4, 9, 174332) You are all lovers of swaraj; some of you are members of the Home Rule League.
('17', 82, 4, 10, 174411) One meaning of Home Rule is that we should become partners in the Empire.
('17', 82, 4, 11, 174485) Today we are a subject people.
('17', 82, 4, 12, 174516) We do not enjoy all the rights of Englishmen.
('17', 82, 4, 13, 174562) We are not today partners in the Empire as are Canada, South Africa and Australia.
('17', 82, 4, 14, 174645) We are a dependency.
('17', 82, 4, 15, 174666) We want the rights of Englishmen, and we aspire to be as much partners in the Empire as the Dominions overseas.
('17', 82, 4, 16, 174778) We look forward to a time when we may aspire to the Viceregal office.
('17', 82, 4, 17, 174848) To bring about such a state of things we should have the ability to defend ourselves, that is, the ability to bear arms and to use them.
('17', 82, 4, 18, 174985) As long as we have to look to Englishmen for our defence, as long as we are not free from the fear of the military, so long we cannot be regarded as equal partners with Englishmen.
('17', 82, 4, 19, 175166) It behoves us, therefore, to learn the use of arms and to acquire the ability to defend ourselves.
('17', 82, 4, 20, 175265) If we want to learn the use of arms with the greatest possible despatch, it is our duty to enlist ourselves in the army.
('17', 82, 4, 21, 175386) There can be no friendship between the brave and the effeminate.
('17', 82, 4, 22, 175451) We are regarded as a cowardly people.
('17', 82, 4, 23, 175489) If we want to become free from that reproach, we should learn the use of arms.
('17', 82, 5, 24, 175568) 1 Probably used by Gandhiji for the text of his address at a meeting, this went into wide circulation in the printed form.
('17', 82, 5, 25, 175691) An English version was also published, in the Press, but is not available.
('17', 83, 0, 1, 175766) 84 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 83, 1, 2, 175807) Partnership in the Empire is our definite goal.
('17', 83, 1, 3, 175855) We should suffer to the utmost of our ability and even lay down our lives to defend the Empire.
('17', 83, 1, 4, 175951) If the Empire perishes, with it perish our cherished aspirations.
('17', 83, 1, 5, 176017) Hence the easiest and the straightest way to win swaraj is to participate in the defence of the Empire.
('17', 83, 1, 6, 176121) It is not within our power to give much money.
('17', 83, 1, 7, 176168) Moreover, it is not money that will win the war.
('17', 83, 1, 8, 176217) Only an army inexhaustible in number can do it.
('17', 83, 1, 9, 176265) That army India can supply.
('17', 83, 1, 10, 176293) If the Empire wins mainly with the help of our army, it is obvious that we would secure the rights we want.
('17', 83, 1, 11, 176401) Some will say that, if we do not secure those rights just now, we would be cheated of them afterwards.
('17', 83, 1, 12, 176504) The strength we employ in defending the Empire now can secure those rights.
('17', 83, 1, 13, 176580) Rights won by making an opportunity of the Empire’s weakness are likely to be lost when the Empire regains its strength.
('17', 83, 1, 14, 176701) We shall not succeed in becoming partners in the Empire by trying to embarrass it.
('17', 83, 1, 15, 176784) Embarrassing it in its hour of crisis will not help us to secure the rights which we must win by serving it.
('17', 83, 1, 16, 176893) To distrust the statesmen of the Empire is to distrust our own strength; it is a sign of our own weakness.
('17', 83, 1, 17, 177000) We should not depend for our rights on the goodness or the weakness of the statesmen, we should depend on our fitness and our strength.
('17', 83, 1, 18, 177136) The Native States are helping the Empire and they are getting their reward.
('17', 83, 1, 19, 177212) The rich are rendering full financial assistance to the Government and they are likewise getting their reward.
('17', 83, 1, 20, 177323) The assistance in neither case is rendered conditionally.
('17', 83, 1, 21, 177381) The sepoys are rendering their services for their salt and for their livelihood.
('17', 83, 1, 22, 177462) They get their livelihood, and prizes and honours in addition.
('17', 83, 1, 23, 177525) All these classes are a part of us, but they cannot be regarded as lovers of swaraj, their goal is not swaraj.
('17', 83, 1, 24, 177636) The help they render is not out of love for the country.
('17', 83, 1, 25, 177693) If we seek to win swaraj in a spirit of hostility, it may well be that the Imperial statesmen will use these three forces against us and defeat us.
('17', 83, 1, 26, 177841) If we want swaraj, it is our duty to help the Empire and we shall undoubtedly get the reward of that help.
('17', 83, 1, 27, 177948) If our motive is honest, the Government will behave honestly with us.
('17', 83, 1, 28, 178018) Assuming for a moment that it will not do so, our honesty should make us confident of our success.
('17', 83, 1, 29, 178117) It is no mark of greatness to be good only with the good.
('17', 83, 1, 30, 178175) Greatness lies in returning good for evil.
('17', 83, 1, 31, 178218) The Government does not give us commissions in the Army, it
('17', 84, 0, 1, 178278) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 85
('17', 84, 1, 2, 178317) does not repeal the Arms Act; it does not open schools for military training.
('17', 84, 1, 3, 178395) How can we then co operate with it?
('17', 84, 1, 4, 178431) These are valid objections.
('17', 84, 1, 5, 178459) In not granting reforms in these matters, the Government is committing a serious blunder.
('17', 84, 1, 6, 178549) The British have many acts of goodness to their credit.
('17', 84, 1, 7, 178605) For these, God’s grace be with them.
('17', 84, 1, 8, 178642) But the heinous sin perpetrated by the British administrators in the name of their people will, if they do not take care betimes, undo the effect of all these acts of goodness.
('17', 84, 1, 9, 178819) If the worst happens to India, which God forbid, and she passes into the hands of some other nation, India’s piteous cry will make England hang her head in shame before the world, and a curse will descend upon her for having emasculated a nation of thirty crores.
('17', 84, 1, 10, 179083) I believe the statesmen of England have realized this and have taken the warning, but they are unable to alter all of a sudden the situation created by themselves.
('17', 84, 1, 11, 179247) Every Englishman upon entering India is trained to despise us, to regard himself as our superior and to keep himself aloof from us.
('17', 84, 1, 12, 179379) They imbibe these ideas from the very atmosphere in which they move.
('17', 84, 1, 13, 179448) Those at the higher levels of administration try to free themselves and their subordinates from this atmosphere but their effort does not bear immediate fruit.
('17', 84, 1, 14, 179608) If there were no crisis for the Empire, we should be fighting against this domineering spirit.
('17', 84, 1, 15, 179703) But to sit back at this crisis, waiting for commissions, etc., is like cutting off one’s nose to spite one’s face.
('17', 84, 1, 16, 179818) It may well be that, while we are waiting for commissions, the opportunity to help the Empire may slip away.
('17', 84, 2, 17, 179927) It is my firm belief that even if the Government desires to prevent us from enlisting in the army and rendering other help by refusing us commissions or by delay in granting them, it is our duty to insist upon joining the army.
('17', 84, 2, 18, 180155) The Government at present wants half a million men for the army.
('17', 84, 2, 19, 180220) They will certainly succeed in raising this number somehow.
('17', 84, 2, 20, 180280) If we supply this number, the credit will be ours, we will be rendering a service and the reports that we often hear of improper methods adopted by recruiting agents will become things of the past.
('17', 84, 2, 21, 180478) It is no small thing to have the whole work of recruiting in our hands.
('17', 84, 2, 22, 180550) If the Government have no trust in us, if their intentions are not pure, they would not recruitment through us.
('17', 84, 3, 23, 180662) The foregoing argument will show that by enlisting in the army we help the Empire, we qualify ourselves for swaraj, we learn to
('17', 85, 0, 1, 180790) 86 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 85, 1, 2, 180831) defend India and to a certain extent regain our lost manhood.
('17', 85, 2, 3, 180893) I admit it is because of my faith in the British people that I can advise as I am doing.
('17', 85, 2, 4, 180982) I believe that, though this nation has done India much harm, it is to our advantage to retain connection with it.
('17', 85, 2, 5, 181096) Their virtues seem to me to outweigh their vices.
('17', 85, 2, 6, 181146) It is painful to remain in subjection to that nation.
('17', 85, 2, 7, 181200) The British have the great vice of depriving a subject nation of its self respect, but they have also the virtue of treating their equals with due respect and of loyalty towards them.
('17', 85, 2, 8, 181384) We have seen that they have many times helped those groaning under the tyranny of others.
('17', 85, 2, 9, 181474) As their partners, there is much we can receive and much that we can give and our connection with them based on that relationship is likely to benefit the world.
('17', 85, 2, 10, 181636) If such was not my faith and if I thought it desirable to become absolutely independent of that nation, I would not only not advise co operation but would on the contrary ask the people to beware, advising them to rebel, and paying the penalty for doing so.
('17', 85, 2, 11, 181894) We are not in a position today to stand on our own feet unaided and alone.
('17', 85, 2, 12, 181969) I believe that our good lies in becoming and remaining equal partners in the Empire and I have seen it throughout India that all those who demand swaraj are of the same view.
('17', 85, 2, 13, 182144) I expect from Kheda and Gujarat not 500 or 700 recruits but thousands.
('17', 85, 2, 14, 182215) If Gujarat wants to save herself from the reproach of effeminacy, she should be prepared to contribute thousands of sepoys.
('17', 85, 2, 15, 182339) These must include the educated classes, the Patidars, the Dharalas, the Vagharis and I hope they all will fight side by side as comrades.
('17', 85, 2, 16, 182478) Unless the educated classes or the elite of the community take the lead, it is idle to expect the other classes to come forward.
('17', 85, 2, 17, 182607) I hope those among the educated classes who are above the prescribed age but who are able bodied will be eligible to enlist themselves.
('17', 85, 2, 18, 182743) Their services will be utilized, if not for actual fighting, for related purposes and for looking after the welfare of the sepoys.
('17', 85, 2, 19, 182874) I hope also that those who have grown up sons will not hesitate to send them as recruits.
('17', 85, 2, 20, 182964) To sacrifice sons in the war ought to be a cause not of pain but of pleasure to brave men.
('17', 85, 2, 21, 183055) Sacrifice of sons at this hour will be a sacrifice for swaraj.
('17', 85, 3, 22, 183118) To the women, my request is that they should not be alarmed by this appeal but should welcome it.
('17', 85, 3, 23, 183216) It contains the key to their protection and their honour.
('17', 85, 4, 24, 183274) There are 600 villages in Kheda district.
('17', 85, 4, 25, 183316) Every village has on an average a population of over 1,000. If every village gave at least
('17', 86, 0, 1, 183407) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 87
('17', 86, 1, 2, 183446) twenty men, Kheda district would be able to raise an army of 12,000 men.
('17', 86, 1, 3, 183519) The population of the whole district is seven lakhs and this number will then work out at 1.7 per cent, a rate which is lower than the death rate.
('17', 86, 1, 4, 183666) If we are not prepared to make even this sacrifice for the Empire, for the sake of swaraj, no wonder that we should be regarded unworthy of it.
('17', 86, 1, 5, 183810) If every village gives at least twenty men, on their return from the war they will be the living bulwarks of their village.
('17', 86, 1, 6, 183934) If they fall on the battle field, they will immortalize themselves, their village and their country, and twenty fresh men will follow their example and offer themselves for national defence.
('17', 86, 1, 7, 184125) If we mean to do this, we have no time to lose.
('17', 86, 1, 8, 184173) I desire that the fittest and the strongest in every village should be selected and their names forwarded.
('17', 86, 1, 9, 184280) I ask this of you, brothers and sisters.
('17', 86, 1, 10, 184321) To explain things to you and to answer the many questions that may be raised, meetings will be held in important villages.
('17', 86, 1, 11, 184444) Volunteers will also go round.
('17', 86, 1, 12, 184475) Messrs Vallabhbhai Jhaverbhai Patel, Barrister at law, Krishnalal Narasilal Desai, M.A.LL.B., Indulal Kanhaiyalal Yagnik, B.A.LL.B., Hariprasad Pitambardas Mehta, Manager of the Hitechchhu Press, Pragji Khandubhai Desai, Mohanlal Kameshwar Pandya, B.Ag., Ganesh Vasudeo Mavlankar, M.A.LL.B., Kalidsas Jashkaran Zaveri, B.A.LL.B., Fulchand Bapuji Shah, Gokuldas B. ('17', 87, 1, 2, 185060) 68. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('17', 87, 2, 3, 185088) [NADIAD, Before June 23, 1918] 1
('17', 87, 3, 4, 185121) As for my offer you know that, in my letter to Maffey, 2 I have said I should kill; neither friend nor foe.
('17', 87, 3, 5, 185229) Regarding those who want to fight but will not, either out of cowardice or spite against the British, what is my duty?
('17', 87, 3, 6, 185348) Must I not say,”If you can follow my path, so much the better, but if you cannot, you ought to give up cowardice or spite and fight.
('17', 87, 3, 7, 185481) You cannot teach ahimsa to a man who cannot kill.
('17', 87, 3, 8, 185531) You cannot make a dumb man appreciate the beauty and the merit of silence.
('17', 87, 3, 9, 185606) 3 Although I know that silence is most excellent, I do not hesitate to take means that would enable the dumb man to regain his speech.
('17', 87, 3, 10, 185741) I do not believe in any Government, —but Parliamentary Government is perhaps better than capricious rule.
('17', 87, 3, 11, 185847) I think it will be clear to you that I shall best spread the gospel of ahimsa, or satyagraha by asking the himsak (militant) men to work out their himsa in the least offensive manner, and may succeed, in the very act, in making them realize the better worth of ahinsa.
('17', 87, 3, 12, 186116) If I have not made the position clear, you should try if you can to come down.
('17', 87, 4, 13, 186195) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('17', 87, 4, 14, 186241) Courtesy: Narayan Desai

('17', 87, 6, 17, 186462) It seems dangerously near the argument that the Indian who has forgotten altogether the blood lust might be encouraged to learn it again first and then repudiate it afterwards of his own account.” 4 Andrews wrote back: “At the same time I do agree with you entirely that it is a free India choosing her own path which can give the world the highest example of ahinsa, not the present subjected India.
('17', 87, 6, 18, 186863) But even then— cannot you conceive on that very freedom being won by moral force only, not by the creation of a standing army to meet the army of occupation.”

('17', 92, 1, 2, 193774) tapascharya.
('17', 92, 1, 3, 193787) Even if we find in thousands of instances that water is made up of two parts of hydrogen and one part of oxygen, it cannot be said finally that this is its composition.
('17', 92, 1, 4, 193956) The conclusion is only an inference.
('17', 92, 1, 5, 193993) If, however, I take two parts of hydrogen and one part of oxygen and combine them to produce water, that would be definitive knowledge.
('17', 92, 1, 6, 194129) It is knowledge verified in experience.
('17', 92, 1, 7, 194169) Even if water can be made in any other manner, I have definitely shown with one experiment that it can be made by compounding [hydrogen and oxygen] in this way.
('17', 92, 1, 8, 194330) We frequently act on inference but come to no harm.
('17', 92, 1, 9, 194382) In matters of moment, we realize the inadequacy of inference and the supreme worth of direct experience.
('17', 92, 1, 10, 194487) It is for this reason that observance of yama niyama, etc., is essential.
('17', 92, 1, 11, 194561) This is the only way to knowledge based on experience.

('17', 92, 4, 14, 194681) 74. LETTER TO MOHANDAS NAGJI
('17', 92, 5, 15, 194710) [NADIAD,] June 23, 1918 My view about remarriage is that it would be proper for a man or a woman not to marry again after the death of the partner.
('17', 92, 5, 16, 194858) The basis of Hinduism is self control.
('17', 92, 5, 17, 194897) Of course, self control is enjoined in every religion, but Hinduism has attached to it especial importance.
('17', 92, 5, 18, 195005) In such a religion, remarriage can be only an exception.
('17', 92, 5, 19, 195062) These views of mine notwithstanding, so long as the practice of child marriage continues and so long as men are free to marry as often as they choose, we should not stop a girl, who has become a widow while yet a child, from remarrying if she so desires, but should respect her wishes.
('17', 92, 5, 20, 195348) I would not, however, put it into the head of even a child widow to remarry, though, if she did marry again, I would not regard her action as sinful.
('17', 92, 6, 21, 195498) Blessings from
('17', 92, 7, 22, 195513) MOHANDAS GANDHI [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('17', 93, 3, 7, 195878) This is not owing to external difficulties; there are many internal problems.

('17', 93, 3, 9, 196040) Enough has been done by way of the former.
('17', 93, 3, 10, 196083) It is necessary now to stop it and do something constructive.
('17', 93, 3, 11, 196145) The League’s capacity for service will not grow to its best unless this is done.
('17', 93, 3, 12, 196226) Join the League by all means, if you want to do so merely that you may be able to guide it towards the path of service.
('17', 93, 3, 13, 196346) But the members of the League will not welcome your entry if you fight with one and all.

('17', 94, 5, 12, 197772) 77. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD
('17', 94, 6, 13, 197796) June 24, 1918
('17', 94, 7, 14, 197810) You all know the purpose of this meeting.
('17', 94, 7, 15, 197852) You also know that Bombay has protested against the insulting behaviour of His Excellency the Governor towards members of the Home Rule League at the War Conference.
('17', 94, 7, 16, 198018) At the Bombay meeting, too, I was in the chair and, having expressed my views there, I shall not take much of your time.
('17', 94, 7, 17, 198139) This meeting is for two things: one, to support the action of Bombay and, two, to explain the position to those who do not read newspapers and, since even newspaper reports are often fragmentary and incorrect, to place the facts before newspaper readers as well.
('17', 94, 7, 18, 198402) This is what today’s meeting is for.

('17', 108, 7, 11, 230276) MY DEAR ESTHER, I had no time to write to you ere this.

('17', 110, 4, 12, 234527) Lord Chelmsford was quite pleased when I spoke at the Conference 1 in Urdu.

('17', 110, 5, 27, 235694) We who must continually elect and select may not always follow the times spirit; we may, we should, anticipate the future.

('17', 111, 6, 25, 237541) This might reveal to you some key which will enable you to impart more knowledge with less effort.

('17', 111, 6, 27, 237718) That will tax the memory less.
('17', 111, 6, 28, 237749) I have told you to consider what arrangements can be made for the Hindi speaking people whom we want to send there to learn Tamil.

('17', 113, 1, 2, 239691) 89. LETTER TO DR.
('17', 113, 1, 3, 239709) PRANJIVAN MEHTA
('17', 113, 2, 4, 239725) [NADIAD,] July 2, 1918
('17', 113, 3, 5, 239748) BHAISHRI PRANJIVAN, I have not been able to write to you for some time past.
('17', 113, 3, 6, 239825) I carry on with the money I get here and do not go out to beg.
('17', 113, 3, 7, 239888) I am in utmost need of money at present.
('17', 113, 3, 8, 239929) Construction work is in progress.
('17', 113, 3, 9, 239963) I have already spent forty thousand rupees on it.
('17', 113, 3, 10, 240013) Sixty thousand more will be required.
('17', 113, 3, 11, 240051) I have to provide accommodation for at least a hundred and fifty persons and install sixteen looms.
('17', 113, 3, 12, 240151) Work on cloth is expanding rapidly.
('17', 113, 3, 13, 240187) After the Ahmedabad strike, I have come into contact with a number of weavers.
('17', 113, 3, 14, 240266) About three hundred women have started working the rentia.
('17', 113, 3, 15, 240325) I believe we shall get, before long, about two maunds of handspun yarn every day.
('17', 113, 3, 16, 240407) These women were unemployed.
('17', 113, 3, 17, 240436) They are employed now.
('17', 113, 3, 18, 240459) About thirty weavers outside have also found employment.
('17', 113, 3, 19, 240516) Some of these are Dheds.
('17', 113, 3, 20, 240541) They used to labour for wages but now they have found an independent vocation.
('17', 113, 3, 21, 240620) I think this is a very important activity.
('17', 113, 3, 22, 240663) For it, too, I need more money.
('17', 113, 3, 23, 240695) I reckon I shall have to invest ten thousand rupees in this.
('17', 113, 3, 24, 240756) The National School activity is, I think, equally important.
('17', 113, 3, 25, 240817) It is my impression that even at present the boys of this school compare favourably with other boys at the same stage of education.
('17', 113, 3, 26, 240949) The qualities of fearlessness, etc., which they have acquired are there for all to see.
('17', 113, 3, 27, 241037) I can see that the school will require one thousand rupees every month, though just now the expenses are lower.
('17', 113, 3, 28, 241149) If I were to look after both these activities myself I am sure I could expand them considerably.
('17', 113, 3, 29, 241246) But I cannot manage that.
('17', 113, 3, 30, 241272) Even as it is, I find that good progress is being made in both.
('17', 113, 3, 31, 241336) I have to tax you for a large amount just now and should like you, as a permanent arrangement, to make good any deficit that may remain after contributions from elsewhere have been received.
('17', 113, 3, 32, 241527) Please give, if you can, what I have asked for, so that my anxieties may end.
('17', 113, 3, 33, 241605) If you disapprove of my work, I certainly cannot ask you for anything.
('17', 113, 3, 34, 241676) But do not stint if you think that it is along the right lines.
('17', 113, 3, 35, 241740) You must be watching my work of recruitment.
('17', 113, 3, 36, 241785) Of all my activities, I regard this as the most difficult and the most important.
('17', 113, 3, 37, 241867) If I succeed in it, genuine swaraj is assured.
('17', 113, 4, 38, 241914) Vendemataram from MOHANDAS [From Gujarati] Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV

('17', 115, 1, 2, 243430) 92. LETTER TO ANNIE BESANT
('17', 115, 2, 3, 243457) [NADIAD,] July 4, 1918
('17', 115, 3, 4, 243480) I search New India in vain for an emphatic declaration from you in favour of unconditional recruiting.
('17', 115, 3, 5, 243583) Surely it must be plain that, if every Home Rule Leaguer became an active recruiting depot, we would ensure the passing of the Congress League Scheme with only such modifications as we may agree to.
('17', 115, 3, 6, 243782) I think this is the time when we must give the people [a] lead and not await their opinion.
('17', 115, 3, 7, 243874) I would like to see you with your old fire growing the stronger in face of opposition.
('17', 115, 3, 8, 243961) If we supplied recruits, we should dictate terms.
('17', 115, 3, 9, 244011) But if we wait for the terms, the War may close, India may remain without a real military training and we should be face to face with a military dictatorship.
('17', 115, 3, 10, 244170) This is taking the most selfish view of the situation and self interest suggests the course I have ventured to place before the country as the only effective course.
('17', 115, 3, 11, 244336) I know you will not consider my letter as a presumption.
('17', 115, 3, 12, 244393) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('17', 119, 8, 18, 250609) [NADIAD,] July 6, 1918
('17', 119, 9, 19, 250632) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letters.
('17', 119, 9, 20, 250670) 2 I prize them.
('17', 119, 9, 21, 250686) They give me only partial consolation.
('17', 119, 9, 22, 250725) My difficulties are deeper than you have put them.
('17', 119, 9, 23, 250776) All you raise I can answer.
('17', 119, 9, 24, 250804) I must attempt in this letter to reduce my own to writing.
('17', 119, 9, 25, 250863) They just now possess me to the exclusion of everything else.
('17', 119, 9, 26, 250925) All the other things I seem to be doing purely mechanically.
('17', 119, 9, 27, 250986) This hard thinking has told upon my physical system.
('17', 119, 9, 28, 251039) I hardly want to talk to anybody.

('17', 119, 9, 30, 251144) I am therefore falling back upon dictation to see
('17', 119, 10, 31, 251194) 1 Father of Raojibhai Patel 2 Vide “Letter to C. F. Andrews”, before 23 6 1918.
('17', 120, 0, 1, 251274) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 121
('17', 120, 1, 2, 251315) whether I can clearly express them.
('17', 120, 1, 3, 251351) I have not yet reached the bottom of my difficulties, much less have I solved them.
('17', 120, 1, 4, 251435) The solution is not likely to affect my immediate work.
('17', 120, 1, 5, 251491) But of the failure I can now say nothing.
('17', 120, 1, 6, 251533) If my life is spared I must reach the secret somehow.
('17', 120, 1, 7, 251587) You say:”Indians as a race did repudiate it, bloodlust, with full consciousness in days gone by and deliberately took their choice to stand on the side of humanity.” Is this historically true?
('17', 120, 1, 8, 251780) I see no sign of it either in the Mahabharata or the Ramayana, not even in my favourite Tulsidas which is much superior in spirituality to Valmiki 1. I am not now thinking of these works in their spiritual meanings.
('17', 120, 1, 9, 251996) The incarnations are described as certainly bloodthirsty, revengeful and merciless to the enemy.
('17', 120, 1, 10, 252093) They have been credited with having resorted to tricks also for the sake of overcoming the enemy.
('17', 120, 1, 11, 252191) The battles are described with no less zest than now, and the warriors are equipped with weapons of destruction such as could be possibly conceived by the human imagination.
('17', 120, 1, 12, 252365) The finest hymn composed by Tulsidas in praise of Rama gives the first place to his ability to strike down the enemy.
('17', 120, 1, 13, 252483) Then take the Mohamedan period.
('17', 120, 1, 14, 252515) The Hindus were not less eager than the Mahomedans to fight.
('17', 120, 1, 15, 252576) They were simply disorganized, physically weakened and torn by internal dissensions.
('17', 120, 1, 16, 252661) The code of Manu prescribes no such renunciation that you impute to the race.
('17', 120, 1, 17, 252739) Buddhism, conceived as a doctrine of universal forbearance, signally failed, and, if the legends are true, the great Shankaracharya did not hesitate to use unspeakable cruelty in banishing Buddhism out of India.
('17', 120, 1, 18, 252951) And he succeeded !
('17', 120, 1, 19, 252970) Then the English period.
('17', 120, 1, 20, 252995) There has been compulsory renunciation of arms but not the desire to kill.
('17', 120, 1, 21, 253070) Even ‘among the Jains the doctrine has signally failed.
('17', 120, 1, 22, 253126) They have a superstitious horror of blood (shed), but they have as little regard for the life of the enemy as an European.
('17', 120, 1, 23, 253249) What I mean to say is that they would rejoice equally with anybody on earth over the destruction of the enemy.
('17', 120, 1, 24, 253360) All then that can be said of India is that individuals have made serious attempts, with greater success than elsewhere, to popularize the doctrine.
('17', 120, 1, 25, 253508) But there is no warrant for the belief that it has taken deep root among the people.
('17', 120, 1, 26, 253593) You say further:”My point is that it has become an unconscious instinct, which can be awakened any time as you yourself have shown.” I wish it was true.
('17', 120, 1, 27, 253746) But I see that I have shown nothing of the kind.
('17', 120, 1, 28, 253795) When friends told me here that passive resistance was taken up
('17', 120, 2, 29, 253858) 1 The author of the original Ramayana in Sanskrit
('17', 121, 0, 1, 253908) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 121, 1, 2, 253950) by the people as a weapon of the weak, I laughed at the libel, as I called it then.
('17', 121, 1, 3, 254034) But they were right and I was wrong.
('17', 121, 1, 4, 254071) With me alone and a few other co workers it came out of our strength and was described as satyagraha, but with the majority it was purely and simply passive resistance what they resorted to, because they were too weak to undertake methods of violence.
('17', 121, 1, 5, 254323) This discovery was forced on me repeatedly in Kaira.
('17', 121, 1, 6, 254376) The people here, being comparatively freer, talked to me without reserve, and told me plainly that they took up my remedy because they were not strong enough to take up the other, which they undoubtedly held to be far more manly than mine.
('17', 121, 1, 7, 254616) I fear that the people whether in Champaran or in Kaira would not fearlessly walk to the gallows, or stand a shower of bullets and yet say, in one case, ‘we will not pay the revenue’, and in the other, ‘we will not work for you’.
('17', 121, 1, 8, 254846) They have it not in them.
('17', 121, 1, 9, 254872) And I contend that they will not regain the fearless spirit until they have received the training to defend themselves.
('17', 121, 1, 10, 254992) Ahimsa was preached to man when he was in full vigour of life and able to look his adversaries straight in the face.
('17', 121, 1, 11, 255109) It seems to me that full development of body force is a sine qua non of full appreciation and assimilation of ahimsa.
('17', 121, 2, 12, 255227) I do agree with you that India with her moral force could hold back from her shores any combination of armies from the West or the East or the North or the South.
('17', 121, 2, 13, 255390) The question is, how can she cultivate this moral force?
('17', 121, 2, 14, 255447) Will she have to be strong in body before she can understand even the first principles of this moral force?
('17', 121, 2, 15, 255555) This is how millions blashpheme the Lord of the Universe every morning before sunrise.
('17', 121, 3, 16, 255642) “I am changeless Brahma, not a collection of the five elements—earth, etc.—I am that Brahma whom I recall every morning as the spirit residing in the innermost sanctuary of my heart, by whose grace the whole speech is adorned, and whom the Vedas have described as ‘Neti, neti’.
('17', 121, 4, 17, 255920) I say we blaspheme the Lord of the Universe in reciting the above verse because it is a parrot recitation without any consideration of its grand significance.
('17', 121, 4, 18, 256079) One Indian realizing in himself all that the verse means is enough to repel the mightiest army that can approach the shores of India.
('17', 121, 4, 19, 256213) But it is not in us today and it will not come until there is an atmosphere of freedom and fearlessness on the soil.
('17', 121, 4, 20, 256330) How to produce that atmosphere?
('17', 121, 4, 21, 256362) Not without the majority of the inhabitants feeling that they are well able to protect themselves from the violence
('17', 122, 0, 1, 256478) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 123
('17', 122, 1, 2, 256519) of man or beast.
('17', 122, 1, 3, 256536) Now I think I can state my difficulty.
('17', 122, 1, 4, 256575) It is clear that before I can give a child an idea of moksha, I must let it grow into full manhood.
('17', 122, 1, 5, 256675) I must allow it to a certain extent to be even attached to the body, and then when it has understood the body and so the world around it, may I easily demonstrate the transitory nature of the body and the world, and make it feel that the body is given not for the indulgence of self but for its liberation.
('17', 122, 1, 6, 256982) Even so must I wait for instilling into any mind the doctrine of ahimsa, i.e., perfect love, when it has grown to maturity by having its full play through a vigorous body.
('17', 122, 1, 7, 257154) My difficulty now arises in the practical application of the idea.
('17', 122, 1, 8, 257221) What is the meaning of having a vigorous body?
('17', 122, 1, 9, 257268) How far should India have to go in for a training in arms bearing?
('17', 122, 1, 10, 257335) Must every individual go through the practice or is it enough that a free atmosphere is created and the people will, without having to bear arms, etc., imbibe the necessary personal courage from their surroundings?
('17', 122, 1, 11, 257550) I believe that the last is the correct view, and, therefore, I am absolutely right as things are in calling upon every Indian to join the army, always telling him at the same time that he is doing so not for the lust of blood, but for the sake of learning not to fear death.
('17', 122, 1, 12, 257825) Look at this from Sir Henry Vane.
('17', 122, 1, 13, 257859) I copy it from Morley’s Recollections (Vol. II):
('17', 122, 2, 14, 257908) Death holds a high place in the policy of great communities of the world....
('17', 122, 2, 15, 257985) It is the part of a valiant and generous mind to prefer some thing before life, as things for which a man should not doubt, nor fear to die....
('17', 122, 2, 16, 258129) True natural wisdom pursueth the learning and practice old dying well, as the very end of life, and indeed he hath not spent his life ill that hath learnt to die well.
('17', 122, 2, 17, 258297) It is the chiefest thing and duty of life.
('17', 122, 2, 18, 258340) The knowledge of dying is the knowledge of liberty, the state of true freedom, the way to fear nothing, to live well, contentedly, and peaceable....
('17', 122, 2, 19, 258489) It is a good time to die when to live is rather a burden than a blessing, and there is more ill in life than good.
('17', 122, 3, 20, 258604) “When his hour came, Vane’s actual carriage on Tower Hill was as noble and resolute as his words” is Morley’s commentary.
('17', 122, 3, 21, 258726) There is not a single recruiting speech in which I have not laid the greatest stress upon this part of a warrior’s duty.
('17', 122, 3, 22, 258847) There is no speech in which I have yet said,”Let us go to kill the Germans.” My refrain is,”Let us go and die for the sake of India and the Empire”, and I feel that, supposing that the response to my call is overwhelming and we all go to France and turn the scales against the Germans, India will then have a claim to be heard and she may then dictate a peace that will last.
('17', 122, 3, 23, 259223) Suppose further that I have succeeded in raising an army of fearless
('17', 123, 0, 1, 259292) 124 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 123, 1, 2, 259334) men, they fill the trenches and with hearts of love lay down their guns and challenge the Germans to shoot them—their fellow men—I say that even the German heart will melt.
('17', 123, 1, 3, 259507) I refuse to credit it with exclusive fiendishness.
('17', 123, 1, 4, 259558) So it comes to this, that under exceptional circumstances, war may have to be resorted to as a necessary evil, even as the body is.
('17', 123, 1, 5, 259690) If the motive is right, it may be turned to the profit of mankind and that an ahimsaist may not stand aside and look on with indifference but must make his choice and actively co operate or actively resist.
('17', 123, 1, 6, 259897) Your fear about my being engrossed in the political strife and intrigues may be entirely set aside.

('17', 128, 5, 23, 268798) 109. SPEECH AT KARAMSAD 1
('17', 128, 6, 24, 268824) July 14, 1918
('17', 128, 7, 25, 268838) [Gandhiji] said at the outset that he was there to give them an unpalatable dose and he hoped that they would not turn away from it all at once, bearing in mind that one of the principal characteristics of a self governing and liberty loving people was to give ear to all counsel and to choose one that appealed to them most.
('17', 128, 7, 26, 269164) What, he asked them, was the meaning of swarajya?
('17', 128, 7, 27, 269214) Our villages are no better than dung hills; we cannot defend ourselves and our families against robbers or wild beasts; mukhis and rawanias coerce and oppress us as they will; we have no arms and we do not know the use of arms.
('17', 128, 7, 28, 269442) Is this swarajya?
('17', 128, 7, 29, 269460) And yet, this is the natural order throughout India.
('17', 128, 7, 30, 269513) Imagine the tidiness and the atmosphere of quiet and healthy independence of an English village
('17', 128, 8, 31, 269609) 1 This was Gandhiji’s third speech in the recruiting campaign delivered in Karamsad, a village in the Anand taluka of Kheda district.
('17', 129, 0, 1, 269743) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 129, 1, 2, 269785) and think how miserably an Indian village compares with it.
('17', 129, 1, 3, 269845) It is because every Englishman can stand on his legs and can defend his home and his village against any invader that the English village appears so incomparably superior to ours.
('17', 129, 2, 4, 270025) The first essential of swarajya is, thus, the power of self protection.
('17', 129, 2, 5, 270097) I am fit for swarajya only when I am able to defend myself and to shed my blood for my country, and India could be said to be living only if five lakhs of men lay down their lives for her.
('17', 129, 2, 6, 270286) A seed must lose itself in earth in order that numerous seeds may spring up from it.
('17', 129, 2, 7, 270371) Even so, from the ashes of the thousands dying for India, will spring up a living India.
('17', 129, 2, 8, 270460) We Indians visit temples every morning and evening and pay our obeisance to gods —gods who, we say, descend on earth to protect the weak and succour the oppressed, when virtue subsides and vice prevails.
('17', 129, 2, 9, 270664) It then ill becomes us to go to these temples, if we have not the spirit and the capacity of self defence in us.
('17', 129, 2, 10, 270777) And what verily did our Ramachandra and Krishna d?
('17', 129, 2, 11, 270828) They modelled heroes out of common clay and equipped them for self defence.
('17', 129, 2, 12, 270904) The golden opportunity for acquiring the power of self defence has come to us and it behoves us to seize it and profit by it.
('17', 129, 2, 13, 271030) An Empire that has been defending India and of which India aspires to be the equal partner is in great peril and it ill befits India to stand aloof at the hour of its destiny.
('17', 129, 2, 14, 271206) The argument that a Government that had behaved unsympathetically towards us does not deserve any help is idle, because helping the Government means nothing but helping ourselves.
('17', 129, 2, 15, 271386) And India too is under grave stress.
('17', 129, 2, 16, 271423) India would be nowhere without Englishmen.
('17', 129, 2, 17, 271466) If the British do not win, whom shall we go to for claiming equal partnership?
('17', 129, 2, 18, 271545) Shall we go to the victorious German, or the Turk or the Afghan for it?
('17', 129, 2, 19, 271617) We shall have no right to do so; the victorious nation will set its mind on imposing taxes, on repressing, harassing and tyrannising over the vanquished.
('17', 129, 2, 20, 271771) Only after making its position secure will it listen to our demands, whereas the liberty loving English will surely yield, when they have seen that we have laid down our lives for them.
('17', 129, 2, 21, 271957) The thought that our hearths, our homes, our fields and cattle will go to rack and ruin if we all go to the war, need not stop us.
('17', 129, 2, 22, 272088) Our old men and women will take care of these, as they naturally must, and it will be a great training for them.
('17', 129, 2, 23, 272201) One feeling and one only should be uppermost in the mind of each of us: No one dare invade my country; if he does, he dare take nothing out of it, excepting my dead body fallen in defence thereof.
('17', 130, 0, 1, 272398) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 131
('17', 130, 1, 2, 272439) Towards the conclusion, he reiterated that enlistment was the surest and the straight way to self government and he exhorted the brave people of Karamsad, who had acquitted themselves so splendidly during the Kaira campaign, to send at least a hundred men to the war.

('17', 130, 2, 4, 272739) 110. LETTER TO HANUMANTRAO

('17', 133, 1, 7, 280183) I would certainly, in as courteous terms as possible but equally emphatic, say that these interests will be held subservient to those of India as a whole and that, therefore, they are certainly in jeopardy in so far as they may be inconsistent with the general advance of India.

('17', 139, 1, 18, 293378) It is my request to them to read it carefully.
('17', 139, 1, 19, 293425) It is up to the wise man to sketch out the right line of action in the light of existing circumstances.
('17', 139, 1, 20, 293529) If it is our intention to break off our connection with the British, to be sure we must not go to their help.
('17', 139, 1, 21, 293639) Very few come out with the opinion that we do want to break this tie.
('17', 139, 1, 22, 293709) It is plain enough to everyone that even those who are for breaking it just cannot do so at the present moment.
('17', 139, 1, 23, 293821) Be that as it may, today our salvation lies in helping the British.
('17', 139, 1, 24, 293889) To help them is to help ourselves.
('17', 139, 1, 25, 293924) When the interests of the two lie in the same direction, it would be the very height of recklessness for either side to keep thinking of the other’s faults and refuse to go to its help.
('17', 139, 1, 26, 294110) If a raid were to descend on an enemy of ours in the village in which we are living, and if it threatened the whole village, we would forget our enmity and run to the succour of that enemy and beat back the raiders.
('17', 139, 1, 27, 294326) The same holds true in this war today.
('17', 139, 1, 28, 294365) To rise against the common danger is not only expediency but our duty as well.
('17', 139, 1, 29, 294444) Another objection that has been raised is: what kind of a dharma is it to send
('17', 140, 0, 1, 294523) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 141
('17', 140, 1, 2, 294564) the best of our men to the war and get them killed?
('17', 140, 1, 3, 294616) This way, all those who are working for swaraj may be killed; how would we win swaraj, then?
('17', 140, 1, 4, 294709) I would have branded this objection as ridiculous had it not been raised by men considered intelligent.
('17', 140, 1, 5, 294813) It is clear that, if India could boast of only five lakhs of men demanding swaraj, we do not deserve it.
('17', 140, 1, 6, 294918) But those who raise the objection mean to say that, whatever be the number of such men, the discerning few who carry on an agitation for swaraj number even less than five lakhs.
('17', 140, 1, 7, 295096) This is true enough.
('17', 140, 1, 8, 295117) Only, one thing is overlooked.
('17', 140, 1, 9, 295148) In preparing five lakhs of men who would be willing to fight to death, we shall have made fifty lakhs familiar with”war”,”swaraj”, etc.
('17', 140, 1, 10, 295284) We want to train five lakhs of free men.
('17', 140, 1, 11, 295325) They will be going with open eyes, of their own free will.
('17', 140, 1, 12, 295384) They will have taken counsel with their friends and relations; so the five lakhs who depart will have left behind them lakhs of other like minded people.
('17', 140, 1, 13, 295538) The plain fact is that we have lost the very capacity to fight and our valour has ebbed away.
('17', 140, 1, 14, 295632) We don’t have the strength even to protect our women folk.
('17', 140, 1, 15, 295691) Running after so called dharma, we forgot the claim of karma (duty).
('17', 140, 1, 16, 295760) We cannot stand up and fight even if there is a raid on our village in broad daylight.
('17', 140, 1, 17, 295847) That some eight men can pillage a population of a thousand with impunity can happen—in all the world—only in India.
('17', 140, 1, 18, 295963) Those in the villages are not so weak of body that they cannot beat back a mere eight.
('17', 140, 1, 19, 296050) But they stand in terrible fear of death.”Who would risk his life or limb by going out to fight?
('17', 140, 1, 20, 296147) Let them loot.
('17', 140, 1, 21, 296162) Leave it to the Government, whose job it is.” So they think and stay at home.
('17', 140, 1, 22, 296240) If the house of a neighbour is set on fire, if he is dishonoured and his property looted, that is no concern of these philosophers.
('17', 140, 1, 23, 296372) So long as this philosophy (darkness) has not perished, India will never know genuine peace.
('17', 140, 1, 24, 296465) That we should have to wait for the arrival of the police or the army before the village becomes safe is an intolerable situation for anyone with self respect.
('17', 140, 1, 25, 296625) An instant means of getting out of this predicament is ready at hand.
('17', 140, 1, 26, 296695) By enlisting in the army, we shall learn the use of weapons, shall have the spirit of patriotism kindled in us and shall be strong enough to defend our villages.
('17', 140, 1, 27, 296857) What about our wives and children if we go?
('17', 140, 1, 28, 296901) Everyone will naturally ask this question.
('17', 140, 1, 29, 296944) A recruit gets a fixed pay, in addition to food and clothing.
('17', 140, 1, 30, 297006) The minimum he gets is eighteen rupees and, according to merit, he rises in rank and scale.
('17', 140, 1, 31, 297098) If he is killed, the Government provides for the maintenance of his wife and children.
('17', 140, 1, 32, 297185) Those who return from the war get prizes and rewards.
('17', 140, 1, 33, 297239) It is my view
('17', 141, 0, 1, 297253) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 141, 1, 2, 297295) that, in the final analysis, soldiering is more paying than other professions.
('17', 141, 1, 3, 297374) “But such privileges are available only to the British; when do they ever come to us?”—I have heard people say.
('17', 141, 1, 4, 297486) To them I would say:”It is not likely that an army of five lakhs of intelligent men raised by our efforts would be denied equal rights with the British.
('17', 141, 1, 5, 297639) If they should be, that would only go to prove the incapacity of those five lakhs and of the leaders.
('17', 141, 1, 6, 297741) If an army of lakhs were raised, it would be a match for the British army and would win equal rights.
('17', 141, 1, 7, 297843) The very fact of our having raised an army of five lakhs will ensure the rights.” “You bid us to go and join the war unconditionally.
('17', 141, 1, 8, 297977) Another advises us to join on promise of equal rights.
('17', 141, 1, 9, 298032) A third says we are not bound to go—why bargain away your sleep and go out of your way to suffer sleeplessness?
('17', 141, 1, 10, 298144) We get confused by these three different counsels.
('17', 141, 1, 11, 298195) In such a predicament, it seems to us that discretion lies in not venturing beyond our depths.” My modest reply to this is:”Sentiments such as these bespeak a coward.
('17', 141, 1, 12, 298362) As time passes, different parties will come into being and a variety of opinions come to prevail.
('17', 141, 1, 13, 298460) You will have to take them all into consideration.
('17', 141, 1, 14, 298511) I would call it a betrayal of the swaraj to which we are all pledged if we refuse to participate in the war at any rate for the sake of that pledge.” In laying down conditions for joining the army, there is a danger that the occasion to join may slip past and the scheme for swaraj may be shelved.
('17', 141, 1, 15, 298809) The security of our nation, as also the certainty of swaraj, lies only in our joining up.
('17', 141, 1, 16, 298899) All the parties would agree that our enlisting in the army will in no way harm the cause of swaraj.
('17', 141, 1, 17, 298999) So, even on a comparative view, of the three the one counsel which advocates enlistment seems to me the best.
('17', 141, 1, 18, 299109) It is my hope that the comrades of Kheda district will be true to the call of duty and give their names to the volunteers or send them directly to the Ashram.
('17', 141, 1, 19, 299268) Women will also, I trust, help in this work.
('17', 141, 1, 20, 299313) I know that some of them dissuade their husbands and sons from enlisting.
('17', 141, 1, 21, 299387) If they reflect over the matter carefully enough, they will see that it is in their own interests, and certainly in the interests of the nation, that their husbands and sons should be brave men.
('17', 141, 2, 22, 299582) For ever your servant,
('17', 141, 3, 23, 299605) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Gujarati]

('17', 143, 6, 14, 301508) Such laying bare is necessary.
('17', 143, 6, 15, 301539) You have done right in writing to me.
('17', 143, 6, 16, 301577) I do not know what excesses are committed in recruitment.

('17', 143, 6, 20, 301822) Whatever the merits of the Scheme, however, I definitely hold that we should join the war.
('17', 143, 6, 21, 301913) We do not join it for the good of the British people; we want to go in for recruitment to do service to the country, and with an eye to its interests.
('17', 143, 6, 22, 302064) What shall I say about the miserable plight of India?
('17', 143, 6, 23, 302118) I see clearly that India cannot attain real swarajya.
('17', 143, 6, 24, 302172) I hold that by joining the army we can accomplish two things: we shall become brave and we shall learn something about the handling of arms; and we shall prove our worth by helping those with whom we wish to become partners.
('17', 143, 6, 25, 302397) Resisting their excesses and sharing their troubles— both these things are worth our doing.
('17', 143, 6, 26, 302489) I want you to think very calmly on this question.

('17', 144, 2, 3, 302848) [BOMBAY,] July 22, 1918
('17', 144, 3, 4, 302872) DEAR PUNJABHAI, What we have taken as dharma is not dharma.
('17', 144, 3, 5, 302932) We commit violence on a large scale in the name of non violence.
('17', 144, 3, 6, 302997) Fearing to shed blood, we torment people every day and dry up their blood.
('17', 144, 3, 7, 303072) A Bania 1 can never practise non violence.
('17', 144, 3, 8, 303115) Dharma does not consist in the outward renunciation practised by some Shravakas 2 or in feeding ants.
('17', 144, 3, 9, 303217) There can be no moksha or knowledge of the Self unless one renounces love of body.
('17', 144, 3, 10, 303300) If you are convinced of this and would discover the true road to moksha, I should advise you to identify yourself with the Ashram.
('17', 144, 3, 11, 303431) See the proposed construction work through and relieve Maganlal for the present.
('17', 144, 3, 12, 303512) You will need a servant.
('17', 144, 3, 13, 303537) Engage Parasaram.
('17', 144, 3, 14, 303555) I think it necessary that Maganlal be relieved.
('17', 144, 3, 15, 303603) Think over this carefully.
('17', 144, 3, 16, 303630) Undertake this only if the truth of this is as clear to you as daylight.
('17', 144, 3, 17, 303703) If it is, you will experience great peace in the Ashram.
('17', 144, 3, 18, 303760) Otherwise you will tire out soon.
('17', 144, 3, 19, 303794) You, Fulchand and Magan lal may discuss this among yourselves.
('17', 144, 3, 20, 303857) But, first, think over it yourself.

('17', 148, 5, 12, 310697) 129. LETTER T0 MAGANLAL GANDHI
('17', 148, 6, 13, 310728) NAVAGAM, Thursday [July 25, 1918]
('17', 148, 7, 14, 310762) MAGANLAL, You have been frightened by Raojibhai as he was by me.
('17', 148, 7, 15, 310827) He read too much into my words.
('17', 148, 7, 16, 310859) No, my ideals have not changed.
('17', 148, 7, 17, 310891) Despite my bitter experiences in India, my conviction remains the same as ever, that we have but little to learn from the West.
('17', 148, 7, 18, 311019) The evils I have seen here have made no change in my fundamental idea nor has this war.
('17', 148, 7, 19, 311107) The old idea has developed into something purer.
('17', 148, 7, 20, 311156) I have certainly not come to feel that we shall have to introduce Western civilization.
('17', 148, 7, 21, 311244) Nor do I suppose that we shall have to take to drinking and meat eating.
('17', 148, 7, 22, 311317) To be sure, I have felt, in all seriousness, that Swaminaryana 1 and Vallabha charya 2 have robbed us of our manliness.

('17', 151, 2, 9, 316843) 131. LETTER TO MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('17', 151, 3, 10, 316878) NADIAD, July 26, 1918
('17', 151, 4, 11, 316900) MY DEAR MILLIE, Sorabji is no more.
('17', 151, 4, 12, 316936) A cable has just arrived from Johannesburg giving the sad news.
('17', 151, 4, 13, 317000) There is nothing striking about this death.
('17', 151, 4, 14, 317044) Many like Sorabji have died before now.
('17', 151, 4, 15, 317084) But Sorabji has played such an important part in our lives that his sudden death comes like a rude shock.
('17', 151, 4, 16, 317190) It is only one’s faith in the indestructibility of energy and continuity of effort that reconciles one to activity in life.
('17', 151, 4, 17, 317314) An event is a shock when we do not understand its purpose and its seasonableness.
('17', 151, 4, 18, 317396) But is God’s plan, I suppose, there is nothing unseasonable and nothing purposeless.
('17', 151, 4, 19, 317481) 1 Do please write to his wife Kunverbai Sorabji Adajania, Surat.
('17', 151, 4, 20, 317546) I hope you received the few lines I sent you the other day at the back of Mr. Hasan Imam’s letter.
('17', 151, 4, 21, 317645) I am just now at a little village to avenge an insult offered to the villagers by a petty official.
('17', 151, 4, 22, 317745) In any other place, there would have been bloodshed over such an insult.
('17', 151, 4, 23, 317818) Here I may end with doing nothing.
('17', 151, 4, 24, 317853) I return to Nadiad today.
('17', 151, 4, 25, 317879) With love to you all, Yours, BHAI From the original: Gandhi Polak Correspondence.

('17', 152, 1, 2, 318111) 132. THE LATE SORABJI SHAPURJI ADAJANIA
('17', 152, 2, 3, 318151) [NADIAD,] July 27, 1918
('17', 152, 3, 4, 318175) THE EDITOR THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('17', 152, 4, 5, 318207) SIR, One of the best of Indians has just passed away in Johannesburg in the person of Sorabji Shapurji of Adajan, near Surat, at the age of thirty five.
('17', 152, 4, 6, 318360) And it is my mournful duty to pay a humble tribute to a fellow worker.
('17', 152, 4, 7, 318431) Mr. Sorabji, though known to a select company of friends, was unknown to the Indian public.
('17', 152, 4, 8, 318523) His work lay in South Africa.
('17', 152, 4, 9, 318553) He was a prince among passive resisters.
('17', 152, 4, 10, 318594) He joined their ranks when the struggle in South Africa was at its highest and when it had travelled beyond the confines of the Transvaal.
('17', 152, 4, 11, 318733) When he joined the struggle, I must confess, I had my doubts about his ability to go through it.
('17', 152, 4, 12, 318830) But he soon made his mark as a front rank satyagrahi.
('17', 152, 4, 13, 318884) Neither he nor I ever expected that he would have to undergo a series of imprisonments amounting in all to over 18 months with hard labour.
('17', 152, 4, 14, 319024) But he went through it manfully and cheerfully.
('17', 152, 4, 15, 319072) Mr. Sorabji was a small trader when he took to public life in South Africa.
('17', 152, 4, 16, 319148) He had a High School education.
('17', 152, 4, 17, 319180) But such as it was, he made the most effective use of it in the Transvaal.
('17', 152, 4, 18, 319255) During the struggle, he showed a steadfastness of purpose, probity of character, coolness of temper, courage in the midst of adverse circumstances, such as the best of us do not often show.
('17', 152, 4, 19, 319445) There were occasions when the stoutest hearts might have broken—Sorabji never wavered.
('17', 152, 4, 20, 319532) After the struggle was closed, it was my intention to send to England some one from among a band of young Indians who had proved themselves capable warriors.
('17', 152, 4, 21, 319690) A friend had offered the needful funds.
('17', 152, 4, 22, 319730) The choice, for a variety of reasons, fell upon Mr. Sorabji.
('17', 152, 4, 23, 319791) It was a question, whether having abandoned the life of a student for over eight years, he could take to it again.
('17', 152, 4, 24, 319906) He was, however, determined.
('17', 152, 4, 25, 319935) His ambition was to become a barrister and fit himself for fuller service.
('17', 152, 4, 26, 320010) To England he went.
('17', 152, 4, 27, 320030) He had come in close touch with Mr. Gokhale when he was in South Africa.
('17', 152, 4, 28, 320103) He came in closer touch in London.
('17', 152, 4, 29, 320138) And I knew that Mr. Gokhale had the highest opinion of Mr. Sorabji’s worth.
('17', 152, 4, 30, 320214) He had invited him to become a member of his
('17', 153, 0, 1, 320259) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 153, 1, 2, 320301) Society.
('17', 153, 1, 3, 320310) The deceased took an active part in all the leading movements among Indians in London.
('17', 153, 1, 4, 320397) He was for some time Secretary of the London Indian Society.
('17', 153, 1, 5, 320458) He was the first to join the Indian Ambulance Corps that was formed in London at the inauguration of the war and served at Netley, nursing the sick and the wounded.
('17', 153, 1, 6, 320623) After being called to the Bar, he proceeded to South Africa, where he intended to practise the profession and return to India after he had given a number of years to South Africa and found a substitute.
('17', 153, 1, 7, 320826) But alas!
('17', 153, 1, 8, 320836) fate has willed it otherwise and a career full of promise had to come to an abrupt end.
('17', 153, 1, 9, 320924) The deceased was only 35 when he died.
('17', 153, 1, 10, 320963) In all I have said above, I have hardly described the man in Sorabji.
('17', 153, 1, 11, 321033) He was faithful to a degree.
('17', 153, 1, 12, 321062) He was a true Parsee, because he was a true Indian.
('17', 153, 1, 13, 321114) He knew no distinctions of creed or caste.
('17', 153, 1, 14, 321157) Love of India was a passion with him, her service an article of faith.
('17', 153, 1, 15, 321228) He was indeed a rare man.
('17', 153, 1, 16, 321254) He leaves a young widow to mourn his death.
('17', 153, 1, 17, 321298) I am sure there are many friends of Sorabji to share her grief.
('17', 153, 2, 18, 321362) Yours, etc.,
('17', 153, 3, 19, 321375) M. K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 29 7 1918

('17', 168, 1, 2, 347386) 148. LETTER TO ADA WEST
('17', 168, 2, 3, 347410) [NADIAD,] July 31, 1918
('17', 168, 3, 4, 347434) MY DEAR DEVI, .
('17', 168, 3, 5, 347450) 1 What a tragedy this death of Sorabji !
('17', 168, 3, 6, 347491) I was feeling most comfortable about South Africa and hoping that now that Sorabji was there all would go well.
('17', 168, 3, 7, 347603) My hopes have come to nothing .
('17', 168, 4, 8, 347635) I do not know what you all think of my recruiting activity.
('17', 168, 4, 9, 347695) I am working all the time at it.
('17', 168, 4, 10, 347728) My argument is briefly this : India has lost the power to strike.
('17', 168, 4, 11, 347794) She must learn to strike before she can voluntarily renounce the power of striking.
('17', 168, 4, 12, 347878) She may never renounce.
('17', 168, 4, 13, 347902) Then she will be as bad as the West, or, better still, the modernists.
('17', 168, 4, 14, 347973) Today she is neither.
('17', 168, 4, 15, 347995) The ancients in India knew the art of warfare—the art of killing—and yet reduced the activity to a minimum and taught the world that it is better to refrain than to strike.
('17', 168, 4, 16, 348168) Today I find that everybody is desirous of killing but most are afraid of doing so or powerless to do so.
('17', 168, 4, 17, 348274) Whatever is to be the result I feel certain that the power must be restored to India.
('17', 168, 4, 18, 348360) The result may be carnage.
('17', 168, 4, 19, 348387) Then India must go through it.
('17', 168, 4, 20, 348418) Today’s condition is intolerable.
('17', 168, 5, 21, 348452) Yours, BHAI
('17', 168, 6, 22, 348464) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
