('17', 168, 7, 24, 348534) 149. SPEECH AT SURAT
('17', 168, 8, 25, 348555) August 1, 1918 I have not come to Surat today to make a speech, but went to Adajan to pay my respects and offer condolences to the wife of a personal friend of mine, Mr. Sorabji Shapurji, who was my co worker in South Africa during the satyagraha campaign and who has, as you must have read in the newspapers, passed away.
('17', 168, 8, 26, 348878) 3 Being, meanwhile, pressed to make a speech, I have this opportunity today.
('17', 168, 8, 27, 348955) As you know, swaraj has become a household word all over India.
('17', 168, 8, 28, 349019) Mr. Montagu’s 4
('17', 168, 9, 29, 349035) 1 Some words are omitted in the source.
('17', 168, 10, 30, 349075) 3 Vide “The Late sorabji Shapurji Adajania”, 27 7 1918.
('17', 168, 11, 31, 349131) 4 E. S. Montagu (1879 1924); Secretary of State for India, 1917 22 and co sponsor of Montagu Chelmsford Reforms, published on July 8, 1918.
('17', 169, 0, 1, 349271) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 169, 1, 2, 349313) scheme of political reforms has been published and people differ in their views on it.
('17', 169, 1, 3, 349400) Newspapers, too, have been expressing themselves on it.
('17', 169, 1, 4, 349456) The scheme is good in parts but also strange in some ways.
('17', 169, 1, 5, 349515) I have already expressed my views on it.
('17', 169, 1, 6, 349556) It is necessary that we press for improvements which we desire in it.
('17', 169, 1, 7, 349626) If we rest content with whatever is offered to us out of the many things we may have demanded, it would not seem that we were earnest in our demands.
('17', 169, 1, 8, 349776) My opinion is that in anything that we demand by way of swaraj, we should agitate to get it as a matter of right, staking our very lives on it, and, simultaneously, stand by the Government and help it.
('17', 169, 1, 9, 349978) In other words, in the war that is going on, we should send our men to France and Mesopotamia.
('17', 169, 1, 10, 350073) We are not entitled to demand swaraj till we come forward to enlist in the army.
('17', 169, 1, 11, 350154) It is futile to expect any results when we have not done our duty.
('17', 169, 1, 12, 350221) It is extremely difficult to mention this in a public speech in Gujarat, especially in Surat, for the citizens of Surat see nothing about which they have to think and come to conclusions.
('17', 169, 1, 13, 350409) It would seem from the attendance today that they had made up their mind on the subject.
('17', 169, 1, 14, 350498) The first duty of a people all too eager for swaraj is to listen attentively and courteously to what is said on occasions like the present and accept whatever appeals to them and reject the rest.
('17', 169, 1, 15, 350694) Till the people have learnt this, they will be unfit not only to enjoy swaraj but even to ask for it.
('17', 169, 1, 16, 350796) All the 30 crores cannot go and listen to speeches but they may read newspapers and accept from them whatever they think best.
('17', 169, 1, 17, 350923) I do not advocate a go slow policy in asking for swaraj; on the other hand, I am a staunch fighter in its cause.
('17', 169, 1, 18, 351036) We would have equal rights in the Empire; if so, we should rescue it from the threat to which it is now exposed and then alone shall we be considered fit for them.
('17', 169, 1, 19, 351200) There is a party which argues that the British Government should first concede our right to swaraj, grant equal rights in the army and in other matters, and then alone should we help it.
('17', 169, 1, 20, 351387) The party making this demand is not to be dismissed out of hand.
('17', 169, 1, 21, 351452) But the snag in this argument is that the Empire is not dependent on your help.
('17', 169, 1, 22, 351532) At present our relationship with it is that of an owner and his slave, or a king and his subjects.
('17', 169, 1, 23, 351631) It depends upon its own will whether it would change this relationship and make us its partners.
('17', 169, 1, 24, 351728) Assuming, therefore, that it is inclined to do nothing of the kind, how do you think we are to lay down our terms before it?
('17', 169, 1, 25, 351853) Some believe that, when its difficulties increase still further, it will accept all our conditions and we shall then come forward to help.
('17', 169, 1, 26, 351992) But in this we run a great risk.
('17', 169, 1, 27, 352025) We should rather wish that it never gets into such difficulty.
('17', 169, 1, 28, 352088) We have got the
('17', 170, 0, 1, 352104) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 171
('17', 170, 1, 2, 352144) opportunity we were looking for to help the Empire and we shall do well to avail ourselves of it fully.
('17', 170, 1, 3, 352248) I have been travelling all over India these days and I tell you, from what I have seen for myself, that India has altogether lost the capacity to fight.
('17', 170, 1, 4, 352401) It has not a particle of the courage it should have.
('17', 170, 1, 5, 352454) If even a tiger should make its appearance in a village, the people would not have the strength to go and kill it and so they petition the Collector to have it killed.
('17', 170, 1, 6, 352622) Nor do they have the strength to fight back dacoits, should any descend on the village.
('17', 170, 1, 7, 352710) Can a nation, whose citizens are incapable of self defence, enjoy swaraj?
('17', 170, 1, 8, 352784) Swaraj is not for lawyers and doctors but only for those who possess strength of arms.
('17', 170, 1, 9, 352871) How in a people who are incapable of defending their lives, their women and children, their cattle and their lands, ever enjoy swaraj?
('17', 170, 1, 10, 353006) This is no time to go into the question of how our people fell on such evil times and who is to blame for this state of affairs; what is necessary is to find a remedy.
('17', 170, 1, 11, 353174) When the people become physically fit and strong enough to wield the sword, swaraj will be theirs for the asking.
('17', 170, 1, 12, 353288) How can people who have lost their strength defend their religion?
('17', 170, 1, 13, 353355) From my experience during the last three months, I know that we are utterly timid.
('17', 170, 1, 14, 353438) People afraid of even a squirrel had much better think of improving their own condition than of getting swaraj.
('17', 170, 1, 15, 353550) Here we have an invaluable opportunity for getting back the capacity to fight which we have lost and we should not miss it.
('17', 170, 1, 16, 353674) If a people who do not know in what direction to look for a fort, do not know how to fire a gun, have no knowledge of the state of fortification on the border,—if they wish to know all this, they should certainly not miss this supreme opportunity which India has of supplying half a million men.
('17', 170, 1, 17, 353970) We should not believe, either, that in availing ourselves of this opportunity we are helping the Government; we should believe, rather, that we are using it to acquire the strength to fight and get training in doing so.
('17', 170, 1, 18, 354190) You will regret it afterwards if you miss this priceless opportunity.
('17', 170, 1, 19, 354260) Mr. Tilak 1 advises us not to take part in the war unconditionally.
('17', 170, 1, 20, 354328) I have greater reverence for Mr. Tilak than you have; in fact, one cannot show him enough reverence.
('17', 170, 1, 21, 354429) If, once half a million men had joined, they refused higher posts [to Indians], there would be revolts everywhere and rivers of blood would flow.
('17', 170, 1, 22, 354575) This is no time to pay attention to what Mr. Tilak says.
('17', 170, 1, 23, 354632) The very services we render will answer his doubts.
('17', 170, 1, 24, 354684) The half a million men whom we shall raise will go with love of swaraj in their hearts.
('17', 170, 1, 25, 354772) When they come back, they are bound to get swaraj.
('17', 170, 1, 26, 354823) If they have learnt military discipline, half a million others will be roused.
('17', 170, 1, 27, 354902) And so parents
('17', 170, 2, 28, 354917) 1 “Lokamanya” Bal Gangadhar Tilak (1856 1920); patriot, politician and scholar.
('17', 171, 0, 1, 354997) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 171, 1, 2, 355039) should be told that, in offering recruits, they show their love for the country.
('17', 171, 1, 3, 355120) This is what I do.
('17', 171, 1, 4, 355139) America helps with three hundred thousand [men] every month; if we refuse, that will cost us our rights.
('17', 171, 1, 5, 355244) I, therefore, entreat you again and again to ponder over what I have said today, for, if this thing [opportunity for military experience] which has offered itself to us slips away from our hands, there will be no possibility of our getting the other [swaraj].

('17', 172, 4, 13, 357481) You may not divide the legal profession from your other activities.
('17', 172, 4, 14, 357549) Have you not renounced the right to earn more than your needs including humble family needs!
('17', 172, 4, 15, 357642) You are a reformer at home as well as abroad.
('17', 172, 4, 16, 357688) Your life must influence the family life or it must stand separately as a protest against its orthodoxy and present day shortcomings.
('17', 172, 4, 17, 357822) I do not pretend to solve these riddles for you.

('17', 172, 5, 20, 357981) These shocks sometimes so shake me that I do not want to live on this earth.

('17', 174, 9, 18, 361162) I have observed that milk is no good when one is ill.

('17', 174, 9, 20, 361301) The diet for illness is fruit juice, green vegetables and things made of wheat but without ghee.

('17', 175, 4, 19, 362788) 154. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('17', 175, 5, 20, 362817) August 6, 1918
('17', 175, 6, 21, 362832) MY DEAR CHARLIE 2, I shall be good this time and not accuse you of crimes against the laws of God and man regarding health.
('17', 175, 6, 22, 362956) But there is no doubt that you need a curator euphemistically called a nurse.
('17', 175, 6, 23, 363034) And how I should like to occupy that post!
('17', 175, 6, 24, 363077) If you cannot have a nurselike me, who would make love to you but at the same time enforce strict obedi ence to doctor’s orders, you need a wife who would see that you had your food properly served, you never went out without an abdo minal bandage and who would not allow you to overworry yourself about bad news of the sickness of relatives.

('17', 184, 1, 2, 378176) 165. LETTER TO A FRIEND 1
('17', 184, 2, 3, 378202) August 9, 1918 2
('17', 184, 3, 4, 378219) If you read my book 3 again you will find the answers to many of your questions,—what fruits to take, for instance.
('17', 184, 3, 5, 378335) The question of the use of oils, etc., is a difficult one.
('17', 184, 3, 6, 378394) My experience is that not more than half an ounce [of these] should he taken.
('17', 184, 3, 7, 378472) We do not have olive oil in this country.
('17', 184, 3, 8, 378514) Sesame oil is good as a substitute but it is not quite as harmless.
('17', 184, 3, 9, 378582) Dates and peanuts are no doubt hard, but if they are made part of one’s diet they can be tolerated.
('17', 184, 3, 10, 378682) Of almonds very few should be taken.
('17', 184, 3, 11, 378719) It is not good to eat too many milk products.
('17', 184, 3, 12, 378765) One can subsist quite well on peanuts taken with guavas, etc.
('17', 184, 3, 13, 378827) Peanuts are no substitute for almonds.
('17', 184, 3, 14, 378866) Wheat is fruit in a way.
('17', 184, 3, 15, 378891) But the word”fruit” is used in a technical sense in my book and is precisely defined.
('17', 184, 3, 16, 378977) More will be found about vegetables than about fruits in my book.
('17', 184, 3, 17, 379043) But I see that vegetables are necessary in India.
('17', 184, 3, 18, 379093) Pulses are difficult to digest.
('17', 184, 3, 19, 379125) On further experience I have come to the conclusion that the best diet for India is wheat and vegetables.
('17', 184, 3, 20, 379231) Those who have to do much physical labour may well use pulses too.
('17', 184, 3, 21, 379298) From a religious point of view what I said about milk still stands.
('17', 184, 3, 22, 379366) But, from the point of view of health and under Indian conditions, giving up of milk seems an impossibility.
('17', 184, 3, 23, 379475) It is many years since I gave up milk and I am under a vow never to take it in this life.
('17', 184, 3, 24, 379565) But I cannot advise others to give up milk so long as I have not a substitute having the qualities of milk.
('17', 184, 3, 25, 379673) I had hoped that it would be possible to manage on sesame and peanuts, and it is in a way possible, but as compared with milk these are somewhat deficient.
('17', 184, 3, 26, 379829) My advice to you is that, if you are in good health, you may take in the normal way wheat, milk, rice, etc., and on ekadashi 4 days take such fruits as may be easily available.
('17', 184, 3, 27, 380006) You should fast when you feel indisposed and have a ten mile constitutional early in the morning every day.
('17', 184, 3, 28, 380114) One question is left unanswered.
('17', 184, 3, 29, 380147) It is quite the right thing to chew sesame seeds, etc., instead of taking the oil.
('17', 184, 3, 30, 380230) Eating more than two or three tolas of anything containing fat can be harmful.

('17', 185, 4, 8, 381003) 166. LETTER TO”THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('17', 185, 5, 9, 381038) NADIAD, August 10, 1918 TO THE EDITOR THE TIMES OF INDIA
('17', 185, 6, 10, 381095) SIR, Your report of my recruiting address to a Surat meeting shows how dangerous it is for a public man to deliver anything but a written speech.
('17', 185, 6, 11, 381241) My experiences of the reporting of my own speeches make my sympathy go out to Mr. Tilak and I certainly think that so long as reporting remains what it is in India, the safest thing is to challenge against them, and to accept their repudiation if they repudiate what is imputed to them.
('17', 185, 6, 12, 381528) And it is quite likely that Mr. Tilak has been unjustly gagged.
('17', 185, 6, 13, 381592) I hardly think that his gagging will improve recruiting in Maharashtra.
('17', 185, 6, 14, 381664) But I know that here in Gujarat my own position becomes difficult.
('17', 185, 6, 15, 381731) Many people will keep aloof simply as a protest against Mr. Tilak’s gag.
('17', 185, 6, 16, 381804) I hold no brief for him and I differ from his views and have told him that the conditions he requires are assured in the act of recruiting by men like him, and it hastens the grant of responsible government because it inspires confidence in us and gives us a power and strength which we do not possess today.
('17', 185, 6, 17, 382113) I can only hope that Government will reconsider their decision and remove the gag and thus also remove a serious obstacle in the path of recruiters.
('17', 185, 6, 18, 382262) I have, however, digressed from my main theme.
('17', 185, 6, 19, 382309) I wish to point out that I never said that those who ask for conditions should be”cast out from their party” nor did I lay stress on the help to the Empire.
('17', 185, 6, 20, 382466) On the contrary, after showing the differences between Mr. Tilak’s views and mine on the question of recruiting, I sympathized
('17', 186, 0, 1, 382593) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 187
('17', 186, 1, 2, 382633) with the audience in their dilemma in having to choose between the advice of a great distinguished and self sacrificing patriot like Mr. Tilak and mine.
('17', 186, 1, 3, 382786) I told them, however, that in their march towards responsible government, they could no longer be satisfied with the ipse dixit of leaders, no matter how great they might be, but that they would continuously have to weigh conflicting opinions and make their choice without in any way diminishing their regard for those leaders whose opinion they felt constrained to reject.
('17', 186, 1, 4, 383160) And I then told them how it was to their whole interest that they should join the army.
('17', 186, 1, 5, 383248) Then finally I put my facorite idea before the audience that if they wanted partnership with the British, the most becoming manner of effecting their purpose was to help them during the war.
('17', 186, 1, 6, 383439) Your correspondent, however, makes the helping of the Empire the central point of my speech.
('17', 186, 1, 7, 383532) I do not mind it.
('17', 186, 1, 8, 383550) But I do wish to emphasize the fact that if public men were to be judged in accordance with the newspaper reports of their speeches, in the majority of cases they would make a poor show.
('17', 186, 1, 9, 383737) Could you, a great journal, not insure the appearance of only accurate reports of public speeches in your columns?
('17', 186, 2, 10, 383852) M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 13 8 1918
('17', 186, 3, 11, 383895) 167. LETTER TO SIR SURENDRANATH BANERJEA
('17', 186, 4, 12, 383936) August 10, 1918
('17', 186, 5, 13, 383952) DEAR MR. BANERJEA 1, I have your telegram redirected from Ahmedabad where I am at present engaged in recruiting.
('17', 186, 5, 14, 384065) A visit to Calcutta means at least a week simply in going and coming back.
('17', 186, 5, 15, 384140) If I am to do my work at all satisfactorily, it is impossible for me to absent myself for such a long time, and at the present moment I dare not do so, for I have just heard from the government that they have acceded to my proposal to open a training depot in Gujarat and to form a Gujarat Company.
('17', 186, 5, 16, 384439) You will agree that I cannot leave this work.
('17', 186, 5, 17, 384485) But even if I could have come, I do not know that I could have rendered much assistance.
('17', 186, 5, 18, 384574) I hold strong, and probably peculiar, views
('17', 186, 6, 19, 384618) 1 1848 1925; one of the founders of the Indian National Congress and president of its Poona session of 1895; member of the Central Legislature
('17', 187, 0, 1, 384761) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 187, 1, 2, 384803) not shared by many of the leaders.
('17', 187, 1, 3, 384838) I implicitly believed that if we were to devote our attention exclusively to recruiting, we should gain full responsible government in a year’s time, if not sooner.
('17', 187, 1, 4, 385003) And instead of allowing our utterly ignorant countrymen to enlist nolens volens, we should get an army of Home Rulers who could be willing soldiers with the knowledge that they will be soldiering for the sake of the country.
('17', 187, 1, 5, 385228) I do, at the same time, believe that we should declare our opinion about the Montagu Chelmsford Scheme in unequivocal terms, we should fix the minimum of our demands and seek to en force them at all costs.
('17', 187, 1, 6, 385434) I consider the scheme to be good in its con ception.
('17', 187, 1, 7, 385487) It requires much modification.
('17', 187, 1, 8, 385518) We should have no difficulty in arriving at a unanimous conclusion.
('17', 187, 1, 9, 385586) I should like a party in the country that would be simply pledged to these two propositions, helping the Government on the one hand in the prosecution of the war, and enforcing the national demands on the other.
('17', 187, 1, 10, 385798) I do not believe that at a critical moment like this we should be satisfied with a patched up truce between the so called extremists and the so called moderates, each giving up a little in favour of the other.
('17', 187, 1, 11, 386008) I should like a clear enunciation of the policy of each group or party and naturally those who, by the intrinsic merit of their case and ceaseless agitation, make themselves a power in the land will carry the day before the House of Commons.

('17', 187, 5, 19, 386407) JEVONS 2, I have gone through your note.

('17', 188, 0, 1, 386988) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 189
('17', 188, 1, 2, 387028) England can afford.
('17', 188, 1, 3, 387048) India is poverty stricken.
('17', 188, 1, 4, 387075) A few have enriched themselves during the war.
('17', 188, 1, 5, 387122) But the masses?
('17', 188, 1, 6, 387138) I have come in the clo sest touch with them in Kaira and Champaran.
('17', 188, 1, 7, 387206) They have nothing.
('17', 188, 1, 8, 387225) In Kaira, the exorbitant demands of the Government have impoverished a people who were once rich and powerful.
('17', 188, 1, 9, 387336) In Champaran, the Planters have sucked the life blood out of the people.
('17', 188, 1, 10, 387409) You talk of a rise in the salt tax and send a shudder through my body.
('17', 188, 1, 11, 387480) If you knew what is happening to the people owing to the tax, you would say,”Whatever else is done, the tax must go today”.
('17', 188, 1, 12, 387604) It is not the heaviness of it which oppresses, but the monopoly has artificially raised the price of salt and today the poor find it most difflcult to procure salt at a reasonable price.
('17', 188, 1, 13, 387791) To them salt is as necessary as water and air.
('17', 188, 1, 14, 387838) As for the publication of the note, I think it need not be.
('17', 188, 1, 15, 387898) The Reformers have no faith in the Government and they feel that even now there is no honesty in their dealings with the people.
('17', 188, 1, 16, 388027) It is a curious phenomenon.
('17', 188, 1, 17, 388055) We do not trust you and yet we want you.
('17', 188, 1, 18, 388096) It shows a consciousness of the wrongs done to the people but their utter incapacity to remedy them.
('17', 188, 1, 19, 388197) Enslavement of the nation is thorough.
('17', 188, 1, 20, 388236) The Englishmen have not deliberately meant it but they could not have done more if they had.
('17', 188, 1, 21, 388329) I only cling to England because I belive her to be sound at heart and because I believe that India can deliver her mission to the world better through England.
('17', 188, 1, 22, 388489) If I had not this faith, I so thoroughly detest her act of disarming India, her haughty and exclusive military policy and her sacrifice of India’s riches and art on the altar of commercial greed, that I should declare myself a rebel.
('17', 188, 1, 23, 388723) I did not want to give you a long letter but my pen would not be checked.
('17', 188, 1, 24, 388797) Yours sincerely,

('17', 190, 3, 4, 390841) BHAISHRI PULCHAND, We had a very important discussion yesterday.

('17', 190, 3, 6, 391076) At present you are that person.

('17', 190, 3, 8, 391160) I kept my sense up to a quarter to six yesterday and added to my store of health.

('17', 190, 3, 10, 391317) Nor did I exercise self restraint in deciding what to eat; I ate ghens 1. If I had taken vegetable soup only, the painful result would certainly not have followed.
('17', 190, 3, 11, 391481) Today I am too weak to get up or walk.
('17', 190, 3, 12, 391520) I have almost to crawl to reach the lavatory and I have such griping pain there that I feel like screaming.
('17', 190, 3, 13, 391628) Though in such pain, I am very happy indeed.

('17', 190, 3, 15, 391751) I am sure my pain will subside at a quarter to six.
('17', 190, 3, 16, 391803) If I committed an error in eating, it is no excessive punishment to suffer for 24 hours.
('17', 190, 3, 17, 391892) And the punishment will be so short because I have fasted today.
('17', 190, 3, 18, 391957) Don’t worry on my account.
('17', 190, 3, 19, 391984) I believe by tomorrow I shall be completely free from the pain at any rate.
('17', 190, 3, 20, 392060) If I am not careless in diet, I shall be my normal self in three or four days.

('17', 192, 1, 2, 393411) 173. IMPERIAL CONFERENCE RESOLUTIONS
('17', 192, 2, 3, 393448) August 15, 1918
('17', 192, 3, 4, 393464) The following contribution of Mahatma Gandhi sent to Mr. G. A. Natesan for the current issue of The Indian Review has been sent to us for publication in advance: The Imperial Conference Resolution 1 on the status of our countrymen emigrating to the Colonies reads well on the surface but it is highly deceptive.
('17', 192, 3, 5, 393776) We need not consider it a great achievement that we can pass the same laws against the colonials that they may pass against us.
('17', 192, 3, 6, 393904) It is like a giant telling a dwarf that the latter is free to give blow for blow.
('17', 192, 3, 7, 393986) Who is to refuse permission and passports to the colonials desiring to enter India?
('17', 192, 3, 8, 394070) But Indians, no matter what their attainments are, are constantly being refused permission to enter the Colonies even for temporary periods.
('17', 192, 3, 9, 394211) South Africa legislation of emigration was purged of the racial taint by the passive resistance
('17', 192, 4, 10, 394307) 1 The following is a summary of the proceedings of the Conference cabled by the Secretary of State to the Viceroy “The fifteenth meeting of the Conference was held on July 25th.
('17', 192, 4, 11, 394485) The first subject discussed was reciprocity of treatment between India and the Dominions.
('17', 192, 4, 12, 394575) This discussion followed on the resolution passed by the Conference last year, accepting the principle of reciprocity and a further resolution passed to that effect .
('17', 192, 4, 13, 394742) in pursuance of which the Conference agreed as follows: (I) It is the inherent function of the Governments of several communities of the British Commonwealth including India that each should enjoy complete control in the composition of its own population by means of restriction on immigration from any other communitics.
('17', 192, 4, 14, 395064) (2) British citizens domiciled in any British country including India should be admitted into any other British country for visits for the purposes of pleasure or commerce including temporary residence for the purpose of education.
('17', 192, 4, 15, 395296) The conditions of such visits should be regulated on the principle of reciprocity as follows: (a) The right of the Government of India is recognized to enact laws which shall have the effect of subjecting British citizens domiciled in any other British country to the same conditions in visiting India as those imposed on Indians desiring to visit such country.
('17', 192, 4, 16, 395658) (b) Such right of visit or temporary residence shall, in each individual case, be embodied in the passport or written permit issued by the country of domicile and subject to vise there by an officer appointed by and acting on behalf of the country to be visited.
('17', 192, 4, 17, 395921) If such a country so desires, such right shall not extend to the visit or temporary residence for labour purpose or to permanent settlement.
('17', 192, 4, 18, 396062) (3) Indians already permanently domiciled in other British countries should be allowed to bring in their wives and minor children on condition (a) that no more than one wife and her children shall be admitted for each such Indian, and (b) that each individual so admitted shall be certified by the Government of India as being the lawful wife or child of such Indian.
('17', 192, 4, 19, 396430) The Conference recommends other questions covered by the Memoranda presented to the Conference by the representatives of India.”
('17', 193, 0, 1, 396559) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 193, 1, 2, 396601) movement.
('17', 193, 1, 3, 396611) But the administrative principles still continue and will do so, so long as India remains both in name and substance a dependency.
('17', 193, 1, 4, 396742) The agreement arrived at regarding those who are already domiciled practically restates the terms of the Settlement of 1914. If it extends to Canada and Australia, it is a decided gain, for in Canada till recently there was a big agitation owing to the refusal of its Government to admit the wives and children of its Sikh settlers.
('17', 193, 1, 5, 397075) I may perhaps add that the South African Settlement provides for the protection of those who had plural wives before the Settlement, especially if the latter had at any time entered South Africa.
('17', 193, 1, 6, 397271) It may be the proper thing in a predominantly Christian country to confine the legality to only one wife.
('17', 193, 1, 7, 397377) But it is necessary even for that country, in the interest of humanity and for the sake of friendship for members of the same Imperial Federation to which they belong adminis tratively, to allow the admission of plural wives and their progeny.
('17', 193, 1, 8, 397621) The above agreement still evades the qutstion of inequality of status in other matters.
('17', 193, 1, 9, 397709) Thus, the difficulty of obtaining licences throughout South Africa, the prohibition to hold landed property in the Transvaal and the Free State, and virtual prohibition within the Union itself of the entry of Indians into the Free State, the prohi bition of Indian children to enter the ordinary Government schools, deprivation of municipal franchise in the Transvaal and the Free State, and practical deprivation of the Union franchise throughout South Africa, barring perhaps the Cape.
('17', 193, 1, 10, 398197) The resolutions of the Imperial Conference therefore are decidedly an eyewash.
('17', 193, 1, 11, 398276) There is no change of heart in the Colonies and decidedly no recognition of Imperial obligations regarding India.
('17', 193, 1, 12, 398390) The Fijian atrocities, to which Mr. Andrews has drawn pointed attention, show what is possible even in the Crown Colonies which are under direct Imperial control.
('17', 193, 2, 13, 398553) New India, 15 8 1918

('17', 201, 6, 9, 412727) DEAR MR. SAMARTH 1, Many many thanks for your letter.
('17', 201, 6, 10, 412781) I do believe in the religious treatment and that is what I have applied in the main, but I believe also in nature cure and fasting.
('17', 201, 6, 11, 412913) Nature cure is hydropathy and enema.
('17', 201, 6, 12, 412950) The only food I am taking is fruit juices, principally orange juice.
('17', 201, 6, 13, 413019) I am free to confess that nature cure means to that extent want of faith in the purely religious cure.
('17', 201, 6, 14, 413122) I have not the courage to keep myself exclusively to the latter when I know that the disease is due to a breach of nature’s laws.
('17', 201, 6, 15, 413252) I am sorry I cannot be with you tomorrow nor can I give my name to the movement.
('17', 201, 6, 16, 413333) I wish to hold myself aloof from both the movements, for I hold views which are acceptable to neither party.
('17', 201, 6, 17, 413442) I feel that at the present moment all the leaders should concentrate their efforts upon recruiting to the exclusion practically of every other activity.
('17', 201, 6, 18, 413595) I know that the Extremists do not agree with me and I hardly think the Moderates go as far as I go.
('17', 201, 6, 19, 413695) Whilst I accept the M. C. Scheme 2 in the main, to make it acceptable I should insist upon certain modifications and my insistence would go the length of wrecking the Scheme if the modifications were not accepted after exhausting every means at my disposal.
('17', 201, 6, 20, 413953) To get the modifications accepted, I should not therefore hesitate to use what has been commonly called passive resistance.
('17', 201, 6, 21, 414077) The Moderates will not accept this condition.

('17', 202, 5, 9, 414542) I am abstaining from the Congress because I know that I hold views which are not acceptable to the principal leaders.

('17', 202, 5, 11, 414756) Nor am I going to attend the Moderates’ Conference.
('17', 202, 5, 12, 414808) I believe that we should render the greatest service to the country by devoting ourselves exclusively to recruiting work.
('17', 202, 5, 13, 414930) Neither party would be prepared to go the length that I go.
('17', 202, 5, 14, 414990) Then I would accept principles of the M. C. Scheme and definitely state the minimum of improvements I should require and fight for their attainment unto death.
('17', 202, 5, 15, 415150) For this, Moderates are certainly not prepared and the Extremists, in so far as they may be prepared, are not in the sense I mean.
('17', 202, 5, 16, 415281) I therefore feel that I should do nothing at the present moment.
('17', 202, 5, 17, 415346) So far as the bringing together of the two parties is concerned, I should do nothing by violence and therefore I do not approve of any give and take.
('17', 202, 5, 18, 415496) These are two definite parties in the country.
('17', 202, 5, 19, 415543) They should put their programme boldly before the Government and the country and agitate for its acceptance.
('17', 202, 5, 20, 415652) Then only in my opinion shall we make real headway.
('17', 202, 5, 21, 415704) Just now we seem to be moving in a vicious circle.
('17', 202, 5, 22, 415755) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('17', 203, 3, 23, 417445) I do not wish to get caught in this false position.

('17', 203, 3, 29, 417876) There are two wings in the country.
('17', 203, 3, 30, 417912) I do not believe that it will do any harm to make the positions of both clear to the Government and the people.

('17', 204, 2, 3, 418463) August 27, 1918
('17', 204, 3, 4, 418479) DEAR DR.
('17', 204, 4, 5, 418488) You may have heard of my illness.
('17', 204, 4, 6, 418522) It was a very serious attack of dysentery.
('17', 204, 4, 7, 418565) Though I seem to be convalescent, I am utterly prostrate with weakness.
('17', 204, 4, 8, 418637) I can scarcely move out of my bed or even sit in it for any length of time.
('17', 204, 4, 9, 418713) The great question is how to build up this broken up body.
('17', 204, 4, 10, 418772) I have abstained from milk and its products for a number of years and vowed to do so for life.
('17', 204, 4, 11, 418867) I therefore need a substitute for milk and butter.
('17', 204, 4, 12, 418918) Hitherto in my strength, I have found an excellent substitute in groundnuts, walnuts and such other nuts, but fats obtained from all these nuts are too strong for my delicate stomach.
('17', 204, 4, 13, 419102) I need an exact vegetable substitute for ghee and milk.
('17', 204, 4, 14, 419158) I have tried kopra milk and almond milk before now.
('17', 204, 4, 15, 419210) The physiological action of these milks is totally different from that of cow’s milk.
('17', 204, 4, 16, 419296) Do you know any vegetable substitutes for ghee or butter and for milk?
('17', 204, 4, 17, 419367) If you do, kindly name them, or better still, if you can procure them, send them.
('17', 204, 4, 18, 419449) I am told that up in the north they manufacture ghee out of delicate mhoura seed which is not the same as the ordinary ghee but is the same as olive oil.
('17', 204, 4, 19, 419603) Please enlighten me if you can.
('17', 204, 4, 20, 419635) It hurts me to think that my only letter of a recent date addressed to you should be of so utterly doleful and selfish character.
('17', 204, 4, 21, 419765) Forgive me if you can.
('17', 204, 5, 22, 419788) Yours sincerely,
('17', 204, 6, 23, 419805) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('17', 204, 6, 24, 419851) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
('17', 204, 7, 25, 419875) 1 This letter is presumably addressed to Dr. P. C. Ray (1861 1944) the eminent chemist.

('17', 206, 2, 3, 421301) August 29, 1918
('17', 206, 3, 4, 421317) MY DEAR CHARLIE,
('17', 206, 4, 5, 421334) I have suffered indeed, but no more than I have deserved to.
('17', 206, 4, 6, 421395) I can trace definitely and directly the causes of this illness.
('17', 206, 4, 7, 421459) They do me no credit and show how weak I am in spite of all my attempts to overcome those weaknesses.
('17', 206, 4, 8, 421561) This illness shows me all the more clearly how continuously we break the known laws of nature.
('17', 206, 4, 9, 421656) There is no temptation so difficult to overcome as that of the palate and it is because it is so difficult that we think so little about it.
('17', 206, 4, 10, 421797) In my opinion, mastery of the palate means mastery of everything.
('17', 206, 4, 11, 421863) But of this more later.
('17', 206, 4, 12, 421887) I am steadily progressing.
('17', 206, 4, 13, 421914) My peace has never been disturbed.
('17', 206, 4, 14, 421949) Pray do not have any anxiety about me.
('17', 206, 4, 15, 421988) I would not have you leave Shantiniketan on any account whatsoever.
('17', 206, 4, 16, 422056) I think that both you and Gurudev are doing the finest work of your lives.
('17', 206, 4, 17, 422131) You are now writing real poems.
('17', 206, 4, 18, 422163) They are living poems.
('17', 206, 4, 19, 422186) I wish I was in Shantiniketan sitting side by side with the privileged boys listening to Gurudev’s discourses and also yours.

('17', 207, 3, 11, 423041) 190. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('17', 207, 4, 12, 423070) August 29, 1918
('17', 207, 5, 13, 423086) DEVDAS, After long waiting, I got your two letters simultaneously today.
('17', 207, 5, 14, 423159) My health is improving.
('17', 207, 5, 15, 423183) There is no cause at all for anxiety.
('17', 207, 5, 16, 423221) Today it is very good indeed.
('17', 207, 5, 17, 423251) Never, from first to last, did I lose control over it and never did I worry about the end.
('17', 207, 5, 18, 423342) While the illness lasted, I was afraid of the pain but the fear of death did not touch me even in my dreams.
('17', 207, 5, 19, 423451) When, moreover, the pain was extreme, I longed to die and be free from it all.
('17', 207, 5, 20, 423530) My wanting to remain active while I live is one thing, but I have no desire to live just that I may work.
('17', 207, 5, 21, 423636) May be I desire moksha 2, but it is not to be had by desiring it.
('17', 207, 5, 22, 423702) One must be fit for it.
('17', 207, 5, 23, 423726) I consider your work so important that you should not leave it even for coming over to see how I am.
('17', 207, 5, 24, 423827) Rest assured that I am being looked after quite well.
('17', 207, 5, 25, 423881) I see no possibility now of my going to France; it seems, rather, that I shall not have to go to the front at all.
('17', 207, 5, 26, 423996) We find the Allies winning every day in the battlefields of France.
('17', 207, 5, 27, 424064) In this situation, it does not seem likely that they will take us there.
('17', 207, 5, 28, 424137) We shall know in about a month.
('17', 207, 5, 29, 424169) Even if I have to go, I cannot hope that it will be to France.
('17', 207, 5, 30, 424232) Possibly, I may have to go to Mesopotamia.

('17', 210, 8, 12, 428566) 195. LETTER TO MILLIE POLAK 2
('17', 210, 9, 13, 428596) August 31, 1918 As I am writing this, I am watching the glorious rain des cending in torrents before me.
('17', 210, 9, 14, 428701) It will gladden the hearts of millions of men and women.
('17', 210, 9, 15, 428758) There was a great dread of a most severe famine overtaking Western India.
('17', 210, 9, 16, 428832) In the twinkling of an eye, all that fear has gone.
('17', 210, 9, 17, 428884) It has given place to boundless joy; this rain is a veritable deliverance for millions upon millions of cattle.
('17', 210, 9, 18, 428996) There is probably no place on earth that is so dependent on rain as India.
('17', 210, 9, 19, 429071) You will now understand what part this rain must have played in giving me health.
('17', 210, 10, 20, 429153) 1 S. K. Rudra, Principal, St. Stephen’s College, Delhi
('17', 210, 11, 21, 429208) 2 Millie Graham Polak, wife of H. S. L,.
('17', 210, 11, 22, 429249) Polak; author of Mr. Gandhi: The Man (1930)

('17', 211, 1, 2, 429335) have suffered agonies—all due to my own follies.
('17', 211, 1, 3, 429384) The punishment was adequate to the wrong done by me to the body.
('17', 211, 1, 4, 429449) Through a faulty experiment, I was suffering from dysentery.
('17', 211, 1, 5, 429510) Whilst I was getting over it, I ate when I should have refrained and that brought on the inevitable crisis.
('17', 211, 1, 6, 429618) I am so reduced in body that I have now to build anew but there is no cause for anxiety.
('17', 211, 1, 7, 429707) I am convalescent and regularly taking some nourishment and am daily increasing the quantity and I hope to be able to walk about in ten days’ time.
('17', 211, 1, 8, 429855) You ask me about nursing.
('17', 211, 1, 9, 429881) Everything that human lovecan do has been done for me.
('17', 211, 1, 10, 429936) It was my privilege and my pain to be on the sickbed— privilege to find so much love rained on me, pained that I should need it all through my weakness and folly.
('17', 211, 1, 11, 430099) This rich experiencing of love makes an added call on such service as I may be capable of rendering to humanity.

('17', 212, 3, 9, 432055) 197. LETTER TO DEVDAS GANDHI
('17', 212, 4, 10, 432084) [AHMEDABAD,] August 31, 1918 The reason why I did not attend the Congress was that I sensed an atmosphere of extreme unreality after my talks with Mrs. Besant and Tilak Maharaj.
('17', 212, 4, 11, 432262) I thought it imperative that, at a great moment like this, instead of indulging in fruitless controversies about the Scheme, we thought out ways and means of getting our demands accepted and employed them.
('17', 212, 4, 12, 432468) I placed my views on the subject before them and suggested that we had two great weapons.
('17', 212, 4, 13, 432558) One was that we should go all out to make sacrifices in the war and win the testimony of the Self in us as to our fitness.
('17', 212, 4, 14, 432681) When the atman 1 stands testimony, it gives such inner strength that nothing can withstand it.
('17', 212, 4, 15, 432776) The second way was that we should make up our minds once for all about what we want and cling to it like fanatics and fight till death to get it accepted.
('17', 212, 4, 16, 432931) The two leaders rejected both suggestions.
('17', 212, 4, 17, 432974) I felt, therefore, that it was useless for me to attend the Congress and that, by not going, I could make my view known silently but effectively.
('17', 212, 4, 18, 433120) It was with this thought that I gave up the idea of attending.
('17', 212, 4, 19, 433183) Blessings from
('17', 212, 5, 20, 433198) BAPU [From Gujarati]

('17', 214, 1, 2, 434825) 199. LETTER TO KHUSHALCHAND GANDHI
('17', 214, 2, 3, 434860) Shravan Vad 10 [August 31, 1918] 1
('17', 214, 3, 4, 434895) WITH HUMBLE RESPECTS TO MU.
('17', 214, 3, 5, 434923) BHAISHRI,
('17', 214, 4, 6, 434933) Your letter arrived just a little while ago and I am replying im mediately.
('17', 214, 4, 7, 435009) You have a right to write to me even in bitter words.
('17', 214, 4, 8, 435063) Who else would write to me in this manner if not you?
('17', 214, 4, 9, 435117) I also understand your being shocked.
('17', 214, 4, 10, 435155) But there seems to be some misunderstanding as to the fact of the case.
('17', 214, 4, 11, 435227) I do not at all desire that kind of change in the society at large.
('17', 214, 4, 12, 435295) In the Ashram, however, from the beginning, it has been our rule not to observe the Varnavyavastha 2 because the position of the Ashram is different from that of the society outside.
('17', 214, 4, 13, 435478) When you were here on a visit, the same practice was followed.
('17', 214, 4, 14, 435541) Dudhabhai, his wife and L[akshmi] all three lived with me at Kocharab and had their meals with me.
('17', 214, 4, 15, 435640) Dudhabhai’s wife used to enter the kitchen, too.

('17', 216, 1, 2, 439554) 200. RESOLUTION BY GUJARAT SABHA, AHMEDABAD 1
('17', 216, 2, 3, 439600) [September, 1918]
('17', 216, 3, 4, 439618) The Gujarat Sabha, of which Mr. Gandhi is the President, issued some time ago the following translation of a resolution unanimously passed at its general meeting held at Ahmedabad: In the opinion of the Sabha, the easiest and straightest method of attaining swarajya is to help the Empire in the hour of danger by supplying all available men for fighting and other purposes in connection with the war, and therefore this Sabha resolves that it should with all possible despatch undertake recruiting and for that purpose obtain the necessary sanction, and advises other kindred associations to do likewise.
('17', 216, 3, 5, 440224) The Sabha authorizes the President and the Secretaries to take all necessary steps with a view to enforcing the foregoing resolution.

('17', 218, 6, 12, 443960) The milk problem with me is not quite so simple as you have stated it.
('17', 218, 6, 13, 444031) It is not regard for the calf that in my illness prevents me from taking milk, but I have taken a definite vow not to take milk or its products even in illness and I feel that it is better to die than to break a vow knowingly and deliberately taken.

('17', 221, 1, 2, 448888) 206. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('17', 221, 2, 3, 448918) September 9, 1918
('17', 221, 3, 4, 448936) It is true that cooking takes some time but I believe that this time is not wasted.
('17', 221, 3, 5, 449020) It is also generally not true that some more important work could be done during that time.
('17', 221, 3, 6, 449112) Ninety five per cent of the people waste more time every day than is taken up in cooking.
('17', 221, 3, 7, 449202) I am being rather liberal in my estimate in saying ninety five per cent.
('17', 221, 3, 8, 449275) You will be surprised in how short a time a person doing his own cooking finishes it when he is very busy.
('17', 221, 3, 9, 449382) If I give my own example, when I was very busy with studies in England I did not take more than half an hour in the morning and in the evening for cooking.
('17', 221, 3, 10, 449538) In the morning, I used to prepare porridge, and this took exactly twenty minutes; if I cooked in the evening, I prepared soup.
('17', 221, 3, 11, 449665) As it did not require stirring, the only time spent was in getting the materials ready.
('17', 221, 3, 12, 449753) After putting the thing on the fire, I would sit by and read.
('17', 221, 3, 13, 449815) Occasionally, students come to me from Benares.
('17', 221, 3, 14, 449863) I ask all of them what they do.
('17', 221, 3, 15, 449895) Most Brahrnins cook their own food.
('17', 221, 3, 16, 449931) One of them told me that he only prepared khichdi 1 and ate it with milk and pickles.
('17', 221, 3, 17, 450017) While he was eating the meal, the bhakhri 2 would be getting baked.
('17', 221, 3, 18, 450085) This bhakhri he would eat with milk in the evening.
('17', 221, 3, 19, 450137) In this, he spent three quarters of an hour in all.
('17', 221, 3, 20, 450189) This is an extreme case I have cited.
('17', 221, 3, 21, 450227) I do not want you to be all that particular.
('17', 221, 3, 22, 450272) This is only to illustrate that it is possible to do one’s cooking in a very short time.
('17', 221, 3, 23, 450361) That student was quite healthy and strong, because khichdi, milk or curds and pickles gave him all the nourishment he needed.
('17', 221, 3, 24, 450487) Anyone who can get good milk or curds will care little for other things.
('17', 221, 3, 25, 450560) Do not imagine that I write this to suggest that you should always cook yourself.
('17', 221, 3, 26, 450642) I have said all this only in order that, on occasion, you should not hesitate in the least to do your own cooking and [when you have to do it] be so unhappy, all without reason, that you were wasting your time.
('17', 221, 3, 27, 450853) Otherwise, when you have mended your ways, I can have no objection to your calling Chanchi 3, having good things to eat and enjoying life, within limits.
('17', 221, 3, 28, 451007) Only see that you do not repeat your mistakes.
('17', 221, 3, 29, 451054) I want you not to be too eager to get rich quickly.

('17', 223, 1, 12, 454089) It has nothing to do with the political problem.
('17', 223, 1, 13, 454138) It can certainly have political consequences, but I have never had that in view.
('17', 223, 1, 14, 454219) I also wish to add that I do not intend suggesting that orthodox religion should not be given the slightest recognition.
('17', 223, 1, 15, 454340) True religion is firm like a rock.
('17', 223, 1, 16, 454375) Orthodox religion should change with the change in times.
('17', 223, 1, 17, 454433) If we were to live according to some of the things mentioned in the Manusmriti, we should be committing immorality.
('17', 223, 1, 18, 454549) We have silently abandoned those things.
('17', 223, 1, 19, 454590) With regards,
('17', 223, 2, 20, 454604) MOHANDAS

('17', 226, 4, 10, 459206) 212. SPEECH ON”THE PILGRIM’S PROGRESS”
('17', 226, 5, 11, 459245) September 21, 1918
('17', 226, 6, 12, 459264) Commencing readings from The Pilgrim’s Progress after Ashram prayers :
('17', 226, 7, 13, 459335) Now then, friends, look, who was the author of this?
('17', 226, 7, 14, 459388) One John Bunyan.
('17', 226, 7, 15, 459405) Do you know who he was?
('17', 226, 7, 16, 459429) A man with a will, like our Prahlad 1, he suffered imprisonment for the sake of truth, much as Prahlad submitted to ordeals for its sake; and as our Tilak Maharaj wrote his Gita Rahasya in jail, so this Bunyan wrote in jail this story of a pilgrim’s journey.
('17', 226, 7, 17, 459688) Call it a journey or progress or rise, what you will— he wrote that.
('17', 226, 7, 18, 459757) Like the commentaries on the Gita that we have, The Pilgrim’s Progress is a commentary on the Bible.
('17', 226, 7, 19, 459858) No, one cannot describe it even as a commentary.
('17', 226, 7, 20, 459907) It is, rather an exposition of the most beautiful portions of the Bible.
('17', 226, 7, 21, 459980) In English, the book is esteemed as a great classic and placed almost on a level with the Bible.
('17', 226, 7, 22, 460077) And Bunyan has written it in such simple and beautiful language for children to follow that, wherever English is spoken, it is considered a most wonderful book for them.
('17', 226, 7, 23, 460247) Even more, he says in his preface to the book, as Tulsidas in his Ramayana, that in time to come it will be read by one and all.
('17', 226, 7, 24, 460376) And indeed it is as good as the Ramayana.
('17', 226, 7, 25, 460418) Tulsi’s Ramayana is a fountain of delight for children while grown ups go messing around, and so likewise this book is of absorbing interest to children.
('17', 226, 7, 26, 460572) But, now, let us read a little from the book.
('17', 226, 7, 27, 460618) Hear what he says : “As I walked through the wilderness of this world .
('17', 226, 7, 28, 460690) .” In our books, too, life in this world is described as a forest of impenetrable
('17', 226, 8, 29, 460772) 1 Prahlad was a devotee of God persecuted by his unbelieving father, the demon king Hiranyakashipu.
('17', 226, 8, 30, 460872) Gandhiji often spoke of him as an ideal satyagrhahi.
('17', 227, 0, 1, 460925) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 227, 1, 2, 460967) darkness, and likewise he has described it as a wilderness.
('17', 227, 1, 3, 461027) He goes on to say that, in that labyrinthine wilderness of life, all tired, he lighted on a fearful den—tired out, that is, not only with physical fatigue, but also in his atman.
('17', 227, 1, 4, 461206) He had turned over a great many thoughts in his mind, had heard countless things from countless sources, but had failed to come by the truth.
('17', 227, 1, 5, 461348) So this poor man, all tired in spirit and bewildered, fell asleep in his exhaustion.
('17', 227, 1, 6, 461433) He slept and dreamt a dream.
('17', 227, 1, 7, 461462) In this dream, whom did he see, do you think?
('17', 227, 1, 8, 461508) Do you know, Rukhi, who it was that he saw?
('17', 227, 1, 9, 461552) A man in rags.
('17', 227, 1, 10, 461567) Well, then, kiddies, tell me, how was Sudama 1 dressed when he went to Lord Krishna?
('17', 227, 1, 11, 461652) Had he put on a dhoti with a silken border, or a coat of lace or a jolly flat Maharashtrian puggree and a scarf of brocade?
('17', 227, 1, 12, 461776) Oh, no !
('17', 227, 1, 13, 461785) He was only in rags, and so was this one, too.
('17', 227, 1, 14, 461832) Here, Rukhi, do you know what Sudama had on?
('17', 227, 1, 15, 461877) You may not, but I do, for I was born in Porbandar, the home of Sudama.
('17', 227, 1, 16, 461949) Well, then, which way was Sudama facing?
('17', 227, 1, 17, 461990) Homewards?
('17', 227, 1, 18, 462001) Brother dear, he had left his home and was making his way to where the Lord dwelt.
('17', 227, 1, 19, 462084) Even so, our Pilgrim had turned his face away from home and taken a road that led elsewhere.
('17', 227, 1, 20, 462177) And, again, what did he carry on his shoulder?
('17', 227, 1, 21, 462224) See, Rukhi, he had a burden on his back, like the gunny bag, weighing five maunds, which that labourer used to bring on his back when we were at Kochrab.
('17', 227, 1, 22, 462378) He used to be all drenched with perspiration and bent so low, how could I ask him to stand erect?
('17', 227, 1, 23, 462476) This man, here, had a book in his hand.
('17', 227, 1, 24, 462516) It was none other than the Bible.
('17', 227, 1, 25, 462550) Tears flowed from his eyes as he read it.
('17', 227, 1, 26, 462592) Do you know the story of Gopichand?
('17', 227, 1, 27, 462628) As he sat bathing, his mother stood looking at him from above, tears from her eyes dropping on his body.
('17', 227, 1, 28, 462733) There was not a cloud to be seen; whence this rain, then?
('17', 227, 1, 29, 462791) Gopichand looked up and saw that it fell from his mother’s eyes.
('17', 227, 1, 30, 462856) Why had she tears in her eyes?
('17', 227, 1, 31, 462887) Well, I shall explain that some other time.
('17', 227, 1, 32, 462931) This good man, too, had tears falling from his eyes.
('17', 227, 1, 33, 462984) He had set out for the House of God, he was a prince among the lovers of God and hence the tears in his eyes.
('17', 227, 1, 34, 463094) [From Gujarati]
('17', 227, 2, 35, 463110) Mahadevbhaini Diary, Vol. IV
('17', 227, 3, 36, 463139) 1 Sudama and Krishna, disciples of the same guru, Sandipani, were friends.
('17', 227, 3, 37, 463214) Sudama had a large family and was very poor.
('17', 227, 3, 38, 463259) His wife chided him for his other worldliness and persuaded him to go to Krishna for help.
('17', 227, 3, 39, 463350) Yet once in the presence of the Lord, he forgot to ask for help.
('17', 227, 3, 40, 463415) But when he returned home, he found it transformed by riches.

('17', 228, 1, 2, 463517) 213. LETTER TO SHUAIB QURESHI
('17', 228, 2, 3, 463547) September 24, 1918 I wish I had sufficient strength in my fingers and my wrists to give you my own hieroglyphics.
('17', 228, 2, 4, 463661) As it is, I must rest content with the help of a friendly wrist and equally friendly fingers.
('17', 228, 2, 5, 463755) You know all about the Committee to investigate the Brothers’ case.
('17', 228, 2, 6, 463823) We are creeping, whether the motion is upward or downward I do not know.
('17', 228, 2, 7, 463896) For a satyagrahi, all motion is upward.
('17', 228, 2, 8, 463936) If the Government have meant well, it is well for us all.
('17', 228, 2, 9, 463994) If they have meant ill, by the infallible law of causation it must react upon them and therefore it must go ill with them and not with us, the only condition being that we do not act even as they.
('17', 228, 2, 10, 464191) It is only because in the vast majority of cases we meet evil by evil that it continues to grow like weeds.
('17', 228, 2, 11, 464299) Resist not evil is the law of our being.
('17', 228, 2, 12, 464340) We come into the world with a double nature, that of the brute and man.
('17', 228, 2, 13, 464412) The latter has continually to gain ascendancy over the former, but this is a digression, and for me a diversion which, however, I do not wish to indulge in this letter.
('17', 228, 2, 14, 464581) To return to our immediate purpose, I am keeping in close touch with the Brothers through Mr. Ghate.
('17', 228, 3, 15, 464682) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('17', 228, 4, 17, 464752) 214. LETTER TO NANUBHAI
('17', 228, 5, 18, 464776) [AHMEDABAD,] September 24, 1918 There is no reason to go as far as to conclude that the need for joining up is over.
('17', 228, 5, 19, 464893) But the signs I see indicate that this will be so.
('17', 228, 5, 20, 464944) One need not assume that heroism is to be acquired only by fighting in a war.
('17', 228, 5, 21, 465022) One can do so even while keeping out of it.
('17', 228, 5, 22, 465066) War is one powerful means, among many others.
('17', 228, 5, 23, 465112) But, if it is a powerful means, it is also an evil one.
('17', 228, 5, 24, 465168) We can cultivate manliness in a blameless way.
('17', 228, 5, 25, 465215) If, through the fight we are carrying on with the body, we can develop the strength for the war which the atman must wage against the anatman 1, we shall have acquired manliness.

('17', 231, 1, 2, 468838) 218. REPLY TO BIRTHDAY GREETINGS IN THE ASHRAM
('17', 231, 2, 3, 468885) October 1, 1918 1
('17', 231, 3, 4, 468903) Am I worthy of the love which you have shown me by all of you coming over here this morning?
('17', 231, 3, 5, 468996) I don’t think I am.
('17', 231, 3, 6, 469016) As a rule, even outside the Ashram, I do not say anything merely in deference to convention and here surely I would not do so.
('17', 231, 3, 7, 469143) My words, there fore, are not just a form of good manners.
('17', 231, 3, 8, 469202) I simply feel in the depth of my soul that I am not worthy of the boundless love you proffer to me.
('17', 231, 3, 9, 469302) From one who has dedicated himself to the service of others, a great deal may he expected.
('17', 231, 3, 10, 469393) In comparison, the little that I have done is of no account.
('17', 231, 3, 11, 469454) You, too, all of you, have dedicated your selves to service.
('17', 231, 3, 12, 469515) I enjoin you all to hold back your veneration.
('17', 231, 3, 13, 469562) It is not in the fitness of things to express it before a person is dead.
('17', 231, 3, 14, 469636) For, how can we measure the worth of his work before his death, before we have seen it in its entirety?
('17', 231, 3, 15, 469740) Even after his death, it takes some time to assess it.
('17', 231, 3, 16, 469795) There is no point, therefore, in our celebrating the birth anniversary of a man before his death.
('17', 231, 4, 17, 469893) What more shall I say to you?
('17', 231, 4, 18, 469923) This morning, before four, I was immersed in thought.
('17', 231, 4, 19, 469977) Surendra 2 had put a question to me: what was the utmost I expected of him?
('17', 231, 4, 20, 470053) And of Devdas?
('17', 231, 4, 21, 470068) Of Chhotalal 3 as well?
('17', 231, 4, 22, 470092) Instead of telling you what I expect of each one of you individually, let me tell you what I expect from you all.
('17', 231, 4, 23, 470206) It is that you should observe to perfection our first and last vow, the vow of truth.
('17', 231, 4, 24, 470292) We must sincerely practise what we believe to be the means of moksha.
('17', 231, 4, 25, 470362) Working accordingly, you should carry out as well as you can the aims with which the Ashram has been established and bring all glory to it.
('17', 231, 4, 26, 470502) The Ashram will be judged by your actions and your character.
('17', 231, 4, 27, 470564) It has been established for the service of India and, through it, of one’s atman.
('17', 231, 4, 28, 470646) We have many critics.
('17', 231, 4, 29, 470668) Critics there will always be, but their criticism need not make us nervous, provided we are faithful to our vow of truth, the first and the last of our vows.
('17', 231, 4, 30, 470826) If we were indulging in hypocrisy and fraud, it would have been a different

('17', 234, 1, 2, 474986) 221. LETTER TO GANGABEHN MAJMUNDAR 1
('17', 234, 2, 3, 475023) [AHMEDABAD,] October 11, 1918 I read only today the postcard giving the news that you, Kiki and others have fallen ill.
('17', 234, 2, 4, 475143) I was, however, glad to read that, by the grace of God, you were all improving.
('17', 234, 2, 5, 475223) The bodies of those who have accepted the way of service should be as strong as steel.
('17', 234, 2, 6, 475310) There was a time when our forefathers could thus harden their bodies.
('17', 234, 2, 7, 475380) Today we have become pathetically weak and succumb to the innumerable poisonous germs in the atmosphere.
('17', 234, 2, 8, 475485) The only way to escape from this, despite our fallen state, is self control, moderation, call it what you will.
('17', 234, 2, 9, 475597) It is the opinion of doctors, and they are right, that the body will run least risk if two things are attended to.
('17', 234, 2, 10, 475712) Even after one feels that one has recovered from an illness, one should take only liquid and bland food easy to digest, and should continue to rest in bed.
('17', 234, 2, 11, 475868) Many patients, deceived when the fever comes down on the second or third day, resume their work and start eating as usual.
('17', 234, 2, 12, 475991) This brings on the attack again, and generally it proves fatal.
('17', 234, 2, 13, 476055) I would, therefore, request you all to remain confined to bed.
('17', 234, 2, 14, 476118) Write to me every day to give me news of your health.
('17', 234, 2, 15, 476172) I am still in bed and will have to remain there for many days; but it can be said that my health is improving.
('17', 234, 2, 16, 476283) The doctors have forbidden even writing letters; but how can I help writing to you?
('17', 234, 2, 17, 476367) If you are inconvenienced there and want to come over here, by all means do.
('17', 234, 2, 18, 476444) There are ten sick beds in the Ashram just now, but the only serious case appears to be that of Shankarlal.
('17', 234, 2, 19, 476552) Even he seems to have taken a turn for the better today.
('17', 234, 2, 20, 476609) Vandemataram from
('17', 234, 3, 21, 476627) MOHANDAS [From Gujarati]

('17', 235, 1, 2, 476904) 222. LETTER TO THE PRESS : THE LATE A. M. KACHALIA 1
('17', 235, 2, 3, 476957) October 20, 1918 2
('17', 235, 3, 4, 476976) TO THE EDITOR THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('17', 235, 4, 5, 477011) SIR, It is my mournful duty to bring to public notice another South African Indian whose death has been just cabled to me.
('17', 235, 4, 6, 477134) He bore the honoured name of Ahmed Mahomed Kachalia.
('17', 235, 4, 7, 477187) He was for a number of years President of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal.
('17', 235, 4, 8, 477278) It was during the passive resistance campaign that Mr. Kachalia suddenly leapt to fame and acquired among the Indians of South Africa a prestige unequalled by any other Indian.
('17', 235, 4, 9, 477455) It was on the 31st day of July 1907, under the shadow of a tree in the holy mosque of Pretoria, that Mr. Kachalia hurled defiance at the might of General Botha and his Government.
('17', 235, 4, 10, 477635) Mr. Hosken 3 had brought a message from the General to be delivered to the great mass meeting that was held in the mosque compound, to the effect that in resisting the Transvaal Government, the Indians were breaking their heads against a stone.
('17', 235, 4, 11, 477880) Mr. Kachalia was one of the speakers.
('17', 235, 4, 12, 477918) As I am dictating these few words of humble tribute, his voice rings in my ears.
('17', 235, 4, 13, 477999) He said:”In the name of Allah, I wish to state that though my head may be severed from the trunk, I shall never obey the Asiatic Registration Act.
('17', 235, 4, 14, 478146) I consider it unmanly and dishonourable to subscribe to a law which virtually reduces me to slavery.” And he was among the very few who never flinched through those long and weary eight years of untold sufferings.
('17', 235, 4, 15, 478360) Mr. Kachalia was by no means amongst the least of the sufferers.
('17', 235, 4, 16, 478425) He felt that as a leader his sacrifice should be striking, and that he should stop at nothing if thereby the honour of this country
('17', 235, 5, 17, 478557) 1 Also published in Prajabandhu, 27 10 1918, and The Indian Review, October, 1918
('17', 235, 6, 18, 478639) 2 A. M. Cachalia passed away on this date.
('17', 235, 7, 19, 478682) 3 William Hosken, M.L.A. (Transvaal) and ex president of the Association of Chamber of Commerce of South Africa.
('17', 235, 7, 20, 478795) He was sympathetic to the cause of British Indians; vide “The Transvaal Immigratopm Bill Debate”, 20 7 1907; Johannesburg Letter”, 31 12 1907 and ; Before 10 1 1908
('17', 236, 0, 1, 478960) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 237
('17', 236, 1, 2, 479000) might be saved.
('17', 236, 1, 3, 479016) He reduced himself to poverty.
('17', 236, 1, 4, 479047) He said goodbye to all the comforts of life towhich he was used, and night and day worked for a cause he held sacred.
('17', 236, 1, 5, 479165) Naturally he acquired a wonderful hold over the Indian community throughout South Africa and his was a name to conjure with amongst them.
('17', 236, 1, 6, 479303) As may be imagined, there were often disputes among Mahomedans and Hindus and other sections of the community.
('17', 236, 1, 7, 479414) Mr. Kachalia held the scales even between the conflicting interests and everyone knew that his decisions would be absolutely just and sound.
('17', 236, 1, 8, 479555) Mr. Kachalia was practically illiterate.
('17', 236, 1, 9, 479596) He was a self made man.
('17', 236, 1, 10, 479620) But his common sense was of the rarest order.
('17', 236, 1, 11, 479666) It always stood him in good stead and he was able to command the confidence and respect of many Europeans who came in contact with him.

('17', 236, 3, 16, 480081) 223. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('17', 236, 4, 17, 480119) SABARMATI, AHMEDABAD, October 20, 1918
('17', 236, 5, 18, 480158) DEAR MR. SASTRIAR, Though being on sick bed, I cannot restrain myself from adding my own humble tribute to your own and other friends’ to Dr. Deva’s 2 memory.
('17', 236, 5, 19, 480317) Both the society and the country have lost a true servant.
('17', 236, 5, 20, 480376) Of all the members of the Society, it was with Dr. Deva that I came in closest touch and the more I knew him the more I loved him.
('17', 236, 5, 21, 480507) If I may say so, Dr. Deva found fuller scope in Champaran for self expression.
('17', 236, 5, 22, 480586) There he was placed amid surroundings which tested all his great qualities including his medical knowledge.
('17', 236, 5, 23, 480694) He never flinched
('17', 236, 6, 24, 480712) 1 Vide “Speech at Surat”, 1 8 1918.
('17', 236, 7, 25, 480748) 2 Dr. Hari Shrikrishna Deva (died October 8, 1918); a Durbar surgeon of Sangli, he joined the Servants of India Society in 1914 and worked with Gandhiji in the Champaran campaign.
('17', 237, 0, 1, 480928) 238 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 237, 1, 2, 480970) and never failed.
('17', 237, 1, 3, 480988) Though he started his relations with the authorities and the planters with suspicion, he disarmed them at the end of his stay.
('17', 237, 1, 4, 481115) The Sub Divisional Officer at Bettiah with whom he came in close contact often told me that he likedDr. Deva for his selflessness and his devotion to his work.
('17', 237, 1, 5, 481275) How could he do otherwise?
('17', 237, 1, 6, 481302) For he was not only medical adviser to the helpless villagers but was his own dispenser.
('17', 237, 1, 7, 481391) He took medicines to their homes.
('17', 237, 1, 8, 481425) He attended to their sanitation.
('17', 237, 1, 9, 481458) He bent his own body to clean the village wells, to fix up the village road.
('17', 237, 1, 10, 481535) With Messrs Soman and Randive, in place of the burnt down grass hut, which was used as school at Bhitiharwa, he raised in a few days’ time, to the marvel of everybody, a pucca school building and, comparatively delicate though he was in body, he worked side by side with able bodied villagers who, touched by his enthusiasm, responded to his call for help in building the school which was designed for their sake.
('17', 237, 1, 11, 481949) What, however, is the pleasantest of all my experiences of Dr. Deva is the tribute Mr. Soman, a B.A., LL.B. of Belgaum, pays to his memory in a letter just received from him.
('17', 237, 1, 12, 482124) He belongs to the Nationalists’ school.
('17', 237, 1, 13, 482164) He was one of the volunteers in Champaran.
('17', 237, 1, 14, 482207) He is himself a staunch and true worker.
('17', 237, 1, 15, 482248) He says in the letter that he approached Dr. Deva with a great deal of suspicion and distrust to his attitude towards the Nationalists, but he adds that”it did not take many days before the suspicion and mistrust gave place to perfect confidence and respect.” Indeed they, retaining their own views to the end, became fast friends.
('17', 237, 1, 16, 482580) Dr. Deva was never a fanatic.
('17', 237, 1, 17, 482610) He had boundless charity in him, and therefore both had the rare gift of seeing the bright side of his opponent’s case.
('17', 237, 1, 18, 482730) The Society has certainly lost in him a fine collector and advertiser.
('17', 237, 1, 19, 482801) He was a true man.
('17', 237, 1, 20, 482820) Yours sincerely,
('17', 237, 2, 21, 482837) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 239, 2, 3, 484067) ASHRAM, SABARMATI, October 29 [1918]
('17', 239, 3, 4, 484104) DEAR PUNDALIK,
('17', 239, 4, 5, 484119) Your letter was shown to Bapuji.
('17', 239, 4, 6, 484152) It has not pleased him.
('17', 239, 4, 7, 484176) He sends you the following message: One comes across a variety of things in the world, but one is not required to get involved in every one of them.
('17', 239, 4, 8, 484325) One ought only to concern oneself with things that are part of one’s duty.
('17', 239, 4, 9, 484400) A man who meddles with what is not his job is not prompted by any concern for the right—he is merely conceited.
('17', 239, 4, 10, 484512) Your duty is only to impart instruction to children and to look after matters of hygiene and sanitation and you may not transgress its limits.
('17', 239, 4, 11, 484655) Therefore your action in stopping the police and getting the cattle released was not right.
('17', 239, 4, 12, 484747) It may be that they will not prosecute you for stopping the police, but not prosecuting you will only involve you in further trouble.
('17', 239, 4, 13, 484881) It is well that you write to me about everything.
('17', 239, 4, 14, 484931) Continue to write in this manner.
('17', 239, 4, 15, 484965) But do not ever leave the field of school work to meddle with something else.
('17', 239, 4, 16, 485043) Your duty is only that and nothing else, It is not right of you to be angry with the Saheb either.
('17', 239, 4, 17, 485142) I hope you will be very cautious in your behaviour in future.
('17', 239, 5, 18, 485204) This is Mahatmaji’s message.
('17', 239, 5, 19, 485233) You will accept it with reverence.
('17', 239, 5, 20, 485268) He would himself have written, but his hand and fingers have not the strength.

('17', 240, 2, 3, 485716) [AHMEDABAD,] October 31, 1918 I got your postcard.

('17', 240, 2, 9, 486377) It is no exaggeration to say that I experience wave after wave of joy from the practice of self restraint which such work requires.
('17', 240, 2, 10, 486509) One will find true happiness in the measure that one understands this and lives accordingly.

('17', 241, 4, 8, 487784) 228. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('17', 241, 5, 9, 487822) November 5, 1918
('17', 241, 6, 10, 487839) DEAR MR. SHASTRIAR, I thank you for your note and I fully appreciate and understand the spirit that has prompted it.
('17', 241, 6, 11, 487956) I assure you that I take the greatest possible care I can of my health.
('17', 241, 6, 12, 488028) It is no joke for a man who has rarely been laid up in bed to have more than three months’ experience of it.
('17', 241, 6, 13, 488137) And if my sickness is still further prolonged, it will be due to my ignorance or folly, or both.
('17', 241, 6, 14, 488234) I cannot ascribe any relapse to want of skill or attention of medical friends.

('17', 241, 6, 16, 488375) But they have become part of myself and give me the greatest comfort and joy even when I am suffering excruciating pain.

('17', 241, 6, 18, 488567) F. Z. Hodge of Motihari.
('17', 241, 6, 19, 488592) He is a missionary of exceptional independence and liberal thought.
('17', 241, 6, 20, 488660) I hope you are keeping well or rather as well as you can under the strain that exacting public work imposes upon you.

('17', 244, 1, 2, 492036) 234. LETTER TO MAHOMED ALI
('17', 244, 2, 3, 492063) THE ASHRAM, November 18, 1918
('17', 244, 3, 4, 492093) MY DEAR FRIEND, It was a perfect delight to receive a letter from you after ages as it were.
('17', 244, 3, 5, 492186) The letters from you all are evidence of your great affection for me for which I am deeply grateful and if, as some return for it, I could strain the letter of my vow and do what you suggest I should gladly do so.
('17', 244, 3, 6, 492400) But there is no getting out of the self imposed restraint.
('17', 244, 3, 7, 492459) I should be false to God and man and to myself if I disregarded the vow taken after the fullest deliberation and in anticipation of all the consequences that have followed it.
('17', 244, 3, 8, 492635) All my usefulness will be entirely gone if yielding to so many friends’ advice I reconsider my position.
('17', 244, 3, 9, 492740) I regard this sickness as a time of trial and temptation for me, and what I need is the prayerful support and encouragement of friends.
('17', 244, 3, 10, 492876) I assure you that within the four corners of the restriction I take every precaution possible in order to preserve the body.
('17', 244, 3, 11, 493001) Just now a medical friend has appeared on the scene who has undertaken to give me physical strength by massage, ice application and deep breathing.
('17', 244, 3, 12, 493149) He thinks that in two months’ time I shall have put on sufficient flesh and weight to be able to move out and undertake ordinary mental strain.
('17', 244, 3, 13, 493293) His treatment is rational and natural.
('17', 244, 3, 14, 493332) What is more, I have confidence in it and with proper dietetic changes I do hope that the friend’s prophecy will be fulfilled.
('17', 244, 3, 15, 493459) I have had the charges against you read to me.
('17', 244, 3, 16, 493506) I have never read a weaker or flimsier indictment and think that your reply will be decisive, straight and dignified.
('17', 244, 3, 17, 493624) It is evident to me that the Committee has been appointed to furnish the Government with anescape.
('17', 244, 3, 18, 493723) Anyway we can now contemplate the findings of the Com mittee with complete indifference.
('17', 244, 3, 19, 493812) Your defence is so overwhelmingly strong that if the Committee’s finding is hostile an agitation can be raised which will make India resound with indignation over the monstrous injustice under which you have laboured so long and so patiently.
('17', 244, 3, 20, 494055) I wish I was with you in Chhindwara to assist in drawing up your reply, but that was not to be.
('17', 244, 3, 21, 494151) Please give my respects to Amma Saheb.
('17', 244, 3, 22, 494190) I am pining to meet you all and to meet the children and to come in closer touch with you.
('17', 244, 3, 23, 494281) As I said at the Lucknow meeting, my interest in your release is quite
('17', 245, 0, 1, 494352) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 245, 1, 2, 494394) selfish.
('17', 245, 1, 3, 494403) We have a common goal and I want to utilize your services to the uttermost, in order to reach that goal.
('17', 245, 1, 4, 494508) In the proper solution of the Mahomedan question lies the realization of swaraj.
('17', 245, 1, 5, 494589) However, of this when we meet, as I hope we shall soon do.
('17', 245, 1, 6, 494648) Yours sincerely,
('17', 245, 2, 7, 494665) M. K. GANDHI
('17', 245, 3, 8, 494678) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('17', 245, 3, 9, 494724) Courtesy: Narayan Desai; also N.A.I.: Home: Political (Deposit): December, 1918: No.
('17', 245, 4, 10, 494809) 235. LETTER TO SAROJINI NAIDU
('17', 245, 5, 11, 494839) November 18, 1918
('17', 245, 6, 12, 494857) DEAR SISTER, I appreciated your little note.
('17', 245, 6, 13, 494902) I observe that you have survived the operation.
('17', 245, 6, 14, 494950) I hope that it will be entirely successful, so that India may for many a year to come continue to hear your songs.
('17', 245, 6, 15, 495065) For me I do not know when I shall be able to leave this sick bed of mine.
('17', 245, 6, 16, 495139) Somehow or other, I cannot put on flesh and gain more strength than I have.
('17', 245, 6, 17, 495215) I am making a mighty attack.
('17', 245, 6, 18, 495244) The doctors of course despair in face of the self imposed restrictions under which I am labouring.
('17', 245, 6, 19, 495343) I assure you that they have been my greatest consolation during this protracted illness.
('17', 245, 6, 20, 495432) I have no desire whatsoever to live upon condition of breaking those disciplinary and invigorating restrictions.
('17', 245, 6, 21, 495545) For me, although they restrict the body somewhat, they free the soul and they give me a consciousness of it which I should not otherwise possess.”You can’t serve God and Mammon” has a clearer and deeper meaning for me after those vows.
('17', 245, 6, 22, 495781) I do not infer that they are necessary for all, but they are for me.
('17', 245, 6, 23, 495850) If I broke them I feel that I should be perfectly worthless.
('17', 245, 6, 24, 495911) Do let me have an occasional line from you.
('17', 245, 7, 25, 495955) M. K. GANDHI
('17', 245, 8, 26, 495968) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.
('17', 245, 8, 27, 496014) Courtesy: Narayan Desai
