('17', 246, 1, 2, 496078) 236. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('17', 246, 2, 3, 496108) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, Kartak Vad 5 [November 23, 1918] 1
('17', 246, 3, 4, 496173) BHAISHRI HARILAL, I have your letter and the translation.
('17', 246, 3, 5, 496231) I am still confined to bed.
('17', 246, 3, 6, 496259) But I have gone through your corrections.
('17', 246, 3, 7, 496301) Once again I have to hurt you.
('17', 246, 3, 8, 496332) If I had been satisfied with your corrections, I would not have been so impudent as to reject the translation after it was printed.
('17', 246, 3, 9, 496464) But I withheld the publication of your translation only when I was convinced that your translation needed drastic changes.
('17', 246, 3, 10, 496587) It still retains what appear to me to be mistakes.
('17', 246, 3, 11, 496638) My complaint is that the translation cannot pass as good Gujarati.
('17', 246, 3, 12, 496705) This defect remains even after your corrections.
('17', 246, 3, 13, 496754) Lest I be unfair to you even unwittingly, I placed the translation before the teachers.
('17', 246, 3, 14, 496842) They went through it carefully and expressed the view that the Gujarati of the translation did not do justice to the original, that it did not convey the strict sense of the original, and the language appeared clumsy.
('17', 246, 3, 15, 497060) While they were going through the translation, an inmate of the Ashram having only passable familiarity with Gujarati was sitting by.
('17', 246, 3, 16, 497194) He was not aware of what the teachers were doing.
('17', 246, 3, 17, 497244) But when he heard the translation, he commented that he was not able to follow the Gujarati language.
('17', 246, 3, 18, 497346) Under these circumstances it seems only proper not to take the risk of publishing the translation as it is.
('17', 246, 3, 19, 497454) I had hoped that you would discard your translation and do it afresh.
('17', 246, 3, 20, 497524) Instead of going over the same translation thrice, if you had laboured as much over a fresh translation, both of us would have been satisfied.
('17', 246, 3, 21, 497667) But how could you do a fresh translation so long as you do not see the faults that we see in your translation?
('17', 246, 3, 22, 497778) I am returning you translation.
('17', 246, 3, 23, 497810) After I recover, if you can spend a few days at the Ashram, we shall go over the translation together and I shall give my comments.
('17', 246, 3, 24, 497942) I naturally wish that you should be able to see the faults in it.
('17', 246, 3, 25, 498008) I felt sad for a moment when I learnt that your family were afflicted with influenza and there was even a death.
('17', 246, 3, 26, 498121) But such news is pouring in from everywhere so that now the mind is hardly affected.
('17', 246, 4, 27, 498206) From a copy of the Gujarati: S.N. 19990
('17', 246, 5, 28, 498246) 1 The year has been inferred from the reference to Gandhiji’s illness.

('17', 247, 1, 2, 498359) 237. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('17', 247, 2, 3, 498389) [AHMEDABAD,] November 26, 1918
('17', 247, 3, 4, 498420) HARILAL, I gave you some news about myself yesterday.
('17', 247, 3, 5, 498474) I give you more today.
('17', 247, 3, 6, 498497) My health is both good and bad.
('17', 247, 3, 7, 498529) I feel that the improvement which should have taken place in some respects has not come about.
('17', 247, 3, 8, 498624) I cannot complain about food now.
('17', 247, 3, 9, 498658) Everyone says that it would be better for me to go out for some time, and I also think I should.
('17', 247, 3, 10, 498755) I have been, therefore, thinking of doing so, and am making arrangements.
('17', 247, 3, 11, 498829) It will be good if you come over before I leave.
('17', 247, 3, 12, 498878) Whatever you wish to say, you may pour out before me without any hesitation.
('17', 247, 3, 13, 498955) If you cannot give vent to your feelings before me, before whom else can you do so?
('17', 247, 3, 14, 499039) I shall be a true friend to you.
('17', 247, 3, 15, 499072) What would it matter if there should be any difference of opinion between us about any scheme of yours?
('17', 247, 3, 16, 499176) We shall have a quiet talk.
('17', 247, 3, 17, 499204) The final decision will rest with you.
('17', 247, 3, 18, 499243) I fully realize that your state at present is like that of a man dreaming.
('17', 247, 3, 19, 499318) Your responsibilities have increased, your trials have increased and your temptations will increase likewise.
('17', 247, 3, 20, 499428) To a man with a family, the fact of being such, that is, having a wife, is a great check.
('17', 247, 3, 21, 499518) This check over you has disappeared.
('17', 247, 3, 22, 499555) 1 Two paths branch out from where you stand now.
('17', 247, 3, 23, 499604) You have to decide which you will take.
('17', 247, 3, 24, 499644) There is a bhajan we often sing in the Ashram; its first line runs: Nirbalke bala Rama.
('17', 247, 4, 25, 499732) One cannot pray to God for help in a spirit of pride but only if one confesses oneself as helpless.
('17', 247, 4, 26, 499832) As I lie in bed, every day I realize how insignificant we are, how very full of attachments and aversions, and what evil desires sway us.
('17', 247, 4, 27, 499970) Often I am filled with shame by the unworthiness of my mind.
('17', 247, 4, 28, 500031) Many a time I fall intodespair because of the attention my body craves and wish that it should perish.
('17', 247, 4, 29, 500134) From my condition, I can very well judge that of others.
('17', 247, 4, 30, 500191) I shall give you the full benefit of my experience; you may accept what you can.
('17', 247, 4, 31, 500272) All this after you come.
('17', 247, 4, 32, 500297) Blessings from
('17', 247, 5, 33, 500312) BAPU [From Gujarati]

('17', 248, 1, 2, 500540) 238. REPLIES TO QUESTIONS ON MONTAGU CHELMSFORD SCHEME [December, 1918]
('17', 248, 2, 3, 500612) In the Hindustan, a Gujarati daily published at Bombay, a writer has addressed
('17', 248, 3, 4, 500691) the following open questions to Mahatma Gandhi:
('17', 248, 4, 5, 500739) (I) On behalf of Gujarat you sent a monster petition 1 to Mr. Montagu in which you asked for certain rights for India.
('17', 248, 4, 6, 500858) Does the Montagu Chelmsford Scheme fall short of those rights or not?
('17', 248, 5, 7, 500928) (2) If it does fall short, why is it that you did not attend the special Congress 2
('17', 248, 6, 8, 501012) to support the demand for granting these rights?
('17', 248, 7, 9, 501061) (3) If you believe that the Montagu Chelmsford Scheme satisfies the Indian public, why did you not attend the Moderate Conference 3?
('17', 248, 8, 10, 501194) To those questions, Mr. Gandhi has sent the following replies: (I) All the rights asked for in the Congress League Scheme 4 are not conceded in the Montagu Chelmsford Scheme.
('17', 248, 8, 11, 501369) (2) I did not attend the Special Congress, because I had differences of opinion on certain principles with the leaders and under such circumstances I thought it improper to place my views from the Congress platform.
('17', 248, 8, 12, 501585) As I did not want to convey even my dumb acceptance of the matters in dispute, I chose to remain absent.
('17', 248, 8, 13, 501690) (3) Just as I had differences of opinion on principles with the Extremist leaders, so I had differences with the Moderate leaders also.
('17', 248, 8, 14, 501826) And so I thought it proper not to attend their Conference, too.
('17', 248, 8, 15, 501890) Here I cannot enter into discussion as to what is my difference of opinion on the principles, because that is acomplicated subject.
('17', 248, 8, 16, 502022) That I am on sick bed is sufficient reason for my refusing discussion about my personal opinion.
('17', 248, 9, 17, 502119) The Indian Review, December, 1918 quoting The New Times
('17', 248, 10, 18, 502175) 1 Vide “Petition to E. S. Montagu”, before 13 9 1917.
('17', 248, 11, 19, 502229) 2 The special session of the Indian National Congress held at Bombay in August September, 1918, under the presidentship of Syed Hasan Imam
('17', 248, 12, 20, 502368) 3 Of November, 1918
('17', 248, 13, 21, 502388) 4 Of 1916

('17', 251, 6, 11, 505233) 244. LETTER TO ESTHER FAERING
('17', 251, 7, 12, 505263) BOMBAY, 1918
('17', 251, 8, 13, 505276) MY DEAR ESTHER 1, This is my first attempt to write after the relapse.
('17', 251, 8, 14, 505347) Though I am not quite clear about your course of duty, I suppose it is as well that you responded to Mr. Andrews’ appeal 2. I myself doubt the utility of your going there.
('17', 251, 8, 15, 505519) Your letters to follow will make this point clear.

('17', 252, 1, 2, 506263) 245. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('17', 252, 2, 3, 506292) January 6, 1919 I suppose I must get used to having ups and downs and not feel any the worse for them, because it appears that before I have done with this protracted illness I am likely still to have many ups and downs.
('17', 252, 2, 4, 506513) Just at the present moment I seem to be all right.
('17', 252, 2, 5, 506564) The hypodermic injections to which I thought I must reconcile myself are producing the expected results.
('17', 252, 2, 6, 506669) They are intended to whet my appetite and I must confess that my food today is the envy of a gourmand, both as to quantity and quality.
('17', 252, 2, 7, 506805) But no one knows when I may have a set back.
('17', 252, 2, 8, 506850) I dare say a careful observer could even cast a table and prognosticate the next relapse and the others to follow.
('17', 252, 2, 9, 506965) I am under the hands of a very eminent doctor.
('17', 252, 2, 10, 507012) He wants to give 15 injections out of which he has given four.
('17', 252, 2, 11, 507075) The prospect before me is therefore by no means very pleasant and the needle pricks are decidedly unpleasant.
('17', 252, 2, 12, 507185) What are we not prepared to bear in order that we may live?
('17', 252, 2, 13, 507245) I observe that the Bishop of Calcutta is dead.
('17', 252, 2, 14, 507292) It must be a great wrench for you, but I suppose it is well that he is free from pain.
('17', 252, 2, 15, 507379) So far as my convenience is concerned your having sent Miss Faering to Bolpur was all right.
('17', 252, 2, 16, 507472) But I did consider your action impulsive.
('17', 252, 2, 17, 507514) As you assure me that she entirely filled your place I can have nothing more to say.
('17', 252, 2, 18, 507599) But I felt upon Miss Faering’s letter that she could not very well take the higher English classes, or for that matter, even the lower classes at Shantiniketan.
('17', 252, 2, 19, 507760) I suppose there is nothing insurm ountable for one possessing the faith that Miss Faering does abundantly and she has succeeded where thousands would have failed.
('17', 252, 2, 20, 507923) Has she taken her discharge from the Danish Mission, because you talk of her coming to me after her finishing Bolpur.
('17', 252, 2, 21, 508041) If she has got her discharge without causing any bad feeling, it is a great thing.
('17', 252, 2, 22, 508124) I am in Bombay at least up to the 15th.
('17', 252, 2, 23, 508164) I shall then have to consider the propriety of my going to Colombo.
('17', 252, 2, 24, 508232) You need not worry about my election as a Congress delegate.
('17', 252, 2, 25, 508293) I have not come to any final conclusion.
('17', 252, 2, 26, 508334) When the actuality faces me, I know that the way will be as clear to me as the blue skies.
('17', 252, 2, 27, 508425) I am, therefore,”careful for nothing”.
('17', 252, 2, 28, 508464) I am not anxious to go as a deputee, but I shall not avoid the task if I must perform it.
('17', 252, 2, 29, 508554) I hope you are doing well.

('17', 254, 1, 2, 510224) 248. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('17', 254, 2, 3, 510255) [BOMBAY,] January 10, 1919 These days, I have been thinking so much about all sorts of things that I often feel a strong urge to share some of my thoughts with you all.
('17', 254, 2, 4, 510424) But, thanks to physical weakness and mental torpor, I can neither write nor dictate.
('17', 254, 2, 5, 510509) Today I cannot help dictating.
('17', 254, 2, 6, 510540) In the changes I am making at present, my atman bears witness that I am showing no weakness.
('17', 254, 2, 7, 510633) I am making them with a detached mind and out of my strength, the main purpose being to satisfy all of you and the other friends.
('17', 254, 2, 8, 510763) I simply cannot bear to look at Ba’s face.
('17', 254, 2, 9, 510806) The expression is often like that on the face of a meek cow and gives one the feeling, as a cow occasionally does, that in her own dumb man ner she was saying something.
('17', 254, 2, 10, 510976) I see, too, that there is selfishness in this suffering of hers; even so, her gentleness overpowers me and I feel inclined to relax in all matters in which I possibly may.
('17', 254, 2, 11, 511148) Only four days ago, she was making herself miserable about milk, and, on the impulse of the moment, asked me why, if I might not take cow’s milk, I would not take goat’s milk.
('17', 254, 2, 12, 511324) This went home.
('17', 254, 2, 13, 511340) When I took the vow, I was not thinking of the goat at all.
('17', 254, 2, 14, 511400) I knew nothing, then, about the use of goat’s milk and it was not a goat’s suffering which was so vividly before my mind.
('17', 254, 2, 15, 511522) My vow related only to cow’s milk.
('17', 254, 2, 16, 511557) I was not thinking about the buffalo either.
('17', 254, 2, 17, 511602) But taking buffalo’s milk would kill my chief aim [in taking the vow].
('17', 254, 2, 18, 511673) It was different with goat’s milk, and I felt I could relieve friends of much of their concern.
('17', 254, 2, 19, 511769) I, therefore, decided to take goat’s milk.
('17', 254, 2, 20, 511812) Though, from one point of view, my vow does not retain its full value, now that I know all about goat’s milk, it does not lose its value altogether.
('17', 254, 2, 21, 511961) Be that as it may, I am glad the thing is over and done with, for friends’ agony was increasing day by day and Dr. Mehta kept bombarding me with telegrams.
('17', 254, 2, 22, 512117) There is no difference between cow’s milk and goat’s milk, if the goat is well looked after.
('17', 254, 2, 23, 512210) It is even on record that in England the goat’s milk is richer than the cow’s.
('17', 254, 2, 24, 512289) The milk from our goats is considered lighter, but this is an advantage rather than otherwise.
('17', 254, 2, 25, 512384) Be the fact of the matter what it is, I have done all I could.
('17', 254, 2, 26, 512447) I even let the doctor to inject arsenic, strychnine and iron.
('17', 254, 2, 27, 512509) If my health does not come round after all this, we certainly cannot say that it will if I give up the vow [restricting me to the use] of no more than five articles [a day].
('17', 254, 2, 28, 512683) No one, therefore, has anything now to complain of.
('17', 254, 2, 29, 512735) We shall have to be patient and watch what effect all these changes have.
('17', 254, 2, 30, 512809) Though I have allowed myself this
('17', 255, 0, 1, 512843) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 255, 1, 2, 512885) freedom, my conscience does not, for a single moment, cease asking me,”Why all this labour?”,”What would you do with life?”,”What is it you would so much exert yourself to reform?” When I think of the plight of Germany’s Kaiser, I feel as if a great Being were playing with us as we play with cowries.
('17', 255, 1, 3, 513187) We are infinitely smaller, in relation to the globe on which we move, than the ants moving on a ball are in relation to that ball and like them, ever ignorant, we press forward and get crushed.
('17', 255, 1, 4, 513381) Despite such thoughts, I have not even a moment’s doubt about our duty.

('17', 264, 2, 3, 531696) [January 27, 1919]
('17', 264, 3, 4, 531715) The Hon’ble Mr. Gokhale’s work in connection with the issue of indenture reveals his single minded devotion better than his other activities do.
('17', 264, 3, 5, 531860) His tour of South Africa 2 and the agitation he subsequently carried on in India give us a very good idea of his ability to identify himself with the work on hand.
('17', 264, 3, 6, 532024) It is because of this ability of his that I have often said that one could see an underlying religious impulse in all his work.
('17', 264, 4, 7, 532152) Let us go over his work in South Africa in some detail.
('17', 264, 4, 8, 532208) When he announced his intention of paying a visit to South Africa, there was a commotion in the official circles in India.

('17', 264, 4, 12, 532506) While yet in England, Gokhale had a foretaste of what he might expect in South Africa.
('17', 264, 4, 13, 532593) He asked for a ticket but the officials of the Union Castle company would not oblige.
('17', 264, 4, 14, 532679) The report reached India Office.
('17', 264, 4, 15, 532712) The latter issued premptory instructions to Sir Owen Tudor, manager of the company, that Gokhale should be treated with the respect due to hisstatus.
('17', 264, 4, 16, 532862) In the event, Gokhale was able to go on the ship like an honoured guest.
('17', 264, 4, 17, 532935) He told me, when describing the incident:”I was not very particular about respect to me as an individual, but the honour of my nation is dear to me as my very life and, since I was going on this occasion in my public capacity, I felt that any insult to me would be an insult to India, and hence I tried to secure for me facilities in keeping with my status.” The wiser for this incident, India Office had seen to it through the Colonial Office that Gokhale should also be properly received in South Africa and the Union Government had made advance arrangements for the purpose.
('17', 264, 4, 18, 533513) They kept a saloon ready for him and also provided a cook to accompany him on his tour.
('17', 264, 4, 19, 533601) An officer was detailed to look after him.
('17', 264, 4, 20, 533644) The Indian community, on its part, had made arrangements to accord him more than royal honours.

('17', 271, 4, 18, 548121) 263. SUMMARY OF LETTER TO SHANKARLAL BANKER
('17', 271, 5, 19, 548165) [Before February 2, 1919]
('17', 271, 6, 20, 548191) Under the joint auspices of the Bombay branches of the Home Rule League, a public meeting was held on February 2, 1919, at Shantaram’s Chawl, Bombay, to protest against the introduction of the Criminal Law Amendment Bill and the Criminal Law Emergency Powers Bill, Pt. Madan Mohan Malaviya presiding.
('17', 271, 6, 21, 548492) A letter from Gandhiji addressed to Mr. Shankarlal Banker, Secretary of the Home Rule League, was read out to the meeting by Mr. Jamnadas Dwarkadas.
('17', 271, 7, 22, 548641) In the course of his letter, he felt that the Rowlatt Committee 1 Report afforded not the slightest warrant for the proposed Bills, and that it was their duty to educate public opinion to oppose the Bills with patience and firm determination.
('17', 271, 7, 23, 548884) If the Rowlatt Bills were passed into law, the Reforms, whatever their value, would be absolutely worthless.
('17', 271, 7, 24, 548993) It was absurd to find on one side the enlargement of the powers of the public and, on the other, to put unbearable restraints on their powers.
('17', 271, 7, 25, 549136) If he were not ill, he would surely have done his share in the agitation against the Bills.
('17', 271, 8, 26, 549228) The Bombay Chronicle, 4 2 1919
('17', 271, 9, 27, 549259) 1 Appointed by the Government of India in 1917 with Justice Rowlatt of the Supreme Court of Judicature in England as president, to investigate and report on the sedition movement in India.
('17', 271, 9, 28, 549448) Its recommendations were published in 1918 soon after the publication of the Montford Reforms, and favoured the enactment of special measures after the Defence of India Act had ceased to operate.

('17', 273, 1, 2, 551062) 266. LETTER TO NARAHARI D. PARIKH
('17', 273, 2, 3, 551096) BOMBAY, Basant Panchami, [February 5] 1 1919
('17', 273, 3, 4, 551141) DEAR NARAHARI, I have your letter.
('17', 273, 3, 5, 551176) Even though we are meeting on Monday, I am writing to you so that you can do some more thinking.
('17', 273, 3, 6, 551273) Accor ding to you, giving a literal meaning to a vow amounts to special pleading.
('17', 273, 3, 7, 551355) I do not agree, because I am not aware of any special pleading at all.
('17', 273, 3, 8, 551426) I gave it the meaning that with the utmost humility and purity of mind I thought it bore.
('17', 273, 3, 9, 551516) Moreover, I also feel that our too strict adherence to the words of the scriptures was not entirely special pleading, but an admission of the fact that men are strong as well as weak.
('17', 273, 3, 10, 551700) For a man of strength, the literal meaning as well as the implied meaning was kept.
('17', 273, 3, 11, 551784) For a man given to weakness, the literal meaning was considered sufficient, and the significance of vows was retained.
('17', 273, 3, 12, 551903) One cannot find fault with this by saying that hypocrites would stand to gain by this.
('17', 273, 3, 13, 551990) The scriptures were written with such people in view.
('17', 273, 3, 14, 552044) Any loophole in a vow indicates the uniqueness and completeness of the vow.
('17', 273, 3, 15, 552120) Mere abstention from milk 2 does notserve the purpose for which the vow had been taken.
('17', 273, 3, 16, 552208) One must either prove that one can live without milk or find a substitute for milk.
('17', 273, 3, 17, 552292) And I shall continue my efforts to find a substitute for milk.
('17', 273, 3, 18, 552355) 3 Even if I die in my search without succeeding it will not matter; because, if I am fated to be born again, I shall re enter the world with the same desires with which I die.
('17', 273, 3, 19, 552531) In writing all this, I am trying to show that under some circumstances, even if we give up the implied meaning of a vow and stick only to the literal meaning, we will have followed the vow perfectly.
('17', 273, 3, 20, 552731) The basis is the same.
('17', 273, 3, 21, 552754) Those who follow both the literal and the implied meaning of a vow would no doubt occupy a higher place.
('17', 273, 3, 22, 552859) Those who follow the literal meaning will have to be content with being at the ground
('17', 273, 4, 23, 552945) 1 The source has “January”.
('17', 273, 4, 24, 552973) However, in 1919, Basant Panchami fell on February 5.
('17', 273, 5, 25, 553027) 2 Gandhiji had taken a vow at the Tolstoy Farm in 1912 to abstain from milk and milk products; vide “An Autobiography—Part IV, chapter XXX”.
('17', 273, 6, 26, 553168) 3 After the very serious attack of dysentery in August, Gandhiji was not able to recover his strength.
('17', 273, 6, 27, 553271) He had been writing to friends to find a substitute for milk.
('17', 273, 6, 28, 553333) Vide “Letter to P.C. Ray”, 27 8 1918 and “Letter to Narahari Parikh”, 27 1 1919.
('17', 274, 0, 1, 553414) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 275
('17', 274, 1, 2, 553454) But a person living at Matheran can take full advantage of the place even if he lives in a hut.
('17', 274, 1, 3, 553550) Similarly a person following the literal meaning can find the strength which comes from the observance of a vow.
('17', 274, 1, 4, 553663) Consider all this, and when there is leisure, cross examine me fully without any hesitation.
('17', 274, 1, 5, 553756) It is possible that wittingly or unwittingly I am being partial to the step I have taken.

('17', 277, 1, 2, 558785) 270. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER
('17', 277, 2, 3, 558811) February 6, 1919 From the experience of these two days I find that when I recite the verses in solitude, it has greater effect for my peace of mind.
('17', 277, 2, 4, 558960) I want you to have the same joy which I find in reciting Sanskrit verses.
('17', 277, 2, 5, 559034) Just as we cannot do without food and sleep, so also we cannot do without what is food for the soul—the morning and evening prayers.
('17', 277, 2, 6, 559167) Let us understand and follow this.
('17', 277, 2, 7, 559202) 1 We cannot respect the wishes of a person uttered while he is half asleep or when he is under the influence of drink or drug.
('17', 277, 2, 8, 559329) We serve him by refusing his wishes.
('17', 277, 2, 9, 559366) In the same way, we must not bow to the wishes of a man who is a prey to attachment.
('17', 277, 2, 10, 559451) I think Surendra is in such a state of mind at present.
('17', 277, 2, 11, 559507) It is my duty to shake him out of it, even if I have to administer him a shock for the purpose.
('17', 277, 2, 12, 559603) I know that the exper ience will be painful to him for a while but, when he is ultimately free from his attachment, he will understand why I restrained him and see that it was for his good.
('17', 277, 2, 13, 559793) My plan, in the last analysis, respects everyone’s freedom, for always what 1 say is entirely by way of advice.
('17', 277, 2, 14, 559905) When my associates take up any activity which does not appeal to me, they may expect no encouragement from me but they can do as they wish.
('17', 277, 2, 15, 560045) If you have followed what I have said and appreciate it, have a talk with Surendra and console him.
('17', 277, 3, 16, 560145) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 6425

('17', 278, 3, 12, 561799) 272. LETTER TO MADAN MOHAN MALAVIYA
('17', 278, 4, 13, 561835) BOMBAY, Saturday, Magh Sud 8 [February 8, 1919]
('17', 278, 5, 14, 561883) DEAR BROTHER, I read all the speeches on the Rowlatt Bills today.
('17', 278, 5, 15, 561949) I was much distressed.
('17', 278, 5, 16, 561972) The Viceroy’s speech is disappointing.
('17', 278, 5, 17, 562011) Under the circumstances, I hope, at any rate, that all the Indian members will leave the Select Committee or, if necessary, even the Council, and launch a countrywide agitation.
('17', 278, 5, 18, 562189) You and other members have said that if the Rowlatt Bills are passed a massive agitation would be launched the like of which has not beep seen in India.
('17', 278, 5, 19, 562342) Mr. Lowndes 1 said that the Government were not afraid of the agitation that is going on.
('17', 278, 5, 20, 562432) He is right.
('17', 278, 5, 21, 562445) Even if you held a hundred thousand meetings all over India what difference would it make?
('17', 278, 5, 22, 562536) I am not yet fully decided but I feel that when the Government bring in an obnoxious law the people will be entitled to defy their other laws as well.
('17', 278, 5, 23, 562687) If we do not now show the strength of the people, even the reforms we are to get will be useless.
('17', 278, 5, 24, 562785) In my opinion you should all make it clear to the Government that so long as the Rowlatt Bills are there you will pay no taxes and will advise the people also not to pay them.
('17', 278, 5, 25, 562961) I know that to give such advice is to assume a great responsibility.
('17', 278, 5, 26, 563030) But unless we do something really big
('17', 278, 6, 27, 563068) 1 Sir George Lowndes, Law Member, Government of India
('17', 279, 0, 1, 563122) 280 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 279, 1, 2, 563164) they will not feel any respect for us.
('17', 279, 1, 3, 563203) And we cannot hope to get anything from people who do not respect us.
('17', 279, 1, 4, 563273) What the Viceroy has said about the Civil Service and about British trade does not seem right to me.
('17', 279, 1, 5, 563374) The power of the Civil Service must be drastically curtailed.
('17', 279, 1, 6, 563436) And it is certain that the protection the British are giving to their trade will not be available to it after India becomes independent.
('17', 279, 1, 7, 563573) Today they enjoy far more rights than we do.
('17', 279, 1, 8, 563618) Tomorrow I go to the Ashram.

('17', 279, 3, 11, 563718) 273. LETTER FO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('17', 279, 4, 12, 563756) BOMBAY, February 9, 1919
('17', 279, 5, 13, 563781) DEAR MR. SASTRIAR, I have just read your forcible speech on the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 279, 5, 14, 563860) This is none too strong.
('17', 279, 5, 15, 563885) The Bills coupled with the Viceroy’s, Sir William Vincent’s and Sir George Lowndes’ speeches have stirred me to the very depths; and though I have not left my bed still, I feel I can no longer watch the progress of the Bills lying in the bed.
('17', 279, 5, 16, 564128) To me, the Bills are the aggravated symptoms of the deep seated disease.
('17', 279, 5, 17, 564201) They are a striking demonstration of the determination of the Civil Service to retain its grip of our necks.
('17', 279, 5, 18, 564310) There is not the slightest desire to give up an iota of its unlimited powers and if the Civil Service is to retain its iron rule over us and if the British commerce is to enjoy its present unholy and privileged position, I feel that the Reforms will not be worth having.
('17', 279, 5, 19, 564581) I consider the Bills to be an open challenge to us.
('17', 279, 5, 20, 564633) If we succumb we are done for.
('17', 279, 5, 21, 564664) If we may prove our word that the Government will see an agitation such that they have never witnessed before, we shall have proved our capacity for resistance to autocracy or tyrannical rule.
('17', 279, 5, 22, 564857) When petitions [and] resolutions of gigantic mass meetings fail, there are but two courses open—the ordinary rough and ready course is an armed rebellion, and the second is civil disobedience to all the laws of the land or to a selection of them.
('17', 279, 5, 23, 565104) If the Bills were but a stray example of lapse of righteousness and justice, I should not mind them but when they are clearly an evidence of a determined policy of repression, civil disobedience seems to be a duty imposed upon every lover of personal and public liberty.
('17', 279, 5, 24, 565375) I wrote
('17', 280, 0, 1, 565383) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 281
('17', 280, 1, 2, 565423) yesterday to Panditji 1 suggesting on the part of all the Indian members or so many of them as would do so resignation of their positions on the Select Committee and a resignation of their positions even on the Council, if they would take the latter step also.
('17', 280, 1, 3, 565684) I think their resignations will shake the Government’s confidence in its ability to disregard public sentiment, and will be an education of great value to the people.
('17', 280, 1, 4, 565851) For myself if the Bills were to be proceeded with, I feel I can no longer render peaceful obedience to the laws of a power that is capable of such a piece of devilish legislation as these two Bills, and I would not hesitate to invite those who think with me to join me in the struggle.
('17', 280, 1, 5, 566137) It is possible that you will not see eye to eye with me in the position I wish to take up.
('17', 280, 1, 6, 566228) But I know that you would not like me to stifle what may be to me the voice of conscience.
('17', 280, 1, 7, 566319) Naturally I would like to secure the approbation of the very few friends whose advice I value.
('17', 280, 1, 8, 566414) If, therefore, you have the time, I would like you to drop me a line telling me what you think about my contemplated step.
('17', 280, 1, 9, 566537) I want to give this assurance that I shall do nothing in haste and I shall do nothing without giving a previous confidential warning couched in as gentle language as I can command.
('17', 280, 1, 10, 566718) I hope you will keep sound health during the very critical times that are ahead of us.

('17', 285, 4, 10, 574330) 281. ADDRESS TO ASHRAM INMATES
('17', 285, 5, 11, 574361) February 17, 1919 The inmates are satisfied with nothing in the Ashram.
('17', 285, 5, 12, 574433) The reason?
('17', 285, 5, 13, 574445) Dissatisfaction over Maganlal’s ideas and conduct, over his manner of speaking and over a certain partiality in his actions.
('17', 285, 5, 14, 574570) Lack of faith in the Ashram on the part of others, those in the school.
('17', 285, 5, 15, 574642) What is my position in these circumstances?
('17', 285, 5, 16, 574686) I must place before you some strict principles.
('17', 285, 5, 17, 574734) I have not invited the ladies, but they, too, feel disgusted, and are thinking of leaving.
('17', 285, 5, 18, 574825) I have told them that they will not get anywhere else what they have gained here.
('17', 285, 5, 19, 574907) You may remain in the Ashram only if you think you can put up with all that life here means.
('17', 285, 5, 20, 575000) So think well before you decide to remain or leave.
('17', 285, 5, 21, 575052) Why do you stick on here des pite your dissatisfaction?
('17', 285, 5, 22, 575108) Surely, none of you is too weak to leave.
('17', 285, 5, 23, 575150) It is, then, out of your love for me and blind attachment to me.
('17', 285, 5, 24, 575215) The first principle, then, which emerges is that to be attached to a person apart from his work is blind attachment.
('17', 285, 5, 25, 575332) I knew persons in South Africa who were blindly attached to me.
('17', 285, 5, 26, 575396) I made it clear to them that, if they found Phoenix 1, which was my creation, of no worth, then I, too, had none.
('17', 285, 5, 27, 575510) If they lacked faith in my creation, then, naturally, they were bound to lose faith in me as well.
('17', 285, 5, 28, 575609) I am a good judge of men but I cannot prove this to you just now.
('17', 285, 5, 29, 575675) Nevertheless, if you have no faith in the Ashram, if you are dissatisfied with it, you had better leave it.
('17', 285, 5, 30, 575783) Only those of you may remain who have joined it to give
('17', 285, 6, 31, 575839) 1 The Phoenix Settlement near Durban founded by Gandhiji in association with his co workers and European friends in 1904. ('17', 287, 2, 14, 579956) 282. MESSAGE ON GOKHALE ANNIVERSARY

('17', 288, 1, 2, 580725) 283. LETTER TO J. L. MAFFEY 1
('17', 288, 2, 3, 580755) SABARMATI, February 20, 1919
('17', 288, 3, 4, 580784) As I am not still quite out of the wood regarding my health and as, if am to obey doctors’ orders, I must not undertake any activity requiring considerable exertion, I thought I would refrain from such activity till I was better.
('17', 288, 3, 5, 581014) But the events that have recently happened impel me to submit the following for His Excellency’s consideration: I feel tempted to write about the Rowlatt Bills, but I am check ing myself for the moment and awaiting the course of the Bills and the agitation about them in the country.
('17', 288, 3, 6, 581298) I wish to confine myself today to a matter that specially interests me—the case of the Brothers Ali.
('17', 288, 3, 7, 581399) You will recall that I made a submission about them on the New Year’s day of 1917 2. Though the Viceroy may not feel inclined to interfere in the matter, he should know the present position from the popular standpoint.
('17', 288, 3, 8, 581618) After the exchange of the final letters between us, I entered into correspondence with Sir William Vincent.
('17', 288, 3, 9, 581726) The result was that a Committee to advise the Government about the Brothers was appoin ted.
('17', 288, 3, 10, 581818) This Committee has duly reported to the Government but so far as I am aware, although nearly two months have elapsed after the submission of the Committee’s Report, the Government’s decision has not yet been pronounced.
('17', 288, 3, 11, 582038) I wrote to Sir William Vincent about it on the 12th instant.
('17', 288, 3, 12, 582099) I have been informed on behalf of the Brothers that from the manner in which they are being treated in the matter of their requests for visits to certain places for urgent business and other circumstances, they infer that the decision is likely to be adverse to them.
('17', 288, 3, 13, 582367) I have read most of the correspondence between the Brothers and the Committee.
('17', 288, 3, 14, 582446) I have read the communication em bodying the charges against them.
('17', 288, 3, 15, 582513) I have read their reply.
('17', 288, 3, 16, 582538) I must assume that the memorandum of charges supplied to the Brothers was exhaustive.
('17', 288, 3, 17, 582624) The impression left upon my mind is that the Brothers have been inter ned and subjected to numerous hardships without the slightest justification.
('17', 288, 3, 18, 582771) The charges in my humble opinion did not warrant
('17', 288, 4, 19, 582820) 1 Private secretary to the Viceroy
('17', 288, 5, 20, 582855) 2 This is obviously slip for “1918”.
('17', 289, 0, 1, 582892) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 289, 1, 2, 582934) action under the Defence of India Act.
('17', 289, 1, 3, 582973) I submit that under a free Government they would hold in it a prominent position instead of being treated as a danger to it.
('17', 289, 1, 4, 583098) They are brave, perfectly straightforward, they are out spoken, God fearing, and able men, commanding the respect alike of the Mahomedans and the Hindus.
('17', 289, 1, 5, 583252) It would be difficult to find throughout India better specimens of joint Hindu and Mahomedan culture.
('17', 289, 1, 6, 583354) In a position which to them is exasperating, they have evinced wonderful self restraint and patience.
('17', 289, 1, 7, 583456) Their very virtues seem to have been regarded as an offence.

('17', 289, 1, 9, 583551) I must disclose one fact to Lord Chelmsford although it hurts my sense of modesty.
('17', 289, 1, 10, 583634) They have ever since the meeting of the Muslim League at Calcutta in the December of 1917 implicitly accepted the advice I tendered to them, and so have the leading Mahomedans, who would, but for my advice, gladly have carried on a powerful and embarrassing agitation long ere this.
('17', 289, 1, 11, 583917) I advised them that if relief was not granted, satyagraha—I abhor the expression”passive resistance”, as it very incompletely expresses the grand truth conveyed by the easily understood Sanskrit word”satya graha”—should be resorted to.
('17', 289, 1, 12, 584153) I assured them that I was in commu nication with the Government about the Brothers’ release.
('17', 289, 1, 13, 584246) As a satyagrahi, I told them that before engaging in a public agitation about it, we should know the Government side of the question, and we should exhaust all milder remedies and be able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of impartial observers the untenability of the Government position before embarking on satyagraha in which, once it is undertaken, there is no turning back.
('17', 289, 1, 14, 584626) I feel thankful to the Brothers and to the gentlemen, with whom it has been a privilege to be associated, that they have abided by my advice, though the delay has almost reached a dangerous point.
('17', 289, 1, 15, 584823) I do must earnestly trust that the Government will by releasing the Brothers prevent a powerful agitation in the country.
('17', 289, 1, 16, 584945) I shall anxiously await your reply.
('17', 289, 1, 17, 584981) I hope that you are enjoying the best of health and it would so please me to learn from you that Lord Chelmsford is keeping good health in spite of the great strain under which, I know, he is working.
('17', 289, 1, 18, 585182) With kind regards,

('17', 295, 4, 4, 595899) THE MOST WORTHY FIRM OF SATYAGRAHIS 1
('17', 295, 5, 5, 595937) Just as I was about to start this letter, I had to hold a court.
('17', 295, 5, 6, 596002) The accused was Rasik, and the complainant an innocent dog.
('17', 295, 5, 7, 596062) The latter declared by his wailing that he had been assaulted by som eone.
('17', 295, 5, 8, 596137) I discovered that the guilty party was Rasik.
('17', 295, 5, 9, 596183) The accused admitted his guilt and confessed previous offences as well.
('17', 295, 5, 10, 596255) I thought of Lord Krishna and Shishupal.
('17', 295, 5, 11, 596296) Shri Krishnachandra had forgiven a hundred 2
('17', 295, 6, 12, 596341) offences, of the latter.
('17', 295, 6, 13, 596366) And so the court had compassion and forgave the accused, Rasik, five offences, warning him at the same time that, if he repeated the offence again, it would not be forgiven and that he would be made to realize, in his own person, the dog’s suffering when stoned.
('17', 295, 6, 14, 596629) As I write this, Kantilal is holding the inkstand.
('17', 295, 6, 15, 596680) He and Ramibehn read the letter as I proceed and correct me.
('17', 295, 6, 16, 596741) The accused, too, is here, meekly standing by the bed.
('17', 295, 6, 17, 596796) Manubai interrupts now and then to give us the benefit of her laughter.
('17', 295, 6, 18, 596868) And now she has started crying, wanting to climb up the bed.

('17', 296, 1, 2, 597450) 288. THE SATYAGRAHA PLEDGE 1
('17', 296, 2, 3, 597479) AHMEDABAD,
('17', 296, 3, 4, 597490) February 24, 1919
('17', 296, 4, 5, 597508) Being conscientiously of opinion that the Bills known as the Indian Criminal Law (Amendment) Bill No.
('17', 296, 4, 6, 597610) I of 1919 and the Criminal Law (Emergency Powers) Bill No.
('17', 296, 4, 7, 597669) II of 1919 are unjust, subversive of the principle of liberty and justice, and destructive of the elementary rights of individuals on which the safety of the community as a whole and the State itself is based, we solemnly affirm that, in the event of these Bills becoming law and until they are withdrawn, we shall refuse civilly to obey these laws and such other laws as a Committee 2 to be hereafter appointed may think fit and we further affirm that in this struggle we will faithfully follow truth and refrain from violence to life, person or property.
('17', 296, 4, 8, 598226) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI, SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM SABARMATI VALLABHBHAI J. PATEL, BAR AT LAW, AHMEDABAD CHANDULAL MANILAL DESAI, L.D.S., AHMEDABAD KESARIPRASAD MANILAL THAKOOR, AHMEDABAD (BEHN) ANASUYABAI SARABHAI, SECRETARY, WOMEN’S BRANCH OF THE HOME RULE LEAGUE, AHMEDABAD AND OTHERS New India, 3 3 1919
('17', 296, 5, 9, 598529) 1 The pledge was drafted on 24 2 1919 and signed by those present at a meeting held at Sabarmati Ashram.
('17', 296, 6, 10, 598634) 2 For laws selected by this Committee for disobeying vide “Statement on Laws for Civil Disobedience”, 7 4 1919.
('17', 297, 0, 1, 598746) 298 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 297, 1, 2, 598788) 289. TELEGRAM TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO VICEROY
('17', 297, 2, 3, 598834) AHMEDABAD, February 24, I919
('17', 297, 3, 4, 598863) EVER SINCE PUBLICATION ROWLATT BILLS HAVE BEEN CONSIDERING MY POSITION REGARDING THEM.
('17', 297, 3, 5, 598950) HAVE BEEN CON FERRING WITH FRIENDS.
('17', 297, 3, 6, 598986) IN MY OPINION BAD IN THEMSEL VES BILLS ARE BUT SYMPTOM OF DEEP SEATED DISEASE AMONG THE RULING CLASS, COMING AS THEY DO ON EVE REFORMS BILLS AUGUR ILL FOR THEIR SUCCESS.
('17', 297, 3, 7, 599156) THOSE WHO HAVE BEEN ASSOCIATED WITH ME IN PUBLIC WORK AND OTHER FRIENDS MET TODAY AND AFTER THE GREATEST DELIBERATION HAVE DECIDED TO OFFER SATYAGRAHA AND COMMIT CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE OF SUCH LAWS AS COMMITTEE TO BE FORMED FROM OURSELVES MAY DECIDE.
('17', 297, 3, 8, 599403) AFTER SIR GEORGE LOWN DES’ SPEECH IT IS NECESSARY TO DEMONSTRATE TO GOVERNMENT THAT EVEN A GOVERNMENT THE MOST AUTOCRATIC FINALLY OWES ITS POWER TO THE WILL OF THE GOVERNED.
('17', 297, 3, 9, 599577) WITHOUT RECOGNI TION OF THIS PRINCIPLE AND CONSEQUENTLY WITH DRAWAL BILLS MANY OF US CONSIDER REFORMS VALUELESS.

('17', 299, 9, 13, 602168) 294. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS February 25, 1919
('17', 299, 10, 14, 602215) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have telegraphed to you today.
('17', 299, 10, 15, 602265) I could not write the letter that I contemplated doing when I sent my first wire.
('17', 299, 10, 16, 602347) I have been passing through perfect agony, doctors telling me that I should not undertake any exertion, the voice within me telling me that I must speak out on the Rowlatt Bills and the Viceregal pronouncement.
('17', 299, 10, 17, 602558) Conflicting views pressed themselves on me and I did not know what to do.
('17', 299, 10, 18, 602632) Many friends have looked to me for guidance.
('17', 299, 10, 19, 602677) How could I desert them?
('17', 299, 10, 20, 602702) We met yesterday at the Ashram.
('17', 299, 10, 21, 602734) It was a good meeting.
('17', 299, 10, 22, 602757) The desire was to take the plunge even if we were only a few.
('17', 299, 10, 23, 602819) The last word rested with me.
('17', 299, 10, 24, 602849) I felt that the cause was true.
('17', 299, 10, 25, 602881) Was I to forsake them?
('17', 299, 10, 26, 602904) I could not do so and remain true to myself.
('17', 299, 10, 27, 602949) You know the result.
('17', 299, 10, 28, 602970) The papers herewith will give you fuller information.
('17', 299, 10, 29, 603024) God only knows how I felt the need of your presence whilst the soul was in travail.
('17', 299, 10, 30, 603108) I am now quite at peace with myself.
('17', 299, 10, 31, 603145) The telegram to the Viceroy eased me considerably.
('17', 299, 10, 32, 603196) He has the warning.
('17', 299, 10, 33, 603216) He can stop what bids fare to become a mighty conflagration.
('17', 299, 10, 34, 603277) If it comes, and if the satyagrahis remain true to their Pledge, it can but purify the atmosphere and bring in real swaraj.
('17', 299, 10, 35, 603401) Have you noticed an unconscious betrayal of the true nature of modern civilization in Mr. Wilson’s 1 speech explaining the League of Nations’ covenant?
('17', 299, 10, 36, 603553) 2 You will remember his saying that if
('17', 299, 11, 37, 603592) 1 Thomas Woodrow Wilson (1856 1924); 28th President of the United States of America

('17', 300, 1, 2, 603798) the moral pressure to be exerted against a recalcitrant party failed, the members of the League would not hesitate to use the last remedy, viz., brute force.
('17', 300, 1, 3, 603956) The Pledge is a sufficient answer to the doctrine of force.
('17', 300, 1, 4, 604016) But this does not close the chapter.
('17', 300, 1, 5, 604053) I have received a long cablegram 1 from Mr. Aswat.

('17', 303, 8, 21, 610782) SIR, The cable received by me from Mr. Aswat, Chairman of the Transvaal British Indian Association, and given below, shows that a revival of satyagraha with all the attendant sufferings is imminent in
('17', 303, 9, 22, 610983) 1 This was published under the caption “Ill treatment of Indians in South Africa” in The Bombay Chronicle.
('17', 303, 9, 23, 611090) The Amrita Bazar Patrika, 28 2 1919 and New India, 27 2 1919 also published it.
('17', 304, 0, 1, 611170) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 305
('17', 304, 1, 2, 611211) South Africa, unless the danger that threatens to overwhelm the Indians of the Transvaal is averted by prompt and effective action by the Government of India, and if necessary, by the public also.
('17', 304, 1, 3, 611408) 1 The situation warrants a repetition of Lord Hardinge’s action 2, and the immediate despatch to South Africa of a mission consisting of, say, a distinguished civilian, and an equally distinguished Indian publicist.
('17', 304, 2, 4, 611624) What is the situation?
('17', 304, 2, 5, 611647) The Precious and Base Metals Act referred to in the cable affects the gold area of the Transvaal in the largest part of its Indian population.
('17', 304, 2, 6, 611790) Krugersdorp is an important town near Johannesburg, and contains many Indian merchants, some of them owning stock probably worth 3 lakhs of rupees.
('17', 304, 2, 7, 611938) If no relief is provided, it means ruin for the merchants and for those residing in the whole of the gold area.
('17', 304, 2, 8, 612050) The goal of the Union Government seems to be, as has been openly declared by several Union statesmen, to reduce its Indian settlers to the position of hewers of wood and drawers of water.
('17', 304, 2, 9, 612238) It is possible that the Court’s interpretation is correct.
('17', 304, 2, 10, 612297) If so, the Act itself must be changed and the Indian community must be saved, not merely because of their status as British subjects, but also because of the Passive Resistance Settlement of 1914, which protects vested or existing rights.

('17', 305, 0, 1, 614232) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 305, 1, 2, 614274) The judgment is a direct attack upon Indian liberty in pursuance of the policy referred to by me.
('17', 305, 1, 3, 614372) The Government want further to harass the community throughout the Union by refusing facilities for conservation of its present Indian population.
('17', 305, 1, 4, 614519) They cannot remain in it, if they may not receive occasional visitors, if, on the death of a propertied man, his trusted relatives may not enter the Union in order to administer his affairs.
('17', 305, 1, 5, 614710) I can understand the dominant community in South Africa not wishing to have an unlimited influx of people alien to them in civilization.
('17', 305, 1, 6, 614847) But it is impossible to understand a policy of ruthless extermination, side by side, with a profession of loyalty to a common Empire.
('17', 305, 1, 7, 614981) Moreover, this refusal to issue temporary permits is a breach of the Settlement.
('17', 305, 1, 8, 615062) It has been all along understood that temporary permits would be granted, whenever the necessity arose.
('17', 305, 1, 9, 615166) Surely nobody could question it in the late Mr. Mahommed Essak’s case quoted by Mr. Aswat in his cablegram.
('17', 305, 1, 10, 615274) The reference to the late Mr. Gokhale in this connection is a libel on a sacred name.
('17', 305, 1, 11, 615360) After the termination of the interview, Mr. Gokhale came directly to the hotel where we were staying.
('17', 305, 1, 12, 615462) I had the privilege of being his secretary and he related to me the whole of the conversation between ministers and himself and there was not a word about his having consented to the stoppage of temporary permits under any circumstances whatsoever.
('17', 305, 1, 13, 615711) He had no authority to enter into any agreement.
('17', 305, 1, 14, 615760) He went only to learn and to plead.
('17', 305, 1, 15, 615796) Your readers will recall that at the historic meeting field in Bombay upon his return from South Africa, he declared publicly that he had no authority to negotiate a settlement and that he had agreed to nothing.
('17', 305, 1, 16, 616008) As representing the Indian community, I was party to the Settlement of 1914. If any such agreement had been made, surely it would at least have formed part of the many discussions between General Smuts and myself.
('17', 305, 1, 17, 616222) It is worthy of note that General Smuts is not now in South Africa.
('17', 305, 1, 18, 616290) If he was asked, I doubt not that he would repudiate Colonel Shaw’s allegation.
('17', 305, 1, 19, 616370) The cablegram adds that there are many other harassments going on throughout the Union.
('17', 305, 1, 20, 616458) We are supposed to be on the eve of embarkation upon Reforms that are to eventuate in the near future in full Responsible Government.
('17', 305, 1, 21, 616592) What answer has India to give to Mr. Aswat’s pathetic appeal?
('17', 305, 1, 22, 616654) The hundred thousand Indians of the Union have a right to look up to the Government of India and the people for the protection of their elementary rights.
('17', 305, 2, 23, 616809) Yours, etc.,
('17', 305, 3, 24, 616822) GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 27 2 1919
('17', 306, 0, 1, 616861) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 307
('17', 306, 1, 2, 616902) 300. SUMMARY OF ROWLATT BILLS
('17', 306, 2, 3, 616932) [Before February 26, 1919] 1
('17', 306, 3, 4, 616961) These Bills have come to be known as the Black Bills.
('17', 306, 3, 5, 617015) A strong agitation has been going on against them all over India and the Bills have been felt to be so oppressive that satyagraha has been started against them.
('17', 306, 3, 6, 617176) Several men and women have taken the Satyagraha Pledge.
('17', 306, 3, 7, 617232) A body known as the Satyagraha Sabha has been formed and the people in general have also been advised to take this Pledge.
('17', 306, 3, 8, 617355) The pledge commits the satyagrahi to sacrifice his all for his honour.
('17', 306, 3, 9, 617426) People who take such an extreme Pledge and those advising them to do so must have strong reasons for acting as they do.
('17', 306, 3, 10, 617546) The satyagrahis have declared in their Pledge that these Bills are unjust, that they are subversive of the principle of the liberty of the subject and destructive of the elementary rights of an individual.
('17', 306, 3, 11, 617752) It is necessary to prove to the people the propriety of these adjectives and the evidence must be in the Bills themselves—so that [they may see how] submission to laws which deserve such epithets is forfeiting one’s humanity and accepting slavery, and those who form such an impression after going through the summary below owe it as a duty to sign the Satyagraha Pledge.
('17', 306, 3, 12, 618124) It is a summary of the Bills, with those Sections omitted which are irrelevant for the purpose of our criticism and whose omission does no injustice to the Government, and with those Sections printed in black type which we have felt to be especially oppressive.
('17', 306, 3, 13, 618386) Both the Bills are before the Legislature and have been named in the Gazette Bill No.
('17', 306, 3, 14, 618472) 1 and Bill No.
('17', 306, 3, 15, 618487) 2 of 1919. Bill No.
('17', 306, 3, 16, 618507) 2, as its preamble suggests, goes further than the ordinary criminal law.
('17', 306, 3, 17, 618581) This second Bill seems to us to be the more dangerous of the two and a summary of it is therefore given first.
('17', 306, 4, 18, 618692) SUMMARY OF BILL NO.
('17', 306, 4, 19, 618712) 2 OF 1919
('17', 306, 5, 20, 618722) The object of the Bill is to make provision that the ordinary criminal law should be supplemented and emergency powers should be exercisable by the Government for the purpose of dealing with dangerous situations.
('17', 306, 5, 21, 618935) The Government has obtained the previous approval of the Secretary of State in Council in England for enacting this law.
('17', 306, 6, 22, 619056) 1 Vide reference in the following item.
('17', 307, 0, 1, 619096) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 307, 1, 2, 619138) Section 1. This Bill may be called The Criminal Law Emergency Powers Bill.
('17', 307, 1, 3, 619213) It extends to the whole of India.
('17', 307, 2, 4, 619247) SOME NOTEWORTHY SECTIONS
('17', 307, 3, 5, 619272) [Section 3.] If the Governor General in Council is satisfied that offences of a certain character 1 are prevalent in the whole or any part of India and that, in the interest of public safety, it is necessary to provide for speedy trial of such offences, he may, by notification in the Gazette [of India], bring this Act into force in the area specified in the notification.
('17', 307, 3, 6, 619646) Section 4. Where the Local Government is of opinion that any person should be tried in accordance with the provisions of this Act, it may order any officer of the Government to prefer a written information to the Chief Justice against that person.
('17', 307, 3, 7, 619894) Such order may be made in respect of any [scheduled] offence even if such offence was committed before the issue of the notification in the Gazette bringing the Act into force in a particular area.
('17', 307, 3, 8, 620092) The information shall state the offence charged and, so far as known, the name, place of residence, and the time and place when and where the offence is alleged to have been committed and all particulars within the knowledge of the prosecuting officer so that the accused might know the offence he is charged with.
('17', 307, 3, 9, 620407) The Chief Justice may by order require any information to be amended so as to supply further particulars and such information or amended information shall be served upon the accused.
('17', 307, 3, 10, 620590) Section 5 provides that, upon such information being served, the Chief Justice shall nominate three of the High Court Judges for the trial of the information.
('17', 307, 3, 11, 620749) Section 6. The court may sit at such place or places in the Province as it may consider desirable, though the Governor General in Council has the power, by a notification, to order the transfer of the trial to any other place if considered necessary in the interest of justice.
('17', 307, 3, 12, 621027) Section 9. After the charge is framed, the accused shall be entitled to ask for an adjournment for a period not exceeding ten days.
('17', 307, 3, 13, 621159) Section 10 provides that the court is bound to arrange for the

('17', 308, 1, 2, 621298) evidence of each witness to be recorded only in summary.
('17', 308, 1, 3, 621355) Comment : Even a layman will readily see that recording only the summary of evidence can lead to serious miscarriage of justice.
('17', 308, 1, 4, 621484) No judge can know in advance, before all the witnesses have been examined, what weight to attach to which part of evidence.
('17', 308, 1, 5, 621608) Section 11. The court, if it is of opinion that such a course is necessary in the public interest or for the protection of a witness, may prohibit or restrict the publication or disclosure of its proceedings or any part thereof.
('17', 308, 1, 6, 621837) Section 12. No questions shall be put by the court to the accused until the close of the case for the prosecution.
('17', 308, 1, 7, 621952) Thereafter, and before the accused enters on his defence, the court shall inform the accused that he is entitled, if he so desires, to give evidence on oath on his own behalf, and shall at the same time inform him that if he does so he will be liable to cross examination.
('17', 308, 1, 8, 622225) If the accused states that he desired to give evidence on oath, the court may put any question to him the reply to which may prove his guilt.
('17', 308, 1, 9, 622367) Section 14 provides that in the event of any difference of opinion among the members of the court, the opinion of the majority shall prevail.
('17', 308, 1, 10, 622509) Section 15. If in the course of the trial, the accused is discovered to have committed any offences other than the one he is charged with, he may be charged with and convicted of these as well.
('17', 308, 1, 11, 622703) Section 17. The judgment of the court shall be final and conclusive and no High Court shall have authority to revise any order or sentence of the court.
('17', 308, 2, 12, 622856) PART II
('17', 308, 3, 13, 622864) Section 20. If the Governor General in Council is satisfied that movements which, in his opinion, are likely to lead to the commission of offences against the State are being promoted in the whole or any part of India, he may, by a notification, bring the provisions of this Part into effect in the area specified in it.
('17', 308, 3, 14, 623185) Section 21. Where, in the opinion of the Local Government, there are reasonable grounds for believing that any person is or has been actively concerned in any movement of the nature referred to above, it may give all or any of the following directions: That such person

('17', 309, 1, 2, 623497) (a) shall execute a bond for good conduct for a period not exceeding one year; (b) shall remain or reside in any area specified in the order; (c) shall notify his residence and any change of residence as ordered; (d) shall abstain from any act which, in the opinion of the Local Government, is calculated to disturb the public peace or is prejudicial to the public safety; (e) shall report himself to such police officer and at such periods as may be specified in the order.
('17', 309, 1, 3, 623972) Comment: Under this Section, an order of this kind may be passed against any person merely on suspicion and without a trial.
('17', 309, 1, 4, 624097) Section 23. Any officer [authorized by the Government] may use all means reasonably necessary to enforce compliance with an order as above.
('17', 309, 1, 5, 624237) Section 24. An order issued under Section 21 above shall continue in force for a period of one month only.
('17', 309, 2, 6, 624344) Section 25. When the Local Government makes an order as above, such Government shall, as soon as may be, forward to the investigating authority to be constituted under this Act a concise statement in writing setting forth all particulars relevant to the order and the grounds for making it.
('17', 309, 3, 7, 624635) The investigating authority shall then hold an inquiry in camera, summon the person in question at some stage in its proceedings and hear any explanation he may have to offer, provided that the investigating authority shall not disclose to the person any fact the communication of which might endanger the public safety or the safety of any individual, and provided further that neither the Local Government nor the person in question shall be entitled to be represented at such inquiry by a pleader.
('17', 309, 3, 8, 625136) The inquiry shall be conducted in such manner as the investigating authority considers best suited to elicit the facts of the case and, in making the inquiry, such authority shall not be bound to observe the rules of the law of evidence.
('17', 309, 3, 9, 625374) On completion of the inquiry, the investigating authority shall report its conclusions to the Local Government.

('17', 310, 1, 3, 625763) Section 26. On receipt of the report of the investigating authority, the Local Government may discharge the order made by it or may make any other order which it is authorized to make; any order so made shall recite the conclusions of the investigating authority and a copy of the order shall be furnished to the person in question.
('17', 310, 1, 4, 626096) No order made by the Local Government shall continue in force for more than one year, provided that, on the expiry of the order, it may make another order if it is satisfied that such a course is necessary in the interests of public safety.
('17', 310, 1, 5, 626337) No order made as herein provided shall continue in force for more than a year from the date on which it was made, though on the expiry of such an order the Local Government may renew it for a further period of one year.
('17', 310, 1, 6, 626557) An order may also be discharged at any time by the Local Government, or altered or substituted by any other order without reference to the investigating authority mentioned above.
('17', 310, 1, 7, 626737) Comment: This means that the Local Government may issue any order at its discretion and that even the nominal investigating authority will serve no useful purpose.
('17', 310, 2, 8, 626901) Section 27. Any person who fails to comply with an order as above shall be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to a thousand rupees, or with both.
('17', 310, 3, 9, 627114) Section 29. The investigating authority shall consist of three persons of whom one shall be a person having held a judicial office not inferior to that of a District and Sessions Judge and one shall be a person not in the service of the Government.
('17', 310, 3, 10, 627363) Section 30. The Local Government shall appoint Visiting Committees to interview the persons under restraint at specified periods and shall by rules prescribe the functions of such committees.
('17', 310, 4, 11, 627555) PART III

('17', 311, 1, 4, 628505) The arrest of such a person may be effected at any place where he may be found by any police officer or any other officer to whom the order may be directed.
('17', 311, 1, 5, 628662) An order for confinement of a person or the search of a place may be carried out by any officer to whom it may be directed and such officer may use all reasonable means for enforcing the same.

('17', 312, 3, 5, 630492) BILL NO.
('17', 312, 3, 6, 630501) 1 OF 1919
('17', 312, 4, 7, 630511) The object of this Bill is to amend the Indian Penal Code and the Criminal Procedure Code so as to put effective curbs on activities dangerous to the State.
('17', 312, 4, 8, 630668) It creates a new offence, as under: Any person found in possession of a seditious document or intending to publish or circulate such document will, unless he proves that it was in his possession for a lawful purpose, be punishable with imprisonment extending to a period of two years or with fine, or with both.
('17', 312, 4, 9, 630980) In this Section, a seditious document is defined as a document containing any writing or sign inciting violence against the Crown or its Government or against officers or any class of officers or any individual officer in the service of the Government, or inciting anyone to wage war against the Crown or to assemble weapons with the intention of waging such war.
('17', 312, 5, 10, 631344) Comment: This means that, if any book or paper believed to be seditious is found in the pocket of an innocent youth ignorant of its contents, he would be taken to be guilty unless he proves that he was carrying it for a lawful purpose.
('17', 312, 5, 11, 631580) This new offence alters one of the fundamental principles of British justice inasmuch as, instead of the prosecution having to prove the guilt of the accused, it is the latter who will have to establish his innocence.
('17', 312, 5, 12, 631798) If I am charged with anything, how can I prove that I am not guilty?
('17', 312, 5, 13, 631867) This can only mean that I shall be in jail.
('17', 312, 6, 14, 631911) When trying offences against the State mentioned in the Indian Penal Code, the court is free to order, if it thinks fit, that the accused, even after he has served the sentence of imprisonment passed on him, should execute a bond of good conduct for two years thereafter.
('17', 312, 6, 15, 632183) Any person who, having been served with a restraint order, under the provisions of this Bill, to report, subsequent to his release, his place of residence and any change therein, may be directed by the Local
('17', 313, 0, 1, 632391) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 313, 1, 2, 632433) Government by an order in writing to abide by any of the following conditions: (a) the person in question must not enter or reside or stop in any specified area; (b) he should confine himself to a particular part of British India; (c) he must not address any public meeting called to discuss issues which might lead to breach of the peace or public excitement or to circulate any written or printed information relating to such issues or to extend support to any political matter.
('17', 313, 1, 3, 632914) Comment: This means that, even after a person has suffered eno ugh for an alleged offence, he may not expect to be free from harassment by the Government.
('17', 313, 2, 4, 633069) ALTERATIONS MADE BY SELECT COMMITTEE 1
('17', 313, 3, 5, 633108) Its report was published on March 1. We list below the important changes which follow from the part of the report which has received the approval of a majority.
('17', 313, 3, 6, 633269) It has not been signed by the Hon’ble Pandit Malaviya, the Hon’ble Vithalbhai Patel and the Hon’ble Mr. Khaparde.
('17', 313, 3, 7, 633383) The Hon’ble Mr. Surendranath Banerjea, the Hon’ble Mr. Shastriar and the Hon’ble Mr. M. Shafi have appended a minute of dissent in which they have suggested several important changes.
('17', 313, 3, 8, 633567) The Committee points out that, though it has made a few changes in Bill No.
('17', 313, 3, 9, 633643) 2, it has hesitated to alter its basic principles.
('17', 313, 3, 10, 633694) If at all, they can be altered only by the Imperial Legislative Council.
('17', 313, 3, 11, 633767) The Bill, in its original form, was intended to be a permanent measure; the Committee has recommended that it be limited to three years.
('17', 313, 3, 12, 633904) The Bill, in its original form, applied to any type of scheduled offence.
('17', 313, 3, 13, 633978) The Select Committee has recommended that it should apply only to the offences of waging war and inciting rebellion against the State.
('17', 313, 3, 14, 634113) Section 9 of the draft Bill enabled the accused to ask for an adjournment of ten days; this has now been changed to 14 days.
('17', 313, 3, 15, 634238) Under Section 10, the Judge was required to record a summary of the evidence.
('17', 313, 3, 16, 634316) Now the evidence will have to be recorded in full
('17', 313, 4, 17, 634366) 1 What follows was evidently added after March 1.
('17', 314, 0, 1, 634416) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 315
('17', 314, 1, 2, 634457) either by the Judge or by a clerk appointed by him.
('17', 314, 1, 3, 634509) Section 12 will be so amended that, if the accused declines to tender evidence himself, the advocate for the prosecution will not be permitted to comment on the fact.
('17', 314, 1, 4, 634676) Under Section 21, the Government is authorized to demand a bond of good conduct without showing any reason.
('17', 314, 1, 5, 634784) Now it will be required to state the reason and make out a case.
('17', 314, 1, 6, 634849) Under Section 23, the officer was authorized to use any means.
('17', 314, 1, 7, 634912) Now, he will not be able to employ unreasonable force.
('17', 314, 1, 8, 634967) Section 25 lays down what may be adduced against the accused.
('17', 314, 1, 9, 635029) In the draft Bill it appeared to give freedom to the Government to adduce any facts it chose.
('17', 314, 1, 10, 635123) This will now be amended so that the Government will be able to adduce only such facts as are relevant to the case.
('17', 314, 1, 11, 635239) Under Section 26, the accused could be detained for a period extending to three years.
('17', 314, 1, 12, 635326) Now the Government will have power to do so for a period extending to two years and the case will have to be referred to the investigating authority on every occasion.
('17', 314, 1, 13, 635494) Section 33 seemed to imply that the accused could even be confined with the ordinary criminals.
('17', 314, 1, 14, 635590) It is now made clear that he will have to be kept apart.
('17', 314, 1, 15, 635647) In Section 34, the period for which the accused could be held in custody without orders from the Government has been fixed at seven days.
('17', 314, 1, 16, 635785) In Section 40, the period of one month has been reduced to 21 days.
('17', 314, 1, 17, 635853) Comment: It must be admitted that the alterations suggested by the Select Committee do effect some improvements in the original Bill but they leave the basic principle of the Bill untouched, and the Bill can be used to harass people so much that, as the Hon’ble Mr. Shastriar has pointed out, even the members of the new Councils with enlarged powers which are to come into being will tremble while making any comments and be able to avail themselves of their nominal freedom only by turning themselves flatterers.
('17', 314, 1, 18, 636368) If this is true as regards members of the Legislature, what will be the condition of the defenceless, ignorant people?
('17', 314, 1, 19, 636487) It is the duty of every thinking Indian to save the people from this danger, a duty one can discharge only by offering satyagraha.
