('17', 315, 1, 2, 636695) 301. INSTRUCTIONS TO VOLUNTEERS
('17', 315, 2, 3, 636727) February 26, 1919 1
('17', 315, 3, 4, 636747) The following instructions to satyagraha volunteers have been issued by the Committee of the Sabha to be strictly followed in taking signatures.
('17', 315, 4, 5, 636892) SPECIAL INSTRUCTIONS
('17', 315, 5, 6, 636913) Volunteers shall read and explain the Satyagraha Pledge to every intending signatory before taking his signature to the vow.
('17', 315, 5, 7, 637038) The Pledge is in three parts: The first lays down the objects of the Pledge.
('17', 315, 5, 8, 637115) It declares that the signatories are of opinion that the Rowlatt Bills are “unjust, subversive of the principle of liberty and justice, and destructive of the elementary rights of individuals”.
('17', 315, 5, 9, 637309) In order to be able to make this statement one must fully understand the Rowlatt Bills, hence it is the duty of the volunteers to explain the Bills clearly to the intending signatory.
('17', 315, 5, 10, 637493) The vow forms the second part of the Pledge.
('17', 315, 5, 11, 637538) Here the signatory solemnly affirms that he will refuse civilly to disobey certain laws.
('17', 315, 5, 12, 637627) Volunteers must explain to the signatory the full significance of the word “civilly”.
('17', 315, 5, 13, 637713) For instance, to break moral laws is not civil disobedience.
('17', 315, 5, 14, 637774) Nor is it civil disobedience to be discourteous to officials with whom one may have to deal, while disobeying laws.
('17', 315, 5, 15, 637890) On the other hand the possession and distribution to the public of literature proscribed by Government and which one sincerely believes to be harmless, would be civil disobedience.
('17', 315, 5, 16, 638071) Volunteers must explain to the would be signatory with the help of such illustrations the full significance of the Pledge.
('17', 315, 5, 17, 638194) Volunteers must explain to every intending signatory that he must be prepared to bear every kind of suffering and to sacrifice, if necessary, both his person and property.
('17', 315, 5, 18, 638366) He should also be made to understand that he must be prepared to carry on the struggle single handed even if left alone.
('17', 315, 5, 19, 638487) The volunteer must accept the signature only after satisfying himself that the signatory is prepared to take all these risks.
('17', 315, 5, 20, 638613) The third part of the Pledge declares that the satyagrahi will during the struggle, fearlessly adhere to truth and ahimsa for instance
('17', 315, 6, 21, 638748) 1 Vide Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('17', 316, 0, 1, 638776) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 317
('17', 316, 1, 2, 638817) he must not misrepresent anything or hurt anybody’s feelings.
('17', 316, 1, 3, 638879) Volunteers must urge upon people necessity of fully realizing the grave responsibility of adhering to truth and ahimsa before signing the Pledge.
('17', 316, 1, 4, 639025) Volunteers must not speak of things they do not understand and must not hold out false hopes to anybody.
('17', 316, 1, 5, 639130) If they find themselves unable to explain anything, they must consult the Committee or refer the would be signatory to it.
('17', 316, 1, 6, 639253) Ahimsa includes advesha.
('17', 316, 1, 7, 639278) Volunteers therefore must never resort to unfair criticism of the movement.
('17', 316, 1, 8, 639354) If in performing their duties they are obstructed by the police or others, they must not lose their temper but must courteously explain to those opposing them, their (volunteers’) duty and their determination under any circumstances to perform the same.
('17', 316, 2, 9, 639608) GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS
('17', 316, 3, 10, 639629) 1. Every volunteer taking signatures has to remember that a single intelligent recruit to satyagraha is worth a hundred signatories who have not realized their responsibility.
('17', 316, 3, 11, 639805) Volunteers must therefore never aim at merely increasing the number of signatories.
('17', 316, 3, 12, 639889) 2. The volunteer shall have to carefully read and understand the summary 1 of the Rowlatt Bills published by the Sabha 2 and must explain the same to such would be signatories as have not read the Bills or the summary.
('17', 316, 3, 13, 640108) 3. In explaining the Pledge the volunteer must lay due emphasis upon the fact that the real strength, the true test of the satyagraha, lies in his capacity to bear pain and must warn the signatory that resort to satyagraha may lead to loss of personal liberty and property and ask him to sign the Pledge only if he is prepared for these sacrifices.
('17', 316, 3, 14, 640457) If the volunteer is then convinced that the would be signatory has made up his mind he will take his signature.
('17', 316, 3, 15, 640569) 4. Volunteers must not accept the signatures of persons under 18 and students.
('17', 316, 3, 16, 640648) And even in the case of those over 18 he must make sure that the signatory has decided after careful consideration.
('17', 316, 3, 17, 640764) Volunteers must not induce persons to sign, upon whose earnings their families are solely dependent for their maintenance.
('17', 316, 3, 18, 640887) 5. After taking the signature, the volunteer must himself take down the designation and full address of the signatory in neat and legible
('17', 316, 4, 19, 641025) 1 Vide the preceding item.
('17', 316, 5, 20, 641052) 2 The words “published by the Sabha” do not occur in the Gujarati version of the instructions in Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('17', 317, 0, 1, 641170) 318 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 317, 1, 2, 641212) handwriting.
('17', 317, 1, 3, 641225) If the signature is not legible the volunteer should copy it down neatly.
('17', 317, 1, 4, 641299) He must note the date on which the signature is taken.
('17', 317, 1, 5, 641354) 6. The volunteer must attest every signature.
('17', 317, 2, 6, 641400) The Bombay Chronicle 12 3 1919; also Young India, 12 3 1919
('17', 317, 3, 7, 641460) 302. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON SATYAGRAHA PLEDGE
('17', 317, 4, 8, 641506) [February 26, 1919] 1
('17', 317, 5, 9, 641528) I enclose herewith the Satyagraha Pledge regarding the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 317, 5, 10, 641598) The step taken is probably the most momentous in the history of India.
('17', 317, 5, 11, 641669) I give my assurance that it has not been hastily taken.
('17', 317, 5, 12, 641725) Person ally I have passed many a sleepless night over it.
('17', 317, 5, 13, 641783) I have weighed the consequences of the act.
('17', 317, 5, 14, 641827) I have endeavoured duly to appreciate Government’s position.
('17', 317, 5, 15, 641888) But I have been unable to find any justifi cation for the extraordinary Bills.
('17', 317, 5, 16, 641967) I have read the Rowlatt Committee’s Report.
('17', 317, 5, 17, 642011) I have gone through its narrative with admiration.
('17', 317, 5, 18, 642062) Its reading has driven me to conclusions just the opposite of the Committee’s.
('17', 317, 5, 19, 642141) I should conclude from the Report that secret violence is confined to isolated and very small parts of India, and to a microscopic body of people.
('17', 317, 5, 20, 642288) The existence of such men is truly a danger to society.
('17', 317, 5, 21, 642344) But the passing of the Bills designed to affect the whole of India and its people arms the Government with powers, out of all proportion to the situation sought to be dealt with, is a greater danger and the Commit tee utterly ignore the historical fact that the millions in India are by nature the gentlest on earth.
('17', 317, 5, 22, 642661) Now look at the setting of the Bills.
('17', 317, 5, 23, 642699) Their introduction is accom panied by certain assurances given by the Viceroy regarding the Civil Service and the British commercial interests.
('17', 317, 5, 24, 642843) Many of us are filled with the greatest misgivings about the Viceregal utterance.
('17', 317, 5, 25, 642925) I frankly confess I do not understand its full scope and intention.
('17', 317, 5, 26, 642993) If it means that the Civil Service and the British commercial interests are to be held superior to those of India and its political and commercial requirements, no Indian can accept the doctrine.
('17', 317, 5, 27, 643189) It can but end in a fratricidal struggle within the Empire.
('17', 317, 5, 28, 643249) Reforms may or may not come.
('17', 317, 5, 29, 643278) The need of the moment is a proper and just understanding upon this vital issue.
('17', 317, 5, 30, 643359) No tinkering with it will produce real satisfaction.
('17', 317, 5, 31, 643412) Let the great Civil Service Corporation understand that it can remain in India
('17', 317, 6, 32, 643491) 1 Vide Mahadevbhai ki Diary, Part I.
('17', 318, 0, 1, 643528) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 319
('17', 318, 1, 2, 643569) only as its trustee and servant not in name but in deed and let the British commercial houses understand that they can remain in India only to supplement her requirements and not to destroy indigenous art, trade and manufacture, and you have two measures to replace the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 318, 1, 3, 643854) They, I promise, will successfully deal with any cons piracy against the State.
('17', 318, 1, 4, 643934) Sir George Lowndes simply added fuel to the fire when he flouted public opinion.
('17', 318, 1, 5, 644015) He has forgotten his Indian history or he would have known that the Government he represents has before now surrendered its own considered opinion to the force of public opinion.
('17', 318, 1, 6, 644194) It will be now easy to see why I consider the Bills to be an un mistakable symptom of a deep seated disease in the governing body.
('17', 318, 1, 7, 644325) It needs, therefore, to be drastically treated.
('17', 318, 1, 8, 644373) Subterranean violence will be the remedy applied by impetuous hot headed youths who will have grown impatient of the spirit underlying the Bills and the circums tances attending their introduction.
('17', 318, 1, 9, 644571) The Bills must intensify the hatred and ill will against the State of which the deeds of violence are undoubtedly an evidence.
('17', 318, 1, 10, 644698) The Indian covenanters by their determin ation to undergo every form of suffering make an irresistible appeal for justice to the Government towards which they bear no ill will and provide to the believers in the efficacy of violence as a means of securing redress of grievances with an infallible remedy, and withal a remedy that blesses those that use it and also those against whom it is used.
('17', 318, 1, 11, 645094) If the covenanters know the use of this remedy, I fear no ill from it.
('17', 318, 1, 12, 645165) I have no business to doubt their ability.
('17', 318, 1, 13, 645208) They must ascertain whether the disease is sufficiently great to justify the strong remedy, and whether all milder ones have been tried.
('17', 318, 1, 14, 645345) They have convinced themselves that the disease is serious enough, and that milder measures have utterly failed.
('17', 318, 1, 15, 645458) The rest lies in the lap of the gods.

('17', 319, 1, 2, 645603) 303. LETTER TO ‘‘THE INDIAN SOCIAL REFORMER”
('17', 319, 2, 3, 645648) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, February 26, 1919
('17', 319, 3, 4, 645689) TO THE EDITOR THE INDIAN SOCIAL REFORMER
('17', 319, 4, 5, 645730) SIR, I have read the paragraph in your issue of the 23rd instant 1
('17', 319, 5, 6, 645797) about the Patel Marriage Bill.
('17', 319, 5, 7, 645828) I have never yet given an interview to anybody on the Bill, and the views attributed to me represent but a partial truth.
('17', 319, 5, 8, 645950) Being laid up in bed, I had not taxed myself about the Bill, but having been asked by several people to express my opinion, I began to study the Bill, and as is my wont, I tried first to understand the author’s position.
('17', 319, 5, 9, 646171) The Hon.
('17', 319, 5, 10, 646180) Mr. Patel told me there was no occasion for me to be in a hurry to form my views, as the Bill was not likely to come up for discussion before September, and in order to help me to study the Bill, he sent Mr. Daftari to me.
('17', 319, 5, 11, 646403) Mr. Daftari has supplied me with a long and exhaustive memorandum on the subject.
('17', 319, 5, 12, 646485) I have not yet been able to study it, and with the present programme of work before me, I do not know when I shall be able to study the memorandum which requires looking up old law cases.
('17', 319, 5, 13, 646673) My position,
('17', 319, 6, 14, 646686) 1 In this issue, The Indian Social Reformer had quoted from a despatch of the Ahmedabad correspondent of The Bombay Chronicle in which the correspondent had written: “He (Mr. Gandhi) sees no objection in inter marriages among the sub castes of the Brahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya and Sudra communities.
('17', 319, 6, 15, 646985) There would, he held, be an infusion of fresh vigour among the present degenerate Rajputs if inter marriages were frequent among the Rajputs, Bhatias, Lohanas and Patidars.
('17', 319, 6, 16, 647158) There can conceivably be nothing wrong if inter marriages among the Modh and Srimali Bania communities were the rule rather than the exception, but on no account should the existing (sic) fourfold division be broken through.
('17', 319, 6, 17, 647383) It is desirable to weld together the four main castes comprising twenty crores of Hindus, by neutralizing the centrifugal tendencies at present separating the various sub castes in any main caste.
('17', 319, 6, 18, 647580) Mr. Gandhi said, subject to the above modification, the Hon.
('17', 319, 6, 19, 647641) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya had promised his whole hearted support when the Inter Caste Marriage Bill would be referred to the Select Committee in the Imperial Legislative Council.
('17', 319, 6, 20, 647822) In conclusion, Mahatma Gandhi pointed out how a wide chasm yawned between the Brahmin and the Dhed and warned the ardent advocates of marriage reform against short cuts to progress.”
('17', 320, 0, 1, 648005) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 321
('17', 320, 1, 2, 648046) so far as I can state it, without the aforementioned study, is this: In my opinion, the question specially as between Brahmins and Dheds 1 does not arise in this connection at all.
('17', 320, 1, 3, 648227) Dheds stand in the same relation to Brahmins as Kshatriyas, Vaishyas or Shoodras.
('17', 320, 1, 4, 648309) Their peculiar disability is not affected either one way or the other by the Bill.
('17', 320, 1, 5, 648392) If the Bill constitutes an attack upon Varnashram, as a believer in Varna shram dharma, I should oppose it.
('17', 320, 1, 6, 648500) I am told by orthodox friends that it does constitute such an attack.
('17', 320, 1, 7, 648570) I am told by the supporters of the Bill that not only does it not interfere with Varnashram, but it merely seeks to restore the pre British state of Hindu Law, which was wrongly interpreted by judges, who being ignorant of it, were guided by biassed or corrupt Pandits.
('17', 320, 1, 8, 648840) Both sides have very able lawyers.
('17', 320, 1, 9, 648875) Without deciding one way or the other, I have suggested that the effect of the Bill should be restricted to inter marriages among sub castes.
('17', 320, 1, 10, 649017) This might satisfy the most ardent reformer at least as a first step, and would enable men like the Hon.
('17', 320, 1, 11, 649122) Pandit Malaviya to support it.
('17', 320, 3, 12, 649153) Yours, etc.,
('17', 320, 4, 13, 649166) M. K. GANDHI
('17', 320, 5, 14, 649179) The Indian Social Reformer, 2 3 1919
('17', 320, 6, 15, 649216) 304. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON NATIONAL SCHOOL
('17', 320, 7, 16, 649260) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, Magh Krishna Ekadashi, Samvat 1975 [February 26, 1919]
('17', 320, 8, 17, 649334) TO THE EDITOR
('17', 320, 9, 18, 649348) SIR, I am sure your readers know that a National School is being conducted in the Satyagraha Ashram for the past two years.
('17', 320, 9, 19, 649472) Further admissions have been stopped, mainly because the teachers on the staff of the school wish to prepare and equip themselves fully for the requirements of the National School curriculum and because their number is not large enough.
('17', 320, 9, 20, 649709) Just now the School needs at least five additional teachers.
('17', 320, 9, 21, 649770) All teaching is done through Gujarati.
('17', 320, 9, 22, 649809) Hence, even persons who possess a high proficiency only in Gujarati will serve the purpose.
('17', 320, 9, 23, 649901) Since, however, higher education is given entirely
('17', 320, 10, 24, 649952) 1 An untouchable caste
('17', 321, 0, 1, 649975) 322 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 321, 1, 2, 650017) through English, the need for men with proficiency in English will remain till such time as we have teachers who can impart higher education through Gujarati.
('17', 321, 1, 3, 650176) Even so, the teachers at present on the staff being well equipped in English, the School can take on men with high proficiency in Gujarati; in fact, it wants to encourage such men.
('17', 321, 1, 4, 650357) A few words about the School: It has three graduates [on its staff], with one music expert and an equally competent Sanskrit scholar.
('17', 321, 1, 5, 650491) The Ashram and the School are situated on a beautiful spot on the banks of the Sabarmati.
('17', 321, 1, 6, 650581) Quarters have been built for teachers here.
('17', 321, 1, 7, 650625) They are paid enough to keep them above want.
('17', 321, 1, 8, 650671) Two of the teachers draw no salary, since they do not need any, and, of the remaining three, the highest salary drawn by any one is Rs. 75. The School is in a position to pay up to this maximum to a competent teacher.
('17', 321, 1, 9, 650889) In my view, anyone who works in this School will be taking part in an experiment which seems small enough at present but which, as time passes, will produce ever bigger results.
('17', 321, 1, 10, 651067) If the experiment fails, it will not be for lack of effort.
('17', 321, 1, 11, 651127) I trust that those who love the profession of teaching and who, though making their living through teaching, are interested primarily in teaching for itself and only incidentally as a means of livelihood will come forward to help this School.
('17', 321, 1, 12, 651370) Candidates must necessarily be in a fit state of health, for they are to learn as well as teach.
('17', 321, 1, 13, 651467) They must know the fundamentals of agriculture, on which 80 per cent of India’s population depends for its livelihood, and also of weaving, which used to be a means of living for hundreds of thousands of people.
('17', 321, 1, 14, 651679) A knowledge of Hindi, too, is essential for those who undertake to work for national education.
('17', 321, 1, 15, 651775) In my humble opinion, even from the point of view of their long range economic interests, young men fresh from college will also do well to plunge into this experiment of national education.
('17', 321, 1, 16, 651966) They will stand to lose nothing, and may possibly gain in some ways.
('17', 321, 2, 17, 652035) MOHANDAS K. GANDHI
('17', 321, 3, 18, 652054) From a photostat of the Gujarati: S.N. 6430

('17', 323, 3, 7, 654171) 307. SPEECH OF ROWLATT BILLS, DELHI
('17', 323, 4, 8, 654207) March 7, 1919
('17', 323, 5, 9, 654221) Mr. Gandhi was prevented from delivering his address owing to weakness, but he asked Mr. Mahadev Desai to read it out for him.
('17', 323, 5, 10, 654348) He did not think there was any necessity for him to comment on the Bills, which were the subject of severe criticism in the Press, but he would say something about the remedy of the disease appearing in the form of the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 323, 5, 11, 654582) The remedy was the satyagraha movement already launched in Bombay.
('17', 323, 5, 12, 654649) Many well known men and women had signed the Pledge.
('17', 323, 5, 13, 654702) Satyagraha was a harmless, but unfailing remedy.
('17', 323, 5, 14, 654751) It presupposed a superior sort of courage in those who adopted it— not the courage of the fighter.
('17', 323, 5, 15, 654850) The soldier was undoubtedly ever ready to die, but he also wanted to kill the enemy.
('17', 323, 5, 16, 654935) A satyagrahi was ever ready to endure suffering and ever lays down his life to demonstrate to the world the integrity of his purpose and the justice of his demands.
('17', 323, 5, 17, 655100) His weapon was faith in God and he lived and worked in faith.
('17', 323, 5, 18, 655162) In his faith, there was no room for killing or violence and none for untruth.
('17', 323, 5, 19, 655240) It was the only weapon with which India could be rid of the Bills.
('17', 323, 5, 20, 655307) He did not admit the Government’s position that these Bills were necessary to cope with anarchy.
('17', 323, 5, 21, 655404) He was convinced that they would bring more anarchy in their train.
('17', 323, 5, 22, 655472) Certain acts of the Government were bound to be disliked by the people and redress was sought in the usual way by holding protest meetings and petitioning the Government, failing which, like the raw youths of Bengal, they resorted to violence and violence was disastrous to the country.
('17', 323, 5, 23, 655759) The Bills themselves had arisen out of violence.
('17', 323, 5, 24, 655808) The only alternative was satyagraha or civil disobedience of the laws of the Government and enduring all the sufferings such disobedience might entail.
('17', 323, 5, 25, 655960) By satyagraha alone could India be rid of violence and her patient suffering was bound to bend the mightiest power.
('17', 323, 5, 26, 656076) He hoped and prayed that by the aid of this spiritual weapon, India might demonstrate to the world the supreme difference between the Eastern and the Western civilizations and concluded with warning the people against hasty steps.
('17', 323, 5, 27, 656307) No one should sign the Pledge without fully realizing the significance of the Rowlatt Bills or the Satyagraha Vow with all the suffering it might entail.
('17', 323, 6, 28, 656461) The Amrita Bazar Patrika, 13 3 1919
('17', 324, 0, 1, 656497) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 325
('17', 324, 1, 2, 656538) 308. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('17', 324, 2, 3, 656576) [DELHI,] March 8, 1919
('17', 324, 3, 4, 656599) I am leaving this evening for Allahabad and I proceed thence to Bombay.
('17', 324, 3, 5, 656671) Had I been in a fit state, I should certainly have waited on most of the signatories to the manifesto 1 against the satyagarha movement inaugurated against the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 324, 3, 6, 656846) I had hoped yesterday, as I was calling on Sir James Dubouley 2, to come down to you after leaving Sir James, but the interview lasted beyond 6 o’clock, and as I did not wish to miss my last meal, I hurried to Mr. Rudra’s.
('17', 324, 3, 7, 657069) I wanted to tell you yesterday, which I now do, that you would please tell the signatories that it was my desire to explain my position fully to them, more fully than I could through the Press, and that for the reasons above stated I could not do so.
('17', 324, 3, 8, 657320) I wish to add—though it is perhaps superfluous —that my regard for those of the signatories whom I have the privilege of knowing is not affected in the slightest degree by the manifesto.
('17', 324, 3, 9, 657507) It is my misfortune that I have failed to secure the concurrence of those whose opinion I value.
('17', 324, 3, 10, 657604) Nevertheless, I am not without hope that as the struggle develops, they will see the brighter side of it and think with me that nothing but an energizing activity which satyagraha certainly is could have prevented the ambitious and high spirited youths of the country from seeking questionable activities for want of a better.
('17', 324, 4, 11, 657931) Yours sincerely,
('17', 324, 5, 12, 657948) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 326, 18, 22, 660126) I do not wish to add anything to it, except a very personal word.
('17', 326, 18, 23, 660192) All the time that satyagraha was going on in South Africa, I had the privilege of addressing General Smuts through his P.S., Mr. Lane.
('17', 326, 18, 24, 660327) As the struggle developed, Mr. Lane veritably became the angel of peace between the Government as represented by Gen.
('17', 326, 18, 25, 660445) Smuts and aliens as represented by me.

('17', 327, 4, 14, 661836) 313. SPEECH ON SATYAGRAHA, ALLAHABAD 2
('17', 327, 5, 15, 661875) March 11, 1919
('17', 327, 6, 16, 661890) I am sorry that I am unable to speak to you myself.
('17', 327, 6, 17, 661942) It is utterly impossible for my voice to reach the farthest end of this meeting.
('17', 327, 6, 18, 662023) I have therefore to content myself with writing a few lines to be read for me.
('17', 327, 6, 19, 662102) It behoves everyone who wishes to take the Satyagraha Pledge to seriously consider all its factors before taking it.
('17', 327, 6, 20, 662219) It is necessary to understand the principles of satyagraha, to understand the main features of the Bills known as the Rowlatt Bills and to be satisfied that they are so objectionable as to warrant the very powerful remedy of satyagraha being applied and finally to be convinced of one’s ability to undergo every form of bodily suffering so that the soul may be set free and be under no fear from any human being or institution.
('17', 327, 6, 21, 662647) Once in it there is no looking back.
('17', 327, 6, 22, 662684) Therefore, there is no conception of defeat in satyagraha.
('17', 327, 6, 23, 662743) A satyagrahi fights even unto death.
('17', 327, 6, 24, 662780) It is thus
('17', 327, 7, 25, 662791) 1 The last paragraph is in Gandhiji’s hand.
('17', 327, 8, 26, 662835) 2 This was read in English by the chairman, Syed Hussain, and in Hindi by Gandhiji’s secretary, Mahadev Desai.
('17', 328, 0, 1, 662946) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 329
('17', 328, 1, 2, 662987) not an easy thing for everybody to enter upon it.
('17', 328, 1, 3, 663037) It therefore behoves a satyagrahi to be tolerant of those who do not join him.
('17', 328, 1, 4, 663116) In reading reports of satyagraha meetings I often notice that ridicule is poured upon those who do not join our movement.
('17', 328, 1, 5, 663238) This is entirely against the spirit of the Pledge.
('17', 328, 1, 6, 663289) In satyagraha we expect to win over our opponents by self suffering i.e., by love.
('17', 328, 1, 7, 663372) The process whereby we hope to reach our goal is by so conducting ourselves as gradually and in an unperceived manner to disarm all opposition.
('17', 328, 1, 8, 663516) Opponents as a rule expect irritation even violence from one another when both parties are equally matched.
('17', 328, 1, 9, 663624) But when satyagraha comes into play the expectation is transformed into agreeable surprise in the mind of the party towards whom satyagraha is addressed till at last he relents and recalls the act which necessitated satyagraha.
('17', 328, 1, 10, 663852) I venture to promise that if we act up to our Pledge day after day, the atmosphere around us will be purified and those who differ from us from honest motives, as I verily believe they do, will perceive that their alarm was unjustified.
('17', 328, 1, 11, 664089) The violationists wherever they may be, will realize that they have in satyagraha a far more potent instrument for achieving reform than violence whether secret or open, and that it gives them enough work for their inexhaustible energy.
('17', 328, 1, 12, 664326) And the Government will have no case left in defence of their measures, if as a result of our activity the cult of violence is notably on the wane if it has not entirely died out.
('17', 328, 1, 13, 664506) I hope therefore that at satyagraha meetings we shall have no cries of shame, and no language betraying irritation or impatience either against the Government or our countrymen who differ from us and some of whom have for years been devoting themselves to the country’s cause according to the best of their ability.
('17', 328, 1, 14, 664822) The Leader, 13 3 1919
('17', 328, 2, 15, 664844) 314. SATYAGRAHA SABHA RULES 1
('17', 328, 3, 16, 664874) The following are the draft rules of the Satyagraha Sabha.
('17', 328, 4, 17, 664933) CHAPTER I : INTRODUCTORY
('17', 328, 5, 18, 664958) 1. This association shall be called the Satyagraha Sabha.
('17', 328, 5, 19, 665016) 2. Its head office shall be situated in Bombay.
('17', 328, 5, 20, 665064) 3. Its objects are to oppose until they are withdrawn the Bills
('17', 328, 6, 21, 665128) 1 Presumably drafted by Gandhiji
('17', 329, 0, 1, 665161) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 329, 1, 2, 665203) popularly known as Rowlatt Bills (Acts I & II of 1919), by, (i) resort to satyagraha in terms of the Pledge 1 which is attached as Schedule A hereto and all other lawful means not inconsistent with satyagrahis.
('17', 329, 1, 3, 665414) 4. The work of the Sabha shall be carried on by means of voluntary contributions from Members and non Members.
('17', 329, 1, 4, 665525) 5. Any person qualified under Rule 6 can become a Member of the Sabha.
('17', 329, 2, 5, 665596) CHAPTER II : CONSTITUTION
('17', 329, 3, 6, 665622) 6. Any person who has signed the Satyagraha Pledge (Schedule A hereto), who has attained the age of 18 years and who is not a student in some school or college and who has been attested by a Member of the Sabha, duly authorized thereto by the Executive Committee, is entitled to become a Member of the Sabha.
('17', 329, 3, 7, 665931) 7. The Sabha shall have an elected President, Vice Presidents not exceeding three, three Hon.
('17', 329, 3, 8, 666025) Secretaries two Hon.
('17', 329, 3, 9, 666046) Treasurers.
('17', 329, 3, 10, 666058) 8. The President of the Sabha shall be the ex officio Chairman of the Executive Committee which shall appoint its own Vice Chairman.
('17', 329, 3, 11, 666191) 9. The Executive Committee shall consist of not more than 50 Members including a Chairman and Vice Chairman not exceeding three.
('17', 329, 3, 12, 666320) The office bearers of the Sabha shall be ex officio Members of the Executive Committee.
('17', 329, 3, 13, 666408) 10. The Hon.
('17', 329, 3, 14, 666421) Secretaries of the Sabha shall be the ex officio Secretaries of the Executive Committee.
('17', 329, 4, 15, 666510) CHAPTER III : POWERS AND DUTIES OF THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE
('17', 329, 5, 16, 666569) 11. The Executive Committee shall be in charge of all the Books and records of the Sabha; it shall stand possessed of all its funds.
('17', 329, 5, 17, 666702) 12. The Executive Committee shall have the power to consider and decide from time to time what steps should be taken to give effect to the Pledge (Schedule A) 2. 13. The Executive Committee shall have the powers to do each and everything necessary to effect the objects of the Sabha.
('17', 329, 5, 18, 666986) 14. The Executive Committee may recognize and start Branches of
('17', 329, 6, 19, 667050) 1 Vide “The Satyagraha Pledge”, 24 2 1919.

('17', 330, 1, 2, 667235) the Sabha in the whole of the Bombay Presidency and may co operate with the Satyagraha Societies and Associations in other parts of India having similar objects.
('17', 330, 1, 3, 667397) 15. The Executive Committee shall meet at least once a week 1 and shall do so more often if the Hon.
('17', 330, 1, 4, 667498) Secretaries call an urgent meeting.
('17', 330, 1, 5, 667534) Special meeting of the Committee shall also be called on a requisition signed by 3 or more Members of the Committee specifying the object of the special meeting.
('17', 330, 1, 6, 667696) 16. The Executive Committee may without assigning any reason by a 2/3rd majority of the total number of its Members expel any Member of the Sabha.

A general meeting of the Members of the Sabha shall be held at least once a month or at any time at the instance of the Executive Committee or on requisition to the Honorary Secretaries which is signed by not less than ten Members provided that not less than 3 days’ [notice is given].

('17', 331, 1, 2, 668931) 316. LETTER TO SIR JAMES DUBOULAY
('17', 331, 2, 3, 668965) March 12, 1919 With reference to the Ali Brothers, I should like to say just one word.
('17', 331, 2, 4, 669052) After the interview with you, 1 I have seen Maulana Abdul Bari Saheb of Lucknow whose disciples the Brothers are.
('17', 331, 2, 5, 669166) And I must state that by still longer detaining the Brothers, the Government would be adding injustice to injustice.
('17', 331, 2, 6, 669283) I do not know the art of Government and what I have seen of it throughout the world makes me look upon it not with any favour.
('17', 331, 2, 7, 669410) But it does seem curious that the Government should ignore what is patent to everybody outside it, viz., the increasing intensity of the smouldering fire which they are simply hiding under the ashes called repression.
('17', 331, 2, 8, 669628) And is it good Government to imprison ability, honesty, and religious conviction ?
('17', 331, 2, 9, 669711) I do wish I could convince you of the necessity of setting the Brothers free, and you in your turn could convince the Government.
('17', 331, 2, 10, 669841) I am leaving for Bombay today.
('17', 331, 2, 11, 669872) My permanent address is Sabarmati, Ahmedabad, but for some days my address will be Laburnum Road, Gamdevi, Bombay.

('17', 332, 4, 7, 670696) 318. SPEECH ON ROWLATT BILLS, BOMBAY
('17', 332, 5, 8, 670733) March 14, 1919
('17', 332, 6, 9, 670748) At the Bombay meeting against the Rowlatt Bills on 14th March, 1919, Mr. Gandhi’s speech which was in Gujarati was read out by his secretary.
('17', 332, 6, 10, 670890) I am sorry that owing to my illness, I am unable to speak to you myself and have to have my remarks read to you.
('17', 332, 6, 11, 671003) You will be glad to know that Sannayasi Shraddhanandji is gracing the audience today by his presence.
('17', 332, 6, 12, 671105) He is better known to us as Mahatma Munshiramji, the Governor of Gurukul.
('17', 332, 6, 13, 671179) His joining our army is a source of strength to us.
('17', 332, 6, 14, 671231) Many of you have perhaps been keenly following the proceedings of the Viceregal Council.
('17', 332, 6, 15, 671320) Bill No.
('17', 332, 6, 16, 671329) 2 is being steamrollered by means of the official majority of the Government and in the teeth of the unanimous opposition from the non official members.
('17', 332, 6, 17, 671482) I deem it to be an insult to the latter, and through them to the whole of India.
('17', 332, 6, 18, 671563) Satyagraha has become necessary as much to ensure respect for duly expressed public opinion, as to have the mischievous Bills withdrawn.
('17', 332, 6, 19, 671700) Grave responsibility rests upon the shoulders of the satyagrahis though, as I have so often said, there is no such thing as defeat in satyagraha, it does not mean that victory can be achieved without satyagrahis to fight for it, i.e., to suffer for it.
('17', 332, 6, 20, 671953) The use of this matchless force is comparatively a novelty.
('17', 332, 6, 21, 672013) It is not the same thing as passive resistance which has been conceived to be a weapon that can be wielded most effectively only by the strongest minded, and you may depend upon it that six hundred men and women who in this Presidency have signed the Pledge are more than enough for our purpose, if they have strong wills and invincible faith in their mission, and that [it] is in the power of truth to conquer untruth which satyagrahis believe the Bills represent.
('17', 332, 6, 22, 672479) I use the word “untruth” in its widest sense.
('17', 332, 6, 23, 672525) We may expect often to be told—as we have been told already by Sir William Vincent—that the Government will not yield to any threat of passive resistance.
('17', 332, 6, 24, 672680) Satyagraha is not a threat, it is a fact; and even such a mighty Government as the Government of India will have to yield if we are true to our Pledge.
('17', 332, 6, 25, 672832) For, the Pledge is not a
('17', 333, 0, 1, 672857) 334 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 333, 1, 2, 672899) small thing.
('17', 333, 1, 3, 672912) It means a change of heart.
('17', 333, 1, 4, 672940) It is an attempt to introduce the religious spirit into politics.
('17', 333, 1, 5, 673006) We may no longer believe in the doctrine of tit for tat; we may not meet hatred by hatred, violence by violence, evil by evil; but we have to make a continuous and persistent effort to return good for evil.
('17', 333, 1, 6, 673213) It is of no consequence that I give utterance to these sentiments.
('17', 333, 1, 7, 673280) Every satyagrahi has to live up to them.
('17', 333, 1, 8, 673321) It is a difficult task, but with the help of God, nothing is impossible.
('17', 333, 1, 9, 673394) (Loud cheers.)
('17', 333, 2, 10, 673409) Mahatma Gandhi: His Life, Writings & Speeches, pp.

('17', 334, 3, 20, 675239) 321. SPEECH ON SATYAGRAHA, MADRAS 2
('17', 334, 4, 21, 675275) March 18, 1919
('17', 334, 5, 22, 675290) You will forgive me for saying the few words that I want to say just now sitting in the chair.
('17', 334, 5, 23, 675385) I am under strict medical orders not to exert myself, having got a weak heart.
('17', 334, 5, 24, 675464) I am, therefore, compelled to have some assistance and to get my remarks read to you.
('17', 334, 5, 25, 675550) I wish to say one word to you.
('17', 334, 5, 26, 675581) Beware before you sign the Pledge.
('17', 334, 5, 27, 675616) But if you do, you will see to it that you shall never undo the Pledge you have signed.
('17', 334, 5, 28, 675704) May God help you and me in carrying out the Pledge.
('17', 334, 6, 29, 675756) [Mahadev Desai, after a few words of introduction, read out the following message:]
('17', 334, 7, 30, 675840) I regret that owing to heart weakness, I am unable to speak to you personally.
('17', 334, 7, 31, 675919) You have no doubt attended many meetings, but those that you have been attending of late are different from the others in that at the meetings to which I have referred some immediate tangible action, some immediate definite sacrifice has been demanded of you for the purpose of averting a serious calamity that has overtaken us in the shape of what are known as the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 334, 7, 32, 676300) One of them, Bill No.
('17', 334, 7, 33, 676322) 1, has undergone material alterations and its further
('17', 334, 8, 34, 676376) 1 The rest of the letter is not available.
('17', 334, 9, 35, 676419) 2 The meeting was held at Triplicane Beach S. Kasturi Ranga Iyengar presided.
('17', 335, 0, 1, 676497) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 335, 1, 2, 676539) consideration has been postponed.
('17', 335, 1, 3, 676573) In spite, however, of the alteration, it is mis chievous enough to demand opposition.
('17', 335, 1, 4, 676659) The second Bill has probably at this very moment been finally passed by that Council, for in reality you can hardly call the Bill as having been passed by that august body when all its non official members unanimously and in strong language opposed it.
('17', 335, 1, 5, 676912) The Bills require to be resisted not only because they are in themselves bad, but also because Government, who are responsible for their introduction, have seen fit practically to ignore public opinion and some of its members have made it a boast that they can so ignore that opinion.
('17', 335, 1, 6, 677197) So far, it is common cause between the different schools of thought in the country.
('17', 335, 1, 7, 677281) I have, however, after much prayerful consideration, and after very careful examination of the Government’s standpoint, pledged myself to offer satyagraha against the Bills, and invited all men and women who think and feel with me to do likewise.
('17', 335, 1, 8, 677528) Some of our countrymen, including those who are among the best of the leaders, have uttered a note of warning, and even gone so far as to say that this satyagraha movement is against the best interests of the country.
('17', 335, 1, 9, 677746) I have naturally the highest regard for them and their opinion.
('17', 335, 1, 10, 677810) I have worked under some of them.
('17', 335, 1, 11, 677844) I was a babe when Sir Dinshaw Wachha and Babu Surendranath Banerjea were among the accepted leaders of public opinion in India.
('17', 335, 1, 12, 677972) Mr. Sastriar is a politician who has dedicated his all to the country’s cause.
('17', 335, 1, 13, 678051) His sincerity, his probity are all his own.
('17', 335, 1, 14, 678095) He will yield to no one in the love of the country.
('17', 335, 1, 15, 678147) There is a sacred and indissoluble tie binding me to him.
('17', 335, 1, 16, 678205) My upbringing draws me to the signatories of the two Manifestoes 1. It is not, therefore, without the greatest grief and much searching of heart that I have to place myself in opposition to their wishes.
('17', 335, 1, 17, 678409) But there are times when you have to obey a call which is the highest of all, i.e., the voice of conscience, even though such obedience may cost many a bitter tear, nay, even more, separation from friends, from family, from the State to which you may belong, from all that you have held as dear as life itself.
('17', 335, 1, 18, 678720) For, this obedience is the law of our being.
('17', 335, 1, 19, 678765) I have no further and other defence to offer for my conduct.
('17', 335, 1, 20, 678826) My regard for the signatories to the Manifesto remains undiminished, and my faith in the efficiency of satyagraha is so great that I feel that if those who have taken the Pledge will be true to it, we
('17', 335, 2, 21, 679027) 1 Issued by Sir D. E. Wachha, Sir Surendranath Banerjea, V. S. Srinivasa Sastriar and other Moderate leaders on March 2, and by the Madras Moderates on March 18.
('17', 336, 0, 1, 679189) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 337
('17', 336, 1, 2, 679230) shall be able to show to them that they will find when we have come to the end of this struggle that there was no cause for alarm or misgivings.
('17', 336, 1, 3, 679375) There is, I know, resentment felt, even by some satyagrahis over the Manifestoes.
('17', 336, 1, 4, 679457) I would warn satyagrahis that such resentment is against the spirit of satyagraha.
('17', 336, 1, 5, 679540) I would personally welcome an honest expression of difference of opinion from any quarter and more so from friends because it puts us on our guard.
('17', 336, 1, 6, 679688) There is too much recrimination, innuendo and insinuation in our public life, and if the satyagraha movement purges it of this grave defect, as it ought to, it will be a very desirable by product.
('17', 336, 1, 7, 679885) I wish further to suggest to satyagrahis that any resentment of the two Manifestoes would be but a sign of weakness on our part.
('17', 336, 1, 8, 680014) Every movement, and satyagraha most of all, must depend upon its own inherent strength, but not upon the weakness or silence of its critics.
('17', 336, 1, 9, 680155) Let us, therefore, see wherein lies the strength of satyagraha.
('17', 336, 1, 10, 680219) As the name implies, it is in an insistence on truth which dynamically expressed means love; and by the law of love we are required not to return hatred for hatred, violence for violence but to return good for evil.
('17', 336, 1, 11, 680435) As Shrimati Sarojini Devi told you yesterday, the strength lies in a definite recognition of the true religious spirit and action corres ponding to it, and when once you introduce the religious element in politics, you revolutionize the whole of your political outlook.
('17', 336, 1, 12, 680705) You achieve reform then not by imposing suffering on those who resist it, but by taking the suffering upon yourselves and so in this movement we hope by the intensity of our sufferings to affect and alter the Government’s resolution not to withdraw these objectionable Bills.
('17', 336, 1, 13, 680981) It has, however, been suggested that the Government will leave the handful of satyagrahis severely alone and not make martyrs of them.
('17', 336, 1, 14, 681116) But there is here, in my humble opinion, bad logic and an unwar ranted assumption of fact.
('17', 336, 1, 15, 681207) If satyagrahis are left alone, they have won a complete victory, because they will have succeeded in disregarding the Rowlatt Bills and even other laws of the country and in having thus shown that civil disobedience of a Government is held perfectly harmless.
('17', 336, 1, 16, 681467) I regard the statement as an unwarranted assumption of fact, because it contemplates the restriction of the movement only to a handful of men and women.
('17', 336, 1, 17, 681620) My experience of satyagraha leads me to believe that it is such a potent force that, once set in motion, it ever spreads till at last it becomes a dominant factor in the community in which it is brought into play, and if it so spreads, no Government can neglect it.
('17', 336, 1, 18, 681886) Either it must yield to it or imprison the workers in the
('17', 337, 0, 1, 681944) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 337, 1, 2, 681986) movement.
('17', 337, 1, 3, 681996) But I have no desire to argue.
('17', 337, 1, 4, 682027) As the English proverb says, the proof of the pudding lies in the eating.
('17', 337, 1, 5, 682101) The movement for better or for worse has been launched.
('17', 337, 1, 6, 682157) We shall be judged not by our words, but solely by our deeds.
('17', 337, 1, 7, 682219) It is, therefore, not enough that we sign the Pledge.

('17', 337, 1, 9, 682556) The cause is great, the remedy is equally great; let us prove worthy of them both.

('17', 338, 3, 7, 684597) 323. SPEECH ON SATYAGRAHA, MADRAS 1
('17', 338, 4, 8, 684633) March 20, 1919 This afternoon I propose to deal with that of the objections that have been raised against satyagraha.
('17', 338, 4, 9, 684751) After saying that it was a matter of regret that men like myself “should have embarked on this movement”, Sir William Vincent, in winding up the debate on Bill No.
('17', 338, 4, 10, 684915) 2, said:
('17', 338, 5, 11, 684924) they could only hope that it (i.e., satyagraha) would not materialize.
('17', 338, 5, 12, 684995) Mr. Gandhi might exercise great self restraint in action, but there would be other young hot headed men who might be led into violence which could not but end in disaster.
('17', 338, 5, 13, 685167) Yielding to this threat, however, would be tantamount to complete abolition of the authority of the Governor General in Council.
('17', 338, 5, 14, 685296) If Sir William’s fear as to violence is realized, it would undoubtedly be a disaster.
('17', 338, 5, 15, 685382) It is for every satyagrahi to guard against that danger.
('17', 338, 5, 16, 685439) I entertain no such fear because our creed requires us to eschew all violence and to resort to truth and self suffering as the only weapons in our armoury.
('17', 338, 5, 17, 685595) Indeed, the satyagraha movement is, among other things, an invitation to those who believe in the efficacy of violence for redress of grievances to join our ranks and honestly to follow our methods.
('17', 338, 5, 18, 685794) I have suggested elsewhere what the Rowlatt Bills are intended to do and what, I verily believe, they are bound to fail in achieving, exactly what the satyagraha movement is pre eminently
('17', 338, 6, 19, 685982) 1 At a meeting on Triplicane Beach, with C. Vijayaraghavachari in the chair.
('17', 338, 6, 20, 686059) This was read by Mahadev Desai due to Gandhiji’s ill health.
('17', 338, 6, 21, 686120) The following resolution was put from the chair and passed unanimously: “In view of the unanimous opposition of India to Rowlatt Bills and the fact that not a single non official member voted with the Government for the passing of the Bill, this public meeting appeals to H.E. the Viceroy to withhold his assent to the Act for the signification of His Majaty’s pleasure under Section 68 of the Government of India Act.”
('17', 339, 0, 1, 686540) 340 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 339, 1, 2, 686582) capable of achieving.
('17', 339, 1, 3, 686604) By demonstrating to the party of violence the infallible power of Satyagraha and by giving them ample scope for inexhaustible energy, we hope to wean that party from the suicidal method of violence.
('17', 339, 1, 4, 686803) What can be more potent than an absolute statement accompanied by corresponding action presented in the clearest terms possible that violence is never necessary for the purpose of securing reforms.
('17', 339, 1, 5, 687001) Sir William says that the movement has great potentialities of evil.
('17', 339, 1, 6, 687070) The Hon.
('17', 339, 1, 7, 687079) Pandit Madan Mohan Malaviya is said to have retorted, “and also of good”.
('17', 339, 1, 8, 687153) I would venture to improve upon the retort by saying “only of good”.
('17', 339, 1, 9, 687222) It constitutes an attempt to revolutionize politics and to restore moral force to its original station.
('17', 339, 1, 10, 687326) After all, the Government do not believe in an entire avoidance of violence, i.e., physical force.
('17', 339, 1, 11, 687425) The message of the West which the Government of India, I presume, represent, is succinctly put by President Wilson in his speech delivered to the Peace Conference at the time of introducing the League of Nations Covenant:
('17', 339, 2, 12, 687647) Armed force is in the background in this programme, but it is in the background, and if the moral force of the world will not suffice physical force of the world, shall.
('17', 339, 3, 13, 687817) We hope to reverse the process, and by our action show that physical force is nothing compared to the moral force, and that moral force never fails.
('17', 339, 3, 14, 687966) It is my firm belief that this is the fundamental difference between the modern civilization and the ancient, of which India, fallen though it is, I venture to claim is a living representative.
('17', 339, 3, 15, 688160) We, her educated children, seem to have lost faith in the supremacy of moral force; we shall have made a priceless contribution to the British Empire and we shall, without fail, obtain the reforms we desire and to which we may be entitled.
('17', 339, 3, 16, 688400) Entertaining such views, it is not difficult for me to answer Sir William’s second fear as to the complete abolition of the authority of the Governor General in Council.
('17', 339, 3, 17, 688570) This movement is undoubtedly designed effectively to prove to the Government that its authority is finally dependent upon the will of the people and not upon force of arms, especially when that will is expressed in terms of satyagraha.
('17', 339, 3, 18, 688806) To yield to a clear moral force cannot but enhance the prestige and dignity of the yielder.
('17', 339, 3, 19, 688898) It is to such a movement that every man and woman in this great country is invited, but a movement that is intended to produce far reaching results, and which depended for success on the purity and the capacity for the self suffering of those who are engaged in it, can
('17', 340, 0, 1, 689168) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 341
('17', 340, 1, 2, 689209) only be joined after a searching and prayerful self examination.
('17', 340, 1, 3, 689274) I may not too often give the warning I have given at satyagraha meetings, that everyone should think a thousand times before coming to it, but having come to it he must remain in it, cost what it may.
('17', 340, 1, 4, 689475) A friend came to me yesterday and told me that he did not know that it meant all that was explained at a gathering of a few satyagrahi friends and wanted to withdraw.
('17', 340, 1, 5, 689642) I told him that he could certainly do so if he had signed without understanding the full consequences of the Pledge, and I would ask everyone who did not understand the Pledge as it has been explained at various meetings, to copy this example.
('17', 340, 1, 6, 689886) It is not numbers so much as quality that we want.
('17', 340, 1, 7, 689937) Let me, therefore, note down the qualities required of a satyagrahi.
('17', 340, 1, 8, 690006) He must follow truth at any cost and in all circumstances.
('17', 340, 1, 9, 690065) He must take a continuous effort to love his opponents.
('17', 340, 1, 10, 690121) He must be prepared to go through every form of suffering, whether imposed upon him by the Government which he is civilly resisting for the time being, or by those who may differ from him.
('17', 340, 1, 11, 690310) This movement is thus a process of purification and penance.
('17', 340, 1, 12, 690371) Believe me that if we go through it in the right spirit, all the fears expressed by the Government and some of our friends will be proved to be groundless and we will not only see the Rowlatt Bills withdrawn, but the country will recognize in satyagraha a powerful and religious weapon for securing reforms and redress of legitimate grievances.
('17', 340, 1, 13, 690716) New India, 21 3 1919
('17', 340, 2, 14, 690737) 324. SPEECH AT TRAMWAYMEN’S MEETING, MADRAS
('17', 340, 3, 15, 690781) March 21, 1919
('17', 340, 4, 16, 690796) This morning at 8 a.m.
('17', 340, 4, 17, 690819) about 150 strikers had assembled at No.
('17', 340, 4, 18, 690859) 2, St. George’s Cathedral Road, to see Mahatma Gandhi and to take his advice.
('17', 340, 4, 19, 690937) Mr. Gandhi spoke in English and his speech was translated to the strikers in Tamil by Mr. C. Rajagopalachariar.
('17', 340, 5, 20, 691049) Mr. Gandhi first of all asked one of them whether he was not tired of the strike and how long he could prolong it.
('17', 340, 5, 21, 691164) He replied that he was not and that he could stand for 10 or 15 days more.
('17', 340, 5, 22, 691239) Questioned again as to what he would do if the strike be prolonged beyond that period, he replied that he would like to remain like that even for 10 days afterwards.
('17', 340, 6, 23, 691405) Mr. Gandhi then spoke as follows: I have heard something about your strike.
('17', 340, 6, 24, 691481) I know on the surface what your demands are.
('17', 340, 6, 25, 691526) But I have not deeply gone into the whole
('17', 341, 0, 1, 691568) 342 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 341, 1, 2, 691610) matter.
('17', 341, 1, 3, 691618) Nor do I know the Company’s side of the question.
('17', 341, 1, 4, 691668) I therefore cannot say whether your demands are absolutely just or not.
('17', 341, 1, 5, 691740) But, assuming that your demands are just, I am sure that you are quite justified in declaring a strike.
('17', 341, 1, 6, 691844) Whenever a body of workmen take their legitimate grievances before their employers and the employers do not listen to them, the only clean weapon in their hands is a strike.
('17', 341, 1, 7, 692018) So, for a good and successful strike, the first thing essential is that the cause should be good and just.
('17', 341, 1, 8, 692125) The second thing is that the strikers should never resort to violence.
('17', 341, 1, 9, 692196) That is to say, you may not hurt your employers nor may you hurt those who do not join you in the strike.
('17', 341, 1, 10, 692302) And you should always, no matter what difficulties you have to suffer, stick to truth.
('17', 341, 1, 11, 692389) And in going through the strike, you must be prepared always to suffer whatever difficulties you may have to go through, even deprivations.
('17', 341, 1, 12, 692529) That strike is a religious strike and is always bound to be successful.
('17', 341, 1, 13, 692601) I hope that your strike is of that character.
('17', 341, 1, 14, 692647) I am simply filled with delight that you are all acting in such perfect co operation that not a single employee here is at present working.
('17', 341, 1, 15, 692787) I am also delighted that you are conducting yourselves in a most orderly manner.
('17', 341, 1, 16, 692868) And having gone so far, I hope you will continue your strike till your demands are granted.
('17', 341, 1, 17, 692960) I would like you to bear this in mind that your demands should be reduced to writing, that every one of you should know what those demands are and when the time for a settlement comes, not to increase your demands.
('17', 341, 1, 18, 693175) If you increase your demands from time to time or change them, you will place yourselves in the wrong.
('17', 341, 1, 19, 693278) If an arbitration is suggested, through men in whom you can place perfect reliance, I would advise you to agree to the arbitration, because the arbitrators will be able to say to you, to the Company and to the world, whether your demands are just or not.
('17', 341, 1, 20, 693533) Lastly, granting that your demands are just, that you are fulfilling the conditions that I have laid down, what are you to do when the strike is prolonged is a fair question.
('17', 341, 1, 21, 693708) I know that all of you do not possess money enough to go out with an indefinitely prolonged strike.
('17', 341, 1, 22, 693808) You are workers and able bodied men and I would advise you not to rely for your bread and butter on public support.
('17', 341, 1, 23, 693924) It is beneath the dignity of a man who has got strength of arms and legs to depend for his bread and butter upon public support.
('17', 341, 1, 24, 694053) I would therefore advise you to seek some work which all of you can do of a temporary nature.
('17', 341, 1, 25, 694147) No honest work is dishonourable for any man on this earth.
('17', 341, 1, 26, 694206) If I were you, I would do spade work indefinitely.
('17', 341, 1, 27, 694257) I have not got the time to tell you the history of a recent strike in Ahmedabad where the people
('17', 342, 0, 1, 694354) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 343
('17', 342, 1, 2, 694395) continued their strike for 23 days.
('17', 342, 1, 3, 694431) You will ask some friend what that strike was.
('17', 342, 1, 4, 694478) But this I want to tell you about that strike, that the men earning Rs. 40 per month did not mind doing spade work, taking earth and carrying it on their heads in baskets from one place to another.
('17', 342, 1, 5, 694676) So they were able to support themselves with four annas a day.
('17', 342, 1, 6, 694739) The result was that 10,000 men who were engaged in it were entirely successful.
('17', 342, 1, 7, 694819) I hope that your demands are just.
('17', 342, 1, 8, 694854) I hope that you will behave in the manner that I have ventured to advise you.
('17', 342, 1, 9, 694932) In that case, you may depend upon it you shall have success.
('17', 342, 1, 10, 694993) I thank you very much for having come here all the way to see me.
('17', 342, 1, 11, 695059) May God bless you.

('17', 342, 2, 13, 695099) 325. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON SATYAGRAHA MOVEMENT 1
('17', 342, 3, 14, 695149) MADRAS, March 23, 1919
('17', 342, 4, 15, 695172) Satyagraha, as I have endeavoured to explain at several meet ings, is essentially a religious movement.
('17', 342, 4, 16, 695276) It is a process of purification and penance.
('17', 342, 4, 17, 695321) It seeks to secure reforms or redress of grievances by self suffering.
('17', 342, 4, 18, 695392) I therefore venture to suggest that the second Sunday after the publication of the Viceregal assent to Bill No.
('17', 342, 4, 19, 695504) 2 of 1919 (i.e., 6th April) may be observed as a day of humiliation and prayer.
('17', 342, 4, 20, 695584) As there must be an effective public demonstration in keeping with the character of the observance, I beg to advise as follows: (i) A twenty four hours’ fast counting from the last meal on the preceding night should be observed by all adults, unless prevented from so doing by consideration of religion or health.
('17', 342, 4, 21, 695898) The fast is not to be regarded, in any shape or form, in the nature of a hunger strike, or as designed to put any pressure upon the Government.
('17', 342, 4, 22, 696042) It is to be regarded, for the satyagrahis, as the necessary discipline to fit them for civil disobedience, contemplated in their Pledge, and for all others, as some slight token of the intensity of their wounded feelings.
('17', 342, 4, 23, 696264) (ii) All work, except such as may be necessary in the public interest, should be suspended for the day.
('17', 342, 4, 24, 696368) Markets and other business
('17', 342, 5, 25, 696395) 1 This was also published in The Amrita Bazar Patrika, 25 3 1919, as released by the Associated Press of India.
('17', 343, 0, 1, 696507) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 343, 1, 2, 696549) places should be closed.
('17', 343, 1, 3, 696574) Employees who are required to work even on Sundays may only suspend work after obtaining previous leave.
('17', 343, 1, 4, 696679) I do not hesitate to recommend these two suggestions for adoption by public servants.
('17', 343, 1, 5, 696765) For though it is unquestionably the right thing for them not to take part in political discussions and gatherings, in my opinion they have an undoubted right to express upon vital matters their feelings in the very limited manner herein suggested.
('17', 343, 1, 6, 697013) (iii) Public meetings should be held on that day in all parts of India, not excluding villages, at which resolutions praying for the withdrawal of the two measures should be passed.
('17', 343, 1, 7, 697195) If my advice is deemed worthy of acceptance, the responsibility will lie, in the first instance, on the various Satyagraha Associations for undertaking the necessary work of organization, but all other associations will, I hope, join hands in making this demonstration a success.
('17', 343, 2, 8, 697475) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 345, 4, 12, 701038) 329. SPEECH ON SATYAGRAHA MOVEMENT, TANJORE 3
('17', 345, 5, 13, 701084) March 24, 1919
('17', 345, 6, 14, 701099) The acceptance, by the country, of the new criminal laws was a degradation, a humiliation.
('17', 345, 6, 15, 701190) When a nation felt that any particular legislation was a national degradation, they had a clear duty to discharge.
('17', 345, 6, 16, 701305) In the countries of the West, when the governors did a wrong, there ensued bloodshed.
('17', 345, 6, 17, 701391) In India, on the other hand, the people instinctively abhorred the doctrine of violence.
('17', 345, 6, 18, 701480) Therefore, they had to find out by what other means they could enforce their will upon the Government.
('17', 345, 6, 19, 701583) They had found that speeches at public meetings and the resolutions of the Legislative Councils had been of no avail.
('17', 345, 6, 20, 701701) The official majority had rejected the national will expressed through the elected members.
('17', 345, 6, 21, 701793) In such circumstances, by what other means could they impose their will on the Government ?
('17', 345, 6, 22, 701885) He suggested that what Prahlad did towards his father, Hiranyakashyapu, should be done by them towards the Govern ment.
('17', 345, 6, 23, 702005) Hiranyakashyapu issued a command to his son which conflicted with his conscience.
('17', 345, 6, 24, 702087) The voice of a disciplined conscience was the voice of the divine; and any man who refused to listen to that voice degraded human dignity.
('17', 345, 6, 25, 702226) The conscience
('17', 345, 7, 26, 702241) 1 26th March
('17', 345, 8, 27, 702254) 2 30th March
('17', 345, 9, 28, 702267) 3 At an open air meeting held at Besant Lodge.
('17', 345, 9, 29, 702314) V. P. Madhava Rao presided
('17', 346, 0, 1, 702341) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 347
('17', 346, 1, 2, 702382) of the speaker told him that they should act even as Prahlad acted against his father’s order; and if their conscience also told the same thing, they should do the same.
('17', 346, 1, 3, 702552) Prahlad disobeyed his father’s command without any irreverence or ill will or disaffection for him.
('17', 346, 1, 4, 702652) He continued to love his father as he was still disobeying his order, and the very love he bore his father made him point out to him his wrong which he dutifully resisted under the dictates of his conscience.
('17', 346, 1, 5, 702861) This was what was called civil disobedience or satyagraha, which mean the force of truth, the force of soul.
('17', 346, 1, 6, 702970) If they accepted satyagraha, they rejected the doctrine of physical violence.
('17', 346, 1, 7, 703048) He hoped that they who were the descendants of Prahlad would not send him away empty handed.
('17', 346, 1, 8, 703141) He had just then received a telegram that the Viceroy had given his consent to Bill No.
('17', 346, 1, 9, 703229) 2. They could not better begin the use of soul force than by adopting some rigorous measures of discipline.
('17', 346, 1, 10, 703337) He had suggested in a letter to the Press that the second Sunday, after the Viceroy had given his consent to the Bills, which would be the 6th April, should be observed as a day of fast by all adults, men and women, who could fast.
('17', 346, 1, 11, 703569) That was not to be mixed up with the hunger strikes in England known in connection with the movement for suffrage for women.
('17', 346, 1, 12, 703694) It was merely an expression of grief, an act of self denial, a process of purification.
('17', 346, 1, 13, 703782) It trained the satyagrahi to begin and carry on his civil disobedience.

('17', 348, 1, 2, 706979) 332. LETTER TO O. S. GHATE
('17', 348, 2, 3, 707006) TRICHINOPOLY, [March 25, 1919]
('17', 348, 3, 4, 707037) DEAR MR. GHATE, I am very sorry I have not been able to reply to your letter earlier than now.
('17', 348, 3, 5, 707132) Upon reaching Madras, I was so much immersed in satyagraha work that I could not attend to any correspondence at all.
('17', 348, 3, 6, 707250) I am ashamed of myself that I have taken so long to reply to your important letter.
('17', 348, 3, 7, 707334) You will forgive me for this delay.
('17', 348, 3, 8, 707370) What happened between Sir James Duboulay and myself was briefly this: He said the Government were not able to come to any decision, they were considering it.
('17', 348, 3, 9, 707528) He would not let me see the Committee’s Report, but he himself was not satisfied with it.
('17', 348, 3, 10, 707618) At the end of the interview, I could see that our friends were being kept under internment for the very qualities I have described in my letter.
('17', 348, 3, 11, 707763) As you are aware, I was in Lucknow and after the conversation there, as also with the friends in Delhi, I have come to the conclusion that you should not fog people and confuse the issue by resorting to separate satyagraha for the release of the Brothers.
('17', 348, 3, 12, 708019) The present movement impliedly includes this question also and I propose to refer to it at a later stage of the struggle.
('17', 348, 3, 13, 708141) I am still not without hope that they may be released.
('17', 348, 3, 14, 708196) Do not think that their proposals to withdraw from India for the time being or actual withdrawal would be helpful.
('17', 348, 3, 15, 708311) When the time comes, if it ever does, my strong advice would be that they should disregard the internment orders and invite imprisonment.
('17', 348, 3, 16, 708449) But that they will do with me.
('17', 348, 3, 17, 708480) If their step is decided, I would go over to Chhindwara myself, so that they would break the law together with me.
('17', 348, 3, 18, 708595) But now that the movement about the Rowlatt legislation is going on, we should be doubly patient about our friends.
('17', 348, 3, 19, 708711) Do not think that the correspondence between Government and myself can be published.
('17', 348, 3, 20, 708796) It is in the nature of a personal correspondence.
('17', 348, 3, 21, 708846) When I have publicly to refer to the question, I shall bring out all the facts, but without some equally important consideration, that correspondence should, I think, not be published.
('17', 348, 3, 22, 709031) The Brothers may write whatever they choose about the religious question.
('17', 348, 3, 23, 709105) But I would like their representation to be free from argument or hatred.
('17', 348, 3, 24, 709179) A colourless representation purely setting forth facts will be infinitely stronger thanan argumentative represen tation.
('17', 348, 3, 25, 709300) I take it that our friends know all about the discussion I had with Bari Saheb.
('17', 348, 3, 26, 709380) Yours sincerely, From a photostat: S.N. 6478

('17', 349, 3, 4, 709533) FRIENDS, You will forgive me for not standing to speak to you.
('17', 349, 3, 5, 709596) I am physically too weak to do so.
('17', 349, 3, 6, 709631) You will also forgive me for speaking to you not in Tamil, but in English.
('17', 349, 3, 7, 709706) It will give me some pleasure if I were to talk to you in Hindi, but it is a misfortune that you have not yet taken to the study of the national language.
('17', 349, 3, 8, 709861) As you are aware, the opportunity is now offered to you of studying that language free of charge, and I hope that as many of you as you can will take advantage of the opportunity thus offered.
('17', 349, 3, 9, 710054) However, I am on a different mission today.
('17', 349, 3, 10, 710098) I was yesterday in Tanjore.
('17', 349, 3, 11, 710126) I ventured to extend to the community of Tanjore an invitation which I wish to extend to you also; but before I do so, I wish to thank you from the bottom of my heart for the beautiful address, the beautiful casket and the Tamil address that have been presented to me.
('17', 349, 3, 12, 710395) As I do not accept any costly presents, the beautiful casket will go to the trust that has been formed which contains all the costly presents that I have ever received in my life, and there, converted into money, it will be used for some national purpose or other.
('17', 349, 4, 13, 710660) You say in the English address that there was a demonstration in the Transvaal or South Africa of the triumph of the spirit over matter.
('17', 349, 4, 14, 710797) Your own belief in the triumph of the spirit over matter will be shortly put to the test.
('17', 349, 4, 15, 710887) My invitation to you will ensure that test.
('17', 349, 4, 16, 710931) You know the Rowlatt Bills perhaps as much as I do.
('17', 349, 4, 17, 710983) I need not explain them.
('17', 349, 4, 18, 711008) You all want them to be withdrawn.
('17', 349, 4, 19, 711043) The Indian councillors in the Imperial Council tried their best to have this legislation withdrawn.
('17', 349, 4, 20, 711143) They failed.
('17', 349, 4, 21, 711156) The Bills are bad, but this flouting of the unanimous voice of the Indian members is worse and it is for you and for me, whose representatives those councillors are, to right this double wrong.
('17', 349, 4, 22, 711350) How can it b righted?
('17', 349, 4, 23, 711372) When the governors of a country do a great wrong to the people whom they govern, history teaches us that they have resorted to violence, sometimes with apparent success, often they have

('17', 350, 1, 2, 711696) been defeated; but violence can only result in violence, as darkness added to darkness really deepens it.
('17', 350, 1, 3, 711802) The doctrine of violence is of the earth, earthy, merely material, and can be no guide for a human being who at all believes in the existence of the soul.
('17', 350, 1, 4, 711957) If, as I am sure you will reject the doctrine of violence, you have to consider other means for seeking redress, and that, as I would translate, would mean shatham prati satyam 1. You have an instance given of it in the name mentioned this evening, i.e., of Prahlad.
('17', 350, 1, 5, 712224) But some of you may be inclined to think that after all Prahlad is not a historical personage.
('17', 350, 1, 6, 712319) That story may be a mere fable.
('17', 350, 1, 7, 712351) I therefore propose to give you this evening a living instance, living in the sense that it has happened within recent memory.
('17', 350, 1, 8, 712478) The authoress is dead.
('17', 350, 1, 9, 712501) The name of the heroine is Valliamma 2. She was born in South Africa of Indian parents.
('17', 350, 1, 10, 712589) She in common with many of our countrywomen in South Africa, joined the satyagraha struggle that was raging there and that raged there for over eight years.
('17', 350, 1, 11, 712746) She had a faith so absolute in the triumph of the spirit over matter that you and I are not privileged to possess.
('17', 350, 1, 12, 712861) She knew nothing of the intricacies of the laws that we resisted in that country.
('17', 350, 1, 13, 712943) It was enough for her that thousands of her countrymen and countrywomen were suffering for something she did not know, but she knew, she realized instinctively that out of the travail of the soul is a nation born and so she voluntarily suffered the hardships of a South African prisoner.
('17', 350, 1, 14, 713231) She was 18 years old.
('17', 350, 1, 15, 713253) In a weakly body she held a spirit that was indomitable.
('17', 350, 1, 16, 713310) She got daily typhoid fever, whilst she was in jail.
('17', 350, 1, 17, 713363) Her friends in the prison suggested that she should pay the fine to pay which she had the option, but she resolutely declined to pay the fine.
('17', 350, 1, 18, 713506) She preferred to die in the prison, but she did not die.
('17', 350, 1, 19, 713563) She was discharged in an ailing condition.
('17', 350, 1, 20, 713606) She was discharged after she had completed the full term of her imprisonment.
('17', 350, 1, 21, 713684) Then a few days after her discharge she died, mourned by the whole of the Indian community of South Africa as a heroine and martyr.
('17', 350, 1, 22, 713816) Before she entered the prison gates, she was a poor girl unknown to fame.
('17', 350, 1, 23, 713890) Today she has risen to [be] one of the very best of her nation.
('17', 350, 1, 24, 713954) I have come here to invite you to follow the example of that beautiful girl, Valliamma, in order that you may successfully resist this Rowlatt

('17', 351, 1, 2, 714372) legislation, and I promise that, if you will approach the question with even a little of the faith of Valliamma, you will see that in a very short time these Bills are destroyed.
('17', 351, 2, 3, 714551) The Bills have violated the national conscience, and resistance to those commands which are in violation of one’s conscience is a sacred privilege and a beauty, and it is not this law or this command of the governor that we resist, but it is our duty, it is open to us to resist all his commands which are not moral commands, and when we respectfully disobey wrongful things of these governors, we serve not only them but the whole nation.
('17', 351, 2, 4, 714991) I have been asked wherever I have gone what law, what other laws, shall we disobey.
('17', 351, 2, 5, 715075) The only answer I am able to give you today is that it is open to us to disobey all the laws which do not involve any moral sanction.
('17', 351, 2, 6, 715209) That being so, it is totally unnecessary for you to know what laws we shall disobey.
('17', 351, 2, 7, 715294) The aim of a satyagrahi is to invite upon his own devoted head all the suffering that he is capable of undertaking.
('17', 351, 2, 8, 715410) Those of you, therefore, who disapprove of the Rowlatt legislation and who have faith in the efficacy of satyagraha, I have come to invite in order that you might sign this Pledge, but I will ask you to consider a thousand times before signing the Pledge.
('17', 351, 2, 9, 715666) It is no discredit to you that you do not sign the Pledge, either because you do not disapprove of the legislation or you have not got the strength and the will, and it is not open to any satyagrahi to resent your refraining from signing the Pledge.
('17', 351, 2, 10, 715916) But if you once sign the Pledge, remember that even as that poor girl Valliamma in spite of her illness underwent the full term of her imprisonment, even so shall you never detract from the Pledge.
('17', 351, 3, 11, 716114) You might have seen from today’s papers received here that I have addressed to the Press a letter embodying some suggestions.
('17', 351, 3, 12, 716240) I will, however, repeat them this evening.
('17', 351, 3, 13, 716283) My first suggestion is, that on Sunday week, i.e., 6th day of April, we shall all observe a 24 hours’ fast.
('17', 351, 3, 14, 716391) It is a fitting preliminary for satyagrahis before they commence civil disobedience of the laws.
('17', 351, 3, 15, 716488) For all others, it will be an expression of their deep grief over the wrong committed by the Government.
('17', 351, 3, 16, 716593) I have regarded this movement as a purely religious movement and fast is an ancient institution amongst us.
('17', 351, 3, 17, 716701) You will not mistake it for a hunger strike (Laughter.) nor will you consider it as designed for exerting any pressure upon the Government.
('17', 351, 3, 18, 716841) It is a measure of self discipline, it will be an expression of the anguish of the soul, and when the soul is anguished, nobody could resist.
('17', 351, 3, 19, 716983) I hope that all adults will take up the
('17', 352, 0, 1, 717023) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 353
('17', 352, 1, 2, 717064) task unless they are prevented from doing so by ill health or religious conviction.
('17', 352, 1, 3, 717148) I have also suggested that on that Sunday all work should be suspended, all markets and all business places should be closed.
('17', 352, 1, 4, 717274) Apart from the spiritual value of these two acts, they will form an education of first class value for the masses.
('17', 352, 1, 5, 717389) I have ventured to include in my suggestions even public servants, because I think that we have to credit them with conscience as also their independence and ability and privilege to associate themselves with wrongs which the nation may want to resent.
('17', 352, 1, 6, 717642) It is right that they should not take part in political meetings and political discussions, but their individual conscience must have full and free play.
('17', 352, 1, 7, 717796) My third suggestion in which public servants may not take part is that on that day, we should visit every hamlet, if we can, and hold meetings and pass resolutions asking the Secretary of State for India to veto this legislation.
('17', 352, 1, 8, 718026) I would not ask you to resort to these public meetings and resolutions, but for one reason, and the reason is that behind these meetings and resolutions lies the force of satyagraha to enforce the national will.
('17', 352, 1, 9, 718238) In these three suggestions, whether you are satyagrahis or not, so long as you disapprove of the Rowlatt legislation, all can join and I hope that there will be such a response throughout the length and breadth of India as would convince the Government that we are alive to what is going on in our midst.
('17', 352, 1, 10, 718543) I thank you for the very great patience with which you have given me this hearing.
('17', 352, 1, 11, 718626) A thousand thanks are due to you for the various ways in which you are showering your affection upon me, but I ask you with all the emphasis at my command to translate this personal affection into real action, and I venture to promise to you that all who join this movement, I have not the slightest doubt, will come out of it all the purer for it.
('17', 352, 1, 12, 718975) Finally, please remember that if those in this great audience who are satyagrahis wish to convert others to their creed, the best way of doing so is not to bear the slightest ill will against them, but to conquer them by their sweetness, gentleness and a spirit of love.
('17', 352, 1, 13, 719246) I thank you once more.
