('17', 353, 2, 3, 719375) March 26, 1919
('17', 353, 3, 4, 719390) MR. CHAIRMAN AND GENTLEMEN, You will pardon me for not standing up whilst I speak to you, because I am too weak to do so.
('17', 353, 3, 5, 719512) I owe you a thousand apologies also for my inability to speak to you in Tamil.
('17', 353, 3, 6, 719591) But I cannot entirely acquit you of blame in that I have to speak to you in the English language.
('17', 353, 3, 7, 719689) If those of you who have received a liberal education had recognized that Hindi and Hindi alone could become the national language of India, you would have learnt it at any cost before this.
('17', 353, 3, 8, 719880) But it is never too late to mend our mistake.
('17', 353, 3, 9, 719926) You have in your midst today—only in Madras and a few other places—an opportunity offered to you of learning Hindi.
('17', 353, 3, 10, 720042) It is probably the easiest language to learn in the world.
('17', 353, 3, 11, 720101) I know something of the Tamil language; it is most beautiful and musical; but its grammar is most difficult to master, whereas the grammar of Hindi is merely a child’s work.
('17', 353, 3, 12, 720275) I hope, therefore, that you will all avail yourselves of the opportunity that is before you.
('17', 353, 3, 13, 720368) But I cannot detain you on the topic of Hindi and I must hasten on to my subject.
('17', 353, 3, 14, 720450) I have come here after visiting Tanjore and Trichinopoly, as you know, to extend to you an invitation which I have already extended in those two places.
('17', 353, 3, 15, 720603) I have come to ask you to sign the Satyagraha Pledge.
('17', 353, 3, 16, 720657) You know its contents; it is designed to offer resistance to the Rowlatt legislation.
('17', 353, 3, 17, 720743) It is not necessary for me to describe the effect of the legislation.
('17', 353, 3, 18, 720813) The public Press and our orators have been before you and you have gathered from them the contents of that legislation and also its far reaching effects.
('17', 353, 3, 19, 720967) It is enough for me to say that the legislation is of such a character that no self respecting nation can accept it.
('17', 353, 3, 20, 721084) It is calculated to degrade the nation against whom it is brought into operation.
('17', 353, 3, 21, 721166) It was carried in the teeth of unanimous opposition on our behalf.
('17', 353, 3, 22, 721233) The Government have committed a double wrong and it is your duty, it is my duty and that of every man and woman in this country, to undo the wrong by every legitimate means in his or her power.
('17', 353, 3, 23, 721427) We have exhausted all the orthodox measures in order to gain the end.
('17', 353, 3, 24, 721497) We have passed resolutions; we have petitioned and our representatives in the Imperial Legislative Council have endeavoured their best to secure a withdrawal of this legislation and all our attempts have failed.
('17', 353, 3, 25, 721709) And yet we must somehow or other undo

('17', 354, 1, 2, 721788) this wrong because it is like poison corroding the whole of the body politic.
('17', 354, 1, 3, 721866) When the national conscience is hurt, people whose conscience is hurt either seek redress through methods of violence or through methods which I have described as satyagraha.
('17', 354, 1, 4, 722041) I consider that methods of violence prove in the end to be of absolute failure.
('17', 354, 1, 5, 722121) They are moreover wholly unsuited to the genius of our people.
('17', 354, 1, 6, 722184) Methods of violence are not consistent with human dignity.
('17', 354, 1, 7, 722243) It is no answer to say that this day Europe is saturated with the belief in brute force.
('17', 354, 1, 8, 722332) True paurusha, true bravery, consists in driving out the brute in us and then only can you give freest play to your conscience.
('17', 354, 1, 9, 722460) The other force which I have in various places described as satyagraha, soul force or love force, is best illustrated in the story of Prahlad.
('17', 354, 1, 10, 722603) Prahlad, as you know, offered respectful disobedience to the laws and orders of his own father.
('17', 354, 1, 11, 722699) He did not resort to violence; but he had unquenchable belief in what he was doing.
('17', 354, 1, 12, 722783) He obeyed a higher call in disobeying the orders of his father.
('17', 354, 1, 13, 722847) And in applying satyagraha to this movement, we shall be only copying the brilliant and eternal insistence of Prahlad.
('17', 354, 1, 14, 722966) But we are living today in a world of unbelief.

('17', 354, 1, 17, 723250) The one instance I related last evening and that was of a beautiful Tamil girl called Valliamma, eighteen years old, who died as a satyagrahi.
('17', 354, 1, 18, 723393) She had joined the satyagraha movement in South Africa which lasted for eight years.
('17', 354, 1, 19, 723478) She was arrested and imprisoned during the struggle.
('17', 354, 1, 20, 723531) In her prison, she got typhoid fever and died of it.
('17', 354, 1, 21, 723584) It was she and her fellow satyagrahis who secured the relief that you all are aware of in South Africa.
('17', 354, 1, 22, 723688) There was a lad of about the same age as Valliamma’s whose name was Nagappan 1 and who suffered imprisonment in the same struggle.
('17', 354, 1, 23, 723819) He did not reason why he should join the struggle.
('17', 354, 1, 24, 723870) He had an instinctive faith in its righteousness.
('17', 354, 1, 25, 723920) He instinctively believed that the remedy adopted was the only true and effective remedy.
('17', 354, 2, 26, 724010) The climate of South Africa is not so beneficent as the climate of the Indian plains.

('17', 355, 1, 11, 725127) There is, however, one other condition; it is not enough that you disapprove of the Rowlatt legislation.
('17', 355, 1, 12, 725232) You must have also faith in the efficacy of this remedy and ability to undergo the suffering that it may involve.
('17', 355, 1, 13, 725346) But I am sure you will agree with me that no nation has as yet become great without having undergone suffering, whether it is through inflicting violence on others or whether it is by way of satyagraha.
('17', 355, 1, 14, 725549) Satyagraha is essentially a religious force.
('17', 355, 1, 15, 725594) Unless we have faith in the inviolable and immutable force of the spirit, we shall not be able to carry the struggle to a successful end.
('17', 355, 1, 16, 725732) The fault then would be not of the movement or the force I have ventured to describe; but it would lie in our own imperfection.
('17', 355, 1, 17, 725860) I ask you all, therefore, to approach the question with a careful consideration.

('17', 355, 1, 19, 726091) It follows from the Satyagraha Pledge that those who take the Pledge will not treat with any disrespect those who will not be able to take the Pledge.
('17', 355, 1, 20, 726242) They may refrain from signing the Pledge either because they do not disapprove of the Bills or they do not believe in the struggle or they are too weak.
('17', 355, 1, 21, 726395) As time passes, we hope even to win them over to the movement.
('17', 355, 1, 22, 726458) You may have seen the letter I have addressed to the Press.
('17', 355, 1, 23, 726518) In it I have suggested that we should observe Sunday week as a day of humiliation and prayer and I have made three suggestions.
('17', 355, 1, 24, 726646) I have suggested fasting, total abstention of work including markets and business places and holding meetings all over India to pass resolutions.
('17', 355, 1, 25, 726792) The proposed fast is not a hunger strike but it is an act of self denial.

('17', 355, 1, 28, 727056) I have up to now simply described the nature of the movement of satyagraha.

('17', 356, 0, 1, 727205) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 357
('17', 356, 1, 2, 727246) from this movement.
('17', 356, 1, 3, 727266) The Government contend that this Rowlatt legislation will rid the country finally of the anarchical movement.
('17', 356, 1, 4, 727376) As I have said elsewhere, it will do nothing of the kind.
('17', 356, 1, 5, 727434) But I venture to suggest to you that this movement of satyagraha, offering as it does something to provide for the inexhaustible energy of the members of the school of anarchism, will alter their very nature and bring them to this cleaner method of obtaining redress of grievances.
('17', 356, 1, 6, 727716) In these circumstances, I trust the movement should command the respect and support of all.

('17', 363, 2, 6, 745286) 337. MESSAGE TO MADRAS MEETING
('17', 363, 3, 7, 745317) March 30, 1919
('17', 363, 4, 8, 745332) DEAR MR. RANGASWAMI 2, I am sorry that I shall not be with you for this evening’s meeting, as I must take the train for Bezwada in order to keep my engagement with our Andhra friends.
('17', 363, 4, 9, 745516) But before my departure, I would like to reduce to writing my impressions of the tour through the southern part of the Presidency, which I have just completed, and to answer some criticism and some doubts that have been offered by friends.
('17', 363, 4, 10, 745756) I have visited Tanojre, Trichinopoly, Madura, Tuticorin and Nagapatam; and taking the lowest estimate, the people addressed must have been not less than thirty thousand.
('17', 363, 4, 11, 745926) Those who have a right to give us warnings, to express misgivings and who have just as great a love of the motherland as we claim to have feared the danger that, however well meaning we may be, and however anxious we may be to avoid violence, the people who may join the movement under an enthusiastic impulse may not be able to exercise sufficient self control and break out into violence, resulting in needless loss of life and, what is more, injury to the national cause.
('17', 363, 4, 12, 746401) After embarking upon the movement, I began addressing meetings with Delhi.
('17', 363, 4, 13, 746476) I passed then through Lucknow, Allahabad and Bombay to Madras.
('17', 363, 4, 14, 746539) My experience of all these meetings shows that the advent of satyagraha has already altered the spirit of those who attend the satyagraha meetings.
('17', 363, 4, 15, 746687) In Lucknow, upon an innocent remark by the Chairman as to the manifes to signed by some of the members of the Imperial Legislative Council disapproving of our movement, the audience cried out
('17', 363, 5, 16, 746879) 1 Sages
('17', 363, 6, 17, 746887) 2 K. V. Rangaswami Iyengar, chairman of the public meeting held on the Triplicane Beach under the auspices of the Madras Satyagraha Sabha
('17', 364, 0, 1, 747025) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 365
('17', 364, 1, 2, 747066) “Shame, shame!” I drew their attention to the fact that satyagrahis and those who attend satyagraha meetings should not use such expressions and that the speeches at our meetings ought not to be punctuated with either marks of disapproval or of approval.
('17', 364, 1, 3, 747321) The audience immediately understood the spirit of my remarks and never afterwards made any demonstration of their opinion.
('17', 364, 1, 4, 747444) In the towns of this Presidency as elsewhere, whilst it is true that the large crowds have refrained from any noisy demonstration out of regard for my health, they have fully understood the necessity of refraining from it on the higher ground.
('17', 364, 1, 5, 747688) The leaders in the movement have also fully understood the necessity for self restraint.
('17', 364, 1, 6, 747777) These experiences of mine fill me with the greatest hope for the future.
('17', 364, 1, 7, 747850) I never had any apprehension of the danger our friends fear; and the various meetings I have described confirm my optimism.
('17', 364, 1, 8, 747974) But I would venture further to state that every precaution that is humanly possible is being and will be taken to avert any such danger.
('17', 364, 1, 9, 748111) It is for that reason that our Pledge commits the signatories to the breach of those laws that may be selected for the purpose by a committee of satyagrahis 1; and I am glad that our Sind friends have understood their Pledge, and obeyed the prohibition of the Hyderabad Commissioner of Police to hold their inoffensive procession, for it is no part of the present movement to break all the laws of the land the breach of which is not inconsistent with the Pledge.
('17', 364, 1, 10, 748575) A satyagrahi is nothing if not instinctively law abiding, and it is his law abiding nature which exacts from him implicit obedience of the highest law, i.e., the voice of conscience, which overrides all other laws.
('17', 364, 1, 11, 748790) His civil disobedience even of certain laws only is only seeming disobedience.
('17', 364, 1, 12, 748869) Every law gives the subject an option, either to obey the primary sanction or the secondary; and I venture to suggest that the satyagrahi by inviting the secondary sanction obeys the law.
('17', 364, 1, 13, 749057) He does not act like the ordinary offender who not only commits a breach of the laws of the land, whether good or bad, but wishes to avoid the consequences of that breach.
('17', 364, 1, 14, 749229) It will seem therefore that everything that prudence may dictate has been done to avoid any untoward results.
('17', 364, 2, 15, 749339) Some friends have said, “We understand your breach of the Rowlatt legislation, but as a satyagrahi there is nothing for you in it to break.
('17', 364, 2, 16, 749479) How can you however break the other laws which you have hitherto obeyed, and which may also be good?” So far as the good
('17', 364, 3, 17, 749600) 1 Vide ‘‘Statement on Laws for Civil Disobedience”, 7 4 1919,
('17', 365, 0, 1, 749662) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 365, 1, 2, 749704) laws are concerned, i.e., laws which lay down moral principles, the satyagrahi may not break them, and their breach is not contemplated under the Pledge.
('17', 365, 1, 3, 749858) But the other laws are neither good nor bad, moral nor immoral.
('17', 365, 1, 4, 749922) They may be useful, or may even be harmful.
('17', 365, 1, 5, 749966) These laws one obeys for the supposed good government of the country.
('17', 365, 1, 6, 750036) Such laws are laws framed for purposes of revenue, or political laws creating statutory offences.
('17', 365, 1, 7, 750134) These laws enable the Government to continue its power.
('17', 365, 1, 8, 750190) When therefore a Government goes wrong to the extent of hurting the national fibre itself, as does the Rowlatt legislation, it becomes the right of the subject, indeed it is his duty, to withdraw his obedience to such laws, to the extent it may be required to bend the Government to the national will.
('17', 365, 2, 9, 750492) A doubt has been expressed during my tour, and by friends who have written to me, as to the validity in terms of satyagraha of the entrustment of the selection of the laws for breach to a committee.
('17', 365, 2, 10, 750691) For, it is argued that it amounts to a surrender of one’s conscience to leave such selection to others.
('17', 365, 2, 11, 750795) This doubt betrays a misunderstanding of the Pledge.
('17', 365, 2, 12, 750848) A signatory to the Pledge undertakes, so far as he is concerned, to break if necessary all the laws which it would be lawful for a satyagrahi to break.
('17', 365, 2, 13, 751000) It is not, however, obligatory on him to break all such laws.
('17', 365, 2, 14, 751062) He can therefore perfectly conscientiously leave the selection of the laws to be broken to the judgment of those who are experts in the matter and who in their turn are necessarily subject to the limitations imposed by the Pledge.
('17', 365, 2, 15, 751293) The worst that can happen to any signatory is that the selection may not be exhaustive enough for him.
('17', 365, 3, 16, 751396) I have been told that I am diverting the attention of the country from the one and only thing that matters, viz., the forthcoming Reforms.
('17', 365, 3, 17, 751535) In my opinion, the Rowlatt legislation, in spite of the amendments which, as the Select Committee very properly says, do not affect its principles, blocks the way to progress, and therefore the attainment of substantial reforms.
('17', 365, 3, 18, 751764) To my mind, the first thing needful is to secure a frank and full recognition of the principle that public opinion properly expressed shall be respected by the Government.
('17', 365, 3, 19, 751936) I am no believer in the doctrine that the same power can at the same time trust and distrust, grant liberty and repress it.
('17', 365, 3, 20, 752060) I have a right to interpret the coming Reforms by the light that the Rowlatt legislation throws upon them; and I make bold to promise that if we do not gather sufficient force to remove from our path this great obstacle in
('17', 366, 0, 1, 752283) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 367
('17', 366, 1, 2, 752324) the shape of the Rowlatt legislation, we shall find the Reforms to be a whitened sepulchre.
('17', 366, 1, 3, 752416) Yet another objection to answer.
('17', 366, 1, 4, 752449) Some friends have argued, “Your satyagraha movement only accentuates the fear we have of the onrush of Bolshevism.” The fact, however, is that if anything can possibly prevent this calamity descending upon our country, it is satyagraha.
('17', 366, 1, 5, 752686) Bolshevism is the necessary result of modern materialistic civilization.
('17', 366, 1, 6, 752759) Its insensate worship of matter has given rise to a school which has been brought up to look upon material advancement as the goal and which has lost all touch with the finer things of life.
('17', 366, 1, 7, 752950) Self indulgence is the Bolshevic creed, self restraint is the satyagraha creed.
('17', 366, 1, 8, 753030) If I can but induce the nation to accept satyagraha if only as a predominant factor in life, whether social or political, we need have no fear of the Bolshevic propaganda.
('17', 366, 1, 9, 753202) In asking the nation to accept satyagraha, I am asking for the introduction in reality of nothing new.
('17', 366, 1, 10, 753305) I have coined a new word for an ancient law that has hitherto mainly governed our lives, and I do prophesy that if we disobey the law of the final supremacy of the spirit over matter, of truth and love over brute force, in a few years’ time we shall have Bolshevism rampant in this land, which was once so holy.
('17', 366, 2, 11, 753617) Yours sincerely,
('17', 366, 3, 12, 753634) M. K. GANDHI
('17', 366, 4, 13, 753647) From a photostat: S.N. 6483
('17', 366, 5, 14, 753675) 338. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('17', 366, 6, 15, 753704) SECUNDERABAD, April 1, 1919
('17', 366, 7, 16, 753732) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I am dictating a letter to you, it seems, after ages, and I might not have been able even now, but for an accident that has befallen us.
('17', 366, 7, 17, 753886) We left Bezwada early this morning, hoping to catch the Bombay Mail at Wadi Junction.
('17', 366, 7, 18, 753972) Our train reached Secunderabad too late for the special train which it joins in order to take the train at [sic] Wadi Junction.
('17', 366, 7, 19, 754100) And so we have to bake here for 24 hours.
('17', 366, 7, 20, 754142) Secunderabad is like an oven, but the vexatious delay has its amenities.

('17', 367, 1, 3, 754534) What is the matter with him?
('17', 367, 1, 4, 754563) I do hope, he is much better now.
('17', 367, 1, 5, 754597) I reach Bombay on Thursday morning, i.e., the 3rd instant.
('17', 367, 1, 6, 754656) I hope to pass the month practically up to the 22nd instant between Bombay and Ahmedabad and I wish we could meet during that time.
('17', 367, 1, 7, 754788) Meanwhile, I must try to explain to you what I mean by the Pledge.
('17', 367, 1, 8, 754855) It somewhat surprises me that you have missed its obvious meaning.
('17', 367, 1, 9, 754922) The signatory undertakes to break, if necessary, all the laws that may not enunciate eternal verities.
('17', 367, 1, 10, 755025) But as a check upon individual extravagance, he surrenders his judgment to that of experts as to the selection of such breakable laws and the order in which they are to be broken.
('17', 367, 1, 11, 755205) That surely is not a matter of conscience.
('17', 367, 1, 12, 755248) If the committee which is bound by the same Pledge that binds the individual satyagrahi commits an error and selects laws whose breach will be inconsistent with satyagraha, naturally, the individual signatory who conscientiously thinks so refrains from breaking such a law.
('17', 367, 1, 13, 755522) In all satyagraha organi zations, this final liberty is understood.
('17', 367, 1, 14, 755590) Is not my meaning clear?
('17', 367, 1, 15, 755615) The entrustment of selection to the committee is the happiest part of the Pledge.
('17', 367, 1, 16, 755697) But for that there would have been confusion worse confounded.
('17', 367, 1, 17, 755760) Take the Sindh incident.
('17', 367, 1, 18, 755785) There the Police Commissioner prohibits an innocent procession.
('17', 367, 1, 19, 755849) The satyagrahis obey because they are bound by the Pledge not to commit disobedience except where authorized by the committee.
('17', 367, 1, 20, 755976) Their first impulse would be to disre gard the prohibition and the consequences of such hasty disregard might be most serious.
('17', 367, 1, 21, 756103) In South Africa, they surrendered to my judgment as to the selection of the laws and the time of breaking them.
('17', 367, 1, 22, 756215) Here the committee was thought of at my instance.
('17', 367, 1, 23, 756265) But of every such committee, I am the President.
('17', 367, 1, 24, 756314) I hope, you find time to read the cuttings I have been sending you.
('17', 367, 1, 25, 756382) I must now end this letter as visitors are waiting to see me.
('17', 367, 1, 26, 756444) I am most anxious to publish something from Gurudev and something from you if both of you can give it.
('17', 367, 1, 27, 756547) With love,

('17', 372, 1, 2, 761679) 346. LETTER TO THE PRESS ON DELHI TRAGEDY 1
('17', 372, 2, 3, 761723) BOMBAY, April 3, 1919
('17', 372, 3, 4, 761745) TO THE EDITOR THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE
('17', 372, 5, 5, 761780) SIR, I venture to seek the hospitality of your columns to make a few remarks on the Delhi tragedy.
('17', 372, 5, 6, 761879) It is alleged against the Delhi people who were assembled at the Delhi railway station, 1. that some of them were trying to coerce the sweetmeat sellers into closing their stalls; 2. that some of them were forcibly preventing people from boarding tram cars and other vehicles; 3. that some of them threw brickbats; 4 that the whole crowd that marched to the station demanded the release of the men who are said to be the coercers and who were for that reason arrested at the instance of the railway authorities; 5. that the crowd declined to disperse, when the Magistrate gave the order to disperse.
('17', 372, 5, 7, 762479) I have read Sannyasi Swami Shraddhanandji’s account of the tragedy.
('17', 372, 5, 8, 762547) I am bound to accept it as true, unless it is authoritatively proved to be otherwise, and his account seems to me to deny allegations, 1, 2 and 3. But assuming the truth of all the allegations, it does appear to me that the local authorities in Delhi have made use of a Nasmyth hammer to crush a fly.
('17', 372, 5, 9, 762848) On their action however, in firing on the crowd, I shall seek another opportunity of saying more.
('17', 372, 5, 10, 762946) My purpose in writing this letter is merely to issue a note of warning to all satyagrahis.
('17', 372, 5, 11, 763037) I would therefore like to observe that the conduct described in allegations 1 to 4, if true, would be inconsistent with the Satyagraha Pledge.
('17', 372, 5, 12, 763180) The conduct described in allegation 5 can be consistent with the Pledge, but if the allegation is true, the conduct was premature, because the committee contemplated in the Pledge has
('17', 372, 6, 13, 763364) 1 This was released through the Associated Press of India and published also in New India, 4 4 1919 and The Amrita Bazar Patrika, 5 4 1919.
('17', 373, 0, 1, 763504) 374 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 373, 1, 2, 763546) not decided upon the disobedience of order that may be issued by Magistrates under the Riot Act.
('17', 373, 1, 3, 763643) I am anxious to make it as clear as I can that in this movement, no pressure can be put upon people who do not wish to accept our suggestions and advice.
('17', 373, 1, 4, 763797) The movement being essentially one to secure the greatest freedom for all, satyagrahis cannot forcibly demand the release of those who might be arrested, whether justly or unjustly.
('17', 373, 1, 5, 763979) The essence of the Pledge is to invite imprisonment and until the committee decides upon the breach of the Riot Act, it is the duty of satyagrahis to obey, without making the slightest ado, magisterial order to disperse, etc., and thus to demonstrate their law abiding nature.
('17', 373, 1, 6, 764256) I hope that next Sunday at satyagraha meetings, all speeches will be free from passion, anger or resentment.
('17', 373, 1, 7, 764365) The movement depends for its success entirely upon perfect self possession, self restraint, absolute adherence to truth and an unlimited capacity for self suffering.
('17', 373, 1, 8, 764531) Before closing this letter, I would add that in opposing the Rowlatt legislation, the satyagrahis are resisting the spirit of terrorism which lies behind it and of which it is a most glaring symptom.
('17', 373, 1, 9, 764731) The Delhi tragedy imposes an added responsibility upon satyagrahis of steeling their hearts and going on with their struggle until the Rowlatt legislation is withdrawn.
('17', 373, 2, 10, 764900) Yours, etc.,
('17', 373, 3, 11, 764913) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 373, 7, 18, 765074) I thought that at the preliminary meeting we had in Bombay, I explained the meaning of satyagraha as fully as I could.
('17', 373, 7, 19, 765193) I remember having stated that satyagraha was an attempt to introduce the religious element in
('17', 373, 8, 20, 765287) 1 Dr. M. B. Velkar, secretary of the Indian Home Rule League, Bombay, and a member of the executive committee of the Satyagraha Sabha
('17', 373, 9, 21, 765421) 2 R. N. Mandlik, a member of the executive committee, Satyagraha Sabha, Bombay

('17', 374, 1, 2, 765541) politics.
('17', 374, 1, 3, 765551) But I appreciate your position and if you do not believe in the prison door being the gateway to liberty, I am sure you cannot remain in the movement.
('17', 374, 1, 4, 765702) It is not my opinion of today but I expressed it years ago in the booklet, Indian Home Rule 1, that boycott was totally inconsistent with satyagraha.
('17', 374, 1, 5, 765852) Satyagraha in the political field is an extension of the law that governs the members of a family.

('17', 374, 1, 7, 766037) If you will care to call, I shall be pleased to discuss the question with you.
('17', 374, 1, 8, 766116) In any case, you will let me know your final decision.

('17', 375, 1, 2, 766923) 349. DIRECTIONS TO DEMONSTRATORS
('17', 375, 2, 3, 766956) April 5, 1919
('17', 375, 3, 4, 766970) We have received the following communication from the secretaries of the Satyagraha Sabha: It should be remembered that tomorrow is a day of humiliation and prayer and also of mourning by reason of the Delhi tragedy.
('17', 375, 3, 5, 767187) It is therefore absolutely necessary that when the demonstrators go out to bathe and form the procession there will be no noise, no talking, amongst themselves, but that they will march in absolute silence and disperse likewise.
('17', 375, 3, 6, 767416) At all the meetings that may be held there should be no demonstration made by cheers, applause, or cries of approval or disapproval or of any other character.
('17', 375, 3, 7, 767575) The behaviour of the mourners should be worthy of the occasion.
('17', 375, 3, 8, 767639) The demonstrators should carry out the instructions that might be given to them by volunteers.
('17', 375, 3, 9, 767734) No pressure of any kind whatever should be put upon those who do not fast or suspend work and all those who may not desire to participate in the national mourning and demonstrations should be left absolutely undisturbed.
('17', 375, 3, 10, 767955) It is the duty of the demonstrators to obey and carry out all police instructions as it is as yet no part of the movement to offer civil disobedience against police orders that may be given in connection with demonstrations, processions organized by Satyagraha Associations.
('17', 375, 4, 11, 768230) The Bombay Chronicle, 5 4 1919

('17', 377, 1, 2, 769103) 352. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('17', 377, 2, 3, 769132) [BOMBAY,] April 5, 1919
('17', 377, 3, 4, 769156) MY DEAR CHARLIE, For 24 hours I was sad beyond measure over the Delhi tragedy.
('17', 377, 3, 5, 769235) I am now happy beyond measure over it.
('17', 377, 3, 6, 769274) The blood spilt at Delhi was innocent.
('17', 377, 3, 7, 769313) It is possible that the satyagrahis in Delhi made mistakes.
('17', 377, 3, 8, 769373) But on the whole, they have covered themselves with glory.
('17', 377, 3, 9, 769432) There can be no redemption without sacrifice.
('17', 377, 3, 10, 769478) And it fills me with a glow to find that full measure was given even on the first day and that too at the very seat of the power of Satan.
('17', 377, 3, 11, 769617) I want to share this happiness with you if you can take it.
('17', 377, 3, 12, 769677) I hope you received my letter answering your doubts.
('17', 377, 3, 13, 769730) I have filed an appeal against you and here is a copy 1 thereof.
('17', 377, 3, 14, 769795) You can do what you like [with] it.
('17', 377, 3, 15, 769831) But I must have Gurudev’s opinion.
('17', 377, 3, 16, 769866) With deep love,
('17', 377, 4, 17, 769882) From the manuscript of Mahadev Desai’s Diary.

('17', 377, 5, 19, 769952) 353. LETTER TO RABINDRANATH TAGORE
('17', 377, 6, 20, 769987) [BOMBAY,] April 5, 1919
('17', 377, 7, 21, 770011) DEAR GURUDEV,
('17', 377, 8, 22, 770025) This is an appeal to you against our mutual friend, Charlie Andrews.
('17', 377, 8, 23, 770094) I have been pleading with him for a message from you for publication in the national struggle which, though in form it is only directed against a single piece of legislation, is in reality a struggle for liberty worthy of a self respecting nation.
('17', 377, 8, 24, 770342) I have waited long and patiently.
('17', 377, 8, 25, 770376) Charlie’s description of your illness made me hesitate to write to you personally.
('17', 377, 8, 26, 770459) Your health is a national treasure and Charlie’s devotion to you is superhuman.
('17', 377, 8, 27, 770539) It is divine and I know that if he could help it he would not allow a single person, whether by writing or his presence, to disturb your quiet and rest.
('17', 377, 8, 28, 770692) I have respected this lofty desire of his to protect you from all harm.
('17', 377, 8, 29, 770764) But I find that
('17', 377, 9, 30, 770780) 1 Vide the following item.
('17', 378, 0, 1, 770807) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 379
('17', 378, 1, 2, 770848) you are lecturing in Benares.
('17', 378, 1, 3, 770878) I have, therefore, in the light of this fact corrected Charlie’s description of your health which somewhat alarmed me and I venture to ask you for a message from you—a message of hope and inspiration for those who have to go through the fire.
('17', 378, 1, 4, 771121) I do it because you were good enough to send me your blessings when I embarked upon the struggle.
('17', 378, 1, 5, 771219) The forces arrayed against me are, as you know, enormous.
('17', 378, 1, 6, 771277) I do not dread them, for I have an unquenchable belief that they are supporting untruth and that if we have sufficient faith in truth 1, it will enable us to overpower the former.
('17', 378, 1, 7, 771457) But all forces work through human agency.
('17', 378, 1, 8, 771499) I am therefore anxious to gather round this mighty struggle the ennobling assistance of those who approve it.
('17', 378, 1, 9, 771609) I will not be happy until I have received your considered opinion 2 on this endeavour to purify the political life of the country.
('17', 378, 1, 10, 771740) If you have seen anything to alter your first opinion of it, I hope you will not hesitate to make it known.
('17', 378, 1, 11, 771848) I value even adverse opinions from friends, for though they may not make me change my course, they serve the purpose of so many lighthouses to give out warnings of dangers lying in the stormy paths of life.
('17', 378, 1, 12, 772055) Charlie’s friendship has been to me on this account an invaluable treasure, because he does not hesitate to share with me even his unconsidered notes of dissent.
('17', 378, 1, 13, 772217) This I count a great privilege.
('17', 378, 1, 14, 772249) May I ask you to extend at this critical moment the same privilege that Charlie has?
('17', 378, 1, 15, 772334) I hope that you are keeping well and that you have thoroughly recuperated after your fatiguing journey through the Madras Presidency.
('17', 378, 2, 16, 772468) Yours sincerely,
('17', 378, 3, 17, 772485) M. K. G.

('17', 380, 1, 2, 773757) 356. LETTER TO B. G. HORNIMAN
('17', 380, 2, 3, 773787) [BOMBAY,] April 6, 1919
('17', 380, 3, 4, 773811) DEAR HORNIMAN, The accompanying is a great letter 1. You know Dwijendrababu.
('17', 380, 3, 5, 773888) He is the eldest brother of Sir R. Tagore and is leading, like his father the late Devendranath Tagore, practically the life of a sannyasi.
('17', 380, 3, 6, 774028) I think he is over eighty years old.
('17', 380, 3, 7, 774065) The letter therefore is, I think, worth reproducing.
('17', 380, 3, 8, 774118) I would even suggest a photoprint of the letter.
('17', 380, 3, 9, 774167) But the object of my writing this is not merely to send the enclosed to you.
('17', 380, 3, 10, 774244) It is to ask you, if I may, to dip your pen in the ink of love for tomorrow’s leading article in the Chronicle.
('17', 380, 3, 11, 774356) I know I have now come to know you enough to know that you are quite capable of writing such an article and, if you will accept my suggestion, I would like you also to make it a signed leader.

('17', 380, 6, 16, 774831) At times, it seems to me that the penance and fastings, etc., which you enjoin [on] me are not quite the things that are necessary and therefore may be dispensed with.
('17', 380, 6, 17, 774999) But on the second thought I find that we are not competent to judge the matter aright from our standpoint.

('17', 381, 0, 1, 775495) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 381, 1, 2, 775537) 357. SPEECH AT CHOWPATTY, BOMBAY
('17', 381, 2, 3, 775570) April 6, 1919
('17', 381, 3, 4, 775584) Bombay presented the sight of a city in mourning on the occasion of the day of national humiliation, prayers and sorrow at the passing of the Rowlatt Bills.
('17', 381, 3, 5, 775741) .and kept the twenty four hours’ fast.
('17', 381, 4, 6, 775780) SEA BATH AND PRAYERS AT CHOWPATTY
('17', 381, 5, 7, 775814) Long before the sun had rises, the Back Bay foreshore was humming and throbbing with life, for it was full of people.
('17', 381, 5, 8, 775932) From an early hour in the morning, people had come to Chowpatty to bathe in the sea....It was a Black Sunday, and the day’s programme had to begin with a sea bath....
('17', 381, 6, 9, 776099) Mr. M. K. Gandhi was one of the first arrivals at Chowpatty with several volunteers, and by 6.30 a.m., or earlier he had taken his seat on one of the stone benches with about a hundred satyagrahis around him....As the day advanced people kept pouring in on the seashore.
('17', 381, 6, 10, 776370) Every new arrival took his bath in the sea first and then came and sat round Mr. Gandhi.
('17', 381, 6, 11, 776459) In this manner the crowd swelled and swelled until it became one huge mass of people.
('17', 381, 6, 12, 776545) Mr. Gandhi, as the time for the meeting on Chowpatty sands neared, moved in that direction, where he was shortly joined by Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, Mr. Jamnadas Dwarkadas, Mr. Horniman and others.
('17', 381, 6, 13, 776738) There were also about twenty five ladies.
('17', 381, 6, 14, 776780) It was a splendid sight at this time, for the whole Sand hurst Bridge swarmed with people and there must have been approximately one and a half lakhs of people....
('17', 381, 6, 15, 776944) All communities were represented there— Mahomedans, Hindus, Parsis, etc., and one Englishman.
('17', 381, 6, 16, 777038) Mahomedans joined the main body of the people at Chowpatty in strong numbers....At exactly eight o’clock, Mr. Gandhi made his speech.
('17', 381, 6, 17, 777172) As he was too ill, the speech was read for him by Mr. Jamnadas.
('17', 381, 7, 18, 777236) MR. GANDHI’S EXHORTATION TO TAKE SWADESHI VOW
('17', 381, 8, 19, 777282) Mr. Gandhi in the beginning said those who wanted to take the swadeshi vow could do so on the Ramnavmi day 1 after taking their bath early in the morning.
('17', 381, 9, 20, 777437) this particular meeting was not the proper occasion for that; if there were any people there who wanted to take the vow, they were welcome to do that.
('17', 381, 9, 21, 777588) There was a world of difference between boycott and swadeshi, for boycott was a sort of punishment, while the swadeshi vrat 2 was a religious duty.
('17', 381, 9, 22, 777736) If they wanted to take the swadeshi vow they
('17', 381, 10, 23, 777781) should do so with due and deliberate consideration.
('17', 381, 10, 24, 777833) He himself was one of the staunchest swadeshists and perhaps the strictest, but if the people wanted to move in
('17', 381, 11, 25, 777945) 1 April 9
('17', 382, 0, 1, 777955) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 383
('17', 382, 1, 2, 777996) the matter they should do so only after careful consideration of all points.
('17', 382, 1, 3, 778073) On Ramnavmi, they could all of them, if they so desired, take the swadeshi vow.
('17', 382, 1, 4, 778153) This was
('17', 382, 2, 5, 778162) repeated by Mr. Jamnadas, sentence by sentence, as Mr. Gandhi instructed him.
('17', 382, 2, 6, 778240) Mr. Jamnadas then read the speech of Mr. Gandhi.
('17', 382, 3, 7, 778289) Mr. Gandhi in his speech said:
('17', 382, 4, 8, 778320) I am anxious to say as little as possible on this occasion, which is perhaps the most solemn of our lives for most of us.
('17', 382, 4, 9, 778442) And I know that this great demonstration could be made more eloquent if we could do away with speeches.
('17', 382, 4, 10, 778546) But it is impossible to ignore the tragedy that was enacted at the capital of India last Sunday.
('17', 382, 4, 11, 778643) We have before us two authoritative versions of the episode.
('17', 382, 4, 12, 778704) Swami Shraddhanandji’s on behalf of the people and that of the Government on behalf of the local authorities.
('17', 382, 4, 13, 778814) The two do not tally.
('17', 382, 4, 14, 778836) They differ as to some of the main particulars.
('17', 382, 4, 15, 778884) An impartial observer will regard both as party statements.
('17', 382, 4, 16, 778944) I, being of the popular party, shall, therefore, for the purposes of my criticism, assume the truth of the official narrative; but there are remarkable gaps in it, amounting to an evasion of some of the charges brought against the local authorities by Sannyasi Shraddhanandji.
('17', 382, 4, 17, 779221) It should be remembered that the Sannyasi’s statement was first on the field.
('17', 382, 4, 18, 779299) The Sannyasi appeared on the scene immediately after the first firing.
('17', 382, 4, 19, 779370) He says, “I went to some Europeans, of whom one was Mr. Currie, City Magistrate, and asked them to tell me the true facts.
('17', 382, 4, 20, 779493) They treated me with indifference, Mr. Currie actually turning his back upon me.
('17', 382, 4, 21, 779574) I told him that I was taking the people away to the meeting ground, although early, and he ought not to threaten people by making a display of military and machine guns.” In my humble opinion, it was the duty of the Government to deal with this charge.
('17', 382, 4, 22, 779827) Mr. Currie must have, or ought to have, known the Sannyasi.
('17', 382, 4, 23, 779887) He is not a young man unknown to fame.
('17', 382, 4, 24, 779926) He occupies a recognized status in the Indian world and it was common knowledge at the time the occurrence took place that he was one of the principal leaders in the satyagraha movement in Delhi.
('17', 382, 4, 25, 780122) Did Mr. Currie ignore the Sannyasi?
('17', 382, 4, 26, 780158) The Sannyasi has described in graphic language the threat used by the Gurkhas.
('17', 382, 4, 27, 780237) Were rifles pointed at him and was he insolently told Tum ko chhed denge 1 ?
('17', 382, 4, 28, 780314) Did a Gurkha brandish
('17', 382, 5, 29, 780336) 1 “We shall pierce you”
('17', 383, 0, 1, 780360) 384 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 383, 1, 2, 780402) before him his naked kukri 1 right and left?
('17', 383, 1, 3, 780447) It would appear that had the authorities endeavoured to regulate the crowd through its natural leaders, there need have been no display or use of military force.
('17', 383, 1, 4, 780609) But the authorities last Sunday simply followed out the traditional policy of ignoring leaders and of overawing the people.
('17', 383, 1, 5, 780733) Assuming every one of the statements in the official communique to be correct, as I have remarked in my letter to the Press, there was no warrant for firing on innocent people.
('17', 383, 1, 6, 780910) At the worst, what was it that the men could have done ?
('17', 383, 1, 7, 780967) It is clear that the men were absolutely unarmed.
('17', 383, 1, 8, 781017) An Indian crowd is the easiest in the world to disperse.
('17', 383, 1, 9, 781074) In any other place but India, the police would have been deemed sufficient to meet an emergency of the Delhi type and then, too, they would have been armed with nothing more than batons.
('17', 383, 2, 10, 781261) AN INCIDENT AT DURBAN
('17', 383, 3, 11, 781283) I remember an occasion when a mob of 6,000 Europeans, who had been previously inflamed by their leaders, tried to lynch one who, I believe, had given no cause for it.
('17', 383, 3, 12, 781450) After a hot pursuit by the lynchers, he found shelter in a friend’s house, which was also the latter’s shop.
('17', 383, 3, 13, 781559) Towards evening, the crowd in a determined manner marched to the house, and demanded delivery of the victim of their wrath on pain of burning down the shop.
('17', 383, 3, 14, 781716) Lives of nearly twenty men, women and children were at stake.
('17', 383, 3, 15, 781778) Goods worth £20,000 might have been destroyed.
('17', 383, 3, 16, 781825) Here, if at any time, the use of the military would have been justified.
('17', 383, 3, 17, 781898) But the Superintendent of Police would not summon any such aid.
('17', 383, 3, 18, 781962) He alone with his dozen constables scattered amongst the crowd, defended the lives and property that were in danger, and after three hours’ contending with the crowd, he succeeded in stealing the victim through the crowd to the police station, and finally in dispersing the lynchers.
('17', 383, 3, 19, 782246) This happened on the 13th day of January, 1897, in Durban.
('17', 383, 3, 20, 782305) 2 Unlike the Durban crowd, the Delhi crowd was without a mind of its own.
('17', 383, 3, 21, 782379) It threatened to do nothing beyond, as alleged in the communique, refusing to disperse.
('17', 383, 3, 22, 782467) The authorities could have without the aid of the military surely succeeded in guarding the station, and could then have left the crowd to its own resources.
('17', 383, 3, 23, 782625) But unfortunately, almost throughout India, it has
('17', 383, 4, 24, 782676) 1 Curved knife
('17', 383, 5, 25, 782691) 2Vide “Memorial to Secretary of State for the Colonies” and An Autobiography, Part III, Ch. III.
('17', 384, 0, 1, 782788) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 385
('17', 384, 1, 2, 782829) become customary to summon the military on the slightest pretext.
('17', 384, 1, 3, 782895) I have, however, no desire to labour this question any further.
('17', 384, 1, 4, 782959) It is enough for us to know that no harm was done to anybody by any action of the crowd and, that on this occasion the crowd was neither overawed nor infuriated.

('17', 388, 1, 2, 793284) 360. “SATYAGRAHI” : I
('17', 388, 2, 3, 793306) BOMBAY, April 7, 1919
('17', 388, 3, 4, 793328) The following are the contents of the Satyagrahi, the unregistered newspaper,
('17', 388, 4, 5, 793406) which Mahatma Gandhi issued on Monday in defiance of the Indian Press Act: (Please read, copy and circulate among friends; and also request them to copy and circulate this paper) No.
('17', 388, 4, 6, 793589) 1Price: one pice
('17', 388, 5, 7, 793606) SATYAGRAHI (Editor: Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, Laburnum Road, Gamdevi, Bombay) Published every Monday at 10 a.m.
('17', 388, 5, 8, 793720) Bombay, 7th April, 1919
('17', 388, 6, 9, 793744) NOTICE TO SUBSCRIBERS
('17', 388, 7, 10, 793766) This paper has not been registered according to law.
('17', 388, 7, 11, 793819) So there can be no annual subscription.
('17', 388, 7, 12, 793859) Nor can it be guaranteed that the paper will be published without interruption.
('17', 388, 7, 13, 793939) The editor is liable at any moment to be arrested by the Government and it is impossible to ensure continuity of publication until India is in the happy position of supplying editors enough to take the place of those arrested.
('17', 388, 7, 14, 794166) We shall leave no stone unturned to secure a ceaseless succession of editors.
('17', 388, 8, 15, 794244) It is not our intention to break for all time the law governing publication of newspapers.
('17', 388, 8, 16, 794335) This paper will, therefore, exist so long only as the Rowlatt legislation is not withdrawn.
('17', 388, 9, 17, 794427) OUR CREDENTIALS
('17', 388, 10, 18, 794443) Our credentials are best supplied by answering the question, What will the Satyagrahi do ?
('17', 388, 10, 19, 794534) Satyagrahi has come into being for the sake of ensuring withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation.
('17', 388, 10, 20, 794629) Its business, therefore, is to show the people ways of bringing about such with drawal in accordance with the principles of satyagraha.
('17', 388, 10, 21, 794765) The Satya graha Pledge requires the signatories to court imprisonment by offer ing civil disobedience by committing a civil breach of certain laws.
('17', 388, 10, 22, 794913) This publication can, therefore, show the best remedy in one way and that is by committing civil disobedience in the very act of publishing this journal.
('17', 388, 10, 23, 795067) In other forms of pubic activity, the speaker is not
('17', 389, 0, 1, 795120) 390 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 389, 1, 2, 795162) obliged to act as he preaches.
('17', 389, 1, 3, 795193) The object is to draw attention to this contradiction as a fault.
('17', 389, 1, 4, 795259) It is a method of doing pubic work.
('17', 389, 1, 5, 795295) The method of satyagraha is unique.
('17', 389, 1, 6, 795331) In it example alone is precept.
('17', 389, 1, 7, 795363) Therefore, whatever are suggested herein will be those that have been tested by personal experience, and remedies thus tested will be like well tried medicine more valuable than new.
('17', 389, 1, 8, 795546) We hope therefore that our readers will not hesitate to adopt our advice based as it will be on experience.
('17', 389, 3, 9, 795654) Yesterday many great events took place; but none was as great as that owing to the ceaseless efforts of satyagrahis the mill hands celebrated the National Day by working in their respective mills as they were unable to get permission of their employers.
('17', 389, 3, 10, 795908) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1919
('17', 389, 4, 11, 795939) 361. INSTRUCTIONS TO SATYAGRAHIS 1
('17', 389, 5, 12, 795974) [BOMBAY, April 7, 1919] We are now in a position to expect to be arrested any moment, It is, therefore, necessary to bear in mind that, if anyone is arrested, he should without causing any difficulty allow himself to be arrested and, if summoned to appear before a court, he should do so.
('17', 389, 5, 13, 796263) No defence should be offered and no pleaders engaged in the matter.
('17', 389, 5, 14, 796331) If a fine is imposed with the alternative of imprisonment, imprisonment should be accepted.
('17', 389, 5, 15, 796423) If only a fine is imposed, it ought not to be paid but that his property, if he has any, should be allowed to be sold.
('17', 389, 5, 16, 796542) There should be no demonstration of grief or otherwise made by the remaining satyagrahis by reason of the arrest and imprisonment of their comrade.
('17', 389, 5, 17, 796690) It cannot be too often repeated that we court imprisonment and we may not complain of it when we actually receive it.
('17', 389, 5, 18, 796808) When once imprisoned, it is our duty to conform to all prison regulations, as prison reform is no part of our campaign at the present moment.
('17', 389, 5, 19, 796950) A satyagrahi may not resort to surreptitious practices, of which ordinary prisoners are often found to be guilty.
('17', 389, 5, 20, 797064) All a satyagrahi does can only and must be done openly.
('17', 389, 6, 21, 797120) The Bombay Chronicle, 9 4 1919
('17', 389, 7, 22, 797151) 1 Issued as a leaflet along with Satyagrahi, 7 4 1919

('17', 390, 1, 2, 797246) 362. STATEMENT ON LAWS FOR CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE
('17', 390, 2, 3, 797292) [April 7, 19I9]
('17', 390, 3, 4, 797308) The following statement has been issued by the Satyagraha Sabha: The committee contemplated by the Satyagraha Pledge has advised that for the time being laws regarding prohibited literature and registration of newspapers may be civilly disobeyed.
('17', 390, 3, 5, 797555) With reference to prohibited literature, the committee has selected the following prohibited works 1 for dissemination: Hind Swarajya by M. K. Gandhi.
('17', 390, 3, 6, 797706) Sarvodaya or Universal Dawn by M. K. Gandhi (being a paraphrase of Unto This Last).
('17', 390, 4, 7, 797790) The Story of a Satyagrahi by M. K. Gandhi (being a paraphrase of the Defence and Death of Socrates by Plato).
('17', 390, 5, 8, 797900) The Life and Address of Mustafa Kamal Pasha (printed at the International Printing Press).
('17', 390, 6, 9, 797991) In making this selection, the community has been guided by the following considerations:
('17', 390, 7, 10, 798080) (1) To cause as little disturbance as possible among the governors and the governed;
('17', 390, 8, 11, 798165) (2) Until satyagrahis have become seasoned, disciplined and capable of handling delicately organized movements, to select such laws only as can be disobeyed individually; (3) To select, as a first step, laws that have evoked popular disapproval and that from the satyagraha standpoint, are the most open to attack;
('17', 390, 9, 12, 798480) (4) To select laws whose civil breach would constitute an edu cation for the people, showing them a clear way out of the difficulties that lie in the path of honest men desiring to do public work;
('17', 390, 10, 13, 798677) (5) Regarding prohibited literature, to select such books and pamphlets as are not inconsistent with satyagraha, and which are, therefore, of a clean type and which do not, either directly or indirectly, approve of or encourage violence.
('17', 390, 11, 14, 798915) 1 These publications were proscribed by the Bombay Government in March 1910 for containing “seditious” matter; vide “Our Publifcations”, 7 5 1910.
('17', 391, 0, 1, 799062) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 391, 1, 2, 799104) HOW TO COMMIT CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE Satyagrahis should receive copies of prohibited literature for distribution.
('17', 391, 1, 3, 799214) A limited number of copies can be had from the secretaries of the Satyagraha Sabha.
('17', 391, 1, 4, 799298) Satyagrahis should, so far as possible, write their names and addresses as sellers, so that they may be traced easily when wanted by Government for prosecution.
('17', 391, 1, 5, 799459) Naturally there can be no question of secret sale of this literature.
('17', 391, 1, 6, 799529) At the same time there should be no forwardness, either, in distributing it.
('17', 391, 1, 7, 799606) It is open to satyagrahis to form small groups of men and women to whom they may read this class of literature.
('17', 391, 1, 8, 799718) The object in selected prohibited literature is not merely to commit a civil breach of the law regarding it, but it is also to supply people with clean literature of a high moral value.
('17', 391, 1, 9, 799904) It is expected that the Government will confiscate such literature.
('17', 391, 1, 10, 799972) Satyagraha is and has to be as independent of finance as possible.
('17', 391, 1, 11, 800039) When, therefore, copies are confiscated, satya grahis are required to make copies of prohibited literature themselves or by securing the assistance of willing friends and to make use of it until it is confiscated by giving readings to the people from it.
('17', 391, 1, 12, 800294) It is stated that such readings would amount to dissemination of prohibited literature.
('17', 391, 1, 13, 800382) When whole copies are exhausted by dissemination or confiscation, satyagrahis may continue civil disobedience by writing out and distributing extracts from accessible books.
('17', 391, 1, 14, 800556) Regarding civil breach of the law governing the publication of newspapers, the idea is to publish in every satyagraha centre a written newspaper, without registering it.
('17', 391, 1, 15, 800726) It need not occupy more than one side of half a foolscap.
('17', 391, 1, 16, 800784) When such a newspaper is edited, it will be found how difficult it is to fill up half a sheet.
('17', 391, 1, 17, 800879) It is a well known fact that a vast majority of newspapers contain much padding.
('17', 391, 1, 18, 800960) Further, it cannot be denied that newspaper articles written under the terror of the very strict newspaper law have a double meaning 1. A satyagrahi, for whom punishments provided by law have lost all terror, can give only in an unregistered newspaper his thoughts and opinions unham pered by any other consideration than that of his own conscience.
('17', 391, 1, 19, 801310) His newspaper, therefore, if otherwise well edited, can become a most powerful vehicle for transmitting pure ideas in a concise manner, and there need be no fear of inability to circulate a handwritten news paper; for it will be the duty of those who may receive the first copies to recopy till at last the process of multiplication is made to cover, if necessary, the whole of the masses of India.
('17', 391, 1, 20, 801709) And it must not be
('17', 391, 2, 21, 801728) 1 For Gandhiji’s views on the mission of a newspaper, vide “Newspapers”, before 14 11 1917.
('17', 392, 0, 1, 801820) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 393
('17', 392, 1, 2, 801861) forgotten that we have in India the tradition of imparting instruction by oral teaching.

('17', 393, 7, 9, 802795) 366. THE SWADESHI VOW I
('17', 393, 8, 10, 802819) [April 8, 1919] 2
('17', 393, 9, 11, 802837) Although the desire for swadeshi animating a large number of people at the present moment is worthy of all praise, it seems to me that they have not fully realized the difficulty in the way of its obse rvance.
('17', 393, 9, 12, 803047) Vows are always taken only in respect of matters otherwise difficult of accomplishment.
('17', 393, 9, 13, 803135) When after a series of efforts we fail in doing certain things, by taking a vow to do them we draw a cordon round ourselves, from which we may never be free and thus we avoid failures.
('17', 393, 9, 14, 803320) Anything less than such inflexible determination cannot be called a vow.
('17', 393, 9, 15, 803393) It is not a pledge or vow when we say we shall so far as possible do certain acts.
('17', 393, 9, 16, 803476) If by saying that we shall so far as we can only use swadeshi articles, we can be deemed to have taken the swadeshi vow, then from the Viceroy down to the labouring man very few people would be found who could not be considered to have taken the pledge, but we want to go outside this circle and aim at a much higher goal.
('17', 393, 9, 17, 803799) And there is as much difference between the act
('17', 393, 10, 18, 803847) 1 Commissioner of Police, Bombay
('17', 393, 11, 19, 803880) 2 Vide the Associated Press of India report dated Bombay, April 8, which read: “Mr. M. K. Gandhi has left for Delhi.
('17', 393, 11, 20, 803997) In his absence the ceremony of taking swadeshi vow which was fixed for today has been postponed.
('17', 393, 11, 21, 804094) Mr. Gandhi before his departure left a message for those desiring to take the vow explaining the difference between swadeshi and boycott.”
('17', 394, 0, 1, 804233) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 395
('17', 394, 1, 2, 804274) contemplated by us and the acts above described as there is between a right angle and all other angles.
('17', 394, 1, 3, 804378) And if we decide to take the swadeshi vow in this spirit, it is clear that it is well nigh impossible to take an all comprehensive vow.
('17', 394, 1, 4, 804514) After having given deep consideration to the matter for a number of years, it is sufficiently demonstrated to me that we can take the full swadeshi vow only in respect of our clothing, whether made of cotton, silk or wool.
('17', 394, 1, 5, 804737) Even in observing this vow, we shall have to face many difficulties in the initial stages and that is only proper.
('17', 394, 1, 6, 804852) By patronizing foreign cloth we have committed a deep sin.
('17', 394, 1, 7, 804911) We have condoned an occupation which in point of importance is second only to agriculture, and we are face to face with a total disruption of a calling to which Kabir was born and which he adorned.
('17', 394, 1, 8, 805109) One meaning of the swadeshi vow suggested by me is that in taking it we desire to do penance for our sins, that we desire to resuscitate the almost lost art of hand weaving, and that we are determined to save our Hindustan crores of rupees which go out of it annually in exchange for the cloth we receive.
('17', 394, 1, 9, 805415) Such high results cannot be attained without difficulties; there must be obstacles in the way.
('17', 394, 1, 10, 805510) Things easily obtained are practically of no value, but however difficult of observance that pledge may be, some day or other there is no escape from it if we want our country to rise to its full height.
('17', 394, 1, 11, 805714) And we shall then accomplish the vow when we shall deem it a religious duty to use only that cloth which is entirely produced in the country and refrain from using any other.
('17', 394, 2, 12, 805889) A HASTY GENERALIZATION
('17', 394, 3, 13, 805912) Friends tell me that at the present moment we have not enough swadeshi cloth to supply our wants and that the existing mills are too few for the purpose.
('17', 394, 3, 14, 806066) This appears to me to be a hasty generalization.
('17', 394, 3, 15, 806115) We can hardly expect such good fortune as to have thirty crores of covenanters for swadeshi.
('17', 394, 3, 16, 806208) A hardened optimist dare not expect more than a few lakhs and I anticipate no difficulty in providing them with swadeshi cloth, but where there is a question of religion there is no room for thoughts of difficulties.
('17', 394, 3, 17, 806425) The general climate of India is such that we require very little clothing.
('17', 394, 3, 18, 806500) It is an exaggeration to say that three fourths of the middle class population use much unnecessary clothing.
('17', 394, 3, 19, 806610) Moreover, when many men take the vow, there would be set up many spinning wheels and handlooms.
('17', 394, 3, 20, 806706) India can produce innum erable weavers.
('17', 394, 3, 21, 806746) They are merely awaiting encouragement.
('17', 394, 3, 22, 806786) Mainly two
('17', 395, 0, 1, 806797) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 395, 1, 2, 806839) things are needful, viz., self denial and honsety.
('17', 395, 1, 3, 806890) It is self evident that the covenanter must possess these two qualities, but in order to enable people to observe such a great vow comparatively easily, our merchants also will need to be blessed with these qualities.
('17', 395, 1, 4, 807108) An honest and self denying merchant will spin his yarn only from Indian cotton and confine weaving only to such cotton.
('17', 395, 1, 5, 807228) He will only use those dyes which are made in India.
('17', 395, 1, 6, 807281) When a man desires to do a thing he cultivates the necessary ability to remove difficulties in his path.
('17', 395, 2, 7, 807386) DESTROY ALL FOREIGN CLOTHING
('17', 395, 3, 8, 807415) It is not enough that we manage if necessary with as little clothing as possible, but for a full observance it is further necessary to destroy all foreign clothing in our possession.
('17', 395, 3, 9, 807598) If we are satisfied that we erred in making use of foreign cloth, that we have done an immense injury to India, that we have all but destroyed the race of weavers, cloth stained with such sin is only fit to be destroyed.
('17', 395, 3, 10, 807819) In this connection, it is necessary to understand the distinction between swadeshi and boycott.
('17', 395, 3, 11, 807915) Swadeshi is a religious conception.
('17', 395, 3, 12, 807951) It is the natural duty imposed upon every men.
('17', 395, 3, 13, 807998) The well being of people depends upon it and the swadeshi vow cannot be taken in a punitive or revengeful spirit.
('17', 395, 3, 14, 808112) The swadeshi vow is not derived from any extraneous happening, whereas boycott is a purely worldly and political weapon.
('17', 395, 3, 15, 808233) It is rooted in ill will and a desire for punishment, and I can see nothing but harm in the end for a nation that resorts to boycott.
('17', 395, 3, 16, 808367) One who wishes to be a satyagrahi forever cannot participate in any boycott movement and a perpetual satyagraha is impossible without swadeshi.
('17', 395, 3, 17, 808511) This is the meaning I have understood to be given to boycott.
('17', 395, 3, 18, 808573) It has been suggested that we should boycott British goods till the Rowlatt legislation is withdrawn and that the boycott should terminate with the removal of that legislation.
('17', 395, 3, 19, 808750) In such a scheme of boycott, it is open to us to take Japanese or other foreign goods even though they may be rotten.
('17', 395, 3, 20, 808868) If I must use foreign goods, having political relations with England, I would only take English goods and consider such conduct to be proper.
('17', 395, 3, 21, 809010) In proclaiming a boycott of British goods, we expose ourselves to the charge of desiring to punish the English but we have no quarrel with them; our quarrel is with the governors.
('17', 395, 3, 22, 809190) And, according to the law of satyagraha, we may not harbour any ill will even against the rulers, and as we may harbour no ill will, I cannot see the propriety of resorting to boycott.

('17', 396, 1, 2, 809416) THE SWADESHI PLEDGE
('17', 396, 2, 3, 809436) For a complete observance of the restricted swadeshi vow suggested above, I would advise the following text: “With God as my witness, I solemnly declare that from today I shall confine myself, for my personal requirements, to the use of cloth, manufactured in India from Indian cotton, silk and wool; and I shall altogether abstain from using foreign cloth, and I shall destroy all foreign cloth in my possession.” I hope that many men and women will be ready to take this vow, and the public taking of the pledge will be desirable only if many men and women are ready for it.
('17', 396, 2, 4, 810013) Even a few men and women may publicly take the pledge, but in order to make swadeshi a national movement, it is necessary that many should join it.
('17', 396, 2, 5, 810161) Those who approve of the proposed movement should, in my opinion, lose no time in taking effective steps to begin it.
('17', 396, 2, 6, 810279) It is necessary to interview merchants.
('17', 396, 2, 7, 810319) At the same time, there need be no undue haste.
('17', 396, 2, 8, 810367) The foundation of swadeshi should be well and truly laid.
('17', 396, 2, 9, 810425) This is the right time for it as I have found that when a purifying movement like satyagraha is going on allied activities have an easy chance of success.

('17', 396, 3, 11, 810639) 367. THE SWADESHI VOW II
('17', 396, 4, 12, 810664) [April 8, 1919] The following is the text of the swadeshi vow: “With God as my witness, I solemnly declare that from today I shall confine myself, for my personal requirements, to the use of cloth manufactured in India from Indian cotton, silk or wool and I shall altogether abstain from using foreign cloth, and I shall destroy all foreign cloth in my possession.” For a proper observance of the pledge, it is really necessary to use only hand woven cloth made out of hand spun yarn.
('17', 396, 4, 13, 811149) Imported yarn, even though spun out of Indian cotton and woven in India, is not swadeshi cloth.
('17', 396, 4, 14, 811245) We shall reach perfection only when our cotton is spun in India on indigenous spinning wheels and yarn so spun is woven on similarly made handlooms.
('17', 396, 4, 15, 811394) But requirements of the foregoing pledge are met, if we all only use cloth woven by means of imported machinery from yarn spun from Indian cotton by means of similar machinery.
('17', 397, 0, 1, 811571) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 397, 1, 2, 811613) I may add that covenanters to the restricted swadeshi referred to here will not rest satisfied with swadeshi clothing only.
('17', 397, 1, 3, 811737) They will extend the vow to all other things as far as possible.
('17', 397, 2, 4, 811802) ENGLISH OWNED MILLS
('17', 397, 3, 5, 811822) I am told that there are in India English owned mills which do not admit Indian share holders.
('17', 397, 3, 6, 811917) If this information be true, I would consider cloth manufactured in such mills to be foreign cloth.
('17', 397, 3, 7, 812017) Moreover, such cloth bears the taint of ill will.
('17', 397, 3, 8, 812067) However well made such cloth may be, it should be avoided.
('17', 397, 3, 9, 812126) The majority do not give thought to such matters.
('17', 397, 3, 10, 812176) All cannot be expected to consider whether their actions promote or retard the welfare of their country, but it behoves those, who are learned, those who are thoughtful, whose intellects are trained or who are desirous of serving their country, to test every action of theirs, whether public or private, in the manner aforesaid, and when ideals which appear to be of national importance and which have been tested by practical experience should be placed before the people as has been said in the Divine Song, “the multitude will copy the actions of the enlightened”.
('17', 397, 3, 11, 812744) Even thoughtful men and women have not hitherto generally carried on the above mentioned self examination.
('17', 397, 3, 12, 812851) The nation has therefore suffered by reason of this neglect.
('17', 397, 3, 13, 812912) In my opinion, such self examination is only possible where there is religious perception.
('17', 397, 3, 14, 813003) Thousands of men believe that by using cloth woven in Indian mills, they comply with the requirements of the swadeshi vow.
('17', 397, 3, 15, 813126) The fact is that most fine cloth is made of foreign cotton spun outside.
('17', 397, 3, 16, 813199) Therefore the only satisfaction to be derived from the use of such cloth is that it is woven in India.
('17', 397, 3, 17, 813302) Even on handlooms for very fine cloth only foreign yarn is used.
('17', 397, 3, 18, 813367) The use of such cloth does not amount to an observance of swadeshi.
('17', 397, 3, 19, 813435) To say so is simple self deception.
('17', 397, 3, 20, 813471) Satyagraha, i.e., insistence on truth is necessary even in swadeshi.
('17', 397, 3, 21, 813540) When men will say, “we shall confine ourselves to pure swadeshi cloth, even though we may have to remain satisfied with a mere loin cloth”, and when women will resolutely say, “we shall observe pure swadeshi even though we may have to restrict ourselves to clothing just enough to satisfy the sense of modesty”, then shall we be successful in the observance of the great swadeshi vow.
('17', 397, 3, 22, 813925) If a few thousand men and women were to take the swadeshi vow in this spirit, others will try to imitate them so far as possible.
('17', 397, 3, 23, 814055) They will then begin to examine their wardrobes in the light of swadeshi.
('17', 397, 3, 24, 814129) Those who are
('17', 398, 0, 1, 814143) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 399
('17', 398, 1, 2, 814184) not attached to pleasures and personal adornment, I venture to say, can give a great impetus to swadeshi.
('17', 398, 2, 3, 814290) KEY TO ECONOMIC SALVATION
('17', 398, 3, 4, 814316) Generally speaking, there are very few villages in India without weavers.
('17', 398, 3, 5, 814390) From time immemorial, we have had village farmers and village weavers, as we have village carpenters, shoemakers, blacksmiths, etc., but our farmers have become poverty stricken and our weavers have patronage only from the poor classes.
('17', 398, 3, 6, 814627) By supplying them with Indian cloth spun in India, we can obtain the cloth we may need.
('17', 398, 3, 7, 814715) For the time being it may be coarse, but by constant endeavours, we can get our weavers to weave out of fine yarn and so doing we shall raise our weavers to a better status, and if we would go a step still further, we can easily cross the sea of difficulties lying in our path.
('17', 398, 3, 8, 814993) We can easily teach our women and our children to spin and weave cotton, and what can be purer than cloth woven in our own home?
('17', 398, 3, 9, 815122) I tell it from my experience that acting in this way we shall be saved from many a hardship, we shall be ridding ourselves of many an unnecessary need, and our life will be one song of joy and beauty.
('17', 398, 3, 10, 815323) I always hear divine voices telling me in my ears that such life was a matter of fact once in India, but even if such an India be the idle dream of the poet, it does not matter.
('17', 398, 3, 11, 815501) Is it not necessary to create such an India now, does not our purushartha lie therein ?
('17', 398, 3, 12, 815589) I have been travelling throughout India.
('17', 398, 3, 13, 815630) I cannot bear the heart rending cry of the poor.
('17', 398, 3, 14, 815679) The young and old all tell me, “We cannot get cheap cloth, we have not the means wherewith to purchase dear cloth.
('17', 398, 3, 15, 815794) Everything is dear—provisions, cloth and all.
('17', 398, 3, 16, 815840) What are we to do?” And they heave a sigh of despair.
('17', 398, 3, 17, 815894) It is my duty to give these men a satisfactory reply.
('17', 398, 3, 18, 815948) It is the duty of every servant of the country but I am unable to give a satisfactory reply.
('17', 398, 3, 19, 816041) It should be intolerable for all thinking Indians that our raw materials should be exported to Europe and that we have to pay heavy prices therefor.
('17', 398, 3, 20, 816190) The first and the last remedy for this is swadeshi.
('17', 398, 3, 21, 816242) We are not bound to sell our cotton to anybody and when Hindustan rings with the echoes of swadeshi, no producer of cotton will sell it for its being manufactured in foreign countries.
('17', 398, 3, 22, 816427) When swadeshi pervades the country, everyone will be set a thinking why cotton should not be refined and spun and woven in the place where it is produced, and when the swadeshi mantra resounds in every ear, millions of men will have in their hands the key to the economic salvation of India.
('17', 398, 3, 23, 816719) Training for this does not require hundreds of years.
('17', 398, 3, 24, 816773) When the
('17', 399, 0, 1, 816782) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 399, 1, 2, 816824) religious sense is awakened, people’s thoughts undergo a revolution in a single moment.
('17', 399, 1, 3, 816912) Only selfless sacrifice is the sine qua non.
('17', 399, 1, 4, 816957) The spirit of sacrifice pervades the Indian atmosphere at the present moment.
('17', 399, 1, 5, 817035) If we fail to preach swadeshi at this supreme moment, we shall have to wring our hands in despair.
('17', 399, 1, 6, 817134) I beseech every Hindu, Mussulman, Sikh, Parsi, Christian and Jew, who believes that he belongs to this country, to take the swadeshi vow and to ask others also to do likewise.

('17', 399, 3, 12, 817683) 368. THE VOW OF HINDU MUSLIM UNITY
('17', 399, 4, 13, 817718) April 8, 1919 1
('17', 399, 5, 14, 817734) The following is a free translation, approved by Mr. Gandhi, of his leaflet 2 on Hindu Muslim unity:
('17', 399, 6, 15, 817835) In the huge mass meeting of Hindus and Mahomedans held in the Sonapur Masjid compound on Sunday, the 6th April, the day of humiliation and prayer, a vow of Hindu Muslim unity was proposed to be taken as in the case of swadeshi proposed at the Chowpatty meeting and I had to utter a note of warning on both the occasions.
('17', 399, 6, 16, 818156) At times in a fit of joyous passion we are spurred on to certain courses of action for which we have afterwards to repent.
('17', 399, 6, 17, 818279) A vow is a purely religious act which cannot be taken in a fit of passion.
('17', 399, 6, 18, 818354) It can be taken only with a mind purified and composed and with God as witness.
('17', 399, 6, 19, 818434) Most of what I have said whilst writing about the swadeshi vow applies here.
('17', 399, 6, 20, 818511) Acts which are not possible by ordinary self denial become possible with the aid of vows which require extraordinary self denial.
('17', 399, 6, 21, 818641) It is hence believed that vows can only uplift us.
('17', 399, 6, 22, 818692) If the Hindu and Muslim communities could be united in one bond of mutual friendship, and if each could act towards the other even as children of the same mother, it would be a consummation devoutely to be wished.
('17', 399, 7, 23, 818906) 1Vide Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('17', 399, 8, 24, 818933) 2 This appears to be Satyagraha Leaflet No.
('17', 400, 0, 1, 818977) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 401
('17', 400, 1, 2, 819017) But before this unity becomes a reality, both the communities will have to give up a good deal, and will have to make radical changes in ideas held heretofore.
('17', 400, 1, 3, 819177) Members of one community when talking about those of the other at times indulge in terms so vulgar that they but acerbate the relations between the two.
('17', 400, 1, 4, 819330) In Hindu society we do not hesitate to indulge in unbecoming language when talking of the Mahomedans and vice versa.
('17', 400, 1, 5, 819447) Many believe that an ingrained and ineradicable animosity exists between the Hindus and Mahomedans.
('17', 400, 1, 6, 819547) In many places we see that each community harbours distrust against the other.
('17', 400, 1, 7, 819626) Each fears the other.
('17', 400, 1, 8, 819648) It is an undoubted fact that this anomalous and wretched state of things is improving day by day.
('17', 400, 1, 9, 819746) The Time Spirit is ceaselessly working on unchecked, and willy nilly we have to live together.
('17', 400, 1, 10, 819841) But the object of taking a vow is speedily to bring about, by the power of self denial, a state of things which can only be expected to come in the fulness of time.
('17', 400, 1, 11, 820006) How is this possible?
('17', 400, 1, 12, 820028) Meetings should be called of Hindus—I mean the orthodox Hindus— where this question should be seriously considered.
('17', 400, 1, 13, 820144) The standing complaint of the Hindus against the Mussulmans is that the latter are beef eaters and that they purposely sacrifice cows on the Bakr i ld day.
('17', 400, 1, 14, 820300) Now it is impossible to unite the Hindus and Mahomedans so long as the Hinuds do not hesitate to kill their Mahomedan brethren in order to protect a cow.
('17', 400, 1, 15, 820454) For I think it is futile to expect that our violence will ever compel the Mahomedans to refrain from cow slaughter.
('17', 400, 1, 16, 820570) I do not believe the efforts of our cow protection societies have availed in the least to lessen the number of cows killed every day.
('17', 400, 1, 17, 820704) I have had no reason to believe so.
('17', 400, 1, 18, 820740) I believe myself to be an orthodox Hindu and it is my conviction that no one who scrupulously practises the Hindu religion may kill a cow killer to protect a cow.
('17', 400, 1, 19, 820903) There is one and only one means open to a Hindu to protect a cow and that is that he should offer himself a sacrifice if he cannot stand its slaughter.
('17', 400, 1, 20, 821055) Even if a very few enlightened Hindus thus sacrificed themselves, I have no doubt that our Mussulman brethren would abandon cow slaughter.
('17', 400, 1, 21, 821194) But this is satyagraha; this is equity; even as, if I want my brother to redress a grievance, I must do so by taking upon my head a certain amount of sacrifice and not by inflicting injury on him.
('17', 400, 1, 22, 821391) I may not demand it as of right.
('17', 400, 1, 23, 821424) My only right against my brother is that I can offer myself a sacrifice.
('17', 400, 2, 24, 821497) It is only when the Hindus are inspired with a feeling of pure love of this type that Hindu Muslim unity can be expected.
('17', 400, 2, 25, 821619) As with

('17', 401, 1, 2, 821669) the Hindus, so with the Musssulmans.
('17', 401, 1, 3, 821706) The leaders among the latter should meet together and consider their duty towards the Hindus.
('17', 401, 1, 4, 821800) When both are inspired by a spirit of sacrifice, when both try to do their duty towards one another instead of pressing their rights, then and then only would the long standing differences between the two communities cease.
('17', 401, 1, 5, 822024) Each must respect the other’s religion, must refrain from even secretly thinking ill of the other.
('17', 401, 1, 6, 822123) We must politely dissuade members of both the communities from indulging in bad language against one another.
('17', 401, 1, 7, 822233) Only a serious endeavour in this direction can remove the estrangement between us.
('17', 401, 1, 8, 822316) Our vow would have value only when masses of Hindus and Mussulmans join in the endeavour.
('17', 401, 1, 9, 822406) I think I have now made sufficiently clear the seriousness and magnitude of this vow.
