('17', 406, 6, 8, 830572) 376. MESSAGE TO COUNTRYMEN
('17', 406, 7, 9, 830599) April 9, 1919
('17', 406, 8, 10, 830613) Mr. Desai, Secretary to Mahatma Gandhi, writes:
('17', 406, 9, 11, 830661) Mahatma Gandhi on his way to Delhi was served with an order at Kosi not to enter the Punjab, not to enter Delhi and restrict himself to Bombay.
('17', 406, 9, 12, 830805) The officer serving the order treated him most politely assuring him that it would be his most painful duty to arrest him if he elected to disobey, but that there would be no ill will between them.
('17', 406, 9, 13, 831003) Mr. Gandhi smilingly said, he must elect to disobey as it was his duty and that the officer ought also to do what was his duty.
('17', 406, 9, 14, 831131) In the few minutes that were left to us, he dictated the following message, laying special emphasis on his oral message to me, as in the written message that none should resent his arrest or do anything tainted with untruth or violence which were sure to damn the sacred cause.
('17', 406, 10, 15, 831409) The message reads: 1
('17', 406, 12, 16, 831430) MY COUNTRYMEN It is a matter of the highest satisfaction to me, as I hope to you, that I have received an order from the Punjab Government not to enter that province and another from the Delhi Government not to enter Delhi, while an order 2 of the Government of India, served on me

('17', 406, 14, 18, 831828) 1 Up to this the report is from The Leader, 12 4 1919
('17', 406, 15, 19, 831882) 2 The order dated Lahore, April 9, 1919, read: “WHEREAS in the opinion of the Local Government, there are reasonable grounds for believing that Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, son of, , resident of village Rajkot, Kathiawar, in the Bombay Presidency, has acted in a manner prejudicial to the public safety, the Lieutenant Governor, with the previous sanction of the Governor General 
('17', 407, 0, 1, 832262) 408 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 407, 1, 2, 832304) immediately after, restricts me to Bombay.
('17', 407, 1, 3, 832347) I had no hesitation in saying to the officer who served the order on me that I was bound in virtue of my Pledge to disregard it which I have done and I shall presently find myself a free man, my body being taken by them into their custody.
('17', 407, 1, 4, 832587) It was galling to me to remain free whilst the Rowlatt legislation disfigured the Statute book.
('17', 407, 1, 5, 832683) My arrest makes me free.
('17', 407, 1, 6, 832708) It now remains for you to do your duty which is clearly stated in the Satyagraha Pledge.
('17', 407, 1, 7, 832797) Follow it and you will find it will be your Kamadhenu 1. I hope there will be no resentment about my arrest.
('17', 407, 1, 8, 832906) I have rec eived what I was seeking, either withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation or imprisonment.
('17', 407, 1, 9, 833005) The departure from truth by a hair’s breadth or violence committed against anybody, whether Englishman or Indian, will surely damn the great cause the satyagrahis are handling.
('17', 407, 1, 10, 833182) I hope the Hindu Muslim unity, which seems now to have taken a firm hold of the people, will become a reality and I feel convinced that it will only be a reality if the suggestions I have ventured to make in my communication to the Press are carried out.
('17', 407, 1, 11, 833437) The responsibility of the Hindus in the matter is greater than that of the Mahomedans, they being in the minority, and I hope they will discharge their responsibility in a manner worthy of their country.
('17', 407, 1, 12, 833641) I have also made certain suggestions regarding the proposed swadeshi vow.
('17', 407, 1, 13, 833715) Now, I commend them to your serious attention and you will find that, as your ideas of satyagraha become matured, Hindu Muslim unity becomes part of satyagraha.
('17', 407, 2, 14, 833876) Finally, it is my firm belief that we shall obtain salvation only through suffering and not by reforms dropping on us from England, no matter how unstintingly they might be granted.
('17', 407, 2, 15, 834058) The English are a great nation, but the weaker also go to the wall if they come in contact with them.
('17', 407, 2, 16, 834160) When they are themselves courageous, they have borne untold sufferings, and they only respond to courage and suffering, and partnership with them is only possible after we have developed
('17', 407, 3, 17, 834347) in Council, is pleased hereby to direct that the said Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi shall forthwith return to Bombay and, until further orders, reside within the limits of the Bombay Presidency.
('17', 407, 3, 18, 834539) By order of His Honour the Lieutenant Governor of the Punjab, Ashghar Ali, Additional Secretary”
('17', 407, 4, 19, 834636) 1 Mythical cow yielding whatever is wished for
('17', 408, 0, 1, 834683) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 409
('17', 408, 1, 2, 834723) indomitable courage and a faculty for unlimited suffering.
('17', 408, 1, 3, 834782) There is a fundamental difference between their civilization and ours.
('17', 408, 1, 4, 834853) They believe in the doctrine of violence or brute force as the final arbiter.
('17', 408, 1, 5, 834931) My reading of our civilization is that we are expected to believe in soul force or moral force as the final arbiter and this is satyagraha.
('17', 408, 1, 6, 835071) We are groaning under the sufferings which we would avoid if we could, because we have swerved from the path laid down for us by our ancient civilization.
('17', 408, 1, 7, 835226) I hope that Hindus, Mahomedans, Sikhs, Parsees, Christians, Jews and all who are born in India or who have made India their land of adoption will fully participate in these national observances and I hope, too, that women will take therein as full a share as men.

('17', 410, 1, 2, 837713) 380. SATYAGRAHA LEAFLET 1: NO.
('17', 410, 2, 3, 837744) April 11, 1919
('17', 410, 3, 4, 837759) MAHATMA GANDHI’S WARNING TO SATYAGRAHIS AND SYMPATHIZERS
('17', 410, 4, 5, 837816) On Friday evening the 12th day 2 of April, 1919, on the Chawpati sea beach, Mahatma Gandhi sounded the following note of warning to satyagrahis and sympathizers assembled in a mass meeting:
('17', 410, 5, 6, 838006) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, This is not the moment for me to enter into the near past.
('17', 410, 5, 7, 838087) I must refer to what has just happened.
('17', 410, 5, 8, 838127) As you see I have been set free by the Government.
('17', 410, 5, 9, 838178) The two days’ detention was no detention for me.
('17', 410, 5, 10, 838227) It was like heavenly bliss.
('17', 410, 5, 11, 838255) The officials in charge of me were all attention and all kindness to me.
('17', 410, 5, 12, 838328) Whatever I needed was supplied to me, and I was afforded greater comforts than I am used to when free.
('17', 410, 5, 13, 838431) I have not been able to understand so much excitement and disturbance that followed my detention.
('17', 410, 5, 14, 838529) It is not satyagraha.
('17', 410, 5, 15, 838551) It is worse than duragraha 3. Those who join satyagraha demonstration are bound at all hazards to refrain from violence, not to throw stones or in any way whatsoever to injure anybody.
('17', 410, 5, 16, 838736) But in Bombay, we have been throwing stones.
('17', 410, 5, 17, 838781) We have obstructed tram cars by putting obstacles in the way.
('17', 410, 5, 18, 838843) This is not satyagraha.
('17', 410, 5, 19, 838867) We have demanded the release of about 50 men who have been arrested for committing deeds of violence.
('17', 410, 5, 20, 838969) Our duty is quietly to submit to being arrested.
('17', 410, 5, 21, 839018) It is a breach of religion or duty to endeavour to secure the release of those who have committed deeds of violence.
('17', 410, 5, 22, 839135) We are not therefore justified on any grounds whatsoever for demanding the release of those who have been arrested.
('17', 410, 5, 23, 839251) I have been asked whether a satyagrahi is liable for the results that follow from that movement.
('17', 410, 5, 24, 839348) I have replied that they are.
('17', 410, 5, 25, 839378) I therefore wish to suggest that if we cannot conduct this movement without the slightest violence from our side, the movement might have
('17', 410, 6, 26, 839516) 1 The original has “Satyagraha Series”.
('17', 410, 6, 27, 839556) For Satyagraha Leaflet No.
('17', 410, 6, 28, 839583) 1, vide “Satyagraha Leaflet No.

('17', 411, 1, 2, 839808) to be abandoned or it may be necessary to give it a different and still more restricted shape.
('17', 411, 1, 3, 839903) The time may come for me to offer satyagraha against ourselves.
('17', 411, 1, 4, 839967) I would not deem it a disgrace that we die.
('17', 411, 1, 5, 840011) I shall be pained to hear of the death of a satyagrahi.
('17', 411, 1, 6, 840067) But I shall consider it to be a proper sacrifice given for the sake of the struggle.
('17', 411, 1, 7, 840152) But if those who are not satyagrahis, who have not joined the movement, who are even against it, receive any injury at all, every satyagrahi will be responsible for that sinful injury.
('17', 411, 1, 8, 840337) My responsibility will be a million times heavier.
('17', 411, 1, 9, 840388) I have embarked upon the struggle with a due sense of such responsibility.
('17', 411, 1, 10, 840463) I have even just heard that some Englishmen have been injured.
('17', 411, 1, 11, 840526) Some may have died from such injuries.
('17', 411, 1, 12, 840565) If so, it would be a great blot upon satyagraha.
('17', 411, 1, 13, 840614) For me Englishmen too are our brethren.
('17', 411, 1, 14, 840654) We can have nothing against them.
('17', 411, 1, 15, 840688) And for me sins such as I have described are simply unbearable.
('17', 411, 1, 16, 840752) But I know how to offer satyagraha against ourselves as against the rulers.
('17', 411, 1, 17, 840828) What kind of satyagraha can I offer gainst ourselves on such occasions?
('17', 411, 1, 18, 840900) What penance can I do for such sins?
('17', 411, 1, 19, 840937) The satyagraha and the penance I can conceive can only be one and that is for me to fast and if need be by so doing to give up this body and thus to prove the truth of satyagraha.
('17', 411, 1, 20, 841117) I appealed to you that you will all quietly disperse, keep the peace and even refrain from acts that may in any way bring disgrace upon the people of Bombay.
('17', 411, 1, 21, 841275) We need not consider the conduct of the police, nor is this the occasion for such consideration.
('17', 411, 1, 22, 841372) We are beholden to H.E. the Governor and the police for the entire absence of rifle fire, or gunfire.
('17', 411, 1, 23, 841474) But the one thing to be remembered is that we should learn how to observe perfect peace and how to undergo intelligent suffering.
('17', 411, 1, 24, 841604) Without this there is no satyagraha.

('17', 412, 1, 2, 841846) 381. TALK TO MAHOMEDANS, BOMBAY
('17', 412, 2, 3, 841878) April 11, 1919
('17', 412, 3, 4, 841893) On Friday a number of Mahomedans called at Mr. Gandhi’s place in connection with the arrests that had been made that day.
('17', 412, 3, 5, 842015) Mahatma Gandhi, explaining to them the true meaning of satyagraha, said if they were arrested whilst practising duragraha, they deserved no sympathy, and if they were arrested whilst offering satyagraha, they should consider it their duty to go to jail; so that neither way would anybody be justified in demanding the release of those who had been arrested.
('17', 412, 3, 6, 842373) The Mahatma then dwelt upon the supreme necessity of Hindu Muslim unity.
('17', 412, 3, 7, 842446) The Bombay Chronicle, 14 4 l919
('17', 412, 4, 8, 842478) 382. INSTRUCTIONS REGARDING SATYAGRAHA
('17', 412, 5, 9, 842517) [April 12, 1919] In order that satyagraha may have full play and a chance of permeating the masses, in my humble opinion, the following instructions should be STRICTLY obeyed.
('17', 412, 5, 10, 842693) Some of the items may require change later.
('17', 412, 5, 11, 842737) The rest are inviolable principles of satyagraha.
('17', 412, 5, 12, 842787) No processions.
('17', 412, 5, 13, 842803) No organized demonstrations.
('17', 412, 5, 14, 842832) No hartals on any account whatsoever without previous instructions of the committee.
('17', 412, 5, 15, 842917) All police orders to be implicitly obeyed.
('17', 412, 5, 16, 842960) No violence.
('17', 412, 5, 17, 842973) No stone throwing.
('17', 412, 5, 18, 842992) No obstruction of tram cars or traffic.
('17', 412, 5, 19, 843032) No pressure to be exercised against anyone.
('17', 412, 6, 20, 843076) AT PUBLIC MEETINGS
('17', 412, 7, 21, 843095) No clapping of hands.
('17', 412, 7, 22, 843117) No demonstrations of approval or disapproval.
('17', 412, 7, 23, 843163) No cries of “Shame!”.
('17', 412, 7, 24, 843185) No cheers.
('17', 412, 7, 25, 843196) Perfect stillness.
('17', 412, 7, 26, 843215) Perfect obedience to instructions of volunteers or management.
('17', 412, 8, 27, 843278) MOHANDAS K. GANDHI The Bombay Chronicle, 14 4 1919
('17', 413, 0, 1, 843329) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 413, 1, 2, 843371) 383. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('17', 413, 2, 3, 843399) April 12, 1919
('17', 413, 3, 4, 843414) In an interview given to Press representatives, Mahatma Gandhi is reported to have said that he had as yet come to no definite decision as to whether or not he would go to Delhi.
('17', 413, 3, 5, 843593) He once again appealed to the public to conduct the struggle against the Rowlatt Bills in a spirit of true satyagraha and to refrain from any acts of violence.
('17', 413, 3, 6, 843753) They should all sympathize with those who might be arrested whilst carrying on the satyagraha struggle but they should not demand their release, for it was the duty of true satyagrahis to go to jail.
('17', 413, 3, 7, 843953) He had absolutely no sympathy whatever with those who were duragrahis.
('17', 413, 3, 8, 844024) They must be punished for their misdeeds and they could claim
('17', 413, 4, 9, 844086) no sympathy from the public.
('17', 413, 4, 10, 844115) He added he firmly believed that if they conducted their struggle in the true spirit of satyagraha, without any acts of violence, the Rowlatt Bills would quickly disappear from the Statute book.
('17', 413, 4, 11, 844310) Considering all circumstances, the satyagraha movement might have to be given a different and still more restricted shape.
('17', 413, 4, 12, 844433) The satyagraha struggle must be conducted in a quiet and peaceful manner and in the true spirit of satyagraha.
('17', 413, 4, 13, 844544) He concluded with another earnest appeal to the public to behave in a peaceful manner and refrain from any acts of violence.

('17', 414, 2, 7, 846549) 385. MESSAGE TO PEOPLE OF AHMEDABAD
('17', 414, 3, 8, 846585) April 13, 1919 Bai Anasuya Behn and I have arrived in Ahmedabad this morning.
('17', 414, 3, 9, 846663) Bai Anasuya Behn was never arrested.
('17', 414, 3, 10, 846700) I also was absolutely free on Friday, and went to Bombay.
('17', 414, 3, 11, 846758) During the time I was in custody, I suffered no kind of trouble, my condition was such as if I was enjoying heavenly happiness.
('17', 414, 3, 12, 846886) After getting free, I became extremely sorry on hearing of the occurrences at Ahmedabad.
('17', 414, 3, 13, 846975) Behn’s heart bled.
('17', 414, 3, 14, 846994) We both felt exceedingly ashamed.
('17', 414, 3, 15, 847028) Now, we both have come to meet you.
('17', 414, 3, 16, 847064) It is necessary to say a couple of words; therefore, I don’t wish to say anything now.
('17', 414, 3, 17, 847151) I also wish, as all of you must be wishing, that martial law should be instantly removed.
('17', 414, 3, 18, 847241) It is in our own hands to get it removed.
('17', 414, 3, 19, 847283) I want to show the key with which this can be done.
('17', 414, 3, 20, 847335) Those who can do so should come to the Ashram at 4 p.m.
('17', 414, 3, 21, 847391) on Monday.
('17', 414, 3, 22, 847402) While coming take the routes where there are no military pickets.
('17', 414, 3, 23, 847468) Do not come in groups of more than two or three persons.
('17', 414, 3, 24, 847525) Obey whatever orders the police give you.
('17', 414, 3, 25, 847567) It is my request that you do not shout or make any kind of noise on the road, and if you will all preserve silence at the Ashram, I shall be able to explain all that I wish to explain.
('17', 414, 3, 26, 847752) It is extremely desirable that all shopkeepers should open their shops and all mill hands resume their work.
('17', 414, 3, 27, 847861) In conclusion, I wish to say that I am so sure about satyagraha that, if the mistakes which have been committed here and at other places had not been committed, the Rowlatt Bill would have been cancelled today.
('17', 414, 3, 28, 848072) May God give you all good understanding and peace.

('17', 415, 4, 6, 848394) SELF EXAMINATION
('17', 415, 5, 7, 848411) Satyagraha has made unexpectedly rapid progress in course of one short week.
('17', 415, 5, 8, 848488) But it is necessary to consider whether the movement is progressing in the right direction or not.
('17', 415, 5, 9, 848587) Several very regrettable and untoward incidents have occurred.
('17', 415, 5, 10, 848650) It has been brought home to satyagrahis that satyagraha is not an easy weapon to handle.
('17', 415, 5, 11, 848739) Satyagrahis have been often asked if they are not responsible for the varied consequences of this struggle.
('17', 415, 5, 12, 848847) We have always answered this inquiry in the affirmative.
('17', 415, 5, 13, 848904) Satyagrahis will always follow truth, and will not by thought, word or deed hurt anybody.
('17', 415, 5, 14, 848994) They will carry on the struggle with such self restraint and discipline as will enable them to acquire firm control over the people whose sympathy and co operation they desire and have already been successful in winning in such an appreciable degree.
('17', 415, 5, 15, 849245) The experience of the last week has clearly shown that satyagrahis are not yet in a position to control the masses.
('17', 415, 5, 16, 849361) The true spirit of satyagraha has not yet permeated the people with the result that they are not yet able to express their feelings in a manner worthy of satyagraha.
('17', 415, 5, 17, 849527) This undoubtedly casts a slur upon satyagraha.
('17', 415, 5, 18, 849574) All the same the satyagrahi will not be discouraged.
('17', 415, 5, 19, 849627) It is only when the Rowlatt legislation is withdrawn or when he has sacrificed himself at the altar of truth that he will rest.
('17', 415, 5, 20, 849755) He will learn from his daily experience during the struggle, educate the people, explain to them in public and in private the secret of satyagraha.
('17', 415, 5, 21, 849903) He will make it clear to them what priceless happiness can be found in suffering in refraining from returning evil for evil, in adhering to truth, in
('17', 415, 6, 22, 850053) 1 Further issues did not come out due to the suspension of satyagraha, vide The Bombay Chronicle, 22 4 1919, which read: “We have been informed by the Satyagraha Sabha that as civil disobedience has been temporarily suspended the publication of the weekly Satyagrahi will be discontinued and the unlicensed printing press will also be closed during the suspension period.”

('17', 416, 1, 2, 850466) sacrificing himself.
('17', 416, 1, 3, 850487) He will capture their hearts with love and will show them how to conquer our enemies by love.
('17', 416, 1, 4, 850581) The path of a satyagrahi is beset with insurmountable difficulties.
('17', 416, 1, 5, 850649) But in true satyagraha there is neither disappointment nor defeat.
('17', 416, 1, 6, 850716) As truth is all powerful, satyagraha can never be defeated.

('17', 417, 6, 9, 852696) 388. LETTER TO J. L. MAFFEY
('17', 417, 7, 10, 852724) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 14, 1919
('17', 417, 8, 11, 852762) DEAR MR. MAFFEY, You will not consider that I was discourteous in not sending even an acknowledgment of your last letter.
('17', 417, 8, 12, 852884) The fact is that I have treasured that letter as worthy of you and the friendship that I hope will ever exist between us, no matter what differences of opinion and standpoint there may be between us.
('17', 417, 8, 13, 853084) I did not wish to send you a mere acknow ledgment, I wanted to reach a decided stage before writing to you again, and I have also reached more than a decided stage, and in the place I have made my abode I find utter lawlessness bordering almost on Bolshevism.
('17', 417, 8, 14, 853344) Englishmen and women have found it necessary to leave their bungalows and to confine themselves to a few well guarded houses.
('17', 417, 8, 15, 853470) It is a matter of the deepest humiliation and regret for me.
('17', 417, 8, 16, 853531) I see that I over calculated the measure of permeation of satyagraha amongst the people.
('17', 417, 8, 17, 853620) I underrated the power of hatred and ill will.
('17', 417, 8, 18, 853667) My faith in satyagraha remains undiminished, but I am only a poor creature just as liable to err as any other.
('17', 417, 8, 19, 853778) I am correcting the error.
('17', 417, 8, 20, 853805) I have somewhat retraced my steps for the time being.
('17', 417, 9, 21, 853859) 1 Collector of Ahmedabad
('17', 418, 0, 1, 853884) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 419
('17', 418, 1, 2, 853924) I feel convinced that my co workers can regulate and restrain crowds, and keep them peaceful, I promise to refrain from seeking to enter Delhi or the other parts of the Punjab.
('17', 418, 1, 3, 854101) My satyagraha, therefore, will, at the present moment, be directed against my own countrymen.
('17', 418, 1, 4, 854195) I do want, however, to say that it was a grievous blunder of the Government of India to have served those orders on me.
('17', 418, 1, 5, 854315) Surely they knew me too well to make such a mistake.
('17', 418, 1, 6, 854368) I could not disregard my Pledge and I was not going to Delhi or to the Punjab to create any disturbance.
('17', 418, 1, 7, 854473) Wherever I have gone, my presence has had a demonstrably restrain ing and soothing influence.
('17', 418, 1, 8, 854567) I was going to Delhi, Lahore and Amrit sar—to the latter places, if certain conditions of mine had been fulfil led—for the purpose of insuring peace, and though the events at Amritsar are, so far as I can see, unconnected with satyagraha and my arrest, I feel sure that had I been able to proceed to these places, the awful occurrences could have been avoided, and I think there would be perfect agreement with me when I say that the mad incendiarism that has taken place in Ahmedabad would have never occurred, if the orders had not been served upon me.
('17', 418, 1, 9, 855122) I venture to suggest therefore that the orders may be withdrawn.
('17', 418, 1, 10, 855187) Rightly or wrongly, I seem to com mand, at the present moment, in an excessive degree the respect and affection of the people all over India.
('17', 418, 1, 11, 855329) The non withdrawal of the orders would be resented by them.
('17', 418, 1, 12, 855389) In order that the resentment may not grow by reason of any avoidable action of mine, I have even refrained from describing them and the manner in which they were served.
('17', 418, 1, 13, 855559) I have even not corrected the inaccuracies that have appeared in the Press—inaccuracies which are designed to make light of my arrest.
('17', 418, 1, 14, 855694) So much for the orders.
('17', 418, 1, 15, 855718) I know you will accept my assurance when I tell you that ever since my being brought to Bombay, and liberated there, I have done nothing but assist in securing order, first in Bombay and secondly in Ahmedabad.
('17', 418, 1, 16, 855928) Even as I am dictating this letter, visitors are pouring in at the Ashram at my invitation.
('17', 418, 1, 17, 856020) I hope to send you, if not with this letter, under separate cover, by the next post the text 1 of my address to the Bombay meeting and to the meeting to be held here today.
('17', 418, 1, 18, 856193) I would like, too, to place before you my reading of the situa tion.
('17', 418, 1, 19, 856262) The ferment among the Mahomedans is too great to be checked for ever.
('17', 418, 1, 20, 856332) It may burst like a torrent at any moment and behind the

('17', 419, 5, 19, 858239) 389. SPEECH AT MASS MEETING, AHMEDABAD 1
('17', 419, 6, 20, 858280) April 14, 1919
('17', 419, 7, 21, 858295) BROTHERS, I mean to address myself mainly to you.
('17', 419, 7, 22, 858345) Brothers, the events that have happened in the course of the last few days have been most
('17', 419, 8, 23, 858435) 1 At Gandhiji’s Ashram, Sabarmati.
('17', 419, 8, 24, 858470) Copies of the speech in Gujarati were distributed in thousands.
('17', 420, 0, 1, 858534) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 421
('17', 420, 1, 2, 858574) disgraceful to Ahmedabad, and as all these things have happened in my name, I am ashamed of them, and those who have been respon sible for them have thereby not honored me but disgraced me.
('17', 420, 1, 3, 858764) A rapier run through my body could hardly have pained me more.
('17', 420, 1, 4, 858827) I have said times without number that satyagraha admits of no violence, no pillage, no incendiarism; and still in the name of satyagraha, we burnt down buildings, forcibly captured weapons, extorted money, stopped trains, cut off telegraph wires, killed innocent people and plundered shops and private houses.
('17', 420, 1, 5, 859137) If deeds such as these could save me from the prison house or the scaffold, I should not like to be so saved.
('17', 420, 1, 6, 859247) I do wish to say in all earnestness that violence has not secured my discharge.
('17', 420, 1, 7, 859327) A most brutal rumour was set afloat that Anasuya Bai was arrested.
('17', 420, 1, 8, 859394) The crowds were infuriated all the more, and disturbance increased.
('17', 420, 1, 9, 859462) You have thereby disgraced Anasuya Bai and, under the cloak of her arrest, heinous deeds have been done.
('17', 420, 1, 10, 859567) These deeds have not benefited the people in any way.
('17', 420, 1, 11, 859621) They have done nothing but harm.
('17', 420, 1, 12, 859654) The buildings burnt down were public property and they will naturally be rebuilt at our expense.
('17', 420, 1, 13, 859751) The loss due to the shops remaining closed is also our loss.
('17', 420, 1, 14, 859812) The terrorism prevailing in the city due to martial law is also the result of this violence.
('17', 420, 1, 15, 859905) It has been said that many innocent lives have been lost as a result of the operation of martial law.
('17', 420, 1, 16, 860007) If this is a fact, then for that, too, the deeds described above are responsible.
('17', 420, 1, 17, 860089) It will be seen that the events that have happened have done nothing but harm to us.
('17', 420, 1, 18, 860174) Moreover, they have most seriously damaged the satyagraha movement.
('17', 420, 1, 19, 860242) Had an entirely peaceful agitation followed my arrest, the Rowlatt Act would have been out or on the point of being out of the Statute book today.
('17', 420, 1, 20, 860389) It should not be a matter for surprise if the withdrawal of the Act is now delayed.
('17', 420, 1, 21, 860473) When I was released on Friday, my plan was to start for Delhi again on Saturday to seek re arrest, and that would have been an accession of strength to the movement.
('17', 420, 1, 22, 860639) Now, instead of going to Delhi, it remains to me to offer satyagraha against our people, and as it is my determination to offer satyagraha even unto death for securing the withdrawal of the Rowlatt legislation, I think the occasion has arrived when I should offer satyagraha against ourselves for the violence that has occurred.
('17', 420, 1, 23, 860968) And I shall do so at the sacrifice of my body, so long as we do not keep perfect peace and cease from violence to person and property How can I seek imprisonment unless I have absolute confidence that we shall no longer be guilty of such errors?
('17', 420, 1, 24, 861214) Those desirous of joining the

('17', 421, 1, 2, 861286) satyagraha movement or of helping it must entirely abstain from violence.
('17', 421, 1, 3, 861360) They may not resort to violence even on my being re arrested or on some such events happening.
('17', 421, 1, 4, 861455) Englishmen and women have been compelled to leave their homes and confine themselves to places of protection in Shahi Baug, because their trust in our harmlessness has received a rude shock.
('17', 421, 1, 5, 861646) A little thinking should convince us that this is a matter of humiliation for us all.
('17', 421, 1, 6, 861732) The sooner this state of things stops, the better for us.
('17', 421, 1, 7, 861790) They are our brethren and it is our duty to inspire them with the belief that their persons are as sacred to us as our own and this is what we call abhayadan 1, the first requisite of true religion.
('17', 421, 1, 8, 861989) Satyagraha without this is duragraha.
('17', 421, 1, 9, 862027) There are two distinct duties now before us.
('17', 421, 1, 10, 862072) One is that we should firmly resolve upon refraining from all violence, and the other is that we should repent and do penance for our sins.
('17', 421, 1, 11, 862212) So long as we do not repent and do not realize our errors and make an open confession of them, we shall not truly change our course.
('17', 421, 1, 12, 862345) The first step is that those of us who have captured weapons should surrender them.
('17', 421, 1, 13, 862429) To show that we are really patient, we will contribute each of us not less than eight annas towards helping the families of those who have been killed by our acts.
('17', 421, 1, 14, 862593) Though no amount of money contribution can altogether undo the results of the furious deeds of the past few days, our contribution will be a slight token of our repentance.
('17', 421, 1, 15, 862766) I hope and pray that no one will evade this contribution on the plea that he has had no part in those wicked acts.
('17', 421, 1, 16, 862881) For if such as those who were no party to these deeds had all courageously and bravely gone forward to put down the lawlessness, the mob would have been checked in their career and would have immediately realized the wickedness of their doings.
('17', 421, 1, 17, 863126) I venture to say that if, instead of giving money to the mob out of fear, we had rushed out to protect buildings and to save the innocent without fear of death, we could have succeeded in so doing.
('17', 421, 1, 18, 863324) Unless we have this sort of courage, mischief makers will always try to intimidate us into participating in their misdeeds.
('17', 421, 1, 19, 863448) Fear of death makes us devoid both of valour and religion.
('17', 421, 1, 20, 863507) For, want of valour is want of religious faith.
('17', 421, 1, 21, 863555) And having done little to stop the violence, we have been all participators in the sins that have been committed.
('17', 421, 1, 22, 863669) And we ought, therefore, to contribute our mite as a mark of our repentance.
('17', 421, 1, 23, 863746) Each group can collect its own contributions and send them on to me through its collectors.

('17', 421, 2, 25, 863889) 1 Assurance of safety

('17', 422, 2, 4, 864120) I have thus far drawn attention to what appears to be your duty.

('17', 422, 2, 8, 864378) I have also given some contribution to the special service of Ahmedabad.
('17', 422, 2, 9, 864451) Its citizens are not quite unfamiliar with my views.
('17', 422, 3, 10, 864504) It is alleged that I have, without proper consideration, persuaded thousands to join the movement.
('17', 422, 3, 11, 864603) That allegation is, I admit, true to a certain extent, but to a certain extent only.
('17', 422, 3, 12, 864688) It is open to anybody to say that but for the satyagraha campaign, there would not have been this violence.
('17', 422, 3, 13, 864796) For this, I have already done a penance, to my mind an unendurable one, namely, that I have had to postpone my visit to Delhi to seek re arrest and I have also been obliged to suggest a temporary restriction of satyagraha to a limited field.
('17', 422, 3, 14, 865038) This has been more painful to me than a wound, but this penance is not enough, and I have, therefore, decided to fast for three days, i.e., 72 hours.
('17', 422, 3, 15, 865188) I hope my fast will pain no one.
('17', 422, 3, 16, 865221) I believe a seventy two hours’ fast is easier for me than a twenty four hours’ fast for you.
('17', 422, 3, 17, 865314) And I have imposed on me a discipline which I can bear.
('17', 422, 3, 18, 865370) If you really feel pity for the suffering that will be caused to me, I request that that pity should always restrain you from ever again being party to the criminal acts of which I have complained.
('17', 422, 3, 19, 865568) Take it from me that we are not going to win swarajya or benefit our country in the least by violence and terrorism.
('17', 422, 3, 20, 865685) I am of opinion that if we have to wade through violence to obtain swarajya and if a redress of grievances were to be only possible by means of ill will for and slaughter of Englishmen, I, for one, would do without that swarajya and without a redress of those grievances.
('17', 422, 3, 21, 865957) For me life would not be worth living if Ahmedabad continues to countenance violence in the name of truth.
('17', 422, 3, 22, 866064) The poet has called Gujarat garvi (great and glorious) Gujarat.
('17', 422, 3, 23, 866128) Ahmedabad, its capital, is the residence of many religious Hindus and Mahomedans.
('17', 422, 3, 24, 866210) Deeds of public violence in a city like this are like an ocean being on fire.
('17', 422, 3, 25, 866288) Who can quench that fire ?
('17', 422, 3, 26, 866315) I can only offer myself as a sacrifice to be burnt in that fire, and I therefore ask you all to help in the attainment of the result that I desire out of my fast.
('17', 422, 3, 27, 866478) May the love that lured you into unworthy acts awaken you to a sense of the reality, and if that
('17', 423, 0, 1, 866575) 424 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 423, 1, 2, 866617) love does continue to animate you, beware that I may not have to fast myself to death.
('17', 423, 1, 3, 866704) It seems that the deeds I have complained of have been done in an organized manner.
('17', 423, 1, 4, 866788) There seems to be a definite design about them, and I am sure that there must be some educated and clever man or men behind them.
('17', 423, 1, 5, 866918) They may be educated, but their education has not enlightened them.
('17', 423, 1, 6, 866986) You have been misled into doing these deeds by such people.
('17', 423, 1, 7, 867046) I advise you never to be so misguided, and I would ask them seriously to reconsider their views.
('17', 423, 1, 8, 867143) To them and you I commend my book Hind Swaraj which, as I understand, may be printed and published without infringing the law thereby.
('17', 423, 1, 9, 867278) Among the mill hands, the spinners have been on strike for some days.
('17', 423, 1, 10, 867348) I advise them to resume work immediately and to ask for increase if they want any, only after resuming work, and in a reasonable manner.
('17', 423, 1, 11, 867485) To resort to the use of force to get any increase is suicidal.
('17', 423, 1, 12, 867548) I would specially advise all mill hands to altogether eschew violence.
('17', 423, 1, 13, 867619) It is [in] their interest to do so and I remind them of the promises made to do so and I remind them of the promises made to Anasuya Bai and me that they would ever refrain from violence.
('17', 423, 1, 14, 867807) I hope that all will now resume work.
('17', 423, 1, 15, 867845) The Bombay Chronicle, 17 4 1919; also Speeches and Writings of Mahatma Gandhi, pp.
('17', 423, 2, 16, 867928) 390. LETTER TO G. E. CHATFIELD

('17', 423, 4, 18, 867998) DEAR MR. CHATFIELD, Would you please give me the name and address of the sergeant who was murdered during the tragic occurrences.
('17', 423, 4, 19, 868128) I understand that there was only one English death.
('17', 423, 4, 20, 868180) If there are any other English casualties, I should like to know them and the names and addresses of their families.
('17', 423, 4, 21, 868297) As you are aware, I asked yesterday for contributions towards maintenance of the bereaved families and I know that the contributors desire to tender pecuniary assistance to the families of Englishmen who might have died or become seriously disabled during mob rule.

('17', 424, 4, 7, 869070) 392. LETTER TO SIR IBRAHIM RAHIMTOOLLA
('17', 424, 5, 8, 869109) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 15, 1919
('17', 424, 6, 9, 869147) DEAR SIR IBRAHIM RAHIMTOOLLA, Contrary to my wont, I write this letter to you in English, as I would like you to submit it to His Excellency for perusal and consi deration.
('17', 424, 6, 10, 869320) As you may know, I arrived in Ahmedabad, accompanied by Anasuya Behn on Sunday.
('17', 424, 6, 11, 869400) There was a very largely attended meeting yesterday at the Satyagraha Ashram, although it is far away from the city.
('17', 424, 6, 12, 869517) It is estimated that 10 to 15 thousand people must have attended.
('17', 424, 6, 13, 869583) There is once more perfect quiet in Ahmedabad, and although I have to say it of myself, I do wish to state that the sudden quiet is due largely, if not entirely, to the soothing effect produced by the presence of Anasuya Behn and myself.
('17', 424, 6, 14, 869821) I enclose herewith copy of my speech in Gujarati and its English translation prepared under my supervision.
('17', 424, 6, 15, 869929) In response to my invitation, money has begun to pour in, and thousands have observed the fast.
('17', 424, 6, 16, 870025) I have already written 1 to the Collec tor, enquiring about the names and addresses of the families of Englishmen who have lost their lives or have been disabled during mob rule.
('17', 424, 6, 17, 870204) Happily, I understand that these cases are not more than 2 or 3. My main purpose, however, in writing this letter is to suggest that no further punitive measures may be taken, and that no prosecutions be undertaken in respect of the tragedy.
('17', 424, 6, 18, 870446) Any arrest and trials would
('17', 424, 7, 19, 870474) 1 Vide “Letter to G.E. Chatfield”, 15 4 1919.
('17', 425, 0, 1, 870520) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 425, 1, 2, 870562) simply cause another ferment.
('17', 425, 1, 3, 870592) In my humble opinion, it would be most impolitic and unwise to select a few individuals as scapegoats, when a whole mob has taken the law in its own hands.
('17', 425, 1, 4, 870748) I performed today the painful duty of visiting the army of wounded men, including little children, in the Civil Hospital.
('17', 425, 1, 5, 870870) I understand that at least 22 have died of the wounds, but probably the real number of those who died during martial law will never be known, for I am told that some dead bodies were actually cremated in the poles 1 of Ahmedabad.
('17', 425, 1, 6, 871100) I simply wish to urge that sufficiently stern punishment has been already dealt out to Ahmedabad.
('17', 425, 2, 7, 871198) I ask the Government to believe me when I say that the ebullition was in no way due to satyagraha.
('17', 425, 2, 8, 871297) It was due to causes which came into being before the satyagraha movement was inaugurated and to the grave blunder in arresting me whilst I was on my way to Delhi, and on a most pacific mission.
('17', 425, 2, 9, 871492) I do not know within the whole of my public experience a single occasion where my presence has had anything but a soothing effect on the elements of disturbance.
('17', 425, 2, 10, 871654) My arrest gave a handle to all discontented forces to gather together and those who were sincerely mourning over my arrest out of personal affection for me involuntarily found themselves drawn into the lawless proceedings.
('17', 425, 2, 11, 871877) I wish also to state that almost every known satyagrahi was simply assisting at the peril of his life in taming the mad fury of the mob.
('17', 425, 2, 12, 872014) It was due to their work that probably the mob did not indulge in further excesses, though what has happened is bad enough.
('17', 425, 2, 13, 872138) I may be mistaken in my last deduction, but there is no mistake about the fact, that satyagrahis did their utmost best to prevent the tragedy.
('17', 425, 2, 14, 872281) But we are yet a handful.
('17', 425, 2, 15, 872307) Time may show that neither India nor the world can have anything better than satyagraha as a restraining force and a force ranged on the side of law and order.
('17', 425, 2, 16, 872467) Civil disobedience alone can inspire sincere and manly obedience.
('17', 425, 2, 17, 872533) My duty as a satyagrahi at the present moment is to refrain from doing anything that may add fuel to the fire.
('17', 425, 2, 18, 872644) I have therefore restrained myself from giving what I hold is a true analysis of the tragedy enacted in Ahmedabad.
('17', 425, 2, 19, 872759) I wish to say nothing of the events in the other parts of India.
('17', 425, 2, 20, 872824) The other causes referred to by me are three in number.
('17', 425, 2, 21, 872880) First and foremost is the profound dissatisfaction of the Mahomedans over what they fear would be the settlement of Islamic questions at the time of the Peace.
('17', 425, 2, 22, 873040) I venture to speak of this with some authority because I
('17', 425, 3, 23, 873097) 1 Residential streets
('17', 426, 0, 1, 873119) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 427
('17', 426, 1, 2, 873159) have taken great pains to ascertain Mahomedan feelings.
('17', 426, 1, 3, 873215) I have moved among Mahomedans high and low practically throughout India, and I have deemed it my duty as a Hindu to understand their position and to share their sorrows.
('17', 426, 1, 4, 873385) The second cause is the fear— vague, I know—that the Reforms that are to come will be only in name.
('17', 426, 1, 5, 873485) And the third cause is bitter resentment over the passing of the Rowlatt legislation in violent defiance of unanimously expressed public opinion.
('17', 426, 1, 6, 873631) I admit that there has been often great exaggeration indulged in by indifferent, ignorant and irresponsible speakers, but as an experienced public man of over 25 years’ standing, I know that exaggerations will not cause ebullitions such as we have witnessed in Ahmedabad, unless there is a substantial grievance behind them.
('17', 426, 1, 7, 873956) I felt that it was due to the Government that I should submit for their consideration the state of things that has come to my knowledge.
('17', 426, 1, 8, 874093) I cannot conclude this letter without expressing my gratitude for the absolute absence of firing in Bombay on Friday last.
('17', 426, 2, 9, 874216) Yours sincerely,

('17', 426, 5, 12, 874274) 393. LETTER TO SIR STANLEY REED
('17', 426, 6, 13, 874306) THE ASHRAM,
('17', 426, 7, 14, 874318) April 15, 1919
('17', 426, 8, 15, 874333) DEAR SIR STANLEY READ According to my usual custom, the time has come for me to place before you things, which, in the interests of public peace, I do not wish to ventilate in the Press.
('17', 426, 8, 16, 874520) The atmosphere is so surcharged with distrust, disaffection and ill will, that I do not want to add to the forces of evil by saying anything which may even remotely produce that result, and which it is not obligatory on me to say in public.
('17', 426, 8, 17, 874761) Though it is a small matter, may I correct the statement of your informant that I was not arrested in reality?
('17', 426, 8, 18, 874872) This is what exactly happened: An officer boarded the train 1 at Palwal, and, laying his hands on me, said, “Mr. Gandhi, I arrest you”.
('17', 426, 8, 19, 875008) I was then immedi 
('17', 426, 9, 20, 875027) 1 On the night of April 9 10
('17', 427, 0, 1, 875056) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 427, 1, 2, 875098) ately handed to an Indian sepoy—I suppose he was that—and I was taken by the arm and marched out of the train.
('17', 427, 1, 3, 875209) I was guarded by four sepoys on four sides of the cot, on which I lay in Palwal on the station platform.
('17', 427, 1, 4, 875314) I was brought to the platform out of the waiting room at my request, and I was sharply pulled up as I passed one of the guards probably two feet from him to clear my throat.
('17', 427, 1, 5, 875488) I was taken to Muttra during the night, and a guard was put in my compartment, which was a second class compartment.
('17', 427, 1, 6, 875605) We had to wait at Muttra for another train.
('17', 427, 1, 7, 875649) Early in the morning, I was again put in the second class compartment, in which accompanied by the guard, I travelled to Sawai Madhopur.
('17', 427, 1, 8, 875786) There we waited for the mail train, and on its arrival Mr. Bowring of Lahore took charge of me, put me in a first class compartment with him, but in that carriage too a guard was kept during whole of the night whilst both he and I were sleeping.
('17', 427, 1, 9, 876032) I do not wish to complain of what happened to me.
('17', 427, 1, 10, 876082) I am simply stating the naked facts to demonstrate that I was under arrest.
('17', 427, 1, 11, 876158) I would have declined to begin the return journey had I not been arrested, as I did actually mention to the officer, who served the first order upon me.
('17', 427, 1, 12, 876311) There are some other incidents which I wish to omit.
('17', 427, 1, 13, 876364) But nothing that I have said is intended to qualify or detract from the public acknowledgement of the extreme personal courtesy that was extended to me by the three officers, who were concerned with the service of the orders, the arrest and the deportation.
('17', 427, 1, 14, 876622) I hastened to Ahmedabad in company with Anasuya Behn in order that the people may be calmed and in all humility I may say that the effect of our arrival on the populace was electrical.
('17', 427, 1, 15, 876807) I placed myself unreservedly at the service of the authorities.
('17', 427, 1, 16, 876871) You will have observed that I spoke at the Monday meeting with the utmost caution.
('17', 427, 1, 17, 876954) I would like you to go through my speech sent to you for publication.
('17', 427, 1, 18, 877024) I deliberately refrained from narrating the acts done by the military under martial law.
('17', 427, 1, 19, 877113) I doubt not that there was much avoidable loss of life.
('17', 427, 1, 20, 877169) I have seen the wounded at the Civil Hospital.
('17', 427, 1, 21, 877216) I spoke to every one of them.
('17', 427, 1, 22, 877246) All of them gave me frank statements.
('17', 427, 1, 23, 877284) Many admitted that they were part of large crowds, not crowds that had any evil designs, but crowds of men, who had hardly realized what the law was.
('17', 427, 1, 24, 877434) They could not immediately upon its being proclaimed have informed themselves of the conditions.
('17', 427, 1, 25, 877531) I know that although eager crowds gathered round me to listen to my speech, and although I had printed 25 thousand copies, it has not reached all.
('17', 427, 1, 26, 877678) How then could the martial law notices indifferently distributed amongst a sullen
('17', 428, 0, 1, 877760) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 429
('17', 428, 1, 2, 877800) population inform vast bodies of men ?
('17', 428, 1, 3, 877839) These crowds, therefore, did gather.
('17', 428, 1, 4, 877876) I understand that they were fired at after due notice being given to them, but you will agree with me when I say that they could not all understand the notice to disperse.
('17', 428, 1, 5, 878048) In the hospital, I saw a few little children 10 or 11 years old.
('17', 428, 1, 6, 878113) I asked them what they were doing, and they said they had gone out to play.
('17', 428, 1, 7, 878189) A husband and wife were shot in their own house.
('17', 428, 1, 8, 878238) The wife died of the wounds.
('17', 428, 1, 9, 878267) The husband who described the affair does not say that they were deliberately aimed at, but that the bullets whizzed through the house and struck them.
('17', 428, 1, 10, 878419) Some of them told me that they were alone.
('17', 428, 1, 11, 878462) The rule was that if ten people collected together, they could be fired at.
('17', 428, 1, 12, 878538) In one case, I was told, a man, who wanted to be extra cautious, first asked the permission to pass the pickets, he got it and he passed the pickets with his friends, and as soon as they had proceeded a few paces, they received bullet wounds.
('17', 428, 1, 13, 878781) The one who asked for permission dropped down dead, and the other is in danger of losing his life.
('17', 428, 1, 14, 878880) The wound is so serious.
('17', 428, 1, 15, 878905) The view I have taken of this is that the people of Ahmedabad have no right to complain of these sad occurrences, after the ruthlessness with which the mob destroyed the property, hacked to pieces Sergeant Fraser, and committed many other excesses.
('17', 428, 1, 16, 879154) It is highly likely that the English lads—I call them lads, because they looked like lads—who were posted as pickets during martial law, had arrived on the scene with the knowledge that a wicked plot was hatched in order to kill the force that was sent from Bombay, of which these lads were members.
('17', 428, 1, 17, 879454) I refer to the derailing near Nadiad, and in their fury to wreak vengeance upon the Ahmedabad people without any nice or exact discrimination, they may have been too free with their rifles.
('17', 428, 1, 18, 879644) I describe this shooting in order to show that the people have been sufficiently punished, and there should be no further punitive measures taken and no prosecutions undertaken.
('17', 428, 1, 19, 879822) I shall now turn to the causes of this upheaval.
('17', 428, 1, 20, 879871) I have talked to over a hundred people myself, my associates of the Satyagraha Ashram and my co workers living in the city have each talked to as many, if not more, and I find that satyagraha had nothing to do with the excesses, that is to say, that it was not the alleged inculcation of the spirit of disobedience which let loose the fury of the mob.
('17', 428, 1, 21, 880223) During the seven weeks that the satyagraha campaign has been going on, there was not a word uttered to encourage ill will against a single Englishman, and I can state positively that whenever I addressed the people, the audience addressed by me became sobered, and there was
('17', 429, 0, 1, 880498) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 429, 1, 2, 880540) an appreciable change in their attitude towards the English, as also towards those Indian leaders whose policy they disliked.
('17', 429, 1, 3, 880666) My chief work, however, is done through private conversation with people who visit me wherever I go.
('17', 429, 1, 4, 880767) I have noticed the vehemence of feelings against British administration, and have noticed too that it was transferred to the administrators themselves.
('17', 429, 1, 5, 880919) After a searching cross examination, I found that they admitted their mistake and I can recall many conversions of people, who came in to express their curses, and went away, if not [with] blessings on their lips, with no unfriendliness towards the British.
('17', 429, 1, 6, 881177) I found mental lawlessness existing everywhere, and it was with the greatest difficulty that I was able to drive home the necessity for restraining this habit of continuous disparagement of law and order, and to replace it by a disciplined and conscientious disobedience, whose effect was to be confined to self suffering and not to involve any destruction of the life or property of their lawgivers or anyone else.
('17', 429, 1, 7, 881593) The lawless spirit then was already there.
('17', 429, 1, 8, 881636) There was not much time given to the spirit of satyagraha, i.e., the spirit of self restraint, to have its effect upon the people, when the Government of India criminally blundered in serving these orders upon me and in arresting me.
('17', 429, 1, 9, 881870) Nor were the forces of discontent weak.
('17', 429, 1, 10, 881910) Here they are: (1) Every Mahomedan is filled with bitterness over questions affecting Islam, and every Mahomedan thoroughly distrusts England in this matter.
('17', 429, 1, 11, 882068) The association of all classes of Mahomedans with the Hindus is significant, and the upheavals, wherever they have taken place, have, as is perfectly apparent, strong Mahomedan backing.
('17', 429, 1, 12, 882254) (2) The people have been taught to distrust Reforms in anticipation.
('17', 429, 1, 13, 882323) The masses are no longer inert.
('17', 429, 1, 14, 882355) They have a general understanding of the situation.
('17', 429, 1, 15, 882407) (3) The alarm produced by the Rowlatt legislation and deep resentment over utter defiance of public opinion.
('17', 429, 1, 16, 882516) I freely admit that there has been much ignorant and even in some cases wilful exaggeration of the effects of the Rowlatt legislation.
('17', 429, 1, 17, 882651) But after you account for all, there is a residue left, which in my opinion makes Rowlatt legislation impossible of acceptance.
('17', 429, 1, 18, 882779) I wonder if it has ever struck you that the amendment of the Preamble is of little consequence.
('17', 429, 1, 19, 882875) As Sir William Vincent very perfectly pointed out, the spirit of the legislation was that it should have operation only in cases where anarchical crime was found to exist.
('17', 429, 1, 20, 883047) The whole question turns upon, who is to be the judge?
('17', 429, 1, 21, 883102) The judge is to be the Executive Government, and is not this the procedure which the Executive has always followed in forming its judgments on these matters?
('17', 429, 1, 22, 883260) A petty
('17', 430, 0, 1, 883268) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 431
('17', 430, 1, 2, 883308) official of the C.I.D. submits a report stating the existence of anarchical crime to his superior officer, who endorses the report.
('17', 430, 1, 3, 883440) The chief of the C.I.D. then handles it and he will be an exceptionally bold Home Member who will challenge a report from the chief of the C.I.D. He will naturally therefore advise notification of the application of the Act to the area of anarchical disturbance so called.
('17', 430, 1, 4, 883713) Nobody has questioned the drastic character of the legislation.
('17', 430, 1, 5, 883777) But I must not labour this point and make the letter long.
('17', 430, 1, 6, 883836) These causes were bound sooner or later to bring about furious deeds of violence, and I can only say that satyagraha has served as a check, no matter how slight, upon them.
('17', 430, 1, 7, 884009) It is clear that the tragedy at Ahmedabad and Viramgam could have been absolutely avoided had I not been served with those orders and subsequently arrested.
('17', 430, 1, 8, 884166) The vast demonstrations took place not because it was the satyagraha movement that was in jeopardy but because it was I who was arrested.
('17', 430, 1, 9, 884304) Such is the blind affection of the people towards me.
('17', 430, 1, 10, 884358) My suggestions therefore would be that the Government should recognize satyagraha as an estimable weapon in the armoury of reformer; they should seek the assistance of Messrs Mahomed Ali and Shaukat Ali, who, so far as I am aware, are able, equally upright and well informed, and solve the Islamic question to the entire satisfaction of the intelligent Mahomedan population.
('17', 430, 1, 11, 884733) There should be some assuring declaration about the Reforms, and the Rowlatt legislation should be withdrawn.
('17', 430, 1, 12, 884843) Until these things are done, I apprehend there will be no peace in India.
('17', 430, 1, 13, 884917) The feeling in India today is like a barometer, sensitive to the slightest atmospheric pressure or change in the political field.
('17', 430, 1, 14, 885047) If you at all accept my suggestions, I know you will do all you can to secure their adoption in your own special way.
('17', 430, 1, 15, 885165) I may add.
('17', 430, 1, 16, 885176) that I have passed on most of these suggestions to the Viceroy, and those that can be locally handled to the Governor of Bombay.
('17', 430, 2, 17, 885305) Yours sincerely,
('17', 430, 3, 18, 885322) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 431, 1, 2, 885405) 394. SATYAGRAHA LEAFLET 1 NO.
('17', 431, 2, 3, 885435) [April 16, 1919] 2
('17', 431, 3, 4, 885454) MY SISTERS AND BROTHERS, I could not speak to you at length in my address at the Satyagrahashram on Monday last; but I wish to place my thoughts before the public through a few leaflets.
('17', 431, 3, 5, 885641) Let me first render accounts.
('17', 431, 3, 6, 885671) I had received till yesterday Rs. 770 towards the fund suggested by me.
('17', 431, 3, 7, 885743) I request that there should be no delay with regard to this fund, and that none in Ahmedabad should be found wanting in his duty.
('17', 431, 3, 8, 885873) This fund has had its origin in the idea of penance, but its public utility is no less than its penitential value.
('17', 431, 3, 9, 885988) I visited the Civil Hospital yesterday in company with Behn Anasuya and Mr. Krishnalal Desai 3, and spoke to all the patients there.
('17', 431, 3, 10, 886121) I see that we shall have to get pecuniary help to the families of the many of the wounded.
('17', 431, 3, 11, 886212) I learnt on the spot that 22 of the men brought there had died of the wounds.
('17', 431, 3, 12, 886290) There is no doubt, there have been many more deaths.
('17', 431, 3, 13, 886343) A clear duty, therefore, lies upon us, as citizens, to find out the families of the deceased and to give them what help we can.
('17', 431, 3, 14, 886471) I have been asked as to who will be the beneficiaries of these moneys.
('17', 431, 3, 15, 886542) I am afraid that we could not compensate those who have sustained loss of property; we can render some little help only to the families of the dead and wounded.
('17', 431, 3, 16, 886703) These include two or three Englishmen (now ascertained to be one); our first duty is to render help to their families, since we are responsible for their deaths.
('17', 431, 3, 17, 886865) We had no excuse whatsoever for killing them.
('17', 431, 3, 18, 886911) They have been killed simply out of animosity.

('17', 432, 1, 2, 887700) Some of us believe that we can obtain our rights by such acts of terrorization, violence and arson.
('17', 432, 1, 3, 887800) Satyagraha, on the contrary, holds that the rights so obtained should be rejected.
('17', 432, 1, 4, 887883) I admit that of the two parties using brute force, the one possessing more of it than the other apparently gains its ends.
('17', 432, 1, 5, 888006) My 40 years’ experience tells me that objects so attained do not permanently benefit the winner.
('17', 432, 1, 6, 888103) There may well be two opinions on this point.
('17', 432, 1, 7, 888149) But there can be no difference of opinion on the fact that so far as brute force is concerned, we are no match for the Government.
('17', 432, 1, 8, 888280) Our physical force is as nought before theirs.
('17', 432, 1, 9, 888327) I would dare say, therefore, that those who advise us to use physical force are sadly mistaken, and we should never listen to their advice.
('17', 432, 1, 10, 888467) Expediency tells us that there is one and only one recourse for us and that is satyagraha or dharmabal (i.e., spirit force).
('17', 432, 1, 11, 888592) Now dharmabal can spring only from suffering.
('17', 432, 1, 12, 888638) Oppressing, harassing, or assaulting others cannot add to our spiritual strength.
('17', 432, 1, 13, 888720) The events in Ahmedabad would have been impossible, had we but a true sense of dharma.
('17', 432, 1, 14, 888807) It is one of our duties to prevent mischief.
('17', 432, 1, 15, 888852) If the men and women of Ahmedabad could be brave, all mischief would cease.
('17', 432, 1, 16, 888928) It is obviously a far greater thing to overcome mischief by spirit force, than to do so by brute force.
('17', 432, 1, 17, 889032) We have seen that violent outbreaks have not benefited us at all.
('17', 432, 1, 18, 889098) I have already said that they had nothing to do with my release.
('17', 432, 1, 19, 889163) The outbreaks commenced on the 10th.
('17', 432, 1, 20, 889200) The decision to release me in Bombay was arrived at on the 9th.
('17', 432, 1, 21, 889264) It cannot therefore have been in any way the result of those outbreaks.
('17', 432, 1, 22, 889336) Moreover, those who have faith in satyagraha should be the last men to resort to violence to secure my release.
('17', 432, 1, 23, 889448) Let us now consider what further loss we have sustained.
('17', 432, 1, 24, 889505) I reminded you on Monday that the offices which were burnt down belonged to ourselves.
('17', 432, 1, 25, 889592) But we have an indirect ownership therein, and the fact that the expenses of re building them may perhaps not fall directly on us may make us indifferent to the mischief done.

('17', 432, 1, 29, 890080) Can we imagine the soreness of his feelings ?
('17', 432, 1, 30, 890126) Surely the incendiaries must never have thought of making up for the loss.

('17', 436, 1, 2, 896251) 398. SATYAGRAHA LEAFLET 1 NO.
('17', 436, 2, 3, 896281) [April 17, 1919] 2
('17', 436, 3, 4, 896300) CHARACTERISTICS OF MAHATMA GANDHI’S WRITINGS
('17', 436, 4, 5, 896345) There are two poems published and being distributed entitled “Mahatma Gandhino Satyagraha” and “Mahatma Gandhina Udgar.” They bear the signature of Labhshanker Harjiwandas Dihorkar.
('17', 436, 4, 6, 896527) The ideas expressed in these verses are not mine.
('17', 436, 4, 7, 896577) Some of them are poisonous, calculated to promote ill will and excite passions.
('17', 436, 4, 8, 896657) They are, therefore, opposed to satyagraha.
('17', 436, 4, 9, 896701) I therefore advise all brothers and sisters not to accept anything as written by me unless it is signed by me.
('17', 436, 4, 10, 896812) The present times are so critical that one cannot be too cautious about anything lest one might be led astray.
('17', 436, 4, 11, 896923) My writings cannot be poisonous, they must be free from anger, for it is my special religious conviction that we cannot truly attain our goal by promoting ill will against the .rulers or anyone else.
('17', 436, 4, 12, 897123) There can be no room for untruth in my writings, because it is my unshakable belief that there is no religion other than truth and because I am capable of rejecting aught obtained at the cost of truth.
('17', 436, 4, 13, 897325) My writings cannot but be free from hatred towards any individual because it is my firm belief that it is love that sustains the earth.
('17', 436, 4, 14, 897461) There only is life where there is love.
('17', 436, 4, 15, 897501) Life without love is death.
('17', 436, 4, 16, 897529) Love is the reverse of the coin of which the obverse is truth.
('17', 436, 4, 17, 897592) It is my firm faith and it is my experience of forty years that we can conquer the world by truth and love.
('17', 436, 4, 18, 897700) I believe that we can remedy the mistakes of our rulers by means of truth and love and my writings can therefore have no incitement to violence to person or property.
('17', 436, 4, 19, 897867) It is obviously not possible for me to read everything that is written or printed in, my name and I would therefore ask everyone to apply the above mentioned test to all that purports to be published in my name and I further wish and pray that everyone should reject anything that has the slightest trace of untruth, disaffection, hatred, violence and the like.
('17', 436, 4, 20, 898229) I do not know the author of the poems mentioned above, but should he see this leaflet I advise him that it is necessary for him before attributing any words or statements to anyone to show them to him and obtain his permission to publish
('17', 436, 5, 21, 898467) 1 The original has “Satyagraha Series”.
('17', 436, 6, 22, 898507) 2 Vide Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('17', 437, 0, 1, 898535) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 437, 1, 2, 898577) them as his.
('17', 437, 1, 3, 898590) This is the least that prudence and self restraint demand.

('17', 437, 5, 8, 898907) 399. LETTER TO SWAMI SHRADDHANAND
('17', 437, 6, 9, 898941) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, April 17, 1919
('17', 437, 7, 10, 898979) DEAR SHRADDHANANDJI, I write this in English as Mr. Shuaib desires that I should do so for the sake of the company before which it is to be read.
('17', 437, 7, 11, 899125) The questions 1 to which I am required to reply may be before you.
('17', 437, 7, 12, 899192) I shall, therefore, only refer to the numbers.
('17', 437, 7, 13, 899239) To question No.
('17', 437, 7, 14, 899255) 1, my answer is—non satyagrahis who join satyagraha demonstrations must for the occasion subscribe to the rules of satyagraha.
('17', 437, 7, 15, 899382) They are, therefore, bound to refrain from retaliation under the gravest provocation.
('17', 437, 7, 16, 899468) For the occasion in which non satyagrahis participate, there can be no distinction between satyagrahis and non satyagrahis.
('17', 437, 7, 17, 899592) Non satyagrahis can only join if they give an undertaking that, for the particular occasion on which we seek their association, they will subscribe to our doctrine.
('17', 437, 7, 18, 899757) I, therefore, hold that we are just as responsible for the action of non satyagrahis when they act with us as we are for our own.
('17', 437, 7, 19, 899887) I think it will be evident to you that without this understanding, satyagraha can easily be smothered by non satyagraha.
('17', 437, 7, 20, 900008) You cannot have a combination of non compatibles without an explosion.
('17', 437, 7, 21, 900079) My answer to question No.
('17', 437, 7, 22, 900105) 2 is really to be inferred from the foregoing.
('17', 437, 7, 23, 900152) I think we must apply to ourselves the ordinary rule of law more strictly because we are satyagrahis.
('17', 437, 7, 24, 900254) That a man is to be presumed to have intended the consequences that can reasonably be proved to have followed from his conduct.
('17', 437, 7, 25, 900382) I think that I at least
('17', 437, 8, 26, 900406) 1 Based on Satyagraha Leaflet No.

('17', 438, 1, 2, 900533) should have foreseen some of the consequences, specially in view of the gravest warnings that were given to me by friends whose advice I have always sought and valued.
('17', 438, 1, 3, 900701) But I confess that I am dense.
('17', 438, 1, 4, 900732) I am not joking.

('17', 438, 1, 6, 900941) There is exaggeration in this charge, but there is also a substance of truth in it.

('17', 439, 3, 17, 904572) 400. SPEECH AT PREPARATORY MEETING FOR HINDI CONFERENCE, BOMBAY 1
('17', 439, 4, 18, 904638) [Before April 18, 1919]
('17', 439, 5, 19, 904662) Consistently with the object of our meeting today, I must speak in Hindi.
('17', 439, 5, 20, 904736) On this occasion, however, I deliberately avoid using it because I want to explain its importance to you and that I shall do in Gujarati.
('17', 439, 5, 21, 904874) I think I can explain the reasons better thus.
('17', 439, 5, 22, 904921) The satyagraha now going on in India covers the issue of the Hindi language.
('17', 439, 6, 23, 904998) 1 Ninth Hindi Literary Conference; Gandhiji was in the chair but owing to his indifferent health the speech was read out on his behalf from a prepared text.
('17', 439, 6, 24, 905155) The report purports to reproduce only its more important portions.
('17', 440, 0, 1, 905222) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 441
('17', 440, 1, 2, 905262) Satyagraha is essentially a fight for truth and, if we have regard for truth, we shall have to admit that Hindi is the only language we can use as a national language.
('17', 440, 1, 3, 905430) There is no other regional language with equal claims.
('17', 440, 1, 4, 905485) We should pause and think what Hindi means.
('17', 440, 1, 5, 905529) I don’t think the Sanskritized language they use is Hindi; it is an artificial product.
('17', 440, 1, 6, 905617) Nor is Persianized Urdu Hindi.
('17', 440, 1, 7, 905648) The language we want to adopt as our national language is a mixture of Hindi and Urdu.
('17', 440, 1, 8, 905735) It is the language spoken, by and large, in Bihar, Delhi and the Punjab.
('17', 440, 1, 9, 905808) The two languages came to be treated as rivals of each other when the idea spread that Hindus and Muslims were not one people and there developed ill will between the two.
('17', 440, 1, 10, 905980) Some would regard that alone as Hindi which was full of Sanskrit words, and the Muslims would accept that alone as Urdu which used Persian and Arabic words.
('17', 440, 1, 11, 906137) But the language spoken by the average Hindu or Muslim is not of this kind.
('17', 440, 1, 12, 906213) Wherever we go and hear Hindus and Muslims speak, we find them, whether Hindus or Muslims, using Sanskrit, Persian and Arabic words, not going out of their way to avoid any.
('17', 440, 1, 13, 906387) When we have accepted this mixed language, we, Hindus and Muslims, shall have been cleansed in our hearts.
('17', 440, 1, 14, 906494) This language I speak of is understood by Muslims everywhere in North and South India, though they also know the regional language.
('17', 440, 1, 15, 906626) Look at the map again and [you will find that], except for a small part, Madras, the Hindus in the rest of India also understand it.
('17', 440, 1, 16, 906759) If we go further and think of the various regions separately, Hindi is spoken in all the provinces except Maharashtra, Gujarat, Bengal and Sind.
('17', 440, 1, 17, 906904) Even in these other provinces, including Gujarat, maulvis 1 and Hindu preachers have spread both the languages.
('17', 440, 1, 18, 907016) You will hardly find anyone not familiar with the Tulsi Ramayana.

('17', 442, 6, 11, 910996) 402. PRESS STATEMENT ON SUSPENSION OF CIVIL DISOBEDIENCE 2
('17', 442, 7, 12, 911055) BOMBAY, April 18, 1919 It is not without sorrow that I feel compelled to advise the temporary suspension of civil disobedience.
('17', 442, 7, 13, 911183) I give this advice not because I have less faith now in its efficacy, but because I have, if possible, greater faith than before.
('17', 442, 7, 14, 911313) It is my perception of the law of satyagraha which impels me to suggest the suspension.
('17', 442, 7, 15, 911401) I am sorry, when I embarked upon a mass movement, I underrated the forces of evil and I must now pause and consider how best to meet the situation.
('17', 442, 7, 16, 911549) But whilst doing so, I wish to say that from a careful examination of
('17', 442, 8, 17, 911619) 1 In reply to Natesan’s telegram of 14th April, urging suspension of civil disobedience because of breaking out of riots.
('17', 442, 8, 18, 911741) A copy of this reply telegram was also sent to C. Rajagopalachari, who was secretary, Satyagraha Sabha, Madras; vide The Hindu, 19 4 1919.
('17', 442, 9, 19, 911880) 2 Gandhiji addressed this as a letter to the secretaries of the Satyagraha Sabha, Bombay, and released it to the Press, vide the preceding item.
('17', 443, 0, 1, 912025) 444 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 443, 1, 2, 912067) the tragedy at Ahmedabad and Viramgam, I am convinced that satyagraha had nothing to do with the violence of the mob and that many swarmed round the banner of mischief raised by the mob, largely because of their affection for Anasuyabai and myself.
('17', 443, 1, 3, 912316) Had the Government in an unwise manner not prevented me from entering Delhi and so compelled me to disobey their order, I feel certain that Ahmedabad and Viramgam would have remained free from the horrors of the past week.
('17', 443, 1, 4, 912539) In other words, satyagraha has neither been the cause nor the occasion of the upheaval.
('17', 443, 1, 5, 912627) If anything, the presence of satyagraha has acted as a check even so slight upon the previously existing lawless elements.
('17', 443, 1, 6, 912750) As regards events in the Punjab, it is admitted that they are unconnected with the satyagraha movement.
('17', 443, 2, 7, 912854) SOUTH AFRICAN PARALLEL
('17', 443, 3, 8, 912877) In the course of the satyagraha struggle in South Africa, several thousands of indentured Indians had struck work.
('17', 443, 3, 9, 912992) This was a satyagraha strike and therefore entirely peaceful and voluntary.
('17', 443, 3, 10, 913068) Whilst the strike was going on, a strike of European miners, railway employees, etc., was declared.
('17', 443, 3, 11, 913168) Overtures were made to me to make common cause with the European strikers.
('17', 443, 3, 12, 913243) As a satyagrahi, I did not require a moment’s consideration to decline to do so.
('17', 443, 3, 13, 913324) I went further and for fear of our strike being classed with the strike of Europeans in which methods of violence and use of arms found a prominent place, ours was suspended and satyagraha from that moment came to be recognized by the Europeans of South Africa as an honourable and honest movement—in the words of General Smuts, a constitutional movement.
('17', 443, 3, 14, 913680) I can do no less at the present critical moment.
('17', 443, 3, 15, 913729) I would be untrue to satyagraha, if I allowed it by any action of mine to be used as an occasion for feeding violence for embittering relations between the English and the Indians.
('17', 443, 3, 16, 913910) Our satyagraha must therefore now consist in ceaselessly helping the authorities in all the ways available to us as satyagrahis to restore order and to curb lawlessness.
('17', 443, 3, 17, 914080) We can turn the tragedies going on before us to good account if we could but succeed in gaining the adherence of the masses to the fundamental principles of satyagraha.
('17', 443, 3, 18, 914249) Satyagraha is like a banyan tree with innumerable branches.
('17', 443, 3, 19, 914309) Civil disobedience is one such branch, satya (truth) and ahimsa (non violence) together make the parent trunk from which all innumerable branches shoot out.
('17', 443, 3, 20, 914466) We have found by bitter experience that whilst in an atmosphere of lawlessness, civil disobedience found ready acceptance.
('17', 443, 3, 21, 914589) Satya and ahimsa, from which
('17', 444, 0, 1, 914618) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 445
('17', 444, 1, 2, 914658) alone civil disobedience can worthily spring, have commanded little or no respect.
('17', 444, 1, 3, 914741) Ours then is a Herculean task, but we may not shirk it.
('17', 444, 1, 4, 914797) We must fearlessly spread the doctrine of satya and ahimsa and then, and not till then, shall we be able to undertake mass satyagraha.
('17', 444, 2, 5, 914932) ROWLATT LAWS
('17', 444, 3, 6, 914945) My attitude towards the Rowlatt legislation remains unchanged.
('17', 444, 3, 7, 915008) Indeed, I do feel that the Rowlatt legislation is one of the many causes of the present unrest.
('17', 444, 3, 8, 915104) But in a surcharged atmosphere, I must refrain from examining these causes.
('17', 444, 3, 9, 915180) The main and only purpose of this letter is to advise all satyagrahis to temporarily suspend civil disobedience, to give Government effective co operation in restoring order and by preaching and practice to gain adherence to the fundamental principles mentioned above.
('17', 444, 4, 10, 915449) The Hindu, 21 4 1919

('17', 445, 9, 15, 917491) DEAR MR. CHATFIELD, A friend has just drawn my attention to the fact that the mill hands will be doubly hit by the levy.
('17', 445, 9, 16, 917612) They have already been made to pay from their wages.

('17', 445, 9, 21, 917953) You have the power of exemption.
('17', 445, 9, 22, 917986) Could you not exempt the mill hands from the double levy if the view submitted by me is correct?
