('17', 447, 7, 13, 919728) 410. SATYAGRAHA LEAFLET 2 NO.
('17', 447, 8, 14, 919758) [April 25, 1919] 3
('17', 447, 9, 15, 919777) SATYAGRAHA : ITS SIGNIFICANCE
('17', 447, 10, 16, 919807) In the first leaflet 4, I hinted that I would consider the meaning of satyagraha in a later number of this series.
('17', 447, 10, 17, 919922) I feel that the time has now arrived to examine the meaning of satyagraha.
('17', 447, 10, 18, 919997) The word was newly coined some years ago, but the principle which it denotes is as ancient as time.
('17', 447, 10, 19, 920097) This is the literal meaning of satyagraha—insistence on truth, and force derivable from such insistence.
('17', 447, 10, 20, 920202) In the present movement, we are making use of satyagraha as a force: that is to say, in order to cure the evil in the shape of the Rowlatt legislation, we have been making use of the force generated by satyagraha, that is, insistence on truth.
('17', 447, 10, 21, 920446) One of the axioms of religion is, there is no religion other than truth.
('17', 447, 10, 22, 920519) Another is, religion is love.
('17', 447, 10, 23, 920549) And as there can be only one religion, it follows that truth is love and love is truth.
('17', 447, 10, 24, 920637) We shall find too, on further reflection, that conduct based on truth is impossible without love.
('17', 447, 11, 25, 920735) 1 The similarity of the contents of this letter and of “Letter to G. E. Chatfield”, 24 4 1919 suggests that both were written on the same day.
('17', 447, 12, 26, 920878) 2 The original has: “Satyagraha Leaflet Series”.
('17', 447, 13, 27, 920927) 3 According to The Indian Review, the date of issue of this leaflet is April 25.
('17', 447, 14, 28, 921008) 4 Vide Leaflet No.
('17', 448, 0, 1, 921027) VOL.17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 449
('17', 448, 1, 2, 921067) Truth force then is love force.
('17', 448, 1, 3, 921099) We cannot remedy evil by harbouring ill will against the evil doer.
('17', 448, 1, 4, 921167) This is not difficult of comprehension.
('17', 448, 1, 5, 921207) It is easy enough to understand.
('17', 448, 1, 6, 921240) In thousands of our acts, the propelling power is truth or love.
('17', 448, 1, 7, 921305) The relations between father and son, husband and wife, indeed our family relations are largely guided by truth or love.
('17', 448, 1, 8, 921426) And we therefore consciously or unconsciously apply satyagraha in regulating these relations.
('17', 448, 2, 9, 921520) If we were to cast a retrospective glance over our past life, we would find that out of a thousand of our acts affecting our families, in nine hundred and ninety nine we were dominated by truth, that in our deeds, it is not right to say we generally resort to untruth or ill will.
('17', 448, 2, 10, 921801) It is only where a conflict of interests arises, then arise the progeny of untruth, viz., anger, ill will, etc., and then we see nothing but poison in our midst.
('17', 448, 2, 11, 921963) A little hard thinking will show us that the standard that we apply to the regulation of domestic relations is the standard that should be applied to regulate the relations between rulers and the ruled, and between man and man.
('17', 448, 2, 12, 922191) Those men and women who do not recognize the domestic tie are considered to be very like brutes or barbarous, even though they in form have the human body.
('17', 448, 2, 13, 922347) They have never known the law of satyagraha.
('17', 448, 2, 14, 922392) Those who recognize the domestic tie and its obligations have to a certain extent gone beyond that brute stage.
('17', 448, 2, 15, 922504) But if challenged, they would say “what do we care though the whole universe may perish so long as we guard the family interest?” The measure of their satyagraha, therefore, is less than that of a drop in the ocean.
('17', 448, 3, 16, 922720) When men and women have gone a stage further, they would extend the law of love, i.e., satyagraha, from the family to the village.
('17', 448, 3, 17, 922851) A still further stage away from the brute life is reached when the law of satyagraha is applied to provincial life, and the people inhabiting a province regulate their relations by love rather than by hatred.
('17', 448, 3, 18, 923060) And when as in Hindustan we recognize the law of satyagraha as a binding force even between province and province and the millions of Hindustan treat one another as brothers and sisters, we have advanced a stage further still from the brute nature.
('17', 448, 4, 19, 923309) In modern times, in no part of the earth have the people gone beyond the nation stage in the application of satyagraha.
('17', 448, 4, 20, 923429) In reality, however, there need be no reason for the clashing of interest between nation and nation, thus arresting the operation of the great law.
('17', 448, 4, 21, 923577) If we were not in the habit generally of giving no thought to our
('17', 449, 0, 1, 923643) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 449, 1, 2, 923685) daily conduct, if we did not accept local custom and habit as matters of course, as we accept the current coin, we would immediately perceive that to the extent that we bear ill will towards other nations or show disregard at all for life, to that extent we disregard the law of satyagraha or love, and to that extent we are still not free from the brute nature.
('17', 449, 1, 3, 924048) But there is no religion apart from that which enables us entirely to rid ourselves of the brute nature.
('17', 449, 1, 4, 924153) All religious sects and divisions, all churches and temples, are useful only so long as they serve as a means towards enabling us to recognize the universality of satyagraha.
('17', 449, 1, 5, 924328) In India we have been trained from ages past in this teaching and hence it is that we are taught to consider the whole universe as one family.
('17', 449, 1, 6, 924471) I do wish to submit as a matter of experience that it is not only possible to live the full national life, by rendering obedience to the law of satyagraha, but that the fullness of national life is impossible without satyagraha, i.e., without a life of true religion.
('17', 449, 1, 7, 924739) That nation which wars against another has to an extent disregarded the great law of life.
('17', 449, 1, 8, 924830) I shall never abandon the faith I have that India is capable of delivering this truth to the whole world, and I wish that all Indians, men and women, whether they are Hindus or Mahomedans, Parsis, Christians or Jews will share with me this unquenchable faith.
('17', 449, 2, 9, 925090) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 450, 1, 2, 925934) 412. LETTER TO CHANDRASHANKAR PANDYA
('17', 450, 2, 3, 925971) April 26, 1919 I was very happy indeed to read your letter, as I was anxious to know how you were keeping.
('17', 450, 2, 4, 926078) What is this ailment of yours, from which you have still not recovered?
('17', 450, 2, 5, 926150) There is an institution in Agra giving Kuhne baths.
('17', 450, 2, 6, 926202) I have heard Pandit Hridayanath Kunzru praise it very much.
('17', 450, 2, 7, 926262) Since you are there, you may perhaps benefit if you go in for a few of these baths.
('17', 450, 2, 8, 926346) I am returning your poem for being revised.
('17', 450, 2, 9, 926390) I see from it your deep affection for me, but I expect something better from you, specia lly as you are ill.
('17', 450, 2, 10, 926499) Substitute another word for “black” to describe the law; you may call it “harsh”, if you like.
('17', 450, 2, 11, 926594) “Black” is suggestive of anger.
('17', 450, 2, 12, 926626) One’s language, too, must be worthy of satyagraha.
('17', 450, 2, 13, 926677) The senti ment expressed in “Trusting the British wholly” is out of place in a description of satyagraha.
('17', 450, 2, 14, 926783) We did nothing wrong in trusting the British; our fault lay in having no faith in ourselves.
('17', 450, 2, 15, 926876) God helps those alone who help themselves, and so too the British.
('17', 450, 2, 16, 926943) Can they be better than God?
('17', 450, 2, 17, 926972) To bear invisible blows is the satyagrahi’s mantra, though he does so in order that his suffering may end.
('17', 450, 2, 18, 927079) In composing a poem on satyagraha, I would bring in no comparison with the Liberals and others.
('17', 450, 2, 19, 927175) I am sending you my latest leaflet.
('17', 450, 2, 20, 927211) Go through it and, if the Goddess Saraswati inspires you with verses conveying the boundless power of truth and nonviolence, as also the difference between civil disobedience and ignorant, arrogant disobedience, if you can compose such verses, I should like you to do so.
('17', 450, 2, 21, 927483) Going again through your letter, I find that you had feared there might be satyagraha against your poem too.
('17', 450, 2, 22, 927592) The fear has virtually come true.
('17', 450, 2, 23, 927626) Don’t mind, though.
('17', 450, 2, 24, 927646) How can the poor satyagrahi help?
('17', 450, 2, 25, 927680) My hands do not give me full service, else I would have written this letter myself.
('17', 450, 2, 26, 927764) You need be in no hurry to send me another poem.
('17', 450, 2, 27, 927813) Write only when your health permits.
('17', 450, 2, 28, 927850) How much time did it take Keats to write the immortal line “A thing of beauty is a joy for ever” ?

('17', 451, 2, 3, 928063) [April 26, 1919] 1
('17', 451, 3, 4, 928082) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, With great sorrow and equal pleasure I have to inform you that the Government have today 2 removed Mr. Horniman from Bombay and he has been placed on board a steamer bound for England.
('17', 451, 3, 5, 928289) Mr. Horniman is a very brave and generous English man.
('17', 451, 3, 6, 928344) He has given us the mantra of liberty, he has fearlessly exposed wrong wherever he has seen it and thus been an ornament to the race to which he belongs, and rendered it a great service.
('17', 451, 3, 7, 928531) Every Indian knows his services to India.
('17', 451, 3, 8, 928573) I am sorry for the event because a brave satyagrahi has been deported while I retain my physical liberty.
('17', 451, 3, 9, 928679) I am glad because Mr. Horniman has been given the occasion of fulfilling his Pledge.
('17', 451, 3, 10, 928764) The publication of the Chronicle will for the time being be discontinued, because the Directors have wisely decided not to accede to the improper demands of the Government.
('17', 451, 3, 11, 928937) In reality, however, the continuance of the Chronicle without Mr. Horniman would be like an attempt to sustain a body when the soul has departed.
('17', 451, 3, 12, 929083) The condition I have described is truly serious.
('17', 451, 3, 13, 929132) Satyagraha is on the anvil.
('17', 451, 3, 14, 929160) At the same time, this is a fine opportunity for demons trating its purity and its invincibility.
('17', 451, 3, 15, 929258) It will rest with satyagrahis and other inhabitants of India to take advantage of the opportunity.
('17', 451, 3, 16, 929357) I can fully appreciate the deep wound that will be caused to every satya grahi by the separation of a dear comrade.
('17', 451, 3, 17, 929473) The nation will certainly feel hurt to find that the one who presented it with a daily draught of liberty is no more in itsmidst.
('17', 451, 3, 18, 929603) At a time like this satyagrahis and others will, in my opinion, demonstrate their true affection for Mr. Horniman only by remaining perfectly calm.
('17', 451, 3, 19, 929751) It will be sheer thought lessness to break the peace.
('17', 451, 3, 20, 929805) Modern civilization challenges the ancient.
('17', 451, 3, 21, 929849) Satyagraha now going on is based upon the teachings of the ancient civilization and if India accepts satyagraha the superiority of the ancient civilization will be indicated.
('17', 451, 3, 22, 930024) The world will see modern civilization in its nakedness and there is no doubt that its votaries will retrace their steps.
('17', 451, 4, 23, 930146) 1 Vide Mahadevbhaini Diary.

('17', 452, 1, 2, 930281) The following are the practical suggestions I venture to place before you.
('17', 452, 1, 3, 930356) There should be no stoppage of business anywhere in Hindustan, there should be no large public meeting of protests, no processions, no violence of any kind whatsoever and every effort should be made to stop any tendency thereto.
('17', 452, 1, 4, 930585) I ask satyagrahis and the sympathizers not to lose faith in the efficacy of satyagraha and firmly to believe that the Satyagraha Pledge will be carried in its entirety.
('17', 452, 1, 5, 930754) More later.

('17', 452, 7, 15, 931185) (Note: He was engaged in an interview with me) 2. When I received the information which led me to come to Bombay, I did not know that brother Horniman would be deported.

('17', 454, 1, 2, 934982) 415. SATYAGRAHA LEAFLET 1 NO.
('17', 454, 2, 3, 935012) BOMBAY, April 28, 2 1919
('17', 454, 3, 4, 935037) It is a good omen for satyagraha that Bombay has preserved peace in spite of the unendurable separation of Mr. Horniman from us.
('17', 454, 3, 5, 935166) I hope that it will be preserved whenever our other friends are arrested and even if I am arrested.
('17', 454, 3, 6, 935266) The Government are entitled to arrest those whom they suspect.
('17', 454, 3, 7, 935329) Moreover in our movement we consider it the proper thing to be arrested and imprisoned, when before our conscience we are found guiltless.
('17', 454, 3, 8, 935468) How can we therefore be angry when any satyagrahi is arrested?
('17', 454, 3, 9, 935531) We ought to know that the sooner innocent men are arrested, the sooner will this struggle end.
('17', 454, 3, 10, 935626) I have heard some people say that in satyagraha also the end is achieved by violence.
('17', 454, 3, 11, 935712) They argue that when satyagrahis are arrested, people become excited, resort to violence and thus get their demands acceded to.
('17', 454, 3, 12, 935840) I held this to be a dreadful superstition.
('17', 454, 3, 13, 935883) The reverse is the truth.
('17', 454, 3, 14, 935909) By the arrest of satyagrahis, violence ensued in Ahmedabad and we have experienced the results of that violence.
('17', 454, 3, 15, 936022) The people there are cowed down.
('17', 454, 3, 16, 936055) Gujarat which never had the military in its midst has had an experience of it.
('17', 454, 3, 17, 936134) It is my firm conviction that the victory of satyagraha is attainable only by adherence to truth, avoidance of violence and by suffering.
('17', 454, 3, 18, 936272) My experience in South Africa, Champaran, Kaira and other places fully bears out the truth of my statement.
('17', 454, 3, 19, 936380) So long as we do not appreciate this truth, we are in no way fitted for satyagraha.
('17', 454, 3, 20, 936464) The question arises:”What then ought we to do?
('17', 454, 3, 21, 936511) Are we to sit with folded hands in spite of Mr. Horniman’s deportation?” I reply that the observance of perfect calm is itself a demonstration of our grief over the separation, and of our intense activity along satyagraha lines and by maintaining 3 the same calmness of spirit we shall be better able to reach our goal and to welcome back our friend.
('17', 454, 3, 22, 936862) When Hindustan [is] accustomed in the course of this struggle to rely only upon truth and non violence, we shall be able to begin civil disobedience.
('17', 454, 3, 23, 937012) Some say that it will take years before India recognizes the supremacy of truth and non violence and therefore it must take years to bring this
('17', 454, 4, 24, 937156) 1 The original has “Satyagraha Series Leaflet”.
('17', 454, 5, 25, 937204) 2 April 27 in Mahadevbhaini Diary.
('17', 454, 6, 26, 937239) 3 The source has “containing”.
('17', 455, 0, 1, 937270) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 455, 1, 2, 937312) struggle to a successful end.
('17', 455, 1, 3, 937342) I would content myself with saying that when once the forces of truth and ahimsa are set in motion, the speed as they move becomes so accelerated that they take no time in permeating millions.
('17', 455, 1, 4, 937535) For what is needful is to produce an impression of truth and non violence upon their hearts and to infect them with faith in the efficacy of these two forces.
('17', 455, 1, 5, 937694) [If] the satyagrahis are true, it need not take longer than a month or two to bring about this result.
('17', 455, 1, 6, 937797) I venture to tender the following advice in order that as suggested above truth and non violence may permeate the masses with an ever increasing velocity.
('17', 455, 1, 7, 937952) Great movements all the world over depend for their success largely upon the mercantile class.
('17', 455, 1, 8, 938047) Bombay is a great emporium of trade in Hindustan, indeed in the world.
('17', 455, 1, 9, 938118) With what rapidity would the force of truth move if the merchants of Bombay were to avoid untruth and all the faults flowing from it even though introduction of truth in their business may mean smaller profits or even loss.
('17', 455, 1, 10, 938342) What greater honour can we pay to Mr. Horniman than by adopting honesty as our watchword in our mercantile transactions?
('17', 455, 1, 11, 938463) The foundation of our success rests in truth and if it pervades mercantile affairs it will be a plaything to pull down the other citadels of untruth.
('17', 455, 1, 12, 938613) Feel convinced that it is not difficult for those merchants of Bombay who have regard for Mr. Horniman to act according to the advice tendered by me that if we can impress the Government with the truth in us and by strictly observing the principle of non violence assure them of their harmlessness, it may not be necessary for us to resume civil disobedience.

('17', 455, 6, 18, 939139) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Friends have been incessantly telling me, a strong feeling prevails that some way ought to be found to give expression to
('17', 455, 7, 19, 939283) 1 The original has “Satyagraha Series Leaflet”.

('17', 456, 1, 2, 939429) popular feeling in the matter of Mr. Horniman’s deportation.
('17', 456, 1, 3, 939490) The desire is quite natural.
('17', 456, 1, 4, 939519) But as I have already observed, the fact that we have preserved peace is itself an eloquent demonstration of our feelings.
('17', 456, 1, 5, 939642) It is my special opinion that such preservation of peace is only possible where satyagraha is going on.
('17', 456, 1, 6, 939746) I believe that the authorities have also been amazed at the profound peace prevailing throughout the city.
('17', 456, 1, 7, 939853) And no wonder.
('17', 456, 1, 8, 939868) The Government know that popular feeling regarding Mr. Horniman runs high.
('17', 456, 1, 9, 939943) In order that a demonstration of this feeling may not run in undesirable channels, the Government have made elaborate military dispositions.
('17', 456, 1, 10, 940084) But it is highly creditable to Bombay that the military have had to remain idle.
('17', 456, 1, 11, 940165) It is a worthy achievement for satyagraha.
('17', 456, 1, 12, 940208) I have no doubt that if people could thus restrain themselves on all occasions, the nation would occupy a much higher status.
('17', 456, 1, 13, 940334) No one need assume that we have not been taking or that we shall no longer take measures for getting Mr. Horniman back in our midst.
('17', 456, 1, 14, 940467) Of all measures, the present calmness is the greatest.
('17', 456, 1, 15, 940522) Yet I suggest that those who are keen on suspension of business may devote a day’s profits to some public activity.

('17', 456, 1, 17, 940825) An appreciation of this fact will of itself remove many of our perplexities.
('17', 456, 1, 18, 940902) We have seen that there is a difference between satyagraha meetings and others.
('17', 456, 1, 19, 940982) Satyagraha is based upon religion.
('17', 456, 1, 20, 941017) In it only truth, calmness, serenity, patience, fearlessness, etc., should alone be seen.
('17', 456, 1, 21, 941107) A satyagraha strike must differ from the others.
('17', 456, 1, 22, 941156) I have already quoted an occasion when a satyagraha strike had to be suspended when a different strike was declared.
('17', 456, 1, 23, 941273) What we expect to attain by acclamations in ordinary movements, we often gain by silence in satyagraha.
('17', 456, 1, 24, 941377) The human voice can never reach the distance that is covered by the still small voice of conscience.
('17', 456, 1, 25, 941478) lnstances to show the unique character of satyagraha can easily be multiplied and we ought not to be surprised to see things not going in the orthodox fashion And I therefore beseech all not to be agitated because they see no outward demonstration over Mr. Horniman’s deportation.
('17', 456, 1, 26, 941759) I ask them to be patient and to have full faith that by going along the path of satyagraha, we shall meet our brother all the sooner for it.
('17', 456, 2, 27, 941900) M. K. GANDHI

('17', 457, 4, 6, 942388) 418. LETTER TO”THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('17', 457, 5, 7, 942423) BOMBAY, April 28, 1919
('17', 457, 6, 8, 942446) TO THE EDITOR THE TIMES OF INDIA SIR, With reference to my address to the meeting held at Ahmeda bad on Monday, the 14th instant, I observe that my remarks therein about the organized manner of violence have been misunderstood and have been applied to the deeds of violence committed elsewhere.
('17', 457, 6, 9, 942741) My reference, however, was only to the violence of Ahmedabad.
('17', 457, 6, 10, 942803) This is the language of the translation of the original address which was in Gujarati.
('17', 457, 6, 11, 942890) It seems that the deeds I have complained of (i.e., deeds of violence in Ahmedabad) have been done in an organized manner.
('17', 457, 6, 12, 943013) There seems to be a definite design about them and I am sure that there must be some educated and clever men behind them.
('17', 457, 6, 13, 943135) My statement is too definite to apply to violence in any other part of India.
('17', 457, 6, 14, 943213) I simply could not refer to other parts as I had then, and in fact even now, no knowledge about them save what one can gather from newspaper scraps.
('17', 457, 6, 15, 943362) Indeed my remarks did not extend even to Viramgam as I then knew so little about its violence.
('17', 457, 6, 16, 943457) M. K. GANDHI The Times of India, 30 4 1919

('17', 458, 1, 2, 943541) 419. LETTER TO J. CRERAR
('17', 458, 2, 3, 943566) BOMBAY, April 29, 1919
('17', 458, 3, 4, 943589) DEAR MR. CRERAR 1, It is perhaps due to Government and to my co workers in the city that I should place before H. E. the very difficult situation that has arisen out of Mr. Horniman’s deportation and the suspension of the publication of The Bombay Chronicle by reason of the censorship orders.
('17', 458, 3, 5, 943883) In my humble opinion, Mr. Horniman’s deportation is totally unjustifiable and the censorship orders quite unnecessary after his deportation.
('17', 458, 3, 6, 944024) Fuel has been added to the fire by the order of forfeiture of security.
('17', 458, 3, 7, 944096) And all this when civil disobedience has been totally suspended !
('17', 458, 3, 8, 944162) Herculean efforts are being made by satyagrahis to help in every way they can to restore peace.
('17', 458, 3, 9, 944258) I might be permitted to say that but for the incessant labours of the satyagrahis, excited demons trations would certainly have taken place in spite of the military precaution.
('17', 458, 3, 10, 944435) Complaints ever increasing in volume have been hourly coming to me against my advice not to have any demonstrations regarding the deportation.
('17', 458, 3, 11, 944578) I do not know that the Satyagraha Sabha will be able altogether to prevent some demonstration.
('17', 458, 3, 12, 944673) I would there fore respectfully suggest that a statement may be made reassuring the public that the deportation orders will be withdrawn at an early date and that censorship and forfeiture orders may be altogether recalled.
('17', 458, 3, 13, 944897) I understand that the government are about to effect further arrests in Bombay of noted satyagrahis.
('17', 458, 3, 14, 944998) I hope that my information is not true.
('17', 458, 3, 15, 945038) From a public standpoint, any further arrests during the suspension of civil disobedience will be a calamity.
('17', 458, 3, 16, 945148) I believe that all my efforts to restrain the pent up fury of the people will be vain, nor shall I be able to hold myself or the movement responsible (morally or otherwise) for any untoward results that may follow any such arrest.
('17', 458, 3, 17, 945379) Mrs. Naidu has received a communication from Sind informing her of the state of things there.
('17', 458, 3, 18, 945473) The arrests that have been made in Karachi seem to have produced a profound impression on the public mind there.
('17', 458, 3, 19, 945586) In the interests of peace, I plead for forbearance during suspension of civil disobedience.
('17', 458, 3, 20, 945678) Yours sincerely,
('17', 458, 4, 21, 945695) From a photostat: S.N. 6574
('17', 458, 5, 22, 945723) 1 Secretary to the Government of Bombay, Judicial Department

('17', 459, 8, 13, 946215) I shall do what I can wherever I am.
('17', 459, 8, 14, 946252) Ever yours affectionately,
('17', 459, 9, 15, 946279) B. G. HORNIMAN That to Mr. Jamnadas is as follows:
('17', 459, 10, 16, 946330) MY DEAR JAMNADAS,
('17', 459, 11, 17, 946348) I hope whatever happens, Bombay will remain quiet.
('17', 459, 12, 18, 946399) I don’t know whether this letter will reach you, but if it does, give my love to everybody.
('17', 459, 12, 19, 946491) In the meanwhile, I shall work for India wherever I may be.
('17', 459, 13, 20, 946551) Ever yours,
('17', 459, 14, 21, 946563) B. G. HORNIMAN
('17', 459, 15, 22, 946578) Both these letters were written by him from s.s.
('17', 459, 15, 23, 946627) Takada.
('17', 459, 15, 24, 946635) Further news is that his health is all right, that he is being well looked after and that the officers have treated him with all courtesy.
('17', 459, 15, 25, 946774) The order of deportation means that Mr. Horniman will be absolutely free on reaching England, that there will no restrictions whatsoever on his liberty, and as he is resolved to work for India, wherever he is, it is likely that he will render great service to India while in England.
('17', 459, 15, 26, 947058) This, however, is but a poor consolation for the people.
('17', 459, 15, 27, 947115) They would be satisfied only if the order of deportation is withdrawn, and we cannot sit still till we find him back in our midst.
('17', 459, 15, 28, 947246) We know how we can get him back in our midst.
('17', 459, 15, 29, 947292) The first and the foremost thing is to observe self restraint and to learn to keep peace.
('17', 459, 15, 30, 947382) If we break the peace, we

('17', 460, 1, 2, 947497) shall only be delaying Mr Horniman’s return and paining him.

('17', 460, 5, 7, 947816) 421. LETTER TO SIR STANLEY REED
('17', 460, 6, 8, 947848) LABURNUM ROAD, BOMBAY , April 30, 1919
('17', 460, 7, 9, 947887) DEAR SIR STANLEY REED, I enclose herewith form of the swadeshi pledge.
('17', 460, 7, 10, 947958) I am anxious, if I can, to secure English supporters.
('17', 460, 7, 11, 948012) I am the more so at the present moment in order to emphasize in a concrete manner the fact that swadeshi is being taken up not in any spirit of antagonism or retaliation, but that it is being taken up as a matter of necessity for the well being of India.
('17', 460, 7, 12, 948267) I would be delighted if you could see your way to sign the pledge, and if you approve of it, I would like you to secure further English signatures.
('17', 460, 8, 13, 948415) M. K. G.
('17', 460, 9, 14, 948424) From a photostat: S.N. 6575
('17', 460, 10, 15, 948452) 422. LETTER TO N. P. COWIE

('17', 460, 12, 17, 948526) DEAR MR. COWIE 2, I beg to enclose herewith for His Excellency’s perusal form of the swadeshi pledge which is now ready for issuing.
('17', 460, 12, 18, 948659) I would esteem it as an event of great significance if His Excellency could see his way to sign the pledge unless his official position precludes him from doing
('17', 460, 13, 19, 948820) 1 For Reed’s reply, vide Appendix “Sir Stanley Reed’s Letter to Gandhiji”, 2 5 1919.

('17', 461, 3, 5, 949253) 423. LETTER TO SIND SATYAGRAHIS
('17', 461, 4, 6, 949285) BOMBAY, April 30, 1919
('17', 461, 5, 7, 949308) DEAR BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('17', 461, 6, 8, 949335) I have heard and read about what is going on in Sind.
('17', 461, 6, 9, 949389) I see that some arrests have been made.
('17', 461, 6, 10, 949429) If the arrests have been made by reason of satyagraha, nothing can be better or more welcome for satyagrahis than such arrests and satyagrahis so arrested will, if convicted, cheerfully go to prison and those who remain behind will share in their sufferings by observing perfect peace and calmness.
('17', 461, 6, 11, 949728) If they are arrested for doing anything in violation of satyagraha, i.e., for breach of laws which have also moral sanction, and are proved guilty of them by an impartial tribunal, they will deserve the punishment that may be awarded against them.
('17', 461, 6, 12, 949976) In either event, therefore, we can have no cause for complaint.
('17', 461, 6, 13, 950040) I understand, however, that many people are excited over these arrests.
('17', 461, 6, 14, 950112) To these, I would say that they have not understood the law of satyagraha.
('17', 461, 6, 15, 950187) We want to employ only truth in all that we say and do.
('17', 461, 6, 16, 950243) We undertake to refrain from injury to any person or property while acting in accordance with the principles of truth and non violence.
('17', 461, 6, 17, 950379) If we find ourselves in trouble those who associate with us have little reason to complain or grumble.
('17', 461, 6, 18, 950482) The essence of satyagraha is that we never resort to any violence even though there may be great provocation.
('17', 461, 6, 19, 950592) The struggle is lost the moment we do any violence whatsoever.
('17', 461, 6, 20, 950655) I, therefore, hope that no matter what prose cutions take place, all will remain quiet and calm.
('17', 461, 7, 21, 950752) From a photostat: S.N. 6577
('17', 462, 0, 1, 950780) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 463
('17', 462, 1, 2, 950821) 424. LETTER TO KER
('17', 462, 2, 3, 950840) [April, 1919] 1
('17', 462, 3, 4, 950856) DEAR MR. KER 2,
('17', 462, 4, 5, 950872) I had hoped to be able to be in Nadiad on Monday, but the critical situation here has detained me in Bombay.
('17', 462, 4, 6, 950981) Some of the friends from Nadiad have been here and they tell me that those who were involved in the cutting of telegraph wires are ready to make a full confession but they want me to be in Nadiad at the time they do so.
('17', 462, 4, 7, 951201) I do not know when I shall be free to go over there.
('17', 462, 4, 8, 951254) I hope, however, that there will be no difficulty about complying with the wishes of the people concerned.
('17', 462, 5, 9, 951361) From a photostat: G.N. 8227
('17', 462, 6, 10, 951389) 1 From the circumstances referred to in the letter, it appears to have been written in April, 1919.
('17', 462, 7, 11, 951489) 2 Collector of Kaira
('17', 463, 0, 1, 951510) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 463, 1, 2, 951552) APPENDICES
('17', 463, 2, 3, 951563) APPENDIX I
('17', 463, 3, 4, 951574) RAB INDRA NATH TAGO RE’S LETTE R TO G ANDHI JI
('17', 463, 4, 5, 951621) SHANTI NIKETAN, April 12, 1919
('17', 463, 5, 6, 951652) DEAR MAHATMAJI,
('17', 463, 6, 7, 951668) Power in all its forms is irrational,—it is like the horse that drags the carriage blindfolded.
('17', 463, 6, 8, 951764) The moral element in it is only represented in the man who drives the horse.
('17', 463, 6, 9, 951841) Passive resistance is a force which is not necessarily moral in itself; it can be used against truth as well as for it.
('17', 463, 6, 10, 951961) the danger inherent in all force grows stronger when it is likely to gain success, for then it becomes temptation.
('17', 463, 7, 11, 952076) I know your teaching is to fight against evil by the help of the good.
('17', 463, 7, 12, 952147) But such a fight is for heroes and not for men led by impulses of the moment.
('17', 463, 7, 13, 952225) Evil on one side naturally begets evil on the other, injustice leading to violence and insult to vengefulness.
('17', 463, 7, 14, 952336) Unfortunately such a force has already been started, and either through panic or through wrath our authorities have shown us the claws whose sure effect is to drive some of us into the secret path of resentment and others into utter demoralization.
('17', 463, 7, 15, 952585) In this crisis you, as a great leader of men, have stood among us to proclaim your faith in the ideal which you know to be that of India, the ideal which is both against the cowardliness of hidden revenge and the cowed submissiveness of the terror stricken.
('17', 463, 7, 16, 952843) You have said, as Lord Buddha has done in his time and for all time to come,—
('17', 463, 8, 17, 952921) Akkodhena jine kodham, asadhum sadhuna jine,—” Conquer anger by the
('17', 463, 9, 18, 952989) power of non anger and evil by the power of good”.
('17', 463, 10, 19, 953040) This power of good must prove its truth and strength by its fearlessness, by its refusal to accept any imposition which depends for its success upon its power to produce frightfulness and is not ashamed to use its machines of destruction to terrorize a population completely disarmed.
('17', 463, 10, 20, 953325) We must know that moral conquest does not consist in success, that failure does not deprive it of its dignity and worth.
('17', 463, 10, 21, 953446) who believe in spiritual life know that to stand against wrong which has overwhelming material power behind it is victory itself,—it is the victory of the active faith in the ideal in the teeth of evident defeat.
('17', 463, 11, 22, 953659) I have always felt, and said accordingly, that the great gift of freedom can never come to a people through charity.
('17', 463, 11, 23, 953776) We must win it before we can own it.
('17', 463, 11, 24, 953813) And India’s opportunity for winning it will come to her when she can prove that she is
('17', 464, 0, 1, 953900) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 465
('17', 464, 1, 2, 953941) morally superior to the people who rule her by their right of conquest.
('17', 464, 1, 3, 954013) She must willingly accept her penance of suffering—the suffering which is the crown of the great.
('17', 464, 1, 4, 954111) Armed with her utter faith in goodness she must stand unabashed before the arrogance that scoffs at the power of spirit.
('17', 464, 2, 5, 954232) And you have come to your motherland in the time of her need to remind her of her mission to lead her in the true path of conquest, to purge her present day politics of its feebleness which imagines that it has gained its purpose when it struts in the borrowed feathers of diplomatic dishonesty.
('17', 464, 3, 6, 954528) This is why I pray most fervently that nothing that tends to weaken our spiritual freedom may intrude into your marching line, that martyrdom for the cause of truth may never degenerate into/fanaticism for mere verbal forms descending into the self deception that hides itself behind sacred names.
('17', 464, 4, 7, 954826) With these few words for an introduction allow me to offer the following as a poet’s contribution to your noble work:
('17', 464, 6, 8, 954944) Let me hold my head high in this faith that thou art our shelter, that all fear is mean distrust of these.
('17', 464, 7, 9, 955051) Fear of man ?
('17', 464, 7, 10, 955065) But what man is there in this world, what king, King of kings, who is thy rival, who has hold of me for all time and in all time and in all truth?
('17', 464, 8, 11, 955212) What power is there in this world to rob me of my freedom ?
('17', 464, 8, 12, 955272) For do not thy arms reach the captive through the dungeon walls, bringing unfettered release to the soul?
('17', 464, 9, 13, 955378) And must I cling to this body in fear of death, as a miser to his barren treasure?
('17', 464, 9, 14, 955461) Has not this spirit of mine the eternal call to thy feast of everlasting life?
('17', 464, 10, 15, 955540) Let me know that all pain and death are shadows of the moment; that the dark force which sweeps between me and thy truth is but the mist before the sunrise; that thou alone art mine for ever and greater than all pride of strength that dares to mock my manhood with its menace.
('17', 464, 12, 16, 955817) Give me the supreme courage of love, this is my prayer,—the courage to spare, to do, to suffer at thy will, to leave all thing or be by alone.
('17', 464, 13, 17, 955960) Give me the supreme faith of love, this is my prayer,—the faith of the life in death, of the victory in defeat, of the power hidden in the frailness of beauty, of the dignity of pain that accepts hurt, but disdains to return it.
('17', 464, 14, 18, 956189) Very sincerely yours,
('17', 464, 15, 19, 956211) RABINDRANATH TAGORE
('17', 464, 16, 20, 956231) From a photos tat: G.N. 4583
('17', 465, 0, 1, 956260) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 465, 1, 2, 956302) APPENDIX II
('17', 465, 2, 3, 956314) SATYAGR AHA LE AFLET N0 .
('17', 465, 3, 4, 956340) March 1919
('17', 465, 4, 5, 956351) EXTR ACTS FROM THE DUTY OF CIVI L DISO BEDIE NCE BY HENR Y THOR EAU (SCHO OLMAS TER OF MASS ACHUS ETTS) D ATE D 184 9
('17', 465, 5, 6, 956469) I heartily the motto: “That government is best which governs least”; and I should like to see it acted up to more rapidly and systematically.
('17', 465, 5, 7, 956611) Carried out, it finally amounts to this, which also I believe: “That government is best which governs not at all”; and when men are prepared for it, that will be the kind of government which they will have.
('17', 465, 5, 8, 956818) Government is at best but an expedient but most governments are Dually, and all governments are sometimes, in expedient.
('17', 465, 5, 9, 956939) The objections which have been brought against a standing army, and they are many and weighty and deserve to prevail, may also at last be brought against a standing government.
('17', 465, 5, 10, 957116) The standing army is only an arm of the standing government.
('17', 465, 5, 11, 957177) The government itself, which is only the mode which the people have chosen to execute their will, is equally liable to be abused and perverted .
('17', 465, 6, 12, 957322) Must the citizen ever for a moment, or in the least degree.
('17', 465, 6, 13, 957382) resign his conscience to the legislator ?
('17', 465, 6, 14, 957424) Why has every man a conscience, then ?
('17', 465, 6, 15, 957463) I think that we should be men first and subject afterwards.
('17', 465, 6, 16, 957523) It is not desirable to cultivate a respect for the law, so much as for the right.
('17', 465, 6, 17, 957605) The only obligation which I have a right to assume is to do at any time what I think right.
('17', 465, 6, 18, 957697) It is truly enough said that a corporation has no conscience; but a corporation of coinscientious men is a corporation with a conscience.
('17', 465, 6, 19, 957835) Law never made men a whit more just; and, by means of their respect for it, even the well disposed are daily made the agents of injustice.
('17', 465, 6, 20, 957974) A common and natural result of an undue respect for law is that you may see a file of soldiers: colonel, captain, corporal, privates, powder monkeys, and all, marching in admirable order over hill and dale to the wars, against their wills, aye, against their common sense and consciences, which make it very steep marching indeed, and produces a palpitation of the heart.
('17', 465, 6, 21, 958346) They have no doubt that it is a damnable business in which they are concerned; they are all peaceably inclined.
('17', 465, 6, 22, 958458) Now, what are they?
('17', 465, 6, 23, 958478) Men at all ?
('17', 465, 6, 24, 958491) or small movable forts ammagazing, at the service of some unscrupulous man in power?
('17', 465, 7, 25, 958576) The mass of men serve the State thus, not as men mainly but as machines, with their bodies.
('17', 465, 8, 26, 958668) They are the standing army, and the militia, gaolers, constables, posse comitatus, etc.
('17', 465, 8, 27, 958756) In most cases there is no free exercise whatever of the judgment or of
('17', 465, 9, 28, 958827) the moral sense: but they put themselves on a level with wood and earth and stones; and wooden men can perhaps be manufactured that will serve the purpose as well.
('17', 466, 0, 1, 958991) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 467
('17', 466, 1, 2, 959032) command no more respect than men of straw or a lump of dirt.
('17', 466, 1, 3, 959093) They have the same sort of worth only as horses and dogs.
('17', 466, 1, 4, 959151) Yet such as these even are commonly esteemed good citizens.
('17', 466, 1, 5, 959211) Others—as most legislators, politicians, lawyers, ministers and office holders serve the State chiefly with their heads; and as they rarely make any moral distinctions they are as likely to serve the devil, without intending it, as God.
('17', 466, 1, 6, 959448) A very few—as heroes, patriots, martyrs, reformers in the great sense and men — serve the State with their consciences also, and so necessarily resist it for the most part; and they are commonly treated as enemies by it.
('17', 466, 3, 7, 959669) All men recognize the right of revolution; that is, the right to refuse allegiance to, and to resist, the government, when its tyranny or its inefficiency are great and unendurable.
('17', 466, 5, 8, 959851) All machines have their friction; and possibly this does enough good to counterbalance the evil.
('17', 466, 5, 9, 959948) At any rate, it is a great evil to make a stir about it.
('17', 466, 5, 10, 960005) But when the friction comes to have its machine, and oppression and robbery are organized, I say, let us not have such a machine any longer.
('17', 466, 6, 11, 960146) What is the price current of an honest man and patriot today?
('17', 466, 6, 12, 960208) They hesitate, and they regret, and sometimes they petition; but they do nothing in earnest and with effect.
('17', 466, 6, 13, 960317) They will wait, well disposed for others to remedy the evil, that they may no longer have it to regret.
('17', 466, 6, 14, 960421) At most, they give only a cheap vote, and a feeble countenance and Godspeed, to the right, as it goes by them.
('17', 466, 6, 15, 960532) There are nine hundred and ninety nine patrons of virtue to one virtuous man.
('17', 466, 6, 16, 960610) But it is easier to deal with the real possessor of a thing than with the temporary guardian of it....
('17', 466, 7, 17, 960713) Even voting for the right is doing nothing for it.
('17', 466, 7, 18, 960764) It is only expressing to men feebly your desire that it should prevail.
('17', 466, 7, 19, 960836) A wise man will not leave the right to the mercy of chance.
('17', 466, 8, 20, 960896) O for a man who is a man, and, as my neighbour says, has a bone in his back which you cannot pass your hand through!
('17', 466, 8, 21, 961013) Our statistics are at fault: the population has been returned too large.
('17', 466, 8, 22, 961086) How many men are there to a square thousand miles in this country?
('17', 466, 8, 23, 961153) Hardly one .
('17', 466, 10, 24, 961166) Action from principle, the perception anfl the performance of right, changes things and relations; it is essentially revolutionary, and does not consist wholly with anything which was.
('17', 466, 10, 25, 961351) It not only divides states and churches; it divides families; aye, it divides the individual, separating the diabolical in him from the divine.
('17', 466, 11, 26, 961495) Unjust laws exist; shall we be content to obey them, or shall we endeavour to amend them, and obey them until we have succeeded, or shall owe trans gress them at once?
('17', 467, 0, 1, 961663) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 467, 2, 2, 961705) They think that, if they should resist, the remedy would be worse than the evil.
('17', 467, 2, 3, 961786) But it is the fault of the government itself that the remedy is worse than the evil.
('17', 467, 2, 4, 961871) It makes it worse.
('17', 467, 2, 5, 961890) Why is it not more apt to anticipate and provide for reform ?
('17', 467, 3, 6, 961952) Why does it cry and resist before it is hurt?
('17', 467, 3, 7, 961998) Why does it not encourage its citizens to be on the alert to point out its faults and do better than it would have them?
('17', 467, 3, 8, 962119) Why does it always crucify Christ, and excommunicate Coper nicus and Luther, and pronounce Washington and Franklin rebels?
('17', 467, 5, 9, 962242) If the injustice is part of the necessary friction of the machine of government, let it go, let it go; perchance it will wear smooth—certainly the machine will wear out.
('17', 467, 5, 10, 962412) If the injustice has a spring, or a pulley, or a rope or a crank, exclusively for itself, then perhaps you may consider whether the remedy will not be worse than the evil; but if it is of such a nature that it requires you to be the agent of injustice to another, then, I say, break the law.
('17', 467, 6, 11, 962704) As for adopting the ways which the State has provided for remedying the evil, I know not of such ways.
('17', 467, 6, 12, 962807) They take too much time, and a man’s life will be gone.
('17', 467, 6, 13, 962863) I have other affairs to attend to.
('17', 467, 6, 14, 962898) I came into this world, not chiefly to make this a good place to live in, but to live in it, be it good or bad.
('17', 467, 6, 15, 963010) A man has not everything to do, but something; and because he cannot do everything it is not necessary that he should do something wrong.
('17', 467, 6, 16, 963148) It is not my business to be petitioning the Governor or the
('17', 467, 7, 17, 963208) Legislature any more than it is theirs to petition me: and if they should not hear my petition, what should I do then?
('17', 467, 7, 18, 963327) But in this case the State has provided no way: its very Constitution is the evil.
('17', 467, 7, 19, 963410) This may seem to be harsh and stubborn and unconciliatory; but it is to treat with the utmost kindness and consideration the only spirit that can appreciate or deserves it.
('17', 467, 7, 20, 963583) So is all change for the better, like birth and death, which convulse the body.
('17', 467, 9, 21, 963663) I meet this American Government, or its representative, the State Govern ment, directly, and face to face, once a year—no more—in the person of its tax gatherer; this is the only mode in which a man situated as I am necessarily meets it; and it then says distinctly, “Recognize me”; and the simplest, the most effectual, and, in the present posture of affairs, the indispensablest mode of treating with it on this head, of expressing your little satisfaction with and love for it, is to deny it then.
('17', 467, 10, 22, 964164) I know this well, that if one thousand, if one hundred, if ten men who whom I could name,—if ten honest men only—aye, if one honest man is (were to be) locked up
('17', 467, 11, 23, 964326) in the country gaol therefor, it would be the abolition of slavery in America.
('17', 467, 11, 24, 964405) For it matters not how small the beginning may seem to be; what is once well done is done
('17', 468, 0, 1, 964495) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 469
('17', 468, 1, 2, 964536) for ever....
('17', 468, 2, 3, 964549) Under a government which imprisons any unjustly, the true place for a just man is also a prison.
('17', 468, 2, 4, 964646) The proper place today, the only place which (Massachusetts) has provided for her freer and less desponding spirits, is in her prisons, to be put out and locked out of the State by her own act, as they have already put themselves out by their principles.
('17', 468, 2, 5, 964901) It is there that the fugitive slave, and the Mexican prisoner on parole, and the Indian come to plead the wrongs of his race, should find them, on that separate but more free and honourable ground, where the State places those who are not with her but against her—the only house in a slave State in which a free man can
('17', 468, 3, 6, 965221) abide with honour.
('17', 468, 3, 7, 965240) If any think that their influence would be lost there, and their voices no longer affect the ear of the State that they would not be as an enemy within its walls, they do not know by how much truth is stronger than error nor how much more eloquently and effectively he can combat injustice who has experienced a little in his own person....
('17', 468, 4, 8, 965581) If a thousand men were not to pay their tax bills this year that would not be a violent and bloody measure, as it would be to pay them and enable the State to commit violence and shed innocent blood.
('17', 468, 4, 9, 965781) This is, in fact, the definition of a peaceable Revolution, if any such is possible.
('17', 468, 4, 10, 965866) If the tax gatherer or any other public officer asks me as one has done: “But what shall I do”, my answer: “if you really wish to do anything resign your office.” When the subject has refused allegiance and the officer has resigned his office, then the Revolution is accomplished.
('17', 468, 4, 11, 966147) But even suppose blood should flow.
('17', 468, 4, 12, 966183) Is there not, a sort of bloodshed when the conscience is wounded ?
('17', 468, 4, 13, 966250) Through this wound a man’s real manhood and immortality flow out and he bleeds to an everlasting death.
('17', 468, 4, 14, 966354) I see this blood flowing now.
('17', 468, 5, 15, 966384) I have contemplated the imprisonment of the offender rather than the seizure of his goods, though both will serve the same purpose,—because they who assert the purest right, and consequently are most dangerous to a corrupt state, commonly have not spent much time in accumulating property....
('17', 468, 6, 16, 966677) I have paid no poll tax for six years.
('17', 468, 6, 17, 966716) I was put into a gaol once on this acco unt for one night; and as I stood considering the walls of solid stones, two or three feet thick, the door of wood and iron, a foot thick, and the iron grating which stra ined the light, I could not help being struck with the foolishness of that institution which treated me as if I were men flesh and blood and bones, to be locked up.
('17', 468, 6, 18, 967092) I wondered that it should have concluded at length that this was the best use it could put me to, and had never thought to avail itself of my services in some way.
('17', 468, 6, 19, 967256) I saw that, if there was a wall of stone between me and my townsmen, there was a still more difficult one to climb or break through before they could get to be as free as I was.
('17', 468, 6, 20, 967434) I did not for a moment feel confined, and the walls seemed a great waste of.
('17', 468, 6, 21, 967511) stone and mortar.
('17', 468, 6, 22, 967529) I felt as if I alone of all my townsmen had paid my tax.
('17', 468, 6, 23, 967586) They plainly
('17', 469, 0, 1, 967599) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 469, 1, 2, 967641) did not know how to treat me, but behaved like persons who are underbred.
('17', 469, 1, 3, 967715) In every threat and in every compliment there was blunder; for they thought that my chief desire was to stand on the other side of that stone wall.
('17', 469, 1, 4, 967863) I could not but smile to see how industriously they locked the door on my meditations, which followed them out again without let or hindrance and they were really all that was dangerous.
('17', 469, 1, 5, 968050) As they
('17', 469, 2, 6, 968058) could not reach me, they had resolved to punish my body; just as boys, if they cannot come at some person against whom they have a spite, will abuse his dog.
('17', 469, 2, 7, 968216) I saw that the state was half witted, that it was timid as a lone woman with her silver spoons, and that it did not know its friends from its foes, and I lost all my remaining respect for it, and pitied it.
('17', 469, 4, 8, 968423) It is for no particular item in the tax bill that I refuse to pay it.
('17', 469, 4, 9, 968493) I simply wish to refuse allegiance to the State, to withdraw and stand aloof from it effectually.
('17', 469, 4, 10, 968591) I do not care to trace the courses of my dollar, if I could, till it buys a man or a musket to shoot with—the dollar is innocent—but I am concerned to trace the effects of my allegiance.
('17', 469, 4, 11, 968778) In fact, I quietly declare war with the State, after my fashion, though I will still make what use and get what advantage of her I can, as is usual in such cases.
('17', 469, 5, 12, 968941) If others pay the tax which is demanded of me from a sympathy with the State, they do but what they have already done in their own case, or rather they abet injustice to a greater extent than the State requires.
('17', 469, 5, 13, 969153) If they pay the tax from a mistaken interest in the individual taxed, to save his property, or prevent his going to gaol, it is because they have not considered wisely how far they let their private feelings interfere with the public good.
('17', 469, 6, 14, 969393) This, then is my position at present.
('17', 469, 6, 15, 969431) But one cannot be too much on his guard in such a case, lest his action be biased by obstinacy or an undue regard for the opinions of men.
('17', 469, 6, 16, 969570) Let him see that he does only what belongs to himself and to the hour.
('17', 469, 8, 17, 969641) They who know of no purer sources of truth, who have traced up its stream no higher, stand, and wisely stand, by the Bible, and Constitution, and drink at it there with reverence and humility; but they who behold where it comes trickling into this lake or that pool, gird up their loins once more, and continue their pilgrimage towards its fountainhead.
('17', 469, 10, 18, 969995) The authority of Government, even such as I am willing to submit to —for I will cheerfully obey those who know and can do better than I, and in many things even those who neither know nor can do well,—is still an impure one: to be strictly
('17', 470, 0, 1, 970235) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 471
('17', 470, 1, 2, 970276) just, it must have the sanction and consent of the governed.
('17', 470, 1, 3, 970337) It can have no pure right over my person and property, but what I concede to it.
('17', 470, 1, 4, 970418) The progress from an absolute to a limited monarchy, from a limited monarchy to a democracy, is a progress towards a true respect for the individual.
('17', 470, 1, 5, 970568) Even the Chinese philosopher was wise enough to regard the individual as the basis of the empire.
('17', 470, 1, 6, 970666) Is a democracy, such as we know it, the last improvement possible in Government?
('17', 470, 1, 7, 970747) Is it not possible to take a step further towards recognizing and organizing the rights of man ?
('17', 470, 1, 8, 970844) There will never be a really free and enlightened State until the State comes to recognize the individual as a higher and independent power, from which all its own power and authority are derived, and treats him accordingly.
('17', 470, 1, 9, 971069) I please myself with imagining a State at last which can afford to be just to all men, and to treat the individual with respect as a neighbour; which even would not think it inconsistent with its own repose if a few were to live aloof from it, not meddling with it, nor embraced by it, who fulfilled all the duties of neighbours and fellow men.
('17', 470, 1, 10, 971414) A state which bore this kind of fruit, and suffered it to drop off as fast as it ripened would prepare the way for a still more perfect and glorious state, which also I have imagined, but not yet anywhere seen.

('17', 472, 1, 2, 975131) APPENDIX IV
('17', 472, 2, 3, 975143) SIR STANL EY RE ED’S LETTE R TO G ANDHI JI
('17', 472, 3, 4, 975186) Apropos of the Swadeshi movement, the following letter addressed to
('17', 472, 4, 5, 975254) Mr. Gandhi, by Sir Stanley Reed on the eve of his departure to England, will be of interest.
('17', 472, 4, 6, 975347) (The italics are ours).
('17', 472, 5, 7, 975371) BOMBAY, 2nd May 1919
('17', 472, 6, 8, 975392) MY DEA R MR. GAN DHI,
('17', 472, 7, 9, 975414) Your letter of April 30th.
('17', 472, 7, 10, 975441) It would be to me the greatest possible pleasure to co operate whole heartedly with you in any of your work, but on the swadeshi issue I should like to explain my position.
('17', 472, 8, 11, 975614) I have been from the day of my arrival in India, a convinced and strong supporter of everything connected with the swadeshi movement.
('17', 472, 8, 12, 975748) Long before the Congress and the political leaders generally took more than a lukewarm interest in the industrial movement, I wed such influence as l possessed to press in season and out of season the importance of our industrial and commercial movement.
('17', 472, 8, 13, 976003) The Times of India has fought consistently against the cotton excise duties, and also for fiscal
('17', 472, 9, 14, 976100) freedom for India.
('17', 472, 9, 15, 976119) Such time as I can spare from my newspaper work is devoted to the furtherance of Indian enterprise; personally, I never buy anything which is made outside India if it can be purchased in India.
('17', 472, 9, 16, 976313) I wear a good deal more swadeshi clothing than many of Indian friends.
('17', 472, 10, 17, 976384) But I am convinced that the commercial and industrial future of India can be secured only if it is mainly on an economic basis.
('17', 472, 10, 18, 976512) We have to make the demand for Indian goods became they are the best at the money.
('17', 472, 10, 19, 976595) To do that, we have to persuade the educated classes that commerce and industry are just as patriotic and dignified as the professions and politics.
('17', 472, 10, 20, 976744) We have to press for the highest standard of commercial morality in India.
('17', 472, 11, 21, 976819) I am confident of the future.
('17', 472, 11, 22, 976849) Apart from the great stirring in India, we have the natural protection which accrues from command of most of the raw materials of manufacture on the spot.
('17', 472, 11, 23, 977004) If we can keep alive the present educated interest in industrial development and if we can coax into circulation the rupees which now go into the ground, I am convinced that our shady progress is assured.
('17', 472, 12, 24, 977209) Perhaps I am mistaking your ideal, that ideal is to prevent the increase of the factory system and to conserve and develop the cottage industries of the country.
('17', 472, 12, 25, 977371) With that ideal I am in most complete sympathy.
('17', 472, 12, 26, 977419) None can survey factory conditions, either here or in the West, and be anything but dismayed at their ugliness.
('17', 472, 12, 27, 977531) But here
('17', 473, 0, 1, 977540) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('17', 473, 1, 2, 977582) again I am convinced that true time solution is the organization of the cottage industries on a co operative basis with cheap capital and co operative distribution.
('17', 473, 1, 3, 977747) It has been my privilege to assist in some small measure in this work as one of the original directors of the Central Co operative Bank.
('17', 473, 2, 4, 977884) If, therefore, I cannot take the Swadeshi [Vow], I know that you will accept my assurance that it is not because I lack sympathy with the swadeshi movement, for my sympathy with and interest in it are acute.
('17', 473, 2, 5, 978092) But I must work for it in my own way and if the handloom weavers want any assistance in the way of capital, my best efforts will be used to secure it.
('17', 473, 3, 6, 978243) Yours very sincerely,
('17', 473, 4, 7, 978265) STANLEY REED
('17', 473, 5, 8, 978278) Young India.

('17', 473, 6, 10, 978301) APPENDIX V
('17', 473, 7, 11, 978312) NOT E BY DIST RICT MA GISTR ATE, AHM EDABA D, ON INT ERVIE W WIT H GAN DHIJI ,
('17', 473, 8, 12, 978391) [After May 11, 1919]
('17', 473, 9, 13, 978412) Mr. Gandhi states that he has not forbidden the members of his Ashram to give evidence as regards identification of rioters.
('17', 473, 9, 14, 978537) Such as have asked his advice have been advised by him to follow their own conscience; but that his opinion was that those who entirely followed the rule of the Ashram could not consistently give evidence incriminating others.
('17', 473, 9, 15, 978764) He had also warned them of the risk each one ran of incurring the penalty of the law for refusing to give evidence.
('17', 473, 9, 16, 978880) He does not consider this a rule of life which everyone would be justified in adopting; it is only justified on those who whilst refusing to give evidence would strain every nerve honestly to induce the guilty to make full confession before the authorities, and who on principle refrain from invoking the assistance of the law in their own cases.
('17', 473, 9, 17, 979227) This view of Mr. Gandhi’s is of long standing—in fact, goes back to a period before 1897 when he first put it into practice in a manner which became known to the public (in South Africa).
('17', 473, 10, 18, 979415) Mr. Gandhi has therefore not passed any order as regards the giving of evidence.
('17', 473, 10, 19, 979496) Nor is the refusal to give evidence a fundamental rule of the Ashram.
('17', 473, 10, 20, 979566) Supposing a member were to give evidence, he would not be turned out.
('17', 473, 10, 21, 979636) He would not even reason with him.
('17', 473, 10, 22, 979671) It is a matter which is left entirely to the conscience of the individual and Mr. Gandhi himself arrived at this point of view after considerable mental struggle and effort (i e., before 1897).
('17', 473, 10, 23, 979865) It was one of the reasons why he threw over his practice as a Barrister in 1908. Apart from the delicacy of the question (which is one for the individual’s conscience), Mr. Gandhi realizes the danger of indiscriminate acceptance of this view by those who have not attained the complete
('17', 474, 0, 1, 980151) VOL. 17 : 26 APRIL, 1918 APRIL, 1919 475
('17', 474, 1, 2, 980192) discipline of satyagraha.
('17', 474, 2, 3, 980218) Mr. Gandhi expressly states that his opinion in this case is in no way due to any feeling of delicacy in the sense that he was directly or indirectly responsible for the fury of the mob.
('17', 474, 2, 4, 980405) It is due to a general principle, the corollary of the doctrine of ahimsa.
('17', 474, 2, 5, 980480) His desire is that the guilty should be punished but that they should undergo their punishment voluntarily.
('17', 474, 3, 6, 980588) Mr. Gandhi admits that this principle leads to the result that there is one rule for himself and his followers and another for the rest of the world, but accepts this as inevitable.
('17', 474, 4, 7, 980770) N. A. I: Home: Politi cal—A: August 1919: Nos.
